description:
One of our favorite regular places to dine in SF. We go every few months and have never been disappointed. The vibrant but casual vibe compliments the delicious food perfectly. Cocktails are always on point. 

The wine service at the table could be much improved. The somm is always very nice and knowledgeable but definitely spread thin. The servers do not pour at all, which it seems they could easily do...

Everyone that works at 1760 is very gracious and passionate about the concept and food, it shows and makes it a lovely experience - even if I'm waiting a while for our next bottle of wine to be opened and poured.
author: Nic S.

description:
Someone nice who dines at 1760 frequently took me on a date here and while we enjoyed most of our food, there was one dish that completely soured the dining experience. The culprit is the Uni Bucatini. Beyond fishy - it seriously stank - it was inedible. It left a film of grease and salt in my mouth and throat and we had to send it back because neither of us could have another bite after our first. In its place, we got the risotto, and that also made us rather salty. Because it was like eating straight sodium. I have to round down to two stars due to these two dishes. We both thought the uni would be our #1 as it was our first choice, but it immediately became a dish we regretted ordering. This is the first time I've ever sent anything back to the kitchen. That is saying a LOT.

I will end this review on a positive note. The gnocchi, scallops, and burrata entrees were delicious. The panna cotta and flan desserts sweetened the sourness of our last two main dishes I really disliked. I would come back but order wisely next time. The ambience and everything is great but when your food makes you unhappy, the ambience means very little.
author: Candace L.

description:
The food here is amazing. We tried the shishito peppers, brussel sprouts, fries, crispy chicken, lamb, crab fried rice, uni bucatini, and the grilled pork ribs. The most memorable items to me were the shishito peppers, crispy chicken and the decadent aji verde sauce. The crab fried rice and the uni bucatini were good too... gee, did I just name every plate I ordered? I suppose the lamb and the grilled pork ribs weren't as up to par as the others.

The interior design is quite nice and spacious. I will say, there was a bit of a kerfuffle when we first sat down, as they positioned us at a table right by the entrance (it was much colder at the time) when there were plenty of open tables elsewhere. My friend politely requested that we be moved - at first they said there wasn't anything they could do but my friend wasn't having that. She spoke up again several minute later, with more persistence in her tone, and lo and behold, we were given the opportunity to sit at one of the booths (it was being reserved for a party that was a healthy 90 minutes away). We finished in under 90.
author: Ojil E.

description: I can check off another location on my "Check Please!" list. I have been watching this PBS restaurant show since I moved to the Bay Area and I'll admit sometimes it lets me down, but not tonight. Everything about 1760 was fantastic. I've been in SF for work so I was alone for dinner. I sat in the bar and was greeted right away by both of the bartenders. They made some great recommendations and even chatted with me about some other restaurants in the city I should check out. I had Lumpia (Philippine egg rolls) to start which was awesome. I had a good friend growing up from the Philippines so I've had this dish quite a few times and they know what they're doing here. As my main I was trying to decide between the ribs and pork belly. The bartender recommended the ribs because they'd had it on the menu since they opened and it was a staple. I'm sooooo glad I did. They were amazing!!!  Kind of an Asian style with a sweet and tangy glaze on them. I'm not sure how else to describe them but they were super tender but really meaty at the same time. The texture was great. I will be back here again and again.
author: Marcus K.

description: This place serve more like Asian fusion food then American. We can taste the flavor with sauce like fish sauce, shrimp paste, tamarin sauce, hoisin sauce (that's what we think with our Asian tongue). We ordered few dishes, tempura octopus, small cold tomato soup shot, grilled ribs, beef tartar and some drinks. Overall food is average but not the ribs caz is too burn. Not too excited and we think the dishes big plates but too little to eat and a bit expensive.
author: Katie M.

description:
San Francisco! Wake up. This place is freakin' stellar. Get down here. Don't wait. You won't be disappointed. A recent post commented on the fish sauce that Chef Carl uses. It's all below the radar and it's inspired. I sampled some off
menu new dishes that are coming up and I was blown away.
author: Charles L.

description:
Prepare for a meal full of [pleasant] surprises. 

Seemingly nothing on the menu comes out the way you would expect it, and that is a good thing! Chef Foronda keeps you guessing with a nice balance of savory and sweet flavors, and uses texture to his advantage to make each dish pop.

Kimthi and the rest of the service staff was excellent all night. (Thank you Kimthi for warming the world with your smile!!) 

Definitely recommend doing family style and ordering a bunch of the small dishes. 

Top recommendations:

- fried olives (w/ linguiça sausage & shrimp)
- Snake River Farms beer tartare
- crispy chicken (w/ berbere spice - almost cinnamon-like)
- crispy, rich brussel sprouts

Try to snag the corner booth and get the added bonus of people-watching the Polk Street passersby!
author: Andy L.

description:
Terrible food, terrible service. Don't go on Friday nights bc they can't handle large crowds. Food is overpriced & not properly cooked! Look at pics :( so disappointed as this place is just a couple blocks down in my neighborhood! 

Steak was still frozen & duck burger tasted like McDonald's chicken :(
author: Sam T.

description:
Food: little gem salad with wasabi dressing was sooo good, steak tartare wasn't my favorite, pork ribs were good but not amazing, uni bucatini was good (could've had more uni). 

Wine: had a glass of Bodegas Olivares (Jumilla) wine which was really good - light like a Pinot
author: Laura D.

description: We had a fine meal overall with great, attentive service. I would definitely have the Duck Burger again, the combination of the slaw with the duck (cake) patty and the sauce on a bed of pickles was a balanced bite. We were a party of 4 and was able to split in quarters. The other highlight was the chocolate ganache dessert (deconstructed s'mores). If you enjoy the toasty/Smokiness of a campfire s'more, you'll enjoy this one even more so. We also had the beef tartar which was a good starter. It's light, but flavorful. The crispy chicken was tasty as well with the yogurt dipping sauce. But if I had to recommend the two dishes to get, it would be the burger and the s'mores.
author: Andrew T.

description:
This place is the ninja of all ninjas. I live a block away and walked past it for a good 6-7 months before I realized there was a swanky restaurant/bar inside!

Finally convinced someone to try the place out last night. Alright, it didn't take much groveling. Our eyes were glossing over the menu and we were anticipating our reservation well in advance. 

Light appetizer on the house consisting of a small toast with salami and Parmesan, garnished with a green thing. Basically, a glorified Lunchable.

Avocado toast because we're basic millennials and we want the whole world to know. The avocado looked a bit... old... but still tasted fine. The salmon skin was a nice contrast to the cayenne peppered avocado and definitely tingled the taste buds.

Shishito peppers were so buttery and not overly doused with oyster sauce. I didn't mind throwing away my calories at this one. Every sesame seed made me believe there's good in the world still.

Scallops were to die for. The cauliflower purée with the pistachios - brilliant. Every inch of my body was wheezing with anticipation for the next bite. I'm usually quite chatty during dinner and this dish rendered me speechless. I'm still savoring that last bite.

Too bad dinner ended on a salty note. The uni pasta was SO SALTY. Even Salt Bae would be wincing. I was really looking forward to this dish and it was the most disappointing.

However, we told the waitress and she was so nice and accommodating! She took it off our bill! Excellent service. I'm a fan.

Also a fan of the ambiance. Saw several small groups - probably ladies that didn't make it to brunch then had to just settle for dinner. And some other dates. The lighting is dim, warm, and inviting. The decor is simple and lux.

Overall, great joint and I'll definitely be back for more drinks and food. Pricey, but well worth it!
author: Vee B.

description:
Came here just for cocktails at 5:30 on a Friday. Had no issue with my choice of bar seats. Though we came for the happy hour discount, the cocktail selection of the sipping hour menu was no match for the regular menu so we indulged in full price libations. 

We tried a variety of cocktails all intricately prepared by our bartender. The peach buck was my personal favorite, featuring Bourbon balanced by a mellowed sweetness and spice. The Garam Masala-Cardamom was also excellent, as our bartender explained in detail the modifications he recently made to the cocktail to bring out some of the brighter notes. 

1760 certainly offers high-quality cocktails and is the perfect spot for those into the art of spirits.
author: Aaron C.

description: Food is good but nothing mind blowing! Prices are $$$$ while portions are TINY. For two people you could easily have 3-4 large plates. It's good- not great, and pretty expensive for the quantity
author: D. C.

description: Had a great time catching up with an old friend here.  Considering we just had drinks an app, I didn't feel like I sampled enough to give it a full 5 stars.  The cocktails were delicious!  We ordered the octopus to share. It was good, but not 'wow I have to come back just for this.'  Overall it was an enjoyable experience.
author: Joby W.

description: Tuna Crudo, Burrata and the Duck Sandwich all amazing!  Love that they bring the bottle when you order wine by the glass so you can taste it first!  We happened to arrive during happy hour which goes until 6:30 which was a nice plus!
author: Jill S.

description:
The dishes here might be a bit on the smaller side, but you can't deny that everything is executed at high quality.

The mushroom tempura was a nice way to start the meal, with the mushroom fried ever so lightly and complemented well with a little dipping sauce on the side. Next, some roasted baby carrots were a good way to feel good about the sinful gluttony that would come afterwards in the form of the fried duck sandwich, which was quite delicious and satisfying. Although the portions were a bit small given the prices, the taste and quality of both the underlying ingredients and the overall preparation all measured up.

Service was also friendly and engaging, and the interior of this space is a beautiful, modern cornerfront on Polk. Worth it, especially for date night.
author: Vincent L.

description: I love this place- cocktails- duck burgers, black cod, pasta with crabmeat... menu changes and portion is small but everything is perfect and not too much calories !!
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Great happy hour great food!! Def will come back!! Started with the fries, lumpia and chicken and for dinner the cod and the ribs and desert banana tiramisu and the sorbet!! It was delicious!!!
author: John C.

description: Service is impeccable! We sat at the bar and started with the drafter was a decadent drink with a slice of dried pineapple and a spring of mint with ice to fill the rim in a small glass. The next drink was a Twist of Faith which is on the sweeter side with coconut and gin and a vintage gin which was delicious and again both drinks were overpriced for the size. The bartender's suggested that we have Steve fried olives which were totally out of this world highly recommend them crunchy on the outside stuffed with a pork sausage in the inside Simply Delicious. We then went to sit at our table where my husband had the scallops I had the swordfish and my daughter had the raviolis vegetarian all three dishes had beautiful presentation but fell short on flavor. I would not go back for dinner but I would definitely go back for the overpriced cocktails and fried olives.
author: RA M.

description:
Having enjoyed dinner here once before, I took two out of town visitors for dinner tonight, knowing they'd enjoy the delicious, inventive food and the family style service. I was right about that, but what I didn't anticipate was the best service I've had in recent memory. Everyone was incredibly welcoming, friendly, and helpful. Super attentive at all times but never intrusive. 
Excellent food, exemplary service, pleasant atmosphere, great neighborhood.
author: Canice F.

description:
Food is amazing but tiny portions

Need to hire an interior designer - too bright, lacks ambience
author: Sowmya S.

description:
One of the better date night restaurants in the city to visit if you can break away from what you call normalcy. Hats off to the executive chef who happens to be my cousin, you have done an amazing job, everything we sampled was delicious, definitely will have to come back and try more.

Here is the list of things we tried and how everything measured up...

small sample of soup - light creamy soup was offered before everything else, didn't see it on the menu but I believe it was a starter to cleanse your palette before trying everything they had to offer. I would probably order a cup if not a bowl of this soup next time, it is that light.

Avocado Toast - dish lives up to its name, fresh avocado sliced and topped with several tidbits, I want to say thin sliced radish, diced bacon, pickled ginger, semi sweet chutney, and the veggie I could not identify but it was light, the dish on a whole was very good, 4 pieces of sourdough bread, with each having a helpful serving of sliced avocado and the other toppings, probably the only time I have had something this fancy served and it tasted as good as it looked

Braised Brussel Sprouts was next on our menu - lets just say I am not a fan of brussel sprouts, from my recollection only two places have these veggies prepped a certain way where I can say i'm a fan, this place is one of them, the other is on Bst in San Mateo.
 
Har Gow Cavatelli - shrimp with shell shaped noodles, presentation alone was beautiful, didn't want to eat it because of the presentation haha, one of the dishes that hits every part of your mouth, another must try

Octopus - more a less a staple in my diet growing up, their version is different in a good way, flash fried sparingly drizzled yellow sauce with grape tomatoes, the octopus itself was the large tentacle type not diced served almost whole. chewy, seasoned well, must try 

Duck Sandwich with sunny side up egg - Sampled this sandwich, the duck patty was different, to describe it let say you had chicken fried steak made with a duck meat, different is how I can describe it, not like anything I have sampled before. If you are a fan of duck this is a must try, tell em to add an sunny side egg haha

Grilled fish - I am not sure what kinda fish (hamachi) it was but what ever it was, it was good, how can I say this, I really don't like fish so if you can make me like it and almost finish the plate you know it was made good. must try

Fries - deep fried in truffle oil thin sliced frites and garnished with furikake need a say more haha

Panna Cotta - warm chocolate cake, raspberry sorbet, so bad for diabetics but so good!!!

Milk Chocolate Ganache - melted marshmallows and ice cream how can you say no to that, just say yes!!!

Chai-Horchata- as if the night could not get any better, this after dinner treat is served in a liquid form, hands down best idea ever, horchata is already a yes for me, chai also a yes for me, and COGNAC!!!!!!!! yeah COGNAC!!!!!!!! and it is not a small shot it is heavy shot in their OH MY GAWD!!!!!! piping hot, once it touches the lips, DONE DEAL!!!!! gonna have to come back and grab the barista that makes this concoction and hire them to make it at home

food ***** must try everything, duck craklins is must try for me next time, and more of that Chai-horchata
price $$
service ***** very attentive staff, very helpful staff
ambiance ***** modern, clean, open, airy, good for dates, or couples

Definite must try if you are in the city, reservations are recommended

Hats again off to the chef and his team, one of the best meals I have had in a long time
author: Clarence A.

description:
Easy to get dinner reservations for Friday night. surprisingly wasn't crowded I could've just walked in and been seated quickly.

the menu is listed from light to heaviest

crudo - light and simple, I could've gone without this
steak tartare - recommend ! another light dish with mint leaf, cilantro? - some other "aromatic herbs" and reminded me of a vietnamese salad called goi
brussel sprouts - crispy & salty - just how I like them
har gow cavatelli - supposed to taste like a pasta version of hargow dimsum shrimp dumplings. not enough shrimp in this but liked how there seemed to be daikon for a crunch in the mix?
fried duck sandwich - this took the longest to come out, there was at least a 20 minute gap from the pasta to this so at this point my friends were full. However I was not yet. I couldn't really taste a duck distinction. The patty had the consistency like a crab cake.

Good music of r&b hip hop throwbacks playing. great service and cute place for a date night.
author: Kim N.

description: The service was amazing! The scallops with the forbidden rice are amazing and the cocktails are also some of the best I have had. Also, I left my phone there and they were so helpful in finding it, which is so rare. The people that work there are so nice and so attentive and it makes the food and drinks all the better!
author: Tara K.

description:
7.12.17

Came here for one of my bday celebrations with reservations that they were flexible with moving back 30mins, thank you! Very hip restaurant with some creative dishes but with smaller than normal portions, healthier dishes and superb service! 

FOOD: 
I was looking forward to trying their duck fat congee, but unfortunately they rotate the items on their menu so we were out of luck that day. Their menu is arranged from the smallest portion/appetizers to larger portions/entrees to desserts. We ordered: 
+ English Peas w/ albacore and wasbi buttermilk $19: although this dish was very refreshing, surprisingly good and definitely unique, I did not think it was worth the price. 
+ Striped Bass $24: corn, edamame, asparagus, morel and cherry ponzu. I don't usually like eating fish skin, but the cook on the bass was so crispy it would have been a crime to skip out on it. The veggie melody was a refreshing touch to the dish but wished there were more fish to to veggie ratio. 
+ Bevette Steak $28: mitake mushroom, bok choy, miso-sherry and wheat berries. They was THE best dish of the night. Beef was cooked medium-rare and to perfection. Veggie to beef ratio and spices were perfect. There is nothing I would change about this dish. 
+ Milk Chocolate Ganche $12: hickory ice cream, bourbon caramel and torched marshmallows. This was pretty much a deconstructed s'more. The flavors were delicious, but 2 scoops of ice cream were tiny compared to the other components on the plate. 
+ Vanilla Panna Cotta with raspberry and chocolate: Bday complimentary dessert! 

SERVICE: 
Excellent service! From the moment we walked in to the moment we left, servers and hostess were really friendly and approachable. They made we were happy with everything and comfortable. 

AMBIANCE: 
Very hip, rustic/modern interior. High ceilings, big windows, semi-open kitchen and very nice bathrooms! The bar is also slightly separated from the dinning area which is a nice touch. 

Verdict: Beautiful food presentations, high quality food, excellent service = I would come back!
author: Samantha F.

description:
Creative menu, sleek ambiance, and friendly staff. My friends and I sat at the bar (walk in) during happy hour (5:30-6:30 everyday) and ordered crispy chicken, lumpia, the fried duck sandwich, and the octopus. 

The lumpia was tasty if inauthentic but we really just ordered it for the crunchy wrappers and the kitchen certainly delivered on that. The panko-breaded crispy chicken was less flavourful than some might want but was an excellent vehicle for a really delicious herb sauce. They were both half off for happy hour. 

Octopus was tender and tasty - doesn't say on the menu, but it's fried. The portion was also smaller than expected given the $27 price tag. Duck sandwich was good (spicy aioli is not very spicy), and the bun was toasted and delicious.

We also ordered a single drink, which had a lot of ice and didn't really elevate any of it's ingredients beyond recognition - so it wasn't really to our party's taste.

Would go back to try their uni pasta, and overall a pleasant experience, but questionably worth the price.
author: Christina T.

description:
Yay! I am totally a fan of 1760. This was my second time here, first time was for brunch, and this time was for dinner. The menus for brunch and dinner are almost the same and everything listed is in order of lightest (appetizers) to heaviest (entrees). Presentation was really nice (see my pictures!) 

What the waiters will tell you is that everything is family style. For two people who want to eat a FULL dinner, they'd recommend ~ 5 dishes to share. My boyfriend and I wanted a light dinner, so we ordered two appetizers and an entree, portion sizes were absolutely perfect. 

SRF Beef Tartare ($16) w/ marcona almond, aromatic herbs was sooo good. The beef was cut into small cubes (not minced/finely chopped) and garnished with fresh herbs.  Ours was a bit too salty but nevertheless delicious. 

Pappardelle ($17 for all you pasta and mushroom lovers, please do yourself a favor and order this!) 
ingredients: black trumpets, fall vegetables truffle sauce. 

Pork Chop ($25) w/ potato puree, snow cap beans, romanesco, picked persimmon (like a puree as well). We loved this dish! Usually you'd expect pork chop to be dry, but somehow the chefs at 1760 managed to cook the pork chop to a very nice tender and juicy texture. 

Other things to order: Fries!!!, hamachi crudo. 

The happy hour is everyday until 6:30 pm and there are some yummy drinks for $5-$6.
author: Dana Z.

description:
Wow. This place was really amazing. Can't wait to get back here and try to rest of the menu.

Started off with the Burrata. Really luscious and delicious.Also did the tuna crudo which was outstanding. The octopus and the bass were delicious, but the shining star was the uni bucatini. So amazing, and doused in uni butter. Uni butter. Say it again. So good.

Great food, amazing service and a super cool location. Go here often, you won't regret it.
author: Bob K.

description:
A contemporary American food restaurant, with hit or miss dishes.

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
- Being at the corner of Polk and Washington, this place is very easy to find even at night.
- Went on a Saturday evening at 6:30pm with reservation. It was less than half full, but starting at around 7pm it started getting crowded, so, do make a reservation!
- Big wine list. There's a big bar counter as well so I guess later at night it turns to a drinking place?
- According to our waiter, all dishes are for sharing and for 2 people we will be good with 4-5 dishes, turned out to be exactly right!

* * * FOOD * * *
Avocado Toast: B+
Nothing special. Avocado was average. The bacon put on top overrode rest of the toast.

Seared Scallop: A
It was really good! The seasoning was fantastic, and it was slightly grilled, making a crispy-outside-soft-inside type of combination texture. Highly recommended (although it was kind of pricy).

Fries: A-
Not too bad. Portion was pretty big considered it was only $6. The mayo sauce that came with it was meh.

Brussel Sprouts: A-
Very well cooked - each brussel sprout it was very crispy on the outside and soft in the center. It would have been perfect if it was not that salty. Almost wanted to ask for a bowl of rice! Do order this dish though, just get some water in advance.

Babette Steak: C
Very disappointed about this. While the other ingredients like wheat berries and bak choi were descent, and the seasoning was okay - the main character - steak - was very, very hard to chew. Meat tenderness was almost zero, it certainly was not overcooked as it's still red in the middle. So I'm not sure what went wrong. Not recommending this at all.

Milk Chocolate Ganache (Dessert): B+
Nothing special about this dessert. Increase, chocolate and mash mellow were all within expectation. I guess the presentation part of it was good.

Other than the scallop and brussel sprouts, I was not too impressed about this restaurant. I guess I would come back for drinks but not so much for meals.
author: Simon C.

description: The decor inside is beautiful. Great place for a date or a great spot for a night out with the ladies. It's pretty big area and their bar has loads of alcohol selections. The customer service is phenomenal our waiter was so attentive and kept refilling our water. We ordered a bunch of things and shared it, the pork ribs, octopus, ravioli, and duck sandwich. The dishes were a small portion but the taste was worth it. I could have done without the ravioli. I've never seen duck sandwich on a menu before and I've been to a lot of places in this world, it was so good a must to try. I will be back and it's walking distance from my place.
author: Angel P.

description:
This is a real treat; even the crispy fries are dripping in truffle oil (and not to forget the shaved parmesan on top). If you're lucky, sommelier Robbie will take care of you for the evening and if he is as cherish as when we were visiting, he'd even top of the glass for you in-between.

The coconut ravioli will bring you to heaven and back in one single bite; it's different from other standard raviolis as this one has a more soft and runny inside. I also loved the tuna: It was a small serving that was brought to us just as a kind gesture, but was just enough to treat my never ending craving for Good Fish.

Only con of this place would be the price. I think we spent around 90 each which for a Tuesday dinner is a little on the expensive side. In fairness, we did have a good few glasses to drink and a bottle of dessert wine to split between the three of us. If ill be back? Oh yeah.
author: Linn L.

description:
This was a great dinner. Overall we really liked our food and had a great time. No complaints about the service. 

My only slight complaint is that everyone raves about the Fried Duck Sandwich, but it's not great at all! Otherwise a lot of the food was very good.  

RESERVATIONS: Made online about a month in advance (dinner for 5 at 8pm). 

THE COST: $251.09 including tax/tip for dinner for five. 

* Pear Shiso, lacryma, campari ice cube, gin ($14) - 3.5 stars
A nice drink! A tad strong, but the custom ice cube was a nice touch and I enjoyed the pear flavor.

* SRF Beef Tartare ($16) - 4 stars
Garnish was ok, but the beef was fresh and pretty amazing. 

* Brussels Sprouts ($13) - 4 stars
Loved the flavor and the crunch! 

* Truffle Oil Fries ($7) - 3.5 stars
Good, not amazing. A little dry. 

* Seared Scallops ($26) - 4 stars
Very nice! Great all-around.

* 'Har Gow' Cavatelli, rock shrimp ($22) - 2.5 stars
Quite an unfortunate dish. The pasta was too hard and this was lackluster in flavor.

* Grilled Pork Ribs, hoisin bbq sauce ($19) - 3.5 stars
Good but not amazing. The meat had good flavor but was a little dry.

* Cheeseburger, potato bun ($15) - 3.5 stars
Solid. Better than the fried duck!

* Fried Duck Sandwich ($19) - 3 stars
Definitely not up to the rave reviews. The patty was dry & flavorless, the bun also a little dry. My friends loved the slaw.

* Panna Cotta ($11) - 4 stars
This was good and had interesting flavors! The slight bitterness of the chocolate cake was nice.

* Milk Chocolate Ganache ($12) - 4 stars
Good for those with a sweet tooth. The variety of textures worked really well.
author: Ziyan C.

description: My husband took me to this place for Valentine's Day. Each dish was elegant and nice presentation!  Lychee Fran was very interesting and taste good! I want to try other dishes too!
author: Kiyoko M.

description: The octopus was delicious and I highly recommend it. My husband had the Uni Bucatini and he did love the pasta and sauce but there was not much sea urchin in in which was the main appeal of the dish. Drinks were great. Hot Toddy and Salt & Punsch were both unique and delicious albeit pricey at about $14-15 each-- however this is to be expected at an establishment like this.
author: Jasmine S.

description:
I had heard glowing comments about the brunch menu at 1760 so I decided to give them a try on a nice Sunday morning. I had made reservations but when we got there there were plenty of open seats. I have to say the interior looks clean and modern. We were seated at a booth with a ground floor window view  which gave us beautiful light to enjoy.

I was looking forward to trying their Brioche French Toast(with Cointreau and fresh berries) and although it was tasty I think expectations were higher than I should've set them. Definitely recommended but not mindblowing. Surprisingly, the Season Fruit side(with Mascarpone cream and granola) was sweet, tangy, and even looked great in presentation. 

Service was polite and acceptable and overall it was a pleasant experience. Not a bad choice for a brunch spot.
author: Angela L.

description:
I've walked by 1760 hundreds of times, always curious when it's bustling on a weekend night. On weeknights, however, there's often empty tables. After a Thursday evening dinner, I know why. 

1760 would be a great place for drinks and snacks, limiting yourself to one drink per person. Their full dinner dishes are tiny, tiny, tiny and very expensive. It's "family style" but a scallop plate is only 3 scallops! 

Drinks were delicious and I'd come back just for one of their well-muddled cocktails. Unfortunately, the price tag is way too high for me to come back. There's many options on Polk with reasonable dinner offerings, and this isn't one of them.
author: Kerry G.

description: I love duck, so the fried duck sandwich at 1760 was right now my alley! It's a beautiful little sandwich for the price but the real kicker was the taste that came with it! I left craving for more. I simply had to control myself with all the other good things available at 1760. If you're ever there, I would also grab the mushroom risotto if I were you or even the BBQ Pork Belly. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. The service here is also one to be envious of for any restaurant in the area. They strive for perfection and they never fail to deliver!
author: Chloe B.

description:
We stopped in within an hour of close for some dessert and a nightcap. Great use of the space, with a bar that's both to itself and a part of the dining space. The open kitchen and floor-to -ceiling windows to the street make it feel a lot larger than it really is.

We drank the Hot Toddy (suspicious at first at the rum and banana combo, but it was outstanding) and an Old Fashion (perfect). We got the Brown Butter Panna Cotta for desert (can't express how much we liked this).

Looking forward to returning for dinner.
author: Brett S.

description:
Yes please! This is everything I want in a new American restaurant. The concept is shared plates but the plate especially the large ones aren't one bite per person. The octopus ($27) was by far the best dish we had and was unlike many upscale places now serving octopus a decent portion although now where like the huge servings you get in Spain or Portugal.

Some of the dishes we tried
Tombo Tuna Crudo ($17) with soy-yuzu. toybox tomatoes. sea beans. -I would have preferred more pieces of fish (only 4) and more of the soy-yuzu dressing

Avocado Toast ($11). with bacon. pickled onions. radish. lime - The French Spouse loves avocado as much as an Mission or Williamsburg hipster and always likes to try it. The bread here was excellent and the topping added texture and flavour but it's avocado toast for 11 bucks.

The larger dishes were large. We could have done with just one and the starter for a full meal.
Two that stood out for us were:

Uni Garganelli (24). sea urchin. duck cracklings. annatto oil- while not at the level of the most perfect sea urchin I've had in SF which is the Fregua Sarda cun Arrizzonisi e Cori de Tonnu at La Ciccia this was pretty damn good with bits of uni as well as rich umami sauce and the pasta was cooked perfectly, the duck crackling added texture as well as more savoriness.

The star was the Octopus (27). with broccoli di ciccio. fingerling potatoes. tamarind-chili sauce. This was new preparation for me and reminded me of the sauce often used for pakora and other Indian dishes as well as a sauce that you find in coastal Malaysian cities that is used on fish and mantis. The potatoes and broccoli were an intergral part of the dish with the octopus which was tender without being mealy served in smaller pieces. 

Being gluttons we had dessert even though we were full trying the Milk Chocolate Ganache ($12) with. hickory ice cream. bourbon caramel. marshmallow. I don't like Milk chocolate and the dish is a gimmick but it's a gimmick that work so well. It was indeed like eating the best s'more ever. 

They have a lively bar that's as popular as the food although the areas are separated by a demi-wall. The place is popular and packed right up till closing. The service was good and attentive without being pushy or rushing us out. The noise is loud and it's a better place for a meal with friends than an intimate romantic dinner. The bathrooms are gendered for no apparent reason. The space is wheelchair accessible. The lighting is good.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Food is ok - neither great, nor particularly bad but priced too high for the value.  Service is friendly.  A redeeming area is that their cocktails are delicious.  Not my first nor even second choice in the neighborhood but wouldn't say no if friends wanted to dine there.
author: Lev E.

description:
Long waiting also we booked our table
But both food and service were good and prices decent for SF
author: Thibault L.

description:
With a new chef in charge, my family and I thought it be worth trying 1760 again 

My last visit was quite memorable and was hoping for another repeat experience. Suffice to say, the new changes did not live up to before

Key differences

Portion size has shrunk for both the food and drinks
Execution is about the same 
Cocktail remakes are sadly not as good as their predecessors
Salt level is much higher especially in the Har Gow Cavatelli (it did taste like the dim sum dish but too much salt) 
Most dishes straddled between Ok to slightly better 

Overall Thoughts

While I am comparing and contrasting, if looking purely at what we had, the meal was truly Just A-OK
author: Eddie W.

description:
Tapas, reborn.

Before you do anything: get a reservation. Let's just get that out of the way first.

Great spot for a date or smaller groups - they have a few larger tables but not many. Great ambiance, with high ceilings and a nice bar. Menu for dinner is mostly a bunch of small dishes meant to be shared, similar to Spanish Tapas. Excellent service, with waiters that give great recommendations. They also have a communal table if you decide to walk in (but you're not going to, remember?? Look at the second line of this review!!) 

Like everyone says, gotta get the duck burger. Not AMAZING, because I've had some better duck in my life, but too good to pass up. Steak Tartare, pretty fresh and a good way to start your meal. Har Gow - shrimp gnocchi lookin' things, which I would say is an interesting asian-italian fusion dish. They mix rock shrimp and small potato dumplings in a savory sauce making this my favorite dish. I feel like this restaurant could be best described as the union between dim sum and new american cooking.

Polk is full of surprises. This is one of the good ones.
author: Albert C.

description:
What is American (New) cuisine? It's such a vague and colloquial term. I associate it with the latest food trends, like avocado toast, for example. Since 1760's menu aims for variety & seasonality and does not have a central theme, that explains why they are lumped into the American (New) category. I appreciate their brief single-page menu, organized from the lighter to heavier dishes, so naturally I gravitated towards the bottom half of the menu. As someone who thrives on variety, but is easily overwhelmed by too many options, this menu offers just enough options.

It's been a while since I've been to 1760. Apparently the menu has changed quite a bit.
The uni bucatini is no more. Some may be disappointed, but if you didn't get to try it, you're not missing much. The creamy sauce and the bread crumb topping were great. However, there wasn't that much uni in the pasta. Also, the texture of bucatini is a little too hard, for lack of a better word. In any case, there are plenty of other restaurants to visit for uni pasta. 
A couple of things have remained. They still serve a duck sandwich and the cocktails are great.

The fried duck sandwich with slaw, pickles, & spicy aioli is okay, but pretty pricey. I would have preferred chunks of duck meat instead of the duck patty. I don't particularly like slaw or shredded anything, so maybe this sandwich just wasn't for me. However, I did like creamy aioli and the thick bun, which sufficiently soaked up the juices of the sandwich.
The sweet & fresh-tasting scallops and the mushroom tempura were far more enjoyable. I would be interested in returning to try their beef tartare and sisig dishes.

The cocktails are great, so if I were in the area, I'd drop by for affordable drinks during their happy hour (5-6PM). However, the cocktails on the dinner menu look much more enticing, but are nearly double the price. The 1760 cocktail was pretty refreshing, and not too sweet. The Pear-Shiso & Basil-Mezcal Sour sound pretty appealing too.

The food was good, but I was a little more appreciative of the setting. The space seemed reminiscent of a former diner transformed into modern wine bar, and done quite well. The tall ceilings created the illusion of more space. There is a semi-exposed kitchen in the back. A sweeping long bar is somewhat separated from the rest of the dining room. The long cushioned bench with high back rest served as the partition to the bar. It was very comfortable, but I was a little paranoid that the people leaning against the divider, which was also the back of my seat, might spill drinks on my head, but it wasn't that sort of crowd, so I dismissed the thought.
author: Joy W.

description:
Best happy hour we've ever had in San Francisco to Date.  

We came in and the front host was really friendly and said we could either sit at the bar or at the table and we still get the happy hour menu. 

The restaurant was very dead at 5:35 PM but it filled up before we left at 6 PM. We stopped by for a quick bite before going to the movies and let our awesome bartender Uzi know that we had to leave early so he quickly brought out our food and drinks.

The house chips with blue cheese dressing changed my life. I would come back over and over just for this dish alone.

The burrata was tasty and unique in presentation with vinegar and olive oil underneath.

I would take a hard pass on the lumpia with shrimp aoili since it was more greasy than crispy.

Venue was nice and classy and perfect for a date night.
 
We'll be back again to try other items on the menu. :)

3 appetizers, a really tasty old fashioned and a white tea rose and the bill was only $40.
author: Vi Y.

description: Expensive and quite honestly, really over rated. The service was good but the food left a lot to be desired for an upscale place: the pannacotta was like eating a flipflop.
author: Marcel C.

description: 2nd time here (almost a year later) was much better. Menu was about 3 weeks old. AJ and Roman at the bar were excellent. Great service and great recommendations. All dishes were fantastic: burrata, lumpia, pork tacos, duck sandwich, and the winner (by far) was the frozen flan. Really really world class do not come here without planning to have this desert.
author: Mr. L.

description:
When I came here, my group and I got 4 small plates (tombo tuna crudo, smoked albacore, brussel sprouts, and parmesan truffle fries) and 2 big plates (scallops & pork ribs) to share among 3 and it was a good amount. the food was all delicious except the parmesan truffle fries - what we got was basically a bowl of plain fries with some parmesan on top, none of us tasted any truffle and i didn't even taste any salt. the 'sriracha ketchup' also tasted like regular ketchup. we ended up sending that one back. 

the other dishes were all delicious (although note that the small plates are very small, and even the 'big/bigger' plates aren't that big. but with the amount we had, we were satiated). 

the service was okay. our waitress was great - she was really friendly and really knew the menu items; however, it took a really long time for us to get our wine. the table next to us sat down much later than us and got their wine before us, and it seemed like it's because they knew the guy bringing the wine and they were chatting while we waited...

the first few dishes also took a while to come out. but once they started coming out, it did go faster. would've been nice to get everything closer together, rather than 1 or 2 dishes at a time though.

it's also pretty loud in there, so can be hard to talk/hear. 

i liked the food but didn't love the restaurant.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
1760 is a gastronomic delight! The food is outrageous. We ordered the octopus. Each morsel was delicious. We also ordered the brussels sprouts, which were full of flavor and out of this world. The pork ribs were juicy and spicy.

The ambiance is clean and open. The space feels pleasant.

Our waiter was pleasant, but not a pro. When you go to Delfina, for example, you get someone who knows and shares a depth of knowledge about both the food and drink. Our waiter seemed to lack that expertise, and for the quality of food 1760's serving, we expected more energy, enthusiasm and warmth.
author: Chad H.

description:
Came here for an early dinner with a friend at 5:30pm last Saturday. The restaurant was empty when we arrived, which was expected, but started filling up around 7pm. The décor is very clean and slightly rustic with exposed wood. Service was great, and the space is fairly large, so there was ample space between tables.

Plating was really nice, but portions are smaller than you'd expect. The menu is meant to be family style, with a range of small to "large" dishes. My friend and I split the following 3 and were reasonably satisfied, though not particularly full.

1) Hamachi crudo (4/5) - I liked the grapefruit gelee and other garnishes, but the hamachi ended up tasting a little too fishy (and that's coming from a seafood lover like me!)

2) SRF beef tartare (4/5) - Tasty! It comes with some delicious fresh herbs to cut the gamey-ness of the beef, but the meat itself wasn't very strongly seasoned.

3) Beef short rib (5/5) - One of the "larger" options on the menu, but it was really only 4 small cubes of meat. The beef was amazing though, with just the right amount of fat in each bite so that it was flavorful and melted in your mouth.

I really enjoyed both of the cocktails that I tried, but the highlight for me was really the chai horchata with cognac for dessert! Absolutely heavenly, and I would come back just for this. It was so smooth and creamy with a thin layer of foam on top, and the cognac adds a kick to it.

Overall, amazing cocktails and tasty food though very very small portions. I had a great time here, but don't come with the expectation to stuff yourself.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
three words:  crab fat congee

When I saw that 1760 offered congee for brunch, I knew I had to come here stat. 

Congee seems to be popping up more and more frequently. Essentially, it is rice porridge that's a common breakfast stable in asian countries like China, Vietnam, etc. It's a pretty homey dish so it has a special place in my heart and brings back childhood memories of when my mom would make it for me when I was sick.

1760's version is a modern take on this classic dish served with crispy pork, tomatoes and a perfectly poached six-minute egg. Delicious! only complaint is that I wished it was served a little hotter - came out lukewarm. 

The brunch menu is a mix of decadent American dishes like the chicken and waffle croquettes and Asian dishes like kimchee fried rice. Somehow this mixture all works together. 

Also got the seasonal fruit which was standard. The buttermilk biscuits are actually mini-biscuits with about six for a serving and were delicious. The cardamom beignets were little bits of fried heavenly dough. 

We also ordered a bottle for the mimosas. Great flavors besides the standard OJ like pear puree. My only grip was that it didn't come mixed. When you're paying $28 bucks for a bottle of sparkling champagne, the last thing you want to see/know is that it's a cheap bottle. 

Would definitely recommend brunch at 1760. Also located in a cool area so you can walk off the calories afterwards.
author: Hieu H.

description:
1760 has gotten it right. It's not cheap but the food and cocktails are really tasty. There are so many other restaurants with this type of ambiance at this price point that fall short. To be honest, I had no expectations that 1760 would be any different.

We started with cocktails and I ordered the refreshing and beautiful Pear Shiso. It was served in a tiny glass but it was so good that I didn't even care how small it was.

The server told us to order 2-3 dishes per person and luckily, we were not very hungry so we ended up getting 3 items to share.

We started with the Little Gem Salad. This is one of the best salads I've ever had. The dressing had a nice kick of wasabi and the fried capers really made the dish special.

Next, we had the Pork Sisig. It was visually pleasing, yet again, and had bold flavors. We were very pleased at this point.

The only slight disappointment was the Duck Sandwich. It was a good value; at $19, it was perhaps the largest dish on the menu and the bread certainly filled us up. But it was one-dimensional and not worth all of the mentions in the Yelp reviews.

We finished off our meal with the delicious Brown Butter Panna Cotta dessert. We debated whether it was truly a panna cotta. Whatever it was, it was addicting.

2 cocktails, 3 dishes, and 1 dessert ended up being ~$110 with tax and tip. Not bad for SF.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Love this place for brunch, and can't wait to come back and try it out for dinner some time.

The SO and I were looking for a brunch spot around noonish on Sunday and didn't want to brave any long lines; 1760 came up on Opentable as an option for a reservation within the next 30 minutes, and since this was within walking distance, we decided to give it a try. I didn't realize it was an offshoot of Acquerello until I read I saw its tag line on Google Maps, but once we knew it was related to that, we had some high expectations.

The place was actually pretty empty around noon, so this is definitely a viable future brunch option if you're willing to spend just a little bit more. It's got a nice clean interior--very simple and almost raw at times (bare concrete floors), silverware comes in a cool carved wooden box, etc. 

We got:

Chicken and waffle croquettes: These were awesome. They're glazed in a maple syrup -- they were super soft and had a great balance between sweet and savory, and were just a delight to eat. 

Biscuits: Also delicious. The SO was not as impressed, but I've never been served little biscuits with some maple flavored butter and some jam -- I thought the flavors complemented the warm biscuit well, the SO thought that the flavor was a little too subtle, but I was pretty pleased with execution. 

Crab fat congee: this was what really impressed me, and this is probably what's going to convince me to come back and try again. I was a little nervous about their attempt at Asian fusion, but they killed it. They got the texture of the congee to be pretty right, the choice to flavor it with crab fat and heirloom tomatos and corn definitely added an interesting fusion component. The crispy pork was a nice flavorful addition and also added some nuance and texture to the dish, and the runny egg was a nice touch as well. This easily sealed the deal for me. 

They also have a really nice mixture of cocktails and drinks, and you can make mimosas with a number of juices! (pear juice is quite good). 

Food itself was about $35, so the price is actually quite reasonable given the high quality of the meal itself. Anyways, overall, highly recommend this place, and can't wait to give dinner a try!

tldr; underrated brunch spot, v good and affordable high quality brunch food, can definitely see myself frequenting this place in the future
author: Jasmine X.

description:
I checked out this place the other night.  Btw I had to make reservations for 1 a day in advance.  Yes they were that busy.  I liked  that it was a small menu but they said they make changes to it daily so what I could be talking about could be off the menu tomorrow.

The smoked tuna appetizer is basically smoked tuna on a cracker.  It was ok guess.

Then I got the scallops. The scallops were absolutely fabulous.  They were fresh and seared to perfection.  But the best part was this sautéed spinach and puréed cauliflower.  This dish totally worked.  But just keep in mind that you only get thee medium scallops for a total of $26.

Now for the reason I came.  I heard about this duck sandwich that they do and I wanted to try it for myself.  It sounded very interesting and unique.  Something an up and coming restaurant can claim as their own.  Unfortunately I was quite disappointed to say the least.  It's ground duck meat that's shaped into a patty and fried.  The put it on a nice bun with slaw and aioli with a few peppers for some heat.  That all sounds good but the problem is that the slaw and aioli and peppers are there to mask the dry and flavor free duck patty.  I felt sorry for the duck that was sacrificed for this pathetic attempt at high end cuisine.  

Normally I would give this place a bad rating for this colossal miscalculation but because the scallop dish was that good I'm willing to at least give this place 4 stars.
author: B B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of this place! I love the dim atmosphere and intimate seating. The service is here is great and on point. 

Their menu is basically tapas style with an arrangement of fresh bites to good ol' hardy dishes. The portions here are a bit small but can fill you up (depending). I recommend getting a couple dishes and sharing with each other or just getting a couple for yourself. 

I highly recommend starting off with their rosemary focaccia with baba ganoush spread. This has at the right amount of salt to it and strong flavor & scent from the rosemary. Next, their 'Har Gow' Cavatelli is phenomenal. The pasta is tossed and filled with tiny rock shrimp, garlic butter, and ginger. It's my favorite thing on the menu in fact. Their duck sandwich is ok; kind of tasted bland and like a veggie burger to be exact. I did love their fingerling potatoes because the charred avocado and cilantro gave so much flavor. The potatoes were cooked up perfectly! 

I also suggest grabbing some drinks off their menu. They have lots to offer and will satisfy your palate. For a great citrus-mint type drink for a quick refreshment, I recommend their 1760 house special cocktail. For a nice sweet drink to just take it easy on, I recommend their Falernum Sour which has egg white for texture and tiki bitters with pineapple! It's a great drink to cool off.
author: Allister D.

description: Wasn't obsessed with this place, it was decent. While dining at 1760 my friend and I ordered the new York lamb, truffle fries, burrata, and the fried duck burger. The New York lamb was a tad bit salty and I was having a hard time enjoying the duck just because I'm not a huge duck fan, however I do think it was prepared well. The burrata lacked flavor and could've used a little more spunk to it. Staff was great and the environment was comfortable.
author: Tas Y.

description:
1760 always seemed busy and trendy, so we decided to give it a try. We had a reservation for two at 9pm on a Friday via OpenTable. 

We ordered a number of the recommended items - 1760 and Fig Strawberry, both were delicious cocktails, though I'd say they were pricey at $14 each. 

For food, we ordered several of the recommended items - the lobster bisque, SRF beef tartare, and Corn-Coconut Ravioli. (Skipped on the duck sandwich since we didn't want anything too oily). 

We actually misread lobster bisque for the famous lobster ceviche, which is no longer on the menu. The lobster bisque was a soup that went down in 1-2 gulps, for a whopping $6 each. It was delicious, though the portion size was disappointing. The beef tartare was more like a salad, which was interesting and well paired with herbs, though again, was a small portion size (priced at $16). The ravioli was very good, though I've always been a fan of Thai curry. Unfortunately this dish was again a very small portion size (priced at $18). 

We decided to order another main since we were still hungry, the Paccheri (octopus) which was surprisingly in a pasta format. This dish was actually a decent portion size, but unfortunately the tomato paste sauce overpowered the octopus (it was priced at $23). 

We did get a free dessert since we were celebrating a birthday (the Intermezzo sorbet), which was a nice gesture.

The service was very good overall and the decor creates a more casual vibe. It's a great hangout spot, but we probably won't be coming back anytime soon since nothing particularly stood out, though I did really enjoy the corn-coconut ravioli.
author: Elisa L.

description:
Recommended to us by a friend, we came to 1760 for dinner at 9pm on Saturday night. Having made reservations ahead of time, we were promptly seated and set to enjoy our culinary experience.
Explaining to our attendant it was our first time at the restaurant, we learned the dishes were served tapas style. That in mind we ordered the beef tartare, summer farro, corn-coconut ravioli, and the seared scallops.
The farro came first- served cold, the dish was good; a little bland, but enjoyable all the same.
Next came the beef tartare- loaded with flavor and well portioned, this was definitely mine and my husband's second favorite dish! 
The seared scallops, which arrived third in our lineup, were salty, as scallops tend to be, but basic- didn't blow our minds.
The highlight of the meal was by far the corn-coconut ravioli! Each little pillow of goodness was perfection! Glazed in a thai-based sauce, one order of these delectable treats was not enough, so we ordered an additional round. Definitely recommend this dish to vegetarians and non-vegetarians, alike!!
Overall, we enjoyed our experience at 1760. Knocked one star because of the hostess who seated us- very rude, curt and unapologetic in her behavior. First impressions can be lasting impressions. Luckily, the rest of the staff well over made up for her.
author: Roma R.

description:
This place is really excellent. One of the best places I've tried lately. Definitely left me with a great impression and stands out from all the other over-priced and mediocre brunch places in SF (the ones with the long lines like Ella's and Mama's and Brenda's. Nothing but glorified American hot breakfast you can cook at home for a fraction of the price). This place doesn't open until 11AM on the weekends, FYI. 

We had the mushroom tempura, crab congee, pork belly fried rice, rock shrimp, and the beignets. The the crab congee and the mushroom tempura (surprisingly) are my favorites. Everything from the presentation of the food, the uniqueness of the flavors, and the service are top-notch. I'm eager to come back and try their dinner menu. 

If you want finer dining for brunch without the over-crowdedness, hectic long lines, and slummy atmosphere just to eat bacon and eggs, definitely come here.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Feed me. 

Are usually the words that come out of my mouth right after a short, but strenuous work out at Core40. As I get older, I realize that I have to put in more work to maintain the figure. Damn you yelp!

My fellow yelper in crime, Cat C., made rezzies for brunch even though it wasn't necessary (dinner is another story) because we don't like waiting. (part of the getting older thing) 1760 is a wonderful brunch addition to the Polk st. scene since this stretch is severely lacking exciting brunch options. 

The french toast must've spent some time soaking in vanilla and Cointreau since it was robustly flavorful. I loved that it was light, yet substantial. Berries topped the thick brioche and added a natural sweetness to the dish.

My rock shrimp with polenta was TO DIE FOR. Simply prepared with hoisin and lime, the flavors really come together and the crunchy soft chicharonnes was a dead giveaway that there's a Filipino chef in the house. Holla, kababayan! =) My only complaint is it's too darn pricey for a very small portion.

If you happen to visit in the evening even just for drinks, cocktails are on point. I've tried their Basil Mezcal sour (kaffir lime, egg white, mezcal) and The 1760 (mint, cumin, mezcal, tonic, gin) and I love that they aren't afraid to use a lot of spices in their creations. Cardamom, cumin, garam masala are a common sight on the list, so don't hesitate to order a flavor profile mix that you've never tried before, it'll be a unique experience. 

1760 is a casual dining destination in the Russian Hill neighborhood that's filled with locals. Quieter at brunch, but more exciting for drinks and dinner. Either way, it sure is a winner.
author: Janice C.

description:
Always wanted to check out 1760.  My now hubby and I had a failed attempt a couple years ago when we tried to go for drinks after seeing how busy Amelie was, yet, 1760 was just as busy.  Janice C. and I made plans to work out a few blocks down and then catch up over brunch.  Not liking nearby Mymy & Olea so much, I suggested 1760, and she agreed.  

I made rezzies in case, and we got there towards the end of brunch, so it was pretty cleared out around 2.  I ordered the brioche french toast and she got the rock shrimp polenta.  

The brioche french toast had hints of vanilla, Cointreau and berries ($12) It was two pieces of brioche and was nice and airy.  It wasn't overly sweet and I loved the very faint hint of Cointreau and the sweet berries.  Definitely a winner and one of the better french toast dishes I've had.  Her rock shrimp polenta ($18) was notably on the smaller side with some rock shrimp, chicharrones, and shiitake mushrooms.  The polenta was nice and smooth, and the chicharrones were a nice touch.  But for $18 the portion should have been a little larger.  

Service was friendly, the ambiance was nice and the brunch was pleasing though we weren't stuffed.  I definitely would like to come back for their dinner some time.
author: Cat C.

description:
Slow, slow service. Careful if you get Roman as a server because he'll just say  "I know" with a careless attitude. 
When your food shows up half the portion size you expected and an hour late and your server Roman turns to you and says I know.... that pretty much explains 1760.
author: Reyna F.

description:
Wow!! Can't wait to come again - and I don't live here, so we rarely visit the same place twice in SF. 

5 - English peas. Surprise favorite.  I was not looking forward to them but the waiter recommended it - and it's going to end up on my top 10 dishes of 2017. They were the biggest, crunchiest sweet fresh peas ever in a cream base which I usually hate with smoked albacore that married beautifully. Al dente peas that crunched - and they were not fried. Weirdest dish ever. 

5 - French fries with mayo. Perfection! 

5 - coconut curry ravioli - creamy, light, al dente. They burst in your mouth. 

All the flavors married artfully.  Next time I gotta get the spaghetti noodles everyone was eating, and the scallops too. Plus all of the above. 

We were going to go to Amelie next door, but it was crowded and loud and 1760 had booth seating and looked like a place we could talk and sit in booths comfortably.  Ended up having one of the best meals this trip.
author: JM L.

description:
All glitz and no substance. It's family style and the plates are all appetizer size.  It's fake gourmet for people with no taste.

The waiter did not take my wheat allergy seriously and I was up all night with indigestion.
author: Trent R.

description:
Previous visits were for dessert only...sadly even that has changed. 

Upside: if you arrive before 6:30pm for dinner you can take advantage of Happy Hour type prices for appetizers. Not a bad deal, assuming serving sizes are the same as the regular menu.

The burrata appetizer w/foccacia was delicious -- I shared it but could have eaten one all by myself. Need to try to prep this at home. 

Shishito peppers - fine if you like peppers. 1 out of 10 is spicy and I got that one...uncomfy at first (although I love spicy food) but the heat eventually dissipated although I was desperate for some food to come to take away the heat. 

Mushroom soup shot -- nothing special. Ordered one only due to peer pressure.

French fries w/parm cheese & siracha ketchup...not bad, but more of a filler. 

Brussels sprouts -- very good although only tried because they offered it to us since one of our entrees took a hella long time to come out. 

Scallops - will withhold comment but order it if you are not super-sensitive to seafood. 

Pork ribs -- on the dry side. What was worse is they served it on a piece of paper that looks like an old wine menu with the ink side up. Inquired about the food safety of serving hot food on a piece of paper that had print/ink on it & the wait staff said it was bought for that purpose & tested for safety or something (didn't sound believable).

Last but not least the panna cotta -- have been here a couple of times for that alone because it was so delicious. The recipe or the chef must have changed or perhaps it was an off night...was not delicious as I had remembered. 

Wait staff/service was good -- the delays or any issues with the food, I blame on the kitchen.
author: D L.

description: I enjoyed my dinner at 1760! I had the duck sandwich, scallops, and risotto. The entrees have a perfect portion size! The deep fried chicken bites with a salad was a perfect starter. The dessert was frozen Leche flan! The chef has some really good Filipino influence!
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Review is for Brunch only. Most Brunch spots with an established reputation do not take weekend brunch reservations so I was a bit taken back when my better half secured a prime brunch time time on a Sunday. As far as first impressions goes, upon walking in the layout and space oozed modern thoughtfulness and the large windows on the left emanated just enough light to create a cool relaxed vibe. 

I had heard good things about the Brioche French Toast and although it was on the small side portion wise, it was soft and yet had a pleasant chewy consistency and overall was solid but not spectacular. I was more impressed by the side of fruit(with mascarpone). Not only was the fruit fresh but the presentation scored high on the visually pleasing scale. Bringing out burnt toast was not so hot on the presentation scale.

Our waitress was pleasant. I have to say that although I gave 1760 3 stars for my bunch experience, it's closer to 3.5 stars.
author: Dennis W.

description: Excellent evening here with terrifically original food in a tasteful space. A bit noisy but really nice feel to 1760 for a lovely date. We had the lamb lumpia, crispy chicken, famous duck burger and an extraordinary beet salad. Dessert was a unique combination of rhubarb sherbet and orange ice. Refreshingly ample cocktails and extensive( but pricey ) wine list. We plan to return to explore more of the very creative menu offerings. One of the best servers ever as a topper to the night!
author: Helen M.

description: I met with an old friend here for brunch. She made reservations, but we probably didn't need them. I really loved the modern feel of the place with all the open windows and high ceiling. The server was accommodating and kept refilling our waters. She recommended ordering 2-3 entrees per person, so we decided to share the Little Gem Salad ($10), B.E.T. ($11), Truffle Fries ($6), and Croquette ($15). Everything was so beautifully presented and tasted just as great too! I would probably pass on the B.E.T. next time as it's only bacon, eggs and toast and really wasn't all too special --I don't know what I was thinking ordering that. Overall, a very chic spot, but can be pricey.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
I went to try this restaurant because of a recent celebration. We had reservations and was quickly seated.  The food was good- though, we were a fan of the duck burger (their signature dish).  The only thing wrong was our server didn't come and ask us how the food was.  She was  attentive but didn't ask how we liked our food :)

Other than that, we enjoyed the food
author: David P.

description:
This place was GREAT. Went here for Mother's Day brunch and the whole family loved it. All plates are family style, so we all ordered two or three dishes each, so everyone had a chance to try everything.  Even though there was so much food, it was all so rich and high quality, we couldn't stop eating even after we were full! 

The restaurant has a really chill vibe: light hip-hop and alternative music playing overhead, large windows and plenty of light, cool and simple decor. 

My mother keeps saying how great of a spot it was. Definitely will be returning.
author: Remington P.

description:
This place has a great, laid back yet stylish vibe!

It's classy and modern but relaxed enough so it's not stuffy. I went with three other friends for dinner and we all really enjoyed the food, service, and ambience. The location is great too as it's right on the corner and parking hasn't been too much of a challenge yet (have been there twice).

I forgot exactly what we ordered but there was a appetizer of ahi tuna (I think), steak, and I believe salmon. Sorry that is not helpful but the takeaway was that we all enjoyed it and thought it was delicious. We also appreciated the size of the portions, not too big/smaller style.

it's a great spot to roll up to for a cocktail at the bar or a dessert. Love this spot and will definitely be back!
author: Karen M.

description:
There is brunch bliss available in San Francisco without hour-long waits, and it's at 1760.

I've enjoyed about four dinners and three brunches at 1760, and they've impressed me every single time. It's also nice to have a restaurant that isn't crazy expensive but serves top-notch (though typically expensive) cocktails.

I have a few favorites that seem to consistently be on their menus:

Little Gem Salad (dinner and brunch)
Bavette Steak (dinner only)
Rosemary Focaccia (dinner only)
Buttermilk Biscuits (brunch only)
Kimchi Fried Rice (brunch only)

That said, I've found any item on either brunch or dinner menus disappointing.

1760 also has a remarkable happy hour (The Stirring Hour) with most cocktails at $8 and a limited selection of tapas-style items (all priced lower than the normal menus).
author: David S.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place! Love the setting and decor of 1760. I was greeted by the host right away as they sat us down for our reservations. They offered a complimentary snack which was a small crostini with some cheese and fruit on top. I would recommend doing family style, it's mostly small plates and it's great to share and try everything. I noticed a lot of people ordered the Fried Duck Sandwich. It seems pretty popular, so definitely I will try that next time. 

I must say, most of the dishes I ordered were on point except for two. The octopus dish was overcooked and the pork belly was a little under cooked. We did mentioned it to the waiter as he gave us a complimentary dish and it was really good!!! It was a string bean type of dish called "Haricots Verts - yuba, lime, and fish sauce." I definitely recommend this dish. 

Other dishes I ordered:
- Lobster Ceviche: caramelized coconut. pineapple. kaffir lime (SO GOOD)
- Corn-Coconut Ravioli: lemongrass. pimentón. cilantro (one of my favorites) 
- Flatbread. burrata: Thai sausage. romano beans. shiitake mushrooms  
- Crispy Octopus - carrot-tamarind. cauliflower. chicken skin (overcooked) 
- Pork Belly - heirloom tomato. Chinese broccoli. mustard-sesame emulsion (undercooked)
author: Jenn L.

description: Worst restaurant. Cancelled our dinner reservation for being 15 mins late. It was crazy because the restaurant wasn't busy at all and there was no one waiting. They didn't have courtesy to call also. Hostess was very unfriendly and this was first time in the City we had this bad experience.
author: Rash B.

description:
After you get past the hostess, the place is enjoyable.  We had a 7:30 reservation, we were running late so I called and said we'd be 5 minutes late.  We ran into traffic from the Chinese New Year, so I called back said we'd be there by 7:45.  She said they only hold a table for 15 minutes.  I said we were on our way and have called twice.  She seemed unmoved.  This seemed unreasonable.  We got there by 7:45, so there was not problem.  When we arrived, no one was waiting for tables.  There were many empty tables and places at the bar, no line of people waiting to get in.  

We came here based on rave reviews on Check Please Bay area.  The food was very good, but none of us would rave.  The shishito peppers and brussels sprouts were very good.  The duck sandwich was good.  Service was fine.
author: David F.

description: This place is ridiculously good - top to bottom. Every plate we shared at our table was unique and delicious, complimented by friendly staff and exceptional service. The cocktails were spot on as well - I recommend the 1760. Can't believe we had never seen/heard/been to the place since it opened four years ago. Highly recommend.
author: Donnie K.

description:
IMPORTANT: 
1. If you are hungry- don't come here.
2. This isn't a $$$ place. Food might be between $20-$40/ plate but when you are paying $20-$40 for a pathetic dish containing 4 tiny things that is definitely not in the $$$ range.
3. If you NEED to come here- order the duck sandwich. It is the biggest and most filling and then you won't have to waste your time with all the other poor excuses for dishes.
4. Service is okay- When we arrived we got this little dish of fancy chips and guacamole " on the house". The chips were : TWO chips- one for my bf and one for me. And the "chips" were the size of my finger nails.  1760, keep your chips!
author: Julianna I.

description: Very cute spot for a small groups, friendly service, and good food. Lively and fun on a Friday evening. And amazing desserts. My favorite spot on Polk by far.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
+friendly staff
+great food
+no TV's (love that)

-very busy
-higher on prices
-street parking can be tough sometimes
-smaller portions of food
author: C J.

description:
I got the gilt city brunch special for two. We got the beignets, the rock shrimp polenta, the French toast and maple bacon. The beignets were pretty good, although I think they out too much sugar on them. The rock shrimp polenta is a pretty small entree and I thought the shrimp didn't taste all that fresh and was over seasoned. 

I was pretty disappointed with the place and now I'm not sure if I would come here for dinner.
author: Alice W.

description:
First visit. It wasn't a WOW experience but a very good one.
AMBIANCE: modern, cozy, noisy, relaxing.
FOOD: Mostly yummy, well presented and portioned dishes. HAD Soup shots, Albacore and Burruta apps (all As), Mushroom risotto (A) and Sol (A- because the fish was a bit over salted) and Intermezzo (A+).
SERVICE: Nice, right to the point, but a bit long wait in between apps and entrees.
VALUE: very good considering you are in SF (with high taxation and extra charges for Health care).
We left in a very good mood with our palates and tummies happy.
author: Tatyana M.

description: Went here for a late dinner last night and had a great meal! Nice space - large bar, plenty of room between tables, good music. Good wine list - and though I didn't go the cocktail route this time I definitely will on future visits -- the list is wonderful. Plenty of small plates -- actually really hard to choose. They've listed them from small to large and from light to rich, which is very helpful when choosing. The husband and I shared the Tombo Tuna Crudo and the Brussels Sprouts. Both dishes were remarkable -- probably the best tuna I've ever had -- perfectly executed. For our mains the husband had the Lamb Steak, which he loved - deeming it perfectly cooked and seasoned. I chose the Risotto with black and king trumpet mushrooms, water chestnuts and parmesan and what can I say - it was like silk. I love risotto but feel like I'm constantly disappointed when I order it out -- this dish was sublime! Of course we had to share their Milk Chocolate Ganache for dessert which was the ideal size after such a meal and couldn't have been moe delicious - I mean c'mon - who doesn't want a deconstructed s'more for a sweet treat? Throw in absolutely charming waitstaff with a good sense of humor and on point service and you've got a winner! Will absolutely be returning again and again!
author: Lisa W.

description: Great service, food, and environment.  Recommended date spot or small group gathering after work.  A1 mixology crew behind the bar as well, don't leave without trying a cocktail or two.
author: James C.

description:
Been here for lunch and dinner and I would highly recommend the place for brunch. Its not going to be one of those places where you're waiting for hours at end to get seated.

Recommend getting the Kim Chi Fried rice, the fingerling potatoes, and the seafood sandwich.
author: Kunal T.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for a nice date night. Our reservation was at 8pm but we were running late so we called in and learned that they can't hold the reservation more than 10 mins so we had to cancel. Someone just happened to cancel their 8:45pm reservation so we took their spot :)

The server told us this place is family style and recommend each person to order 2-3 dishes. Here is what we ordered:

Avocado Toast (4/5): Pretty good. I liked the addition of the lime. I mean its hard to mess this one up. I did like the fact that the toast was made from scratch.

Hamachi Crudo (3/5): Came with 4 small slices of hamachi. It was topped with lemon, mango, and cucumber. The sauce had a nice kick of spice. The fish itself wasn't as soft as I expected; It didn't have that 'melts in your mouth' factor that I was looking for.

Lobster Risotto (5/5): Our favorite dish of the night. Super yummy with a generous amount of lobster meat.

Fried Duck Sandwich (2/5): Really disappointed at this dish. I really don't get why people rave about this dish so much. I wish they used actual slices of duck meat instead of a patty. The patty didn't even taste like duck.

Grilled Pork Ribs (4/5): The ribs were very tender. The sauce was okay. Nothing special in terms of flavor.

Milk Chocolate Ganache (5/5): Served with hickory ice cream, bourbon caramel, marshmallow. WE LOVED EVERYTHING ON THE PLATE! It was the perfect ending to our meal.
author: Angelyn S.

description:
It's too bad I have to give 1760 a 3* because it absolutely used to be a solid 4*

We hadn't been here in a couple years but wanted to try some of our old favorites: the brussel sprouts, the pork ribs, the octopus and we also added in the uni pasta, which we didn't remember from the old menu.

Unfortunately, the octopus was not the grilled charred octopus we fondly remembered but some sort of breaded, deep-fried version that was just terrible. They would be smart to go back to the old recipe. 

The service was so so because they clearly forgot our ribs and when they were ready to bring them we had already waited 30 minutes and cancelled the order.

I'll give 1760 another shot because I've had good experiences in the past but they need to step it up a bit!
author: Farid V.

description: Love this place, what a solid spot. Have been back several times and always enjoy myself. Great food and wine, highly recommended for a dinner date.
author: Adam P.

description: A great place for drinks and dinner. The ambiance is right on. The staff friendly. Started off with a glass of Oberon Cab Sav. The olives, beef tartare, sprouts and scallops were amazing. The pork belly and shrimp tagliatelle were good. It's a tapas, shared plate style dinner. They pace the dinner so you definitely don't feel rushed. An enjoyable dining experience. Definitely would come back for their signature drinks and desserts.
author: Linda H.

description:
1760 is the exciting sister to Acquerello. It did not disappoint! It was Friday and I was fresh back from 2 years in hell....namely the suburbs of DC.....the dreaded DMV! I wanted to celebrate some great news and an exciting week so I looked thru my bookmarks and asked Acquerello to shoehorn me in, knowing it was an abject "negativo". They recommended 1760 and the reviews were, in a word, "tasty!" 

The vibe is casual but cool....the tunes nice, the ambience great and the service absolutely top-notch. We had several great dishes which are sort of tapas in nature, the "tempura", scallops (perfectly cooked), and a super-yummo macapuno dessert along with the star, two tasty cocktails (happy hour) and the brilliant recommendation of the sommelier, a great CabSav from the Alexander Valley. All in all, we had a delightful time.

just a note: our waitress had an unusually flat affect which was a little unnerving but the food, beverages and other service people made up for it, as well as the beauty of the setting inside!

Definitely going back
author: Kevin F.

description:
I watched Check Please on TV.   And got really good reviews.  But in my opinion, the food isn't that good and very expensive.

We ordered a few happy our starters, the lumpia, the tacos and the crispy chicken.    All three were quite greasy.   The lumpia was just dripping with oil,  the filling was not very good,  I also had the crispy chicken.   The crust was heavily battered and greasy again.
