I felt like I had this tiny chicken morsel in a heavy lump of deep fried batter.    I have had crispy chicken that was light, yet crispy.   

Our entree was the ribs and the baby corn.   These miniature baby corn,  a total of five or six of them were accompanied by a few feta cheese morsels,  costed $17.00.      We also ordered the ribs.   At first bite, I liked the taste, my husband said  it was too spicy.  But toward the end of my first rib, I liked it less and less.   The texture of the pork was too dry.   I have had better.   
Three happy hour appetizers, the miniature baby corn and the bbq ribs came to $86.00.
We each only had one rib because we did not want a second piece.

The service was very good.   But I am a foodie.   This restaurant did not cut it for me.
author: Doris A.

description:
Probably my favorite spot that I've eaten at in SF.  

Not only a fantastic ambiance, but the food is all top notch.

This is one of those places where you go with a few friends and order literally one of everything on the menu.  It's all for sharing, and if you don't try everything you're missing out.  I literally wouldn't be able to tell you what my favorite item is as they're all equally mouthwatering. 

The cocktails are also exceptional. Try the 1760.
author: Christopher S.

description:
The cutest brunch place! Came here with 8 friends for a boozy brunch reunion and it was so great! Totally hip and modern upscale atmosphere for decently affordable prices. At $10-20 per plate, we got half the things on the brunch menu and were able to share - I definitely recommend the congee. Everything on the menu definitely sounds a little different at first, but everything I sampled from my friends' plates were fantastic. Our waiter was great, attentive, but not too attentive, and was very patient with helping us weigh out our options on the menu. 

To top it all off, they had pitchers of mimosas with different flavors of fruit juices to mix it with! Instead of getting the traditional OJ mimosa, we got it with grapefruit juice and it was so delicious!

Next time I'm in the city for brunch (or another meal) I'll definitely have this on my list of favorite places to go :)
author: Abrianna R.

description:
Ever since 1760 opened on Polk, I was never able to grab a table. Every time I walked by, it was super packed, and I was never patient enough to wait.

I made reservations easily on a Wednesday evening at 7. The restaurant was nearly empty, so accordingly, the wait staff was very attentive.

1) A waitress brought over a complimentary starter - apple slices with some sort of sweet puree on top that was delicious and refreshing. It was a nice surprise, and probably tasted better because it was free ;)

2) I started off by ordering this poppy sticky bread with lavender butter to start. This was good, but nothing to write home about. It's a perfect size to share for 3 people, though, and it keeps you from over-eating!

3) Corn-Coconut Ravioli was up next. So good! There were six raviolis in total, so it was easy to share between three people. The flavour was unique, and not a bad Asian-fusion combo.

4) Seared Scallops were delicious but some were overcooked. STILL GOOD THOUGH.

5) Grilled Pork Ribs with Hoison BBQ sauce was our last savory dish. I don't usually like pork or go for ribs, but this was bombbbb. It was spicy and even our friend who doesn't like spicy food enjoyed it.

6) Honey Panna Cotta - you know when you think that the dessert won't taste as good because you're already full? THIS WAS NOT THE CASE. The portion size for this was oddly large compared to everything else. It was probably the best bang for your buck. It was also a nice size to split between 3 people. I would come back to 1760 just to order this. 

Everything menu seems over priced, but when I really think about portion control and how much I should be eating, it is the perfect amount.

Between three people and many "courses," we were full and not weighed down; and our bill came out to ~$100.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
After pouring over multiple restaurants finally decided to come here. Parking is a little tough in this area but worth it if you plan on spending a night out. Unfortunately, I was a little disappointed with my meal. I had done some research and had my mind set on ordering a few things, but they didn't have the lobster ceviche or grilled octopus I had wanted. This is what we got: 

Hamachi crudo 4/5: decent sized piece of hamachi but not as soft as I had hoped. Wasn't that impressed. 

Seared scallops: 3.5/5. Beautiful plating and good sear on the scallops but overlooked a little. 

Cavatelli: 2/5. Got this after reading a couple of reviews and it was one of the few bigger dishes on the menu. Super disappointed. This was pretty much just like pasta in cream of mushroom soup. 

Beef short ribs: 5/5. They melted in your mouth. One of my favorite dishes of the night. 

Duck burger: 5/5 I was hesitant about this because so many people raved about it in the reviews and it lived up to the hype. Another decent sized serving and loved the spicy cole slaw.

Overall, one time is probably enough of this place. Good to try, but not a place to continuously return based on the food. Staff was great and super attentive!
author: Katy C.

description:
What a terrible experience I had here.  If you have food allergies, I suggest you find another place to eat!  When  I arrived, I alerted my server I had allergies to nuts. He assured me he would tell the kitchen and would let me know if there were nuts in anything brought to the table. I specifically ordered the salad that came with pecans and asked if they could serve it without them.  He assured me no nuts would touch the salad.  The salad was served with several pieces of nuts in it which I didn't realize until eating one.  I called him over and he apologized and said he'd let the kitchen know and that I wouldn't have to pay for the salad.  Really, how generous.  You could have killed me and your offer is to give me is to take the salad I couldn't eat off the bill.  I asked to talk with the manager.  No one came.  I asked him again.  
Then, the executive chef came out and apologized and I asked him if he realized what happened and takes this seriously.  His comment was,"well that's why I'm out here." Then asked me if I wanted benadryl and if I needed medical attention.  I told him I would let him know.  I asked him if he was the manager and he said no he'd send him over.  Again, no one came.  Nothing else was done and I had to take the medication to keep from anaphylaxis.  When this happens in any restaurant, my experience has been that the manager falls over himself or herself, comps the meal and offers something to like a gift card for a return visit and a second chance.  The arrogance of this place is astounding.  Do they not realize a lawsuit could destroy their business.  They do not deserve my money and will never see it again.  I hope that you read this and choose another place for dinner.  SF has incredible restaurants who treat their customers with respect.  In addition, I told many friends who used to go there often and will never return now.
author: Carl G.

description:
Very trendy and posh cocktail and tapas spot. Definitely high-priced but everything I've tried is absolutely delicious. Try brunch for a casual atmosphere with little wait.

Ambiance is very modern and hipster from the bar to the bathroom. I would like the designer to decorate my next apartment...although might be out of my price range.
author: Stefanie K.

description:
I came here for dinner with my family and it was a hit! It's pretty difficult for me to find something that pleases everyone (picky eaters, huge appetites, etc.) but we were very happy with our meal at 1760.

Our dishes:
- lobster bisque
- mushroom tempura
- avocado toast
- chicken and waffle croquettes
- Brussels sprouts
- paccheri
- pork sisig
- Bavette steak
- grilled pork ribs
- intermezzo 
- honey panna cotta
- macapuno
- milk chocolate ganache

The servings were a bit on the small side but that allowed us to try more things. I really liked the mushroom tempura, the paccheri, and the grilled pork ribs.

We also ordered one of each dessert to try. Unfortunately, while they were plated very well, the flavors didn't match the level of quality of the savory dishes. The intermezzo was probably the best dessert. The milk chocolate ganache was too rich (and broke apart once the server set it on the table! :c so sad).

I will definitely come back to try the other dishes - I hear the breads are very good - but will pass on dessert next time.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Impeccable service and the the most attentive sommelier in San Francisco.

1760 never fails to impress and live up to its rep.  Kind of like a "Polk st. NOPA" is one of the best descriptors I've heard.  1760's upside to the Divis favorite is the elegance of presentation and intimacy of the room.

The only detractor is the somewhat limited menu, IMO.  I've been here 3 times and have tried all the things that sounded appealing (and a few that didn't).  I look forward to returning but would love to see a refreshed list of offerings.
author: Lee S.

description: Beautiful and amazing food. Fresh, original, creative,  and perfectly portioned to order 2 to 3 dishes each to try out a good part of the menu. Great espresso, open view from the kitchen to the dining room, clean,  excellent wait staff, and beautiful bar to match the open concept layout. Tempura mushrooms were delectable and perfect. Crab fat congee was original and unctuous. Pork belly fried rice was ammmmmmmmmmazing. Fried duck sandwich was hot, crispy, and prefect with the radishes and aioli.
author: Judy L.

description: Bloody Mary Review - Bar manager Chris Longoria brings California fresh style to creating ingredient-driven cocktails, and the Red Bell Pepper and Cucumber Bloody Mary at 1760 fits squarely inside that mould. Featuring sriracha, lemon and thyme alongside house roasted bell peppers and refreshing cucumber, this complex brunch drink is treated with the same precision and thought as the most gourmet of entrees. Why go? A fresh and complex bloody mary. | Price: $13
author: Shelley B.

description:
Finally got to try this place since it opened 3 years ago. I probably shouldn't have waited this long since I picked out what I wanted from the menu since their opening and now the menu has changed, I was quite disappointed I didn't get to try their corn ravioli and the squash blossom. With a disappointed heart, I tried to be open and order something else, but at that point...my appetite has turned bias.

For a party of two, we made a reservation 3 weeks in advance (I was determined to try this place once and for all!). Parking was surprisingly easy for that particular Saturday night, but only street parking is available. Seating was a breeze since we had the reservation, but it does seem like the restaurant is packed so expect to wait if you're a walk in party.

What we ordered:
Lobster Bisque - 3/5 stars: individual sized (espresso shot), my husband said it didn't have enough lobster essence assuming it was be very concentrated since it's such a small cup. However there was a small piece of lobster in there.

Mushroom Tempura - 4/5 stars: light and fragrant, easy to eat and almost didn't want to share.

Brussel Sprouts - 3.5/5 stars: pack with flavors. Love how it's paired with some sunflower seeds for a bit of texture. The slight bitterness from the brussel sprouts and the honey was infused perfectly. However, it starts to feel overly salted if indulged.

The infamous duck burger - 3/5 stars: didn't live up to the hype. It was good, but I don't see the reason behind it's staple of the menu.

Not a great place for party over 6 people. Best to visit with a group of 2-4.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
The food scene in SF is lacking and pretty much a lot of restaurants I've tried, especially 4+ star places on Yelp, were very underwhelming and lacking in taste and variety so I had low expectations coming in and boy was I pleasantly surprised.

My boyfriend made a reservation for 9pm on a Friday and it was still packed and lively. Here is what we ordered:

1) Hamachi Crudo - Four slices of hamachi soaked in a delicious white soy sauce and oil. The sauce was so good that I soaked as much as I could with the fish and then dipped my spoon in just to finish up the sauce (yes, that's what I did!). The best way to eat this dish is not with a fork but with a spoon so you can scoop up more of the sauce when you eat the fish. 

2) Sea Scallops - Only comes with four scallops but definitely quality over quantity with this dish. The scallops had a perfect, flavorful char on it that was cooked just right and therefore, did not come out rubbery. The best scallops I've had to date. The rainbow chard was tangy and was a nice balance to the flavor of the scallops. Eat the scallops with all the cauliflower puree! I don't like cauliflower but there was no hint of the actual taste of the veggie in this puree.

3) Fried Duck Sandwich - I expected the duck to some out completely fried but only the outside was lightly fried and the inside left to remain moist and bursting with delectable flavors. The spicy aioli gave it a nice creamy flavor and texture to the duck. Definitely the most filling dish. 

4) Lobster Risotto - My least favorite dish. The rice was a little too al dente to my liking and tasted just okay with no variety of flavor like the previous dishes. I've had better risotto at Ruth Chris and Gary Danko. However, it did had a generous amount of lobster and for $32 it better have!!

Overall, AMAZING food, great atmosphere and ambience, and attentive service. This would be the third restaurant (along with Ono seafood in Oahu and Gary Danko) that would rate 5/5 stars.
author: Kristina D.

description:
I'm known for over ordering. So when two people who over order get together, it can be a dangerous combo. Welcome to Thursday night at 1760 with me and Peter L!

Drinks:
*Old fashioned 17: wild turkey 81 rye, campari, jelenik fernet, fee bros orange bitters, angostura ($12)
*The 1760: mint, cumin, mezcal, tonic, gin ($12)
*Domaine tempier, bandol 2011 ($78)
*Faust, cabernet sauvignon napa valley 2012 ($58 for 375ml)
*Enrico gatti grappa di moscato ($10)
*Americano ($3)

Drinks were very good. I enjoyed the cocktails. Plus they were donating $2 per Old Fashioned to the SF-Marin food bank. A good cause. I really enjoyed the Faust cabernet sauvignon. The half bottle wasn't on the menu, but our sommelier suggested it. It was perfect for my palate! Full bodied and bold.

Food:
*Caviar: hokkaido scallop tartare, uni, chive ($8)
*Hamachi crudo: nori, yuzu kosho, avocado, daikon ($6)
*Lobster ceviche: caramelized coconut, pineapple, kaffir lime ($17)
*Burrata: grilled bread, sweet peppers, spearmint (anchovy 'bagna cauda' on side) $14
*Uni: bucatini, garlic, red pepper, bread crumb ($22)
*Crispy octopus: chorizo 'paella', lemon-mussel ($22)
*Bbq pork belly: corn porridge, charred frisee ($23)
*Hanger steak: carrot-serrano, pearl onions ($28)
*Strawberry & cream bavarian: lemon basil gelato, basil sponge cake ($10)

So. Much. Food. But good food it was! I enjoyed the Caviar & Hamachi crudo very much! They really are just small bites and made for one person. But since we ordered so many dishes, I was fine having a tiny bite of each. The Uni bucatini is a must order! The creamy, briny, sweet, oceany uni went well with the bread crumbs. If I wasn't so full eating all our other dishes, I could have definitely finished this all by myself. I love uni! And finally, our dessert offered a nice sweet treat at the end. And very refreshing due to the lemon and basil.

So after three hours, nine courses and lots of drinks, 1760 and I parted ways. Our server and sommelier were both great and super helpful. I would definitely come back for their Caviar, Hamachi crudo & Uni bucatini. Yum!
author: Elena N.

description:
Four of us arrived for our 10pm reservations, and it took about 20-25 minutes before we were seated.  The restaurant was very busy, and the bar was tight, so it made it difficult to get a drink while we waited.

We decided to try:
Hamachi Crudo
Lollipop Kale
Lobster Ceviche
Crispy Octopus
Brussel Sprouts
Roasted Carrots
BBQ Pork Belly
Beef Short Ribs
Fried Duck Sandwich

We ordered the Hanger Steak, yet they were out and we substituted the Short Ribs in.  They brought us a taste of their salted Apple slices to start and dishes continued to come, one by one.  For dessert, we ordered the Chocolate Ganache, and it was light and delicious.  A great way to wrap up the evening after all the other dishes. 

A good tip is to drink all your alcohol before midnight.  
They will physically remove the beverages from your table if you do not.

We were the last table in the restaurant and they actually started turning some of the lights off near the bar and kitchen.
author: Andrew H.

description: Server barely acknowledged us, each dish came out over 30 minutes apart (I know because I Snapchat a picture and it has a time stamp). At the end, the hostess came over to give me the bill. Thank you hostess for picking up the slack from our server. Food was mediocre, def not worth the price. Won't come here again.
author: Siri E.

description:
Mind blown!  I had 1760 on my bookmarks for quite some time and I finally got to try it for date night with my boyfriend. 

It's a really modern interior and it feels really fancy but it's also ok to dress casually. The food here is absolutely amazing, each dish was so flavorful and delicious!

Lobster ceviche: 5/5: delicious! I loved the combination of coconut lime sauce with the lobster. It was a perfectly light combination to start off with. The portion size just sucks cause it's so small. But it's so delicious!

Uni bucatini: 5/5: so heavy, flavorful and tasty. It had a nice cream sauce that wasn't too heavy. The breadcrumbs, cheese and uni together were a perfect combination. A bit on the oily side but this was delicious! Another plus was that the uni didn't taste like the ocean, it was fresh and tasty!

BBQ pork belly: 5/5: the best dish of the night! It was a new dish on the menu. The pork belly had the perfect fat to meat ratio. It  had plenty of meat, that was cooked to perfection. It pretty much cut apart without a lot of effort. It was intensely flavorful and went so well with the Swiss chard, mustard seeds and sauce. I wish this dish was bigger, it was amazing!

Octopus paella: 5/5: it was super tasty, oddly I didn't like the crispy octopus pieces as much as I liked the lime infused octopus and when you eat it with a little paella it was so good. Wish this was also a bigger portion as well. So damm tasty!

Fried duck burger: 5/5: almost had no room for this. Wow this was better than what I had expected. The crispy fried duck, the aioli, bread and slaw worked together magically. Even with the duck being heavy, the slaw cut down the fatty taste of it and made it more delicious. Even though we didn't finish it the quarter that I ate was delicious.

Green tea dessert: 4/5: it was a decent dessert. I'm picky when it comes to green tea desserts, I like it with a really strong green tea flavor and this was not strong enough for me. The cake was tasty, it was layered with raspberry, cream and green tea. It was tasty. They raspberry jelly on the side was a bit too tart for me but the green tea ice cream was ok, just not enough green tea flavor. 

A very delicious meal, it's a must try! I would definitely come back here again in the future. It's a great spot with amazing food and drinks! 

Total for 2: $185
author: Stella J.

description:
1760...doesn't belong in 2015.

First of all, skip the duck burger. It's really not that great. The patty is not sliced duck breast. It's mushed up duck meat of some sort. Almost like a mushy chicken salad, minus the mayonnaise.

The drinks were okay, nothing to rave about.

The best thing about this place was the waiter. He was attentive and funny!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Delicious cocktails and tasty food.
Great food for its price range/ambiance.
Sister restaurant to Acquerello.

Favorite Food/Drinks:
Love thePear-Ginger cocktail, so delicious!
1760
Peach Buck
Corn ravioli- it's like a soup dumpling and corn soup purée explodes in your mouth
Uni pasta
Tempura mushrooms
Lobster ceviche
Chocolate ganache

On crowded days, may not be seated immediately even with a reservation. Parking in the neighborhood could be difficult, so plan enough time to account for parking.
author: Iris H.

description:
I swear I am not exaggerating....this is the most memorable and outstanding dining experience I've had in SF! I've only lived here for a year, but I am a food slut and have eaten at a huge majority of the hot spots in this city!

You'll definitely want to make reservations at this place. The wait can be pretty long. We started off with a bottle of lambrusco which was reasonably priced.

Everything is great for sharing. The top of their menu starts with the smaller plates and as you work your way down, they become more of entree portions. My friend and I started with the SRF Beef Tartare, Della Frattoria Bread, and White Truffle dishes. The Beef Tartare was the best I've ever had, amazing flavor and great portion for 2 to share. The Della Frattoria Bread is perfect if you like eating things like patte. Has a similar texture but the onions they add to the dish give it a nice crunch and savory flavor. 

But OMG the dish that completely won me over was their White Truffle. We had second thoughts about ordering an appetizer sized dish that was $50 but it was so worth it! This was hands down, one of the best things I've ever ate. It has a 63 degree egg which was very creamy, mushrooms, white truffle, all in a parmesan emulsion. I think I died and went to heaven when I ate that dish. I would go back there in a heartbeat and have no problem spending another $50 to have that dish. So.freaking.amazing!!!! I've had dreams about it ever since.

Lastly, the fried duck sandwich is bomb but very filling. I would suggest splitting it with someone. It's very hearty and full of flavor. You will not be disappointed with any of the dishes here. This place is incredible! I can't wait to come back!
author: Chisholm T.

description:
Tried looking for a good spot to
Have dinner with friends,
Since my friends don't want to eat heavy I chose this place. This place is good for sharing since there serving is appetizer style "tapas" it's a fusion of American and Asian
author: Apple V.

description: I wish I could give less than 1 Star. Sat at the bar with 3 friends, ordered a few apps to share and some cocktails. Everything was going good until we tried to order another round of drinks (martini for me) at 9:52 pm. We were told by the bartender (beard and almost man bun) that all the tools were washed and only shots and beer.  So lame and lazy that the bartender could not even wash a spoon and a glass to make a stirred gin martini. Not sure what the standards of hospitality are at 1760 but hopefully it was just an off bartender having an off night. Would be hard pressed to go back with so many other options.
author: Gilbert P.

description:
Sharing is encouraged so we family-styled  dinner.  We ordered shishito peppers, potatoes, Brussels sprouts and crab fat congee for two people.

Pros: 
- Larger than expected portion size.  We couldn't finish
- Creative cocktail menu using a lot of eastern spices
- Service

Cons:
- Complex seasoning that masked the natural goodness of the featured ingredients.  The shishito peppers were covered in fish sauce, red peppers and etc.  The potatoes were also drenched in sauce with diced avocados and spicy peanuts.  
-  Heavy hand with sauce.  The brussel sprouts were nicely charred.  However, it also drowned in dressing.
- Temperature of garnish for the congee was off.  It shouldn't be cold when the dish is hot.
author: Amy J.

description:
One of my favorite meals in a long time. 
Great space. Friendly service. Very reasonable.

Reservations on opentable. It's often really crowded so make reservations. Definitely busy and loud on the weekends but just plan ahead!

Menu is often seasonal so sometimes they will change up the items, so I hope hope hope that they don't change some of these out!!

Truffle dish: WOW.  Yes it's like $50 but for the amount of truffles they give you with that soft boiled egg.  Wow.  It really didn't even need the sauce or the mushrooms.  I ordered it once without mushrooms, and it was a much better pure experience.  Heaven!!!!!!!!!!

Fried duck sandwich: yes yes yes.  yes it is worth it.  I had it as my "dessert" once.  Wow.  Even better without the pickles...for me at least.

Steak: it was good, but pretty normal, unlike the truffle and fried duck.

Octopus paella dish: not my thing but my husband thought it was probably better than heaven.  I had my truffle, he had his octopus.  No conversation needed.

Pasta in potato soup was good, but not out of this world

I am waiting to go back and get me some truffle dish again.   And maybe a fried duck sandwich for dessert again.  WOW.
author: Traci H.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night, and it was not difficult to get a walk in table for 4.  We did come a little bit early, around 6:30.  I like the atmosphere of the place, wide open and modern, yet classy.  1760 serves there dishes pretty much Tapas style, with the menu of small plates ordered from light to rich.  

Highlights:
Sashito pepppers - You really can't mess up to bad as they have a lot of sweet peppery flavor on their own.  It was seasoned will and quite tasty..munched on most of the plate on my own.

Beef Tartare - I actually like this dish a lot.  The beef was super fresh and had a really clean beefy taste.   

Brussel Sprouts - Another delicious plate that utilizes the flavor of its main vegetable perfectly.  There was creamy sauce drizzeled over it that tasted amazing.

Pumpkin Ravioli - I wasn't expecting too much out of this one, but it turned out to be quited delicious.  The sweetness of the pumpkin was really highlighted here and the ravioli had a good chew consistency.

Low Lights:
Sisig - hmmm, this just didn't belong.  It sounded good on the menu, but wasn't well executed.  I felt the pork itself didn't have too much flavor, and the sauces and toppings took more away from the flavor itself.  

Crab Oil Congee - Hmm, this didn't even feel like Congee, more like grits...was hoping for something a bit more soupy.

Duck Burger - The biggest complaint here was that the Duck was grounded beyond recognition, then fried dried.  Even with it being highly processed, it still tasted gamey.

Service was good, we were able to consistently keep the drinks coming.  We had a lot of drinks, and here is where it gets prices.  Specialty drinks start at $14, which is more than most of the specialty bars in the city.  Not really worth it to drink at dinner, when you can drink after on Polk street for much less.

Overall the food was good but pricey, and the menu is a bit mashed up but offers a wide range of choices.
author: Veasna H.

description: We planned a weekend here in San Francisco to try out this restaurant per Check Please Bay Area. It did not fail. We had several dishes including the Corn Ravioli (OMG!!!!) and the pork ribs (succulent).   For dessert....The Genache,,,,,,WOW!
author: Wine T.

description:
While I normally feel cheated by the minuscule portions at tapas places, 1760 was great!

It's one of those sophisticated, modern joints that work well for dates or small groups. They have nice, comfy booths that accommodate up to four. Slightly dressy atmosphere, but I came in yoga attire and didn't feel too out of place.

The food was great, albeit a touch overpriced. Like most tapa restaurants, each person is supposed to order 2-3 dishes. My group of 3 ordered 6 dishes and that was the right amount of food, leaving us satisfied but not stuffed.

Would order again:
+ Cavatelli with mushrooms and charred broccolini (loved the combination)
+ Fried duck sandwich (duh!)
+ Fingerling potatoes with charred avocado and roasted peanuts (addicting)
+ Mushroom tempura
+ Pork sisig

Pass:
+ Grilled pork ribs, as they were too spicy for me and nothing special.

Overall, a solid choice for dinner. I'll give brunch a shot to try the crab fat congee!
author: Valerie L.

description:
If you are looking for a nice date night or birthday celebration, this is the place for you.

Get excited, this place served spectacular innovative entrées.

We ordered:

- Lobster Ceviche = luxurious mixture; giving it a tasty and refreshing touch. Portion was extremely small though. 

- Uni Bucatini =  excellent mild creamy texture. Never thought uni could be beautifully blended with bucatini pasta. A must try!

- Corn Ravioli = cooked to perfection. Love. Love. Love.

- Fried Duck Sandwich = flavorful, tender, and moist. Great for sharing. 

- Warm Banana Bread = I am a fan of banana bread. This was a delicious combo of crunchy peanut butter and "chunky monkey" ice cream. YUM!

- Intermezzo = yogurt ice cream. rhubarb compote, and strawberry granita. Standard.

All in all, great food, great service, and great ambiance. Give this place a whirl. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
We had dinner here last night, and we were a little disappointed. Here is the breakdown of how I evaluated the restaurant:

Service - 3 stars. The waitstaff were friendly and efficient. The Sommelier was extremely helpful and knowledgeable about the wine selection. However, they seemed to be short staff, because water was filled maybe 2X in the course of 2hr, the wait person has to be reminded 2x because she forgot to put in items. 

Food - 3 stars. The presentation is great, and food combination is interesting too. However, the scallop dish my husband ordered was Luke warm, and lamb steak was bland. We ordered three other appetizers, and the results were not any better. For the price of these dishes, we were dismay about how bland most of our dishes were. 

Atmosphere - 4 stars. It's causal but fun. People seem to have a great time. And it's walking distance to a lot of bars and fun places on Polk street. 

Overall - If you want to impress your date, I would not recommend this place due to the food /service and price. But if you happens to be in the neighborhood, and don't mind paying above average price for average food, then there you go.
author: Sandie Y.

description:
1760, Verbena, & Stones throw were on my top 3 To-Try list in the Nob Hill neighborhood this past year. I was pleasantly surprised that 1760 probably surpassed my expectations.

I came here on two occasions thus far and look forward to returning again. Once during SF Negroni Week which enabled me the opportunity to try all their different cocktails on their special Negroni list. Everything was phenomenal and the prices were absolutely fair ($9-11). 

On a second occasion I came for date night with my boyfriend and was definitely very impressed with the food and service! The ambiance feels very contemporary and modern, with the exception of the high-top communal table at the front of the restaurant facing Polk street which offer a more family-style affair.

The food here is delicious but also innovative. The Uni Bucatini were to-die for in my opinion! It's one of those special dishes in the city kind of like Seven Hills' or Cotogna's "Raviolo." Everything else was solid - we ordered several dishes and shared between the two of us. My other favorites included the lobster, the caviar & uni spoons, and the pork belly. The pork belly was insanely tender and exploding in flavor - I like that it had a charred exterior to it.

1760 probably is one of my favorite Nob Hill restaurants at the moment. It doesn't disappoint and is perfect for any occasion! The only downside is that they do not take large parties but other than that, it's a great spot and worthwhile to check out at least once.  

Prices are competitive with others. Again they have the "small dish" concept ranging from $9-$15, and larger/entree-like dishes that are $18-$29.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Summary: Creative food and plating with a relatively minimalist interior. To many of the other fancy-pants restaurants in this city, you're on notice; these guys can compete!

Interior: layout is somewhat like a starker mirror of Nopa with only one floor but high celings, with a communal table up front, long dining hall leading to an open kitchen, and long bar paralleling the tables. The fairly simple decor with more muted grays found around the restaurant (aside from the wooden table and bar tops) certainly helps focus attention on the vibrant food when it arrives. The large windows catch plenty of the setting sunlight, adding a wonderful warm glow to many of the dishes. Silverware rests in containers at your table, giving this minimalism more of a casual vibe.

Food:
Lollipop kale - interesting, slightly asian-flavored dish that works best with the red currant sauce paired with it. However, I found it a little too salty after a while, either due to the amount of what I think is soy sauce on the bottom, or perhaps the guanciale lending its own salt. Canela in Duboce does a better lollipop kale in my opinion, but good effort here!

Hamachi crudo - beautifully presented, and an excellent combination of ingredients. This was easily my favorite of the savory items we shared. First time I've seen pluot paired with hamachi, and it was an excellent match.

Dungeness Crab - The cantaloupe-serrano sorbet was the best addition to crab in this dish. It added a nice refreshing little spicy kick to your bites. It also had a very fun presentation. Only quibble is that the cantaloupe flavors from the broth and and sorbet eventually drown out the crab near the end, so it ends as a mostly crab-textured cantaloupe flavor.

fried duck sandwich - sorry yelpers, you led me very astray here. Sounds fun on paper, but in practice I found it missing more of a duck flavor than I would have preferred, replaced with too much salt instead. Don't bother filling yourself up with this one.

Strawberry & Cream Bavarian with a lemon basil gelato and basil sponge cake  - their menu leaves out mention of jellied strawberries and a milk-powder based crumble, both yummy additions that help make this dessert amazing (not to mention a few other touches). The Bavarian is a slightly foamy cream item, sort of like a light mousse. The basil sponge cake is a little denser than what normal sponge cake is like, but all the flavors and textures work wonderfully well together. This and the hamachi were my favorite presentations.

Almost forgot to mention that they also start a little amuse bouche (that day was pink lady apples with a raspberry jam) and end with a mignardise (cocoa powdered marshmallow - yum).

All of the above ran about $80 pre-tip, but the food shares well between two and filled us up. This would easily be a 5 star in my book if it weren't due to some items overdoing it on the salt and the disappointing duck sandwich, along with somewhat slower service in taking our follow-on orders, as we did not order all the dishes at once. The cocktails also look very intriguing, whose names could easily be mistaken for another tasting menu (to try at another time ;). Not a place my wallet can comfortably come to on a regular basis, but rest assured I will be back with wide eyes and an adventurous appetite!
author: Linus W.

description:
Overhyped and overpriced. Things started promisingly enough when R ordered a basil-infused mezcal sour. And that's where 1760 peaked.

The tuna crudo was acceptable -- you could even say it was topped with an interesting aioli but some might say it was nothing more than mayo with a big ego.

The summer salad was wilted and pedestrian. Come to my house and R will make you a better salad any day of the week.

I decided to be adventurous and ordered the Uni bucatini. Big mistake. Fishy, sloppy, and greasy. The kind of restaurant dish that R will finish because he knows he paid a lot of mi eye for it. 

The corn-coconut ravioli was someone's half-baked idea of Thai-Italian fusion. You're never heard of that combo and with good reason. The dish was overly sweet and soupy and none of the flavors meshed together. Shoutout to Calabrian chiles -- the only redeeming feature. Thank you to my ancestors.

R ordered a second cocktail, the "Salt and Punsch", with hopes that the misplaced "s" was a portent of masterful mixology but it was another humdrum affair. Come over and R will mix you a better cocktail and you can stay in your pjs.

We decided to skip dessert and eat the Alter Eco chocolate bar and a leftover scone from Arizmendi's. Sad but true: dessert was the highlight of the evening.

Maybe we ordered the wrong things but a restaurant should not have so many wrong things.
author: M G.

description:
Good dinner and drinks spot in Nob Hill. Wait staff is fantastic - friendly, fast, and attentive. They were really nice with tasting wines before a full pour and on the spot with recommendations.

The best single item was the squash blossom done tempura style. The foam it comes with tastes like uni and has amazing umami profile.

The poppy seed pain de mie was exquisite. One of the top breads at a restaurant. The focaccia was forgettable and a waste for paid bread.

The Corn-Coconut Ravioli was tasty and light. I'd get again.

The pork sisig was a refined version of the Filipino dish but ultimately disappointing.

The Calamarata Pasta had a nice kick but was also didn't have us wishing for more. It was a spicy tomato pasta with calamari but didn't become more than the sum of the parts.
author: Victor W.

description:
It's one of those hot, hip, cool, trendy, upscale, gastropub-like places that serve small, fancy, delicate, artsy, gourmet, tapa dishes that are meant to be shared and paired with your favorite drinks.  But the servings here at 1760 weren't small at all.

They were tiny.

The LOBSTER CEVICHE ($17) had a few small pieces of meat and was served with a piece of lime so tiny that I could not even hold it in my fingers to squeeze it.  The presentation was absolutely beautiful which made you feel like you are presented with a piece of art.  You feel ecstatic - until you realize that you just paid $17 for literally 2 bites of meat.  To give them credit though, there was a good contrast of flavors and it was good that the flavorings did not overwhelm the natural taste of the lobster meat.

The BABY RED ROMAINE ($11) consisted of 3 small pieces of tiny romaine hearts in a lemon vinaigrette that was very tasty.  The romaine tasted fresh and sweet and you can tell it's top notch quality.

The BURRATA ($14) was a piece of grilled bread topped with Burrata (a creamy mozzarella cheese) and garnished with paper-thin slices of Asian pear.  The Asian pear was juicy and sweet which enhanced the flavor of the Burrata, and in that sense, I liked the pairing of the flavors.  The presentation was again awesome and artsy - absolutely pleasing to the eyes, albeit that it may not satisfy the stomach.

The FRIED DUCK SANDWICH ($16) was a slight disappointment.  Firstly, it was not a filet of duck breast, but a patty of ground duck meat.  Think: duck burger.  Secondly, the slaw, although very tasty, overwhelmed the flavor of the duck and there were so much slaw that made it a very messy sandwich.  Thirdly, the duck was overly salty, although this could just be my personal taste.

SERVICE has been top notch throughout our meal.  Wine recommendation was on point.  The food came out in the proper order - lobster ceviche first, then romaine, Burrata and lastly, the duck sandwich.  The pacing was good, although a bit faster than I would like; but again this is just my personal preference as I would like to have a break of at least a few minutes between dishes.  Our server and his assistants have been friendly, cool and efficient throughout.

When we visited San Francisco about 3 months ago we went to NOPA and were completely blown away.  I was so impressed that I left my heart in San Francisco - NOPA, San Francisco.  Therefore, I can't help but compare 1760 with NOPA in terms of menu execution, presentation, flavors, prices and portion sizes.
 
And in that respect, 1760 is 3.5 stars.  But until Yelp has a half-star rating system, I'll just be nice and click on 4.
author: Rob L.

description:
This has to be one of my favorite restaurants in the city. Awesome food, excellent service, and extremely easy to get reservations. I hate how now I have to plan months in advanced if I want to eat somewhere good, with 1760 I made a reservation just a couple days in advanced. Score. 

It's recommend each person order 2-3 plates and share. Now the food:

- Caviar w/ Uni and Scallop tartare - Everything amazing served in one bite. The moment you put the spoon in your mouth, you get the bold flavors of uni and everything just melts in your mouth. A must order and a great way to start the meal. 

- Lobster Ceviche - The coconut cream served on the side was genius. I thought the lobster ceviche was a bit on the salty side, but the coconut helped balance out the saltiness and tanginess of the dish.

- Corn-Coconut Ravioli - OMG. SO. GOOD. The corn in the ravioli was rich and full of flavor and paired perfectly with the thick coconut curry sauce.

- Grilled Pork Ribs  - These succulent ribs are doused in Hoisin sauce. They are nice and crispy with the perfect amount of sweetness. Be prepared to walk away with some dirty fingers. 

- Fried Duck Sandwich - I can't remember the details of the sandwich, but I do remember it was excellent. 

- Coconut cake w/ ube ice cream white chocolate and hazelnut - Anytime I see ube ice cream, I'm going to order it. There were so many strong flavors in this dish and it all worked together perfectly. 

For two people the bill came out to be around $180 (including $30 corkage fee) and we walked away super stuffed. It's a great place for a date or to come with a group of friends. Will definitely be back.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Ahhh-mazzzingg!! 
Skip the wait and make reservations beforehand! I learned the hard way but it was well worth it. I started off with the pear ginger cocktail and it had a big ice cube of Campari. I was pretty happy with my cocktail!

My friend, Cindy, and I wanted to try the uni bucatini but they ran out for the night. However, we were still happy with everything we ordered!
The shishito peppers were great! The hazelnuts added a crunch to this dish.
The crispy octopus was one of my favorites! Especially paired with the paella.
The fried duck sandwich came with a knife through it, part of the presentation, but it's also nice to have the knife when you plan on sharing the dish.
We finished off with the espresso panna cotta! So good! I licked the plate clean. My friend usually isn't a fan of sweets, but she liked this! 

My tastebuds are happy, plus we received great service! Excited for the next time I get to dine at this amazing establishment!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
My co-worker who recently moved to San Francisco picked this place for three of us. The earliest reservation she could get on a Tuesday night was 8:15, a good sign that the food would be good. 

For appetizers, we got the shishito peppers with yuzu-miso, bonito and sesame ($9). Good, but nothing too creative. The fingerling potatoes with charred avocado, cilantro, and roasted peanuts ($10) were delicious.

For entrées, I went with the grilled pork ribs, hoisin bbq sauce, peanuts, radish ($18). The ribs were absolutely delicious. Tender and falling right off the bone with just that right amount of tug. I would put these ribs in my top 10, maybe my top 5. My co-worker opted for the  1/2 roasted chicken, aji verde, pickled green onion, and garlic croutons for $24 (You can get the whole bird for $42). My other co-worker trusted what my fellow Yelpers had to say and ordered the fried duck sandwich with slaw, pickles, and spicy aioli ($19). For the entrée round, everyone was happy.

For dessert, none of us really cared for the plantain with goat cheese-vanilla semifreddo. rum caramel and granola ($10). I'm not sure if it was the granola, but something about this was off-putting. The milk chocolate ganache, hickory ice cream, bourbon caramel and marshmallow ($12) looked like a roller coaster. Nice and rich but I couldn't get into the presentation.

The espresso here is super bitter. If you order it and don't like it, it's not because of the cup or the machine. It's the beans they use, which the server admitted were "not for everyone."

The ribs and polite service were really the saving graces for my experience.
author: Adam D.

description: I've been here twice during work trips.  Love the variety and creativity of the dishes.  Try a bunch of plates and share with a friend.  It's loud but not unbearable, and the cocktails are very good.
author: Kat M.

description:
Between 3 to 4 stars. 4 stars if I had not had the duck sandwich. 

The lobster ceviche was very good. The lobster was very tender and "cooked" perfectly. The coconut cream went very well with the whole dish. 

The octopus with gigante beans was also very good. The lobster had the perfect amount of chew and tenderness. The beans were well seasoned and the sauce was very good. Can't recall what kind of sauce. 

The corn ravioli was good. Not great but still very nice. The corn filling was very creamy but the skin was a little too thick. The broth it was served it was very light but good. 

The fried duck sandwich could have been good but it was way too salty. Hubby did not want to finish his half. I took out the duck and ate little bites of it with the bun. Also, SF has such good bread but the bun is a travesty. It had this weird sponge-y-ness to it. Disappointed with this dish.
author: Hae A.

description:
This place had great drinks. Great drinks. My blueberry sage cocktail was DELICIOUS. The ambiance is also very nice. 

The food was mostly meh and overpriced to me. We ordered a plate of stuffed olives, which was basically the green olives with the pepper in them that you can buy in any grocery store. We spent $8 on olives that we could have gotten in a large jar from the store for $3. Lame. They could have at least had one type of olive that was stuffed with feta or something! The duck burger was really strange. Duck is usually served sweet to offset the greasiness of the meat, and the sauerkraut was not a good addition. The sandwich dripped, fell apart, and was unappetizing. It did not form a comprehensive dish. The heirloom tomatoes were good, however, how difficult is it to cut up some tomatoes and pour balsamic on them? 

Seriously overpriced, mediocre food.

Just come here for the drinks.
author: Samara J.

description:
FANTASTIC.
Drinks...amazing, fresh, hyper seasonal. The creativity in this place is what brings me back.

Shisito Peppers - yes
Beef Tartare - yes
Corn Coconut Ravioli - YES
Bread - yes

Haven't had anything to drink that was bad, mediocre, or boring ever here. All drinks are a total win.
author: Amy O.

description:
freaking yummy!!

had a date night on saturday and was really floored by this place.

great service. the staff was on top of it.

great wine. great food...and a great freaking dessert.

honestly, it is worth the money and the atmosphere.
author: John C.

description: It's a nice room, and it's a young stylish crowd.    The bar seems a bit part of things and drinks look good.    Food is small plates style.    Presentation of better than average.     Wine is expensive if you're looking at bottles.    They do have a decent list of wines by the glass.  We had two cocktails, one appetizer, 2 small plates, one dessert, and two glasses of wine,    Tab including tip:  $146.00
author: Charles L.

description:
It was Monday night and I really really really couldn't be asked to cook.  Combined with a stormy night, I sort of just wanted someone else to do the hard work for Greg and I.  Greg forced me to pick a new place to go to for dinner, and we decided on 1760. A word to the wise: Make a reservation.  We saw people walk in and were turned away (on a Monday, no less!) because it was too crowded.

We decided on:
Brussels Sprouts. crispy onion. aromatic herbs 
SRF Beef Tartare. marcona almond purée. herbs. Thai vinaigrette
Cavatelli. 48 hour lamb shoulder. green garlic. burnt rosemary oil  
Fried Duck Sandwich. slaw. pickles. spicy aioli  

Out of everything, I most definitely thought the Cavatelli was the winner.  Greg thought everything he had was really an interesting and wonderful take on typically traditional things like beef tartare and a "burger".  The fried duck sandwich was messy, but the spicy aioli on the burger was to die for.  The brussels sprouts were definitely a deviation away from the traditional crispy with bacon, but this absolutely delicious.  I personally thought the Beef Tartare was sort of "meh", but Greg thought it was one of the better interpretations he had.  Overall, we would certainly go back to 1760, and next time, we'll stay for dessert!
author: Lisa I.

description: Celebrating my BFFs bday:  front corner table for 7.  Where do I begin.......arrived in time for happy hour but it was called the "stirring hour".   Cocktails and apps at great prices!  We just about ordered half the menu and I couldn't pick my favorite, ALL were great.  Dinner continued and MORE food!  Sorry no details but ordering about 75% of the menu, there were no disappointments.  No dessert because we had bday cake at home but our server brought the frozen flan for bday girl, AWESOME.  The only issue we had was the timing of the food, slow!  Long gaps between dishes, wonder if the chief made each and every dish for the whole Restuarant?  It was worth the wait.  Definitely a do over
author: Grace F.

description:
As did most people, when I came inside this restaurant it made me feel as though i was in Nopa. Decor was very modern with clean lines. All the bottles at the bar were organized. We had to take a later reservation since the restaurant was pretty booked but when we came in there were plenty of tables. I assume people cancelled their reservations since it was pouring outside. That's probably the reason why our food came out so fast. Still didn't stop be from enjoying my food! 

Lobster Ceviche- Had to try this upon recommendations from other people. It was very fresh and tasty. It did have an Asian flavor to it. A little lemongrass I believe. Nonetheless it was delicious.

Monkfish Liver Mousse- reminded me a lot of Foie gras. It was a carefully crafted place with richness and smoothness to it. Definitely recommend this dish.

Brussels Sprouts- Tasty but this kind of dish I've had at many places before. 

Crispy Octopus-  Grilled to perfection and very flavorful.

Bucatini- I am a big fan of Uni but this this dish lacked in flavor. I've had Uni pasta before at the Uni Club and that had more of a complete flavor profile. This one was a miss for me.

Beef short Rib- By the time I got to this dish I was so full. The combination of the the celery root and the salsa was perfect. Not to mention the mean was cooked to perfections. Would recommend this dish as well.

Even though I was utterly full at this point I always make a point to save that little space in my stomach for dessert.

Cinnamon Custard - the server recommended this since it was a favorite of the Chef but I didn't like it. The horchata sherbet lacked flavor and didn't go well with the cinnamon custard.

Mike Chocolate Ganche - This was quite a creation. The combined flavor reminded me of S'mores with a modern twist.

I also tried their signature 1760 drink but that was just so so. I'm a big gin fan so I was expecting much more.
author: Nguyen L.

description:
I was already dialed in on that uni bucatini, but I had no idea what else to order.

Our server that night was SO helpful! Not just that but she was very friendly and cheery. She explained the menu to us and helped us pick out our meal.

For 2 people, it is recommended that you order between 3-4 dishes BUT that will vary for everyone because it depends on which dishes you order.

The top of the menu is the lightest item, and it gets heavier toward the end. We went with :

Brussels sprouts (light item) $8 - sauteed with onions, herbs and covered in cooked egg yolk (that's what the yellow stuff in the photos are). although this was at the top of the menu and considered to be a "light" item it ended up being VERY filling. Still, it was very very good and I would recommend it.

Crispy octopus (medium but leaned more toward heavy) $18 - gorgeously cooked with a beautiful seared char on the outside that gave it the crisp. it came on top of a bed of roasted fingerling potatoes so this dish was pretty filling as well. 

the bucatini (heavy) $19 - LOVE LOVE LOVE. Why don't more places have bucatini? And why don't more places serve it with uni? Why don't more people feed me this!? MAKE IT FOR ME NOW! Just kidding. I LOVED this so much. The uni in it was PERFECT. It was rich, but sweet and creamy and the bread crumbs and garlic made it crunchy and salty. Bucatini is fun. More places should do it. If you're an uni lover, well.. you have to get this.

fried duck sandwich (very heavy) $16 -  fried duck with spicy slaw.. oh man. I was ready to throw in the towel after the bucatini. This sandwich is extremely filling and did me in. I was only able to take 2 bites and had to hand it off to ajusshi oppa. crispy and had a nice smoky aftertaste to teh spicy slaw. 

We also had cocktails. I went with the peach buck because who doesn't like bourbon? Oh you? Okay we can't be friends. The peach buck was excellently crafted. I was a bit thrown off by the star of anise in it at first but thought what hell it will probably be good. Yup, it was. If you're a bourbon person that enjoys your bitters then go with this drink.

ajusshi oppa had the garam-masala cardamom. I didn't try it but he said it was very good. 

An excellent belated birthday (for me!) dinner for 2. a solid 4 dishes. 2 very well crafted drinks. 

total damage: around $90 but really not bad at all considering all that we had. 

1760 advertises itself as tapas but man, these portions are big. I could definitely go back just for the bucatini as a meal in itself.


Thank you for my birthday dinner ajusshi oppa!!! Tiny side boba girl will not keeeeeel you.
author: Susy C.

description: The lobster ceviche was the worst ever with the pieces being too small and the flavor drenched in some overly sweet yogurt sauce. Would almost want to guess that they got a bad batch of lobster and tried to salvage it by cutting it to shreds so it wouldn't be recognizable. They also forgot to add any lime for acidity. The octopus was surprisingly good, moist and interesting in flavor. The wine selections are okay. The servers are friendly. If you bring a heavy coat, they'll put it in the coat rack for you. The overall vibe isn't very unique or interesting. Think they need a new chef with some vision to ramp things up.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Trendy, fun, and with an impressive decor, 1760 is definitely a great new restaurant making Frisco yet more of a wonderland for foodies. 

The food here is, for me, four stars, but the ambiance, the relaxed tone, the waitstaff's professionalism, the drinks, the creative ingredients, and the amazing dessert all make me feel this place should get the full 5. 

While the menu itself did not blow me away (it is supposed to go from lightest to heaviest but even our waiter admitted this was a slightly misleading suggestion) the food was certainly quite good.

The burratta is a Must Try. It is just insane and perfectly plated. The lollipop kale is similarly awesome. The Crispy Octopus and Cavatelli are also well worth your time. Our waiter was very chill and answered all our questions without a hint of impatience.

I must say the dessert here was the best part. Check it out in the pic below. It was a Milk Chocolate Ganache with hickory ice cream. bourbon caramel and little dollops of marshmallow. It was a play on S'mores and it was utterly awesome.

Anyway, do not go here expecting food like you are at Benu or Saison, but if you are with a date or some friends and just want to have a straight up awesome time in a really excellent and beautiful dining room then definitely head here. It is fun and very chic without feeling pretentious.

Oh yeah, and make sure to get that milk chocolate ganache dessert. So sick.
author: Paul A.

description:
I have yet to try Acquerello, for fear of being disappointed, it seems to be the trend for me as I have been a bit slower catching up with all the SF institutions.  

I love this mid-range less buttoned up style of dining as of late.  There is energy, eye candy and great food to boot.  That's what the Bay Area excels in right?!?! 

*Amuse: hibiscus apple, crisp, cold and delightful way to start the meal, use the salt
*Lobster ceviche, caramelized coco, pineapple, coriander, mopped up the coco, balanced
*Beef tartare, loved the fresh herbs, the marcona almond butter was questionable, easy to omit
*Bucatini with uni, loved the briney uni and bread crumbs, healthy portion
*Cavatelli, pillowy good, favorite of the two, I think I just like the shape more, both good
*Fried duck sandwich, upon first bite, not too exciting but gets better as you savor more, it's huge, definitely to share if you are ordering other dishes.  

If you order NOTHING else, get the brown butter cake, with apple bourbon gelato and -cheesecake mousse-it's wonderful.  We were stuffed and still cleaned the plate. This dessert left GINORMOUS smiles on our faces.  What a fabulous way to end the evening. 

Price for two with two glasses of wine, $150.  Going straight to my SF favorites list.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
I really want to like this place. I mean I REALLY do. The better part of my 20 years in San Francisco, this part of Polk Street has been my 'hood. But it has never had especially good high end('ish) food. So I was happy when 1760 (related to the insane (2) Michelin-starred Acquerello) moved in -- I KNEW this was what I was waiting for...

But, I left both of my visits underwhelmed. With such a beautiful menu, with such impressive ingredients, with its Acquerello provenance, how could this not come together?! But nothing did -- despite the great ingredients, the flavors never seem to work together. And in this age of increasingly impressive presentation, the dishes all looked a little 'muddy' and just thrown together. (I am the king of 'food porn' photos, and not even I could make this stuff look good.)

My experiences:

Crispy Octopus w/ carrot-tamarind, cauliflower, chicken skin -- Flavors, meh. Octopus, dry.

Baby artichokes w/ pistachio, orange and basil -- Bland, boring "salad" that looked like it was just shot out of a Salad Shooter. 

Beef Tartare w/ marcona almonds, herbs, Thai vinaigrette -- I almost always order the steak tartare when on a menu, but this left me underwhelmed -- merely barely seasoned raw meat with a little Thai essence. 

Bucatini (perfectly al dente) with uni (creamy!), garlic, red pepper and bread crumbs -- My best experience, but sadly, just one for four on the food wins.

I have never had any of their cocktails, but it looks like a great menu. Their wine selection is top notch, and on both visits, the bartender made great recommendations. Sadly though, on my final visit, I found myself without wine and just a little remaining bit of my bucatini. I asked if I might have a half-glass to finish my meal off. Response: "Sorry. We do not do that." Yes, a small nit. But very disappointing for a restaurant of this caliber. Looks like the service is on par with the food -- looks good on paper, but just does not come together...

Sorry for the 2-star (rare for me), but with high hype comes high expectations. 

Maybe I should try brunch?
author: Corey M.

description:
Came here about a month ago to celebrate my birthday. I've been keeping this place on the radar since it opened and I finally had the chance to check it out. We had reservations but had to wait about 20 min for the table to be ready. I wasn't too annoyed by it since it was primetime Saturday night. The hostess checked on us a few times which was sweet of her and very professional.  

It's tapas style which I like since you can try a variety of dishes without going overboard. We opted for 5 dishes. The first 3 are on the smaller side and the pasta and sandwich were the main dishes. 

Hamachi Crudo
Lobster Ceviche
Crispy Octopus
Bucatini
Fried Duck Sandwich

What was the best dish? Personally, it has to be the lobster ceviche. It's the only dish that I wanted more of and I scraped every ounce of that sauce out of that bowl. The coconut with lime sauce was refreshing and light but had a creamy texture that went with the lobster perfectly. 

The one I could do without? Probably the Hamachi. It didn't do much, was overpriced and had shaved celery which didn't add anything other than texture. 

The bucatini was good. It was a nice change from SPQR's version. I like both to be honest. SPQR is rich and smokey, however 1760 is surprisingly light and refreshing. 

Overall, I'd come back again for a dinner party or to check out some of the other dishes. It's not bad and should be around for a while.
author: Andrew S.

description:
3.5 for 1760

Our meal at 1760 did not live up to the hype, but the overall experience was very good. My mother and I came here for a ladies night, and I was very excited to order all of the items that friends had recommended. The cocktail list was very impressive and we both really enjoyed our drinks. 

We ordered the squash blossom tempura, which was fantastic. It's hard to find squash blossoms on menus, so I always order them when I can. I'm not sure what they made the foam out of, but it was overpowering and left a bitter unpleasant taste in my mouth. The lobster ceviche (which everyone said was a must), was the most disappointing. The coconut sauce was yummy but didn't pair well with the lobster. The lobster ceviche itself seemed to have a lot in it besides lobster, which was a bit of a bummer. The crispy octopus was good, but a tad too burnt-tasting. The star dish of the night was definitely the cavatelli; the pasta was clearly made in-house and the mushrooms added such a rich, delicious flavor. 

The vibe in the restaurant was pretty good. It was definitely louder than expected, seeing how close all of the tables were to each other. Our server was on the cold side, overall a fun time. I do think that if I had gone in blind (so to speak), I would have enjoyed the food more, but it's been so hyped up, I expected everything to blow my mind.
author: Regina L.

description:
Went to 1760 to check it out, didn't have reservations so couldn't sit in the booth.  Had a small table or communal table - I picked small table.

Since we both had late lunches we weren't hungry which is the way to go here, their portions are SMALL & EXPENSIVE.  Hate that!

FREE tap water in black wine size bottle - fine.

FREEBIE of 2 small cubes of honeydew - fine, & tiny.

Dungeness crab $15 - just a small thing of crab w/ some celery, & whatever & some dots of hot sauce.  Overpriced & not worth it.

Crispy octopus $16 - maybe 3 pieces of octopus, some tiny ass potatoes, pinenuts & pretty gross avocado.  

brussel sprouts $8 - couldn't even see them when brought to the table, cuz they were burnt, egg yolk covered it up, w/ some green stuff.  Skip this dish.

Bucatini $19 - uni pasta.  Tiny portion, they say you can share - only if you're not hungry folks.  Nothing special, can do the same thing at home - get some spaghetti cook it & buy some uni mix it up!

Charge it. 

Bathrooms in the back on the Right side.  One women's & one men's, extra sinks outside.
author: Ann L.

description: It seemed like a slow night so we got plenty of attention from the staff. Boyfriend and I were walking down Polk and decided to stop by and eat here on a whim. The style and decor was very nice inside. The Rosemary focaccia with burrata was on point  boyfriend had the fried duck sandwich that seemed to get good reviews and I tried the crispy octopus with the spicy aioli. The dish was good but I felt it needed some kind of citrus, like lemon, to really make the rest of the flavors pop. Other than that, I ate the entire thing!!
author: Annie G.

description:
Service...
+ with a smile
- slow and not terribly attentive

Drinks...
- Pricey (14 bucks for cocktails). I'm betting 20 bucks a cocktail in San Francisco in most places by early 2018.

Food...
+ Brussel sprouts - really tasty and unusual lime flavor
~ Hamachi Crudo $17 for four tiny pieces - ok-ish
+ Fries - yummy/crisp/great seasoning
- Har Gow Cavatelli ($22) - unevenly cooked. bad stuff!
- Seared Scallops ($26 for four pieces) - overcooked
- Roasted chicken - the spices did not work
- Pork Belley - overcooked and butter beans etc. - too heavy

Tried the Panna Cotta  and Ganache for desert... table of five didn't finish two deserts completely.

1760 is just a business that needs to make money in the expensive city that is San Francisco. No culinary adventure to be had here. (The conversation was lively though!)
author: noflaps c.

description:
Mr. NSS: "If I was single, I would never date a 'foodie' again."
Me: "Excuse me? WTF is that suppose to mean?" 

Mr. NSS: "I feel like Al Bundy....always broke."
Me: "The only 'Al Bundy' thing about you is, you watching TV with your hands in your pants doing gawd knows what down there!"

Mr. NSS: "This conversation better not become part of your Yelp reviews."

Oppsie. Too late...

One of the most highly anticipated fall restaurant openings, Mr. NSS and I visited 1760 for the grand opening tonight. 

After celebrating my birthday two years ago at Acquerello, I knew 1760 would be very promising. They've consecutively held a Michelin star since 2007 after all. 

Promising was an understatement as 1760 was one of the best grand openings I've been to this year. Awesome food. Stiff cocktails. Stellar service. It's a triple threat. 

While Acquerello is very formal, 1760 is its casual sister restaurant serving Nouvelle American cuisine with Japanese, Italian, and Spanish influences.

Everything on the menu is meant to be shared and it's recommend that you order 2-3 plates per a person. Currently, there's only 13 items on the menu and 3 desserts: http://bit.ly/1dXhV2V. Expect to spend about $60 a person (pre-tip) including one cocktail. 

We left full with no room for dessert unlike another recent opening we attended last week (La Urbana) where we had to make a pit stop to McD afterwards because we were still hungry. 

~ * ~F O O D~ * ~ 
*Lobster Ceviche w/ Carmelized Coconut, Pineapple & Coriander ($16) - 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1dXfgq3
I'm usually not a fan of ceviche because I find it too acidic but the use of coconut and pineapple were genius as it added an exotic creaminess and touch of tangy sweetness to the fresh lobster chunks. 

*Sliced Hamachi w/ Pluots, Yuzu Kosho & Puffed Rice ($16) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/1dXfNIt
As a sashimi feen, the buttery cuts of hamachi along with the plum and citrus-chili concoction was a nice twist to a Japanese classic. 

*Uni Bucatini w/ Garlic, Red Pepper & Bread Crumbs ($19) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/17SXFZX
As a huge uni fan, this Japanese-Italian fusion dish was done right; perfectly al-dente pasta gently caressed by a light cream sauce and topped with uni and deliciously crunchy bread crumbs for a texture contrast. 

*Grilled Pork Belly w/ Gigante Bean, Radicchio Slaw & Carrots ($20) - 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/1dXghyb
Like pork butter, the pork belly was nicely crisp on the outside and uber tender on the inside. Loved the radicchio slaw which helped cut through the richness of the pork belly. 

*Hanger Steak w/ Carmelized Onion, Grapes & Arugula ($22) - 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/1dXfjSw
Sous-vide before grilling, the steak was wonderfully tender and flavorful to boot. I only wished there was more of a char to give that smoky nuance.

~ * ~S E R V I C E~ * ~ 
For grand opening day, the staff was very polished, not to mention very knowledgable (about the menu) and attentive. Food service was very timely as well. 

One of the owners came by to thank us for coming which is always a nice touch.

~ * ~A M B I A N C E / D E C O R~ * ~ 
Reminiscent of a typical Mission hot spot, 1760 was very minimalistic with a grey and brown color scheme, a communal table, leather booths, and open kitchen in the back. There's a long, narrow bar partitioned off from the main dining area. Make sure to order one of their stiff cocktails (the Yuzu-Shiso was my fav: http://bit.ly/17mCz7l).

~ * ~P A R K I N G~ * ~
Fairly easy street parking before 6 pm.

When I returned from the restroom, I found Mr. NSS bopping his head from side-to-side. 

Mr. NSS: "This is my jam...yea...this is my jam...they're playing Outkast!"
*Small fist pump*
Me: "Shhhh...we're not in a club."

Mr. NSS: "4.5 STARS."
Me: "Huh?"

Mr. NSS: "Not only are they playing my jam, the food is really good here. Both the steak and pork belly had good depth of flavor."

WTF happened to my food noob bf?
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Having celebrated Jessica H.'s birthday for over a week we needed to find a dinner location worthy of celebrating her Birthday eve, and we did!

This is Aquarello's newest family member and it is on the same fabulous level. Read more here http://www.sfgate.com/restaurants/article/1760-opens-in-San-Francisco-4813196.php.

We started off with a round of cocktails. Jessica had a Strawberry Shrub which she loved and I enjoyed The Mango and Spice Cocktail with fresh Manila Mango, Long Pepper, Cayenne, Lime, and Rum, yum! The cocktails were fresh and flavorful but not too sweet and perfectly balanced.

I am currently in a committed relationship with Ceviche. Tonight ceviche delivered in the form of 1760's Lobster Ceviche with caramelized coconut, pineapple, coriander, and a lime to squeeze on top. It was delish be sure to squeeze the lime before you consume. The citrus really brings out the flavor in the herbs. Mmm... Want more.

The Sautéed peaches with Greek yogurt, mint, almond, and honey were perfect. At first I thought it would be too sweet but it was not and really balanced out the palate.

Hanger steak, caramelized onion, grape and arugula. Oh, those grapes? My goodness those grapes! To start the steak was served a perfect medium rare and the arugula and grape salad was so amazing I could eat it every day of my life.

Before we could even ask for a dessert menu our server Robert, who had been incredibly attentive came over with the menus and informed Jessica H. that her birthday dessert was on the house tonight. Wink. Score. Since dessert is the only reason Jessica agreed to try this place we went with the Angel food cake with strawberry and brown sugar whipped cream.

Oh my god! Yes, the whipped creme was beautifully whipped into shape and tasted like pure brown sugar decadence. The strawberry drizzle had basil seeds that gave it an intense strawberry basil flavor. It paired perfectly with Jessica's Strawberry Squash Cocktail.

Side bar: the communal bar really needs some purse hooks. However it makes for excellent people watching.
author: Caro S.

description: Rare and unusual small plates wonderfully presented   Excellent wine  list with daily specials reasonably priced. Delighted that they poured tastes so you can drink the wine you really like
author: Irwin R.

description:
A total keeper. From the beginning to end. Flawless service, charming staff and great food. Saturday night dining. Make reservation always. Fried duck sandwich with my girl to share as the entree. Highly recommended. Between the steak and the duck, get the duck. Octopus had the same stylish presentation one would only find in Santorini, and it has been 8 months since I was there last and this brought me right back to the Greek isle where the only way to describe food was heavenly. So I'd get that if I were you. The peppers were done just perfect with yuzu and miso dressing with bonito flakes on top. One could not have asked for better presentation.

Shirley temple for the nearly 11 year old tween who is looking more like 16 and is as tall as I. She had two. The bartender served the second one and said, "Double shot vodka with cranberry juice. Did anyone card you? Oh well, here you go." Clearly joking. The girl was confused (thankfully and rightfully so), and the mother was charmed. The drink was delicious and so fanciful. The sweetest wait staff was very nice to the two of us, often came to check on us to make sure water was filled and plates were clean. The bus boy came to take photos for us. So cool that he did that. I was doing my flashcard as I had an exam to prepare and the girl was reading on Kindle in between courses. We discussed her latest fave show which was called the Death Note, apparently popular around tweens and teens and a Japanese detective supernatural series. As we went about our chat while on our date, the waitstaff came over to clean up and set the table for the next course, all seamlessly.  Surprisingly they brought dessert for the birthday girl, complimentary of course. The girl was so happy.

I've always been fond of Polk Street. Have been to Amelia bar, which is right next door many times over. Now there is another great dining locale to choose from.

A perfect place to take your young one to dine. Flawless execution in dinner service. Great ambience. Tasty food. As good as it gets.
author: Victoria E.

description:
I would have given this place 5 stars but I'm not because (1) Our waitress was lowkey rude/sassy and made my friend I feel slightly burdensome to her (2) Lack of vegetarian options

Other than that, both my friend and I loved our dinner here. We ordered the corn cheese ravioli, both the breads, shishito peppers and the roasted potatoes. I would give all the items a 5/5 except for the ravioli, I'd give that a 3/5. It was just way too expensive and not that good. 

I love the decor, it seems like a hip & fancy place, but people were straight up wearing sneakers and flannel so I guess the motto is, you do you. 

One day when I'm making money, I would love to come back here again
author: Megha M.

description: We went there for a breakfast. Mixed fruit salad is delicious. Fresh orange juices recommended. Except their food plates are small potions. If you are the big eaters, it's not going to fill up your tummy.
author: PerK N.

description:
Food: still good. Yum good. Lobster cerviche must get.the duck Burger and spring peas were good also. The ravioli so so. Desserts yum. Milk chocolate ganache and strawberries with a chocolate cake and sweet cream. 

Atmosphere: same same. Noisy, but not more than other spots. Good service as usual. I've been here dressed not my best. Dressed well for work. Casual. Don't matter. They treat you well regardless if you get a bottle of wine or no alcohol at all. If you take time to decide or not. My biggest pet peeve is when you go to a place and get that oh so slight tone of disappointment and condescension for the rest of the meal if you don't feel like drinking that night. Yup. This place knows how to hire their team. They know the value of long term good customer service. So now I come back to eat and drink.
author: P L.

description:
Good food. Poor value. Fun atmosphere.

Went here on a Friday night a while back. Fun buzz to the room and very good service. Young crowd on Polk.

Pleased with the food overall, everything was good, just missing out on being great.

Portion sizes are tiny, and prices are not.

Cocktail - the 1760 was, frankly, one of the worst I've ever had. And it's on the 7x7 Big Drink List. Someone must have had quite a few drinks before trying this one, methinks.

Probably won't be back anytime soon. Maybe if you sit at the bar, order drinks and a few key food items, you'd leave feeling a little better about the experience.

Food: 4
Value: 2
Service: 4
Ambiance: 3.5

Overall: 3.5 (rounded down to 3 for Yelp's purposes)
author: Ethan R.

description:
Mediocre. I had higher expectations but I was definitely disappointed. The lobster ceviche...interesting with the lemon grass and coconut flavors..I liked it but I didn't love it. It was different. Moving on...The crispy octopus....failed. Tastes like burnt dried meat. Flavors were not too bad but texture was terrible...so over cooked that I wouldn't have been able to even tell if that was octopus or not. Also had the infamous fried duck sandwich...well...not much to say here...buns were dry and hard, wouldn't have been able to tell that it was duck if I wasn't informed prior

To top it of...the only cabernet offered by the glass was $17. Really? That's above and beyond.

Nothing special here really. Cool decor and atmosphere tho. Nice place to visit and catch up.
author: .I I.

description: Had a wonderful brunch with my gurls yesterday. I got dropped off by Uber but there were plenty of street parking if you choose to drive in. Great place: spacey, high ceilings, soothing wall coloring, large tables, very clean restroom. Our server was funny too (sorry I'm horrible with names) he had lots of patience while we took a long time to order our five blood marys. We ordered a bunch of plates to share: French Toast, Charcuterie board, Kim Chee fried rice, Pork Belly Porridge and Flatbread. Enough food to get us nice and full. I'm gonna come back to try out dinn menu soon.
author: Vee V.

description:
Terrific brunch service - got there at 11AM on a Saturday morning and the place was empty. By noon, the place was packed. 

Kimchi pork belly rice was perfect portion, flavorful and almost juicy. The egg yolk was runny but thick and golden yellow. Incredible.

Biscuits were fluffy, warm and buttery. Even the fruit plate felt elevated from the average. 

Almost every part of the meal was delicious and unique. I will be back again and again.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Decent.  I ordered the fried duck sandwich with a fried egg.  It was very good, but messy.  I don't how you can serve a dish with paper on the bottom but it has a runny egg.  Relatively small portions...

Service was good but not very attentive.
author: Brian S.

description:
Came here as a walk-in with a party of four and got seated immediately around 945pm on a Saturday night - super accommodating! Sat at the communal table with hooks beneath them to hold our jackets and purses - very convenient. The waiter was super friendly and helpful with recommendations. We all liked the dishes we were served, except the portions were a bit small but we left satisfied and not overly full. 

We started off with beers all around - the white ale and trumer Pilsner were good. The white ale tasted very pretty! And we also tried the red rice ale which was very interesting as well - nothing like we have tried before but a good beer choice as well. We then got a complimentary egg salad on top of a chip for starters before our appetizers and it was delicious but the chip tasted like something we bought from the grocery store. 

-Lobster bisque: we were all a huge fan of this dish! delicious soft lobster bits and the creamy soup wasn't too thick like usual lobster bisques I've had are but he perfect texture - $6 per person and it's fairly small but delicious!
