- Beef tartare: came with nut pieces, Apple pieces and mint leaves. All tasted very delicious together, the top part of the tartare when first served is bit salty so mix it around before diving in; would definitely order again!
- Brussels sprouts: usually a huge fan of Brussels sprouts so I had to order and it didn't let us down. There were full pieces and crispy pieces (my favorite) with a strong sauce on top which was a tad bit overpowering but the texture of the Brussels sprouts were perfect.
- Paccheri: similar to a pasta dish but with octopus pieces. I liked this entree best - rich in tomato flavor and soft pasta pieces; would order again!
- Cavatelli: little shell pieces that were chewy but a bit hard (which I didn't like) but it came with mushroom fennel and was a bit bland next to the Paccheri. Probably won't order again.
- Baby back ribs: came with five pieces which were so soft that they fell off the bone. The but pieces on top was a good texture combination to give it a crunch with the soft ribs. However I'm not a huge fan of bbq items so it was alright to me. It was also a bit spicy.
- Duck Sandwich: not as good as I expected it to be. The duck meat was soft but not rich in flavor at all - almost tasteless. Probably won't order again.
- Macapuno: dessert was delicious! Loved the ube and coconut uber with soft cake under ganache :) would definitely order this again! Very good end to our meal.
- Chai-Horchata: my friend ordered this and the Cognac in the hot drink was so strong in scent and taste that we didn't finish but if you're a fan of cognac, youd probably like it but we weren't a fan.

Overall, would definitely come again if you want to splurge on a good meal! Service was great, along with beers and dishes!
author: Amanda C.

description:
This place blew me away!! New American restaurants in SF never have availability esp if it's last minute. Came here on a Friday night and thankfully, they had space in the communal table. Our waitress was attentive and constantly checked in on us without being overbearing. She let us know that for a party of two, five dishes would be best; I'm glad she said that cause our appetizers were pretty small. On to the food! 

APPETIZERS: 
Beef tartar: amazing! The best beef tartar I've had. The Asian fusion flavors were great combo in this dish. 

Asparagus w quail egg: I felt like they overlooked the asparagus because I like my vegetables with a  crunch but overall, it was good. 

Poppy seed Pecan bread w butter: yum! It seems like Tiniest loaf of bread but the bread was phenomenal. Really moist (even without the butter) and the pecan added the right amount of sweetness. 

MAIN DISH: 
Short rib: OH MAN. This was the best short rib I've ever had in my life. The meat was cooked just right and the flavors...gah party in my mouth 

Duck burger: super juicy and delicious! The patty was THICK and moist. What I loved is that the components of the burger didn't fall apart as I bit into the burger. It was just a perfect amount of ingredients.
author: Samantha S.

description:
The service is is incredible here, its quite difficult to decide if it is even better than the amazing food!  A creative and changing, fresh menu along with creative and well balanced cocktails make this restaurant a triple threat.

While they're not always available, the uni pasta is an absolute must, as is the mushroom tempura and SRF beef tartare!  

My money is on 1760 acquiring their first Michelin star very soon.

Also, they're participating in Dine Out For Life on April 26th!
author: Patrick P.

description:
Acquerello's new, more casual little sibling, 1760 offered up a solid dining although not overall experience.

The menu is a selection of dishes ranging from smaller offerings up top to more hefty ones toward the bottom.  Some like the brussel sprouts, grilled pork ribs and grilled pork belly turned out to be absolutely delicious while others like the kabocha ravioli fell a bit flat.  In one case, the cavatelli actually had to be sent back as one of the components made the dish far too acidic and thus one oddly sour bite after another.  While we appreciated that the staff took the order off of our bill without issue, not so much as an apology was offered...

And on that note, I was very disappointed when I saw that no effort whatsoever was made after mentioning that it was a birthday dinner with my family.  Perhaps our server didn't catch it, but he certainly caught everything else I said and this ultimately made for a lackluster experience, pasta aside.

On the upside, cocktails were particularly well done and very unique.  The garam masala-cardamom was a hit and definitely worth revisiting.

While there's potential here, the first visit could've been a better one.
author: Eric F.

description:
Impeccable service.
Food that is as delicious as it looks (and each dish is beautifully presented).
Excellent ambiance. 

I can't say enough about our recent experience at 1760. Everything was perfect, but what really stood out was the service. I served in restaurants for years, and had my fair share of fine dining experiences, and this staff blew me away. And, all while wearing jeans. I love the relaxed attitude and culture of this restaurant, paired with the top-notch quality of the food and service. Great juxtaposition. 

I'll definitely be back soon.
author: Jay S.

description:
SOOOOO GOOOOOD and one of my new favorite restaurants in SF. 
We came here on a Friday evening and didn't have to wait, thank goooosh. We ordered the scallops/uni/caviar, fried duck sandwich, grilled pork belly and flatbread. Everything was amazing, service was good and the restaurant/ambiance was nice, perfect date spot! The flatbread we had was alright, nothing to rave about but the caviar was the best- all my favourites in one spoon. The grilled pork belly melts in your mouth and the fried duck sandwich. I just can't. I really can't explain, you just have to hit up 1760 and try it yourself. Can't wait to come back :).
author: Valerie L.

description: Awesome foodie spot with a great selection of small plates in a fun upbeat atmosphere. I highly recommend the Hamachi Crudo (it's a little on the spicy side), Bavette Steak (medium rare will melt in your mouth) and the seared scallops are amaze! If you're going veggie, you can't go wrong with the Little Gem Salad. 1760 is also a great place to stop by for a drink at their bar.
author: Derwood A.

description:
This place was perfect. We walked in to eye contact and a welcoming smile from the bartender, and it went uphill from there. The cocktails were perfect - no wonder they won the Negroni award award this year. (Try their Negroni with TCHO cacao-infused Campari!)

We're vegetarian, so ate from the appetizer menu and were extremely happy. Lots of care went into this place - the decor, the recipes, and the exceptional staff.
author: Joy T.

description:
I have to say the food was deliciously flavoured but overly priced.
I ordered scallops , $24 , they brought me 4 pieces about an inch in size,
and barely a bit of cauliflower pure, maybe a couple of tablespoons.
My drink was $14 and it was a bitter, carrot juice lime and rum and it was too small to enjoy the benefits.
I had to go out around the corner to get some chinese takeaway so i could satiate my hunger .
Overall, the plates need to have a little more food.
The dinner plates are like small tapas just be aware of that.  
the appetizers were good and decently sized and larger  than the entries.
author: Danitza A.

description: All dishes were tasty enough, but nothing was memorable to me. I've been here twice, and the second time I didn't even realize I've been already (within the year). I think the problem with this restaurant is not the food, but not having a signature item that makes it easier for people to remember.
author: Betty T.

description:
A solid addition to the grow scene in this area.  Interesting menu, including an excellent octopus entree.  I'll definitely go back when I'm in the area.  

Taking one star off for no decaf coffee.
author: Robert M.

description: I love 1760! The food is always fresh, they have vegetarian options and kick ass drinks and the servers are awesome! This team is always coming up with innovative food ideas and the ambiance of the restaurant is swanky yet comfortable.
author: Kencho G.

description:
When my bf and I heard that Aquerello was opening up a casual little sister restaurant down the block, we knew we had to eat here. Dining at Acquerello for Valentines' Day and our 3-year anniversary, both times were winners, so we were both very eager to try 1760.

Getting reservations was easy when the 1760 first opened, but as time went on, their popularity grew. We tried adjusting our reservation to add more people, which was an impossible task -so we settled on a table for two on a Friday night at 6:15pm. FYI as of last week, they told me they're booked solid for tables 3+ until end of October! O_O But, I just checked on open table and they still have 5pm, 5:30pm reservations open.

The menu is fantastic, described as "contemporary American" but I think it also contains seafood influences. We wanted to get a whole bunch of things since practically everything on the menu seemed to jump out at us!

Food in order from most favorite to decent:
1) Corn Ravioli. Not sure if you have been to Cotogna when they've done a corn triangoli pasta, but we had it once before, and these flavors tasted like almost a replica (in a good way)! The ravioli had a circular shape, filled with sweet corn sauce on the inside - it was melt in your mouth heaven. Think of the juice that's inside a Xiao Long Bao!

2) Uni Bucatini. How wonderful! Uni from Santa Barbara, with pasta, one of the best combinations ever. 1760 definitely executed this dish well. 

3) Pork Belly. We unexpectedly ordered this one at the end since my bf was still hungry. We were blown away by how different the dish was from what we expected it to be. It did not resemble bacon at all, no distinct levels of fat. Instead, it was just a nice slab of fatty meat - yahoo! Definitely surprise of the night.

4) Lobster Ceviche. Fresh lobster, fresh vegetables, sweet taste of everything combined. It was a very simple dish, but showcased how simplicity can also be sublime. It was the freshness of each ingredient that made this dish stand out.

5) Duck sandwich. Although delicious, and very beautifully presented, it was a bit too heavy for my taste. My boyfriend really loved this dish though! 

We also got the Milk Chocolate Ganache for dessert, which was beautiful and delicious too. With ganache the shape of a soft curly candy bar, and marshmallows that were slightly torched, it was delicious. The presentation was similar to what Dominique Crenn would do, aka, "A walk through the forest."

We already made a second reservation for November...can't wait!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Very busy restuarant- no name out front so trust your GPS. Great bar and cocktails. Everyone in our group of 6 had a great cocktail. Really liked the bar, and they had a happy hour between 5:30 and 6:30
author: Vikas A.

description:
1760 has some good food items. However, the owners now add an illegal SF Health tax to the  checks. There is no mention or documentation of this Health Tax prior to the arrival of the check. 

I understand that the owner may not like paying for the health of his employees, but extracting additional money under the guise of a tax is illegal. The employee stated that others restaurants include it in taxes on the check (again illegal). I asked the server to remove the charge. He refused, and said it could not be done. I asked to see the owner, and was told he was not on the premises.

My strong recommendation to the owner is "Pay your Taxes".
author: David F.

description:
Uh huh. Oh yes honey! Due to the fact that the menu spreads just like
pnah! pnah! pnah! pnah! pnah! pnah! p!p!p!nah!
pnah! pnah! pnah! pnah! pnah! pnah! pnahbutta!

1760 said #letmeshowyouhowtoinstigate
Except no it didn't - *I* did:
-----
Just a Note 1/18/2014

For your tip at: 1760

Wow you're million "tips" are annoying! Just eat, write a review and be done with it. There is no need to read your every thought.
-----
#ihearthaters #killthemwithaloha #cheehu #POG

Must be Crispy 'cause Octo don't shake!
Must be Buca 'cause Tini don't shake!
Must be Ducko 'cause Sando don't shake!

[[Crispy Octorok $18]] You had me at avocado. And peanuts. And Octopussy. Even though my faves are still Moonraker and Casino Royale (the canonical one #pretendyouknewabouttheotherone).

[[Bucadibeppounicornfluffyimgonnadietinishakennotstirred $21]] After the 3 or 4 sea urchins, it's just a heap of noods. As far as #nastapasta, I prefer the squid ink(!) s'ghetti at Mifune (review http://www.yelp.com/biz/mifune-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:7D7NLwqMGkyOD3EL9ZOz8Q).

[[Fried Girl From Duckpanema Sandy $16]] Had the knife been a switchblade, this would've auto been the badazzest sando in SF. Also probo the illegalest. #themostbeautifullestthinginthisworld What was with the coley? More like a red-headed stepchild of sauerkraut, coleslaw, and mul kimchi. Where's its long-form birth cert? I prefer Chomp N' Swig's #guiltypleasurestatus sandys.
author: Dan B.

description: While 1760 has all the makings of a decent restaurant, I will never eat here again. I was shocked at their lack of care to food prep when my friend communicated his severe nut allergy to the waiter, and the first dish out had nuts in it without his knowledge. Nut allergies are one of the more severe allergies, and while it did not kill him, it certainly could have. Mistakes happen, I get that, but it was the way the staff at 1760 handled the situation that left me compelled to write this review. Any other restaurant would be bending over backwards to make sure their restaurant goers don't die, are satisfied and leave wanting to come back. 1760's approach was more like, "I'll comp the side salad, and... I mean... There's a Walgreen's a block away so you can go get Benadryl or an Epipen." Seriously? You almost kill my friend, and you're comping the side salad and telling him to take a walk?? Don't eat here. There are a ton of other incredible restaurants in this city.
author: Ashley H.

description:
One of my favorites right now! 

The food is great and the staff is very attentive. 

They suggest sharing the dishes family style. I'm assuming because the every dish is quite rich, but it's a great way to try everything (and no one gets jealous of your dish)!

I daydream about the Uni Bucatini sometimes and the Corn Ravioli is cooked perfectly. I hate overcooked pasta, and the ravioli in this dish is chewy enough that the warm corn soup in the middle bursts in your mouth when you bite into it. Yum. The Duck Sandwich is also good to split into bites. 

They have a tall communal table in the front, next to huge windows facing Polk which is fun to sit at.
author: Monica H.

description:
This is currently my favorite restaurant.  =)

It's unbeatable in terms of unique cocktails.  And in SF, that's saying something.  Garam masala cocktail is great.  So was the sweet pea thing.  They also have very good wine.  But seriously, you should try a weird cocktail.  Live a little.

Also, someone please shake the chef's hand for me -- or maybe kiss her.  or him.  The food is excellent.  EXCELLENT.  So adventurous!  But subtle flavors are still given their due, as well.  It's a fun place to go, if you like tasting lots of things, since most of the food is tapas style.  It's the perfect combo for me: funky delicious drinks, not having to settle on "just one thing" for dinner, and also just such a variety of flavor... I really can't say that enough.  I can't wait for another excuse to go back.
author: Amanda C.

description:
We had a dinner club with our friends here recently and had a greta experience all the way around.  The food was amazing besides our final dish (but we won't let that ruin anything).  We had a lot of food, including the Shishito Peppers, Hamachi Crudo, Lobster Ceviche, Flatbread, Cavatelli and the Fried Duck Sandwich.  It was hard to pick a favorite out of anything of them since they were all so good.  The one disappointment was the Hanger Steak as we asked for it medium but it came out very rare.  We asked for them to cook it more but when they did that it still wasn't cooked the way we wanted it and we lost a lot of flavor.  Dessert made up for that one small mistake though.  Plus the meal wasn't too expensive either.

If you're looking for a special night out, I highly recommend 1760.
author: Blake B.

description:
Good ambiance. A good date spot. Went with a girlfriend and shared 4 dishes. Nothing stood out in particular and I left feeling uninspired. Food isn't bad -- just not amazing to justify the price point. Overhyped in my opinion. 

Started off with their brussels sprouts -- loved the hazelnuts sprinkled throughout. The balsamic sauce was delicious. Then we had the steak tartare, which had chili, fresh basil, mint, and cilantro, and some Japanese seasoning salt. Unusual combo but it was good. Loved the kabocha ravioli in coconut broth and pepitas. This was my favorite dish. I sprinkled a bit of rock salt and it really brought out the flavors. We had the fried duck sandwich, which was really greasy and heavy. It was good, but I didn't get much of the duck flavor because it was overpowered by the sauce and slaw. We finished off the meal with their green tea dessert, which was awesome. It was like a deconstructed white chocolate raspberry almond cake with green tea ice cream. It was light and clean.

Overall, I thought the food was beautiful and well balanced. Nothing really WOWed me except for the prices. Their portions are small. The service was good except at the end, the hostess rushed us out, maybe 10 minutes after we received our bill, saying people need to be seated.. Really? Never had that happen to me at a nice restaurant like this.. 

I'd prefer to spend my money at Frances or Bar Tartine next time. 

Tldr: good but not amazing food, fancy presentation, creative dishes, overpriced... Go if you want to impress your date but be prepared to shell out some serious cash.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Super slow and not at all attentive. Molasses move faster than the service here. But molasses don't have attitude. It's New Year's Eve and it's pretty obvious no one wants to be working here especially the skinny girl w the choker and the doc martens. She just looks irritated with everything, which I get, it's NYE... but totally not professional. When I let her know that I had requested they do something nice for my sister's bday on the reservation and had spoke with the server about it, she had a "so what do you want me to do about it?" attitude. The server was ok, but she was totally lost... forgot the simple drink order. Had to walk up to her and let her know because she was so spacey. When I went up and told her after our appetizer she gave me this look like I had never ordered a drink to begin with. I reminded her that I had wanted a saison and then she remembered and brought out my drink with the second course. 

1760 should seriously close on holidays. It doesn't help their business at all that the patrons have a horrible experience because none of their staff want to be there.
author: Mi K.

description:
I had an amazing meal here last weekend!  The food was excellent, the cocktails were delicious, the service was great, and the ambiance was lovely.

Our group of 4 shared a number of dishes, and enjoyed them all.  We loved the lobster ceviche, lollipop kale (which we got with the guanciale on the side), and brussel sprouts (which we got with the prosciutto on the side).  The beef tartare and cavatelli were also quite good.

I loved my pear-ginger cocktail, as well as my garam masala-cardamom cocktail.  Both were refreshing, delicious, and potent.

The service was also great.  We appreciated the fact that they seated us when only 2 of the 4 in our group had arrived.  The wait staff was also very patient with our indecisive group, and allowed us to enjoy a leisurely dinner that lasted nearly 3 hours.

The ambiance was also lovely and we loved the modern, sleek decor. 

My only complaint is that the space is a bit too loud.

Overall, we have a wonderful meal here!  Thank you, 1760 - we'll be back!
author: Barnali D.

description: Been here twice now (in 4 months) & both times the service, ambiance and food have been outstanding. 4-5 plates share well for a couple. Been all up/down the menu and nothing to avoid here - all delicious!!!
author: Paul L.

description:
Great food and excellent service! 

We came in Wednesday night at 8pm with no reservation and didn't have any trouble getting seated. 

We ordered the crispy octopus (crispy on the outside, tender on the inside), kabocha ravioli (perfectly al dente), duck sandwich (hearty and flavorful - easily the most filling dish of the night), and the roasted chicken (juicy and oh so deliciously seasoned) for the two of us. Every dish was beautifully plated and had wonderful, complex flavors - though it took some time for the plates to start coming out. We also had the milk chocolate ganache for dessert. It arrived nearly immediately, tasted like the ultimate fancy s'more, and looked like modern art (the good kind). 

Adding this one to my list of fave SF restaurants! Not cheap - we averaged about $20/plate - but damn tasty.
author: Natalie M.

description:
I hate to do it but this place deserves a 3 or 3.5 in my opinion due to being way overpriced for the portion size and quality. I still enjoy the scene, but it's just way overpriced for what it is. I was there last week and was probably most shocked by the $9/spoon caviar item in the menu. I love caviar, and it looked like a decent amount when it arrived, but the other fish/flavors on the spoon completely overpowered the caviar so we couldn't taste it at all. I felt like I bought an expensive bite of salty fish....which could be fine...but I paid to taste the caviar. 

I still love the bar, and like the inventive menu quite a bit. It's just not worth the spend at the end of the day (the food that is, the bar is worth it). The place is always packed though (and even the bar seating is reserved) so really no business reason to lower any prices...until everyone figures out what me and a lot of other yelpers have. I'll be back again, but probably not for full meals. Maybe an app and a drink before heading somewhere I feel less "taken" for after paying the bill.
author: Aggie N.

description:
I love the addition of a higher-end restaurant to the neighborhood. I do feel like the prices are a tad on the expensive-for-what-you-get side and that if they're truly meant to be small plates that you order several of, either the portions need to be a little bit bigger or the prices need to be a little bit cheaper.

But as far as the actual food, it was delicious. The cocktails were also good. The service was above average for San Francisco, but they could have refilled my water more frequently.
author: Dani D.

description:
I'm 85% positive that this restaurant does a Google search for "most hipster/esoteric/snobby food", puts said food components on some sort of giant Wheel of Fortune contraption, spins it until 2-3 items are randomly selected, and throws the winners onto the menu under the guise of food artistry. 

I didn't like a thing I ate. And no, I'm not a hick with an uncultured pallet who stabs at things with chopsticks while lamenting a world in which forks aren't ubiquitous. I just don't like foam on my oily brussel sprouts or ganache with hints of ashtray, served to resemble the poop emoji. 

The staff was nice, albeit slow. We finished an appetizer before we ever got our wine, and ultimately felt like everything took forever to arrive. I'm sure part of that is because we didn't enjoy the experience, but it's obvious they aren't a well oiled machine.
author: Christine M.

description:
My friend and I were looking for a place we hadn't been before.  I found "1760" on the net so we tried it last night.  EVERYTHING we ordered was excellent.  I don't think there are any bad choices here.  Looking forward to my next visit to work through the menu. 

Also, the server, Amber, was just great.  The sommelier was very on target with his assistance.  KUDOS to chef and the back of the house.  A real outstanding dining experience in our city filled with many fine restaurants. 

THANKS TO ALL!
author: Kenneth L.

description:
Really underwhelming plates, especially for a group setting. Food is served tapas-style and for a group of 3 it was suggested we order 5 dishes. 

Not only were a few plates of over-verbalized potatoes and asparagus trees served to us slowly one dish at a time, nothing ever quelled our hunger. We got burgers afterwards. 

Cocktails were creative and tasty and the wine selection was decent as well. That earns at least 2 stars
author: Tom S.

description:
The food are very creative and beautiful. However, I will have to rob the bank to go there every time.  I liked the food and service. I just wish there is a little bit more food.... 

Note: No Cola/Dogs allowed!
author: Wen Hsia C.

description:
Place I would've never heard of if not for yelp and it was SF fantastic. 4.5 stars

Food: 4.5, Service: 4, Atmosphere: 4.5 
Cost to worth it rating: 3 (plates $10-$24)
Return worthiness: yes

Highlights:
- Pork ribs: fave dish of the night. Spicy and tangy thick BBQ sauce, lime, and pile of peanuts topped these succulent tender ribs. Makes my top ribs list. 5 stars. 
- Hamachi: with chili slices and yuzu gelee. Legit quality sashimi slices and lovely plating. 5 stars. 
- Coconut curry corn ravioli: Liked the sweet corn and Thai flavors and beautiful presentation. 4.5 stars 
- Mushroom tempura: lightly breaded with foam to play off the airy-ness. 4 stars. 
- Fried duck sandwich: pretty tasty but a bit on the dry side and I liked another dishes better. 3.5 stars
- Sharing: small plates stly 
- Cocktails: interesting concoctions like a coconut pineapple kaffir lime rum one or an indian spiced masala cardamom bourbon
- Atmosphere: speaks San Francisco dining to me. Nice open room with lots of energy, wood bar along the side, friendly waiters who take pride in their food and drink, and comfortable seating with a set of small setups of either booths or tables.

Lowlights: 
- If you're dine commuting into the city it's a 1.5 mile walk from Bart so more of an uber locale 

Loved my spontaneous dinner date here with a friend and would come back with my hub and try some more menu items.
author: Eve K.

description:
What we know about 1760:
1760 was a leap year.
March 20, 1760 - Great Fire of Boston
1760 yards equals 1 mile.
June 10, 1760 - NY passes 1st effective law regulating practice of medicine (all you doctors and pharmacists out there didn't know that did you?)
1760 on a hazardous placard lets you know inside contains a corrosive.
October 25, 1760 George III became King of Great Britain.
1760 was the start of the Road to Revolution where the 13 colonies here in the US severed ties from Great Britain.

Those are old news I suppose so let's add a new one that's quite notable in my opinion.

1760 restaurant established itself on the corner at 1760 Polk Street San Francisco California.

You can rest assure that this menu labeled 1760 has no corrosives involved.  Instead, you can always count on 1760 to use fresh and exotic ingredients to create beautiful contemporary dishes while retaining that feel of good honest food.

I've been here over a handful of times and since then they have changed their menu a couple of times according to the ingredients they can get for the season. 

My very first impression of this place came from that first delicate bite of Lobster Ceviche. I'm guessing it's how Jasmin felt back in 1992 when she catted off with Aladdin... 1760 took me to 'a whole new world' a dazzling place I never knew, and got me lifted like I was on a magic carpet ride... a whole new world indeed.  Lobster so fresh you can still hear Sebastian singing 'Under the Sea'. (Had to throw a couple of those in there for one of my favorite Elite yelpers Ringo M. aka food kid f.A.A.t city... you'll get it if you catch his lyrical reviews on IG ringomak). It was such an over the top preparation with soft bright flavors from coconut milk, fresh avocados, and a squeeze of lime to complement the light crisp crustacean flesh. A very generous portion for the price by the way.

Another dish that always blows me away with such mastery of ingredients is their Hamachi Crudo (hamachi aka yellowtail). It's like sashimi but contemporary style utilizing complementary flavors to create a whole new portrait on your palate.  The ingredients constantly change when it comes to this dish.  I've already had 3 different versions of this dish and they were all to die for.  The hamachi was always highlighted and contrasted delicately with a sweet fruit like melon, citrus lime foam, and/or salted avo puree topped with colorful little petals and flowers. If this dish could speak to us it would probably tell us, 'You can fully enjoy all of me... BUT FIRST LET ME TAKE A SELFIE.'

They have the spoon of caviar, uni (sea urchin that 1760 sometimes pick up from santa barbara or mendocino), and hokkaido scallops which get me every time.  I just can't help it.  That is a deadly combination that no seafood/sushi lover can ever resist.  In my opinion the natural brininess of the caviar and sauce over powers the delicate scallop and the mellow yet sweet uni just a bit.  

The bucatini, a classic dish, easily made exotic with uni.  Although their bucatini (a pasta resembling spaghetti but thicker with a hole running through the center of the entire string) is not made in house, it is still a treat dressed in a fresh creamy sauce made with top quality uni.  Uni lovers go nuts for this.

There are a few other dishes I love but I will let you explore this whole new world yourself.

On another note, the ones I would not care to order again.
The ribs because the hoisin sauce is way too overbearing and salty.  Furthermore, it was rather dry.  I was hoping for it to be tender and falling off the bones and less salty.
The duck sandwich. Not much personality in flavor to such a beautifully prepped sandwich.  I was sad.
Octopus was tough.  A well prepped octopus needs to be tender.

If you don't like something they will gladly take it back for you so that is a plus.

For the most part their service is excellent from the servers to runners to bartender to sommelier to manager AS LONG AS:
You avoid the blondish female server that normally serves at the communal table.  She seems to rush us each time, and was quick to be irritated in her tone and manner whenever we had questions about the menu.  Also don't bother asking her for a taste of a particular wine because her response is always, 'Try this one first and if you want to change it you can order the other one later.' No... I want to taste it first or just grab the sommelier please... they do have a sommelier.  A very knowledgeable one by the way. 

King George III might not be coming back anytime soon but I sure will. The overall experience is well worth the minor kinks here.

4.5 stars for food - only a couple of things are a miss but overall spectacular.
3.5 Service I really want to give them 5 but you are as strong as your weakest link. Sorry we got her 2 times in a row last month and one of the hostesses was fairly rude. 
5 stars for vibe
4 stars overall (looking forward to giving them 5)
author: Colin M.

description:
Yummy! We were a group of 7 so we ordered up! Smaller portions allowed everyone to get a taste of different menu items....everything was so good, not to mention beautifully presented!!! Definitely worth the trip (and price) when in SF! 

Here's what we got:
Avocado Toast
Roasted Chicken 
Duck Burger (a MUST try)
Octopus -(a MUST try)
Brussel Sprouts (a MUST try, even if you dont like Brussel Spouts, you will LOVE these)
Lobster Bisque
Beef Short Rib
Potatoes
author: Cali M.

description:
I was in San Francisco for a get-together with my close friends from college. Having read excellent things about this place, we excitedly booked seating exactly a month in advance (FYI, the restaurant does not accept earlier reservations than that). I'm so glad we were able to secure one as this was by far the best overall meal I had as well as one of the absolute highlights of my entire trip!

There were three of us in the group, and we shared six dishes plus one dessert. They were ALL phenomenal. I loved every single dish, and this rarely happens. We ordered the steak tartare, brussel sprouts, cavatelli, pork ribs, poppy seed bread with lavender honey butter (one of the best bread/bread combos I've had in my entire life), fried duck sandwich (a real standout dish) and honey panna cotta. Not only were all the items delicious and well-balanced, but they were beautiful to behold as well. 

1760 is a great place to go with friends since the food is served family style and is meant to be shared. There really wasn't a single misstep in the evening - I just look forward to visiting again!
author: J K.

description: This place is pretty amazing.  Nice decor and excellent service!  We came early to our dinner reservation and was seated in minutes.  We ordered the crispy octopus, duck sandwich and the hanger steak.  All the dishes was great.  The crispy octopus was fried just right., not the crispy you expect from a fried chicken but a soft crispy.  The duck sandwich was packed full of favor and the hanger steak was cooked to perfection.  Parking can be an issue, but we got lucky after circling around twice.
author: Len L.

description:
Been wanting to go here since it opened. I love Aquerello, so was excited for a more affordable option. Whenever I walk by in the 6-7pm timeframe, it always looks empty. My friend had finished a big work project and wanted to treat for dinner...she had not been here yet and it is in her 'hood, so off we went.  We each ordered an artisanal cocktail, mine was a coconut kumquat, hers a raspberry chocolate. They were both amazing. 

We ordered a few things to share, and our waiter Ian was very accommodating. We had the steak tartar - amazing, might have been the best I have ever had, with a thai flavoring - chili's and some apples and almonds and mint...truly spectacular. Then we had the mushroom tempura, it was lightly fried wild mushrooms with a creamy foamy dipping sauce. Very delicate. The final thing we ordered was the fried duck sandwich, which I had heard great things about - what you need to know about the sandwich is that it is duck confit made into a patty and fried. It is served on a brioche roll with a spicy slaw and a creamy dressing, good, but don't try to eat a whole one, very rich, perfect for splitting.

Loved this place, want to go back for another cocktail and that tartar!

Here is what I would really love, can't you guys just offer the Fois gras pasta from Aquerello? PLEASE?
author: Amy W.

description: k so my cousin is the executive chef, but honestly the food is amazing and the wine selection is super on point. check out the pics! a very relaxed, sexy, beautiful spot with a neighborhood quaint feel. perfect for a nice date. :)
author: Vanessa D.

description:
You know you've hit the jackpot when you find yourself involuntarily smiling between bites of food and barely stopping yourself from licking your plate clean. Really amazing experience from start to finish--all the complex flavors and ingredients you'd expect from a place like SPQR, but without the crazy price tag or overly intricate, half-a-bite-sized servings. Plus NOPA-like ambiance and specialty cocktails without needing reservations a month in advance! 

Our picks for 2 people: 
- Fig-strawberry bourbon cocktail
- Blood orange-rosemary rye cocktail 
- Shishito peppers
- Cavatelli 
- Fried duck sandwich
- Brussels sprouts 

The shishito peppers and brussels sprouts were especially over-the-top flavorful and unique, and in hearty-sized portions as well. I've never had duck before and was a little intimidated, but the fried duck sandwich was perfectly crispy, fatty, and felt like a very delicate, upscale hamburger. If I come back again I'd re-order everything but the cavatelli, but that's only because I saw so many other dishes floating around that I wanted to try! 

Service was perfect -- not too heavy-handed with the recommendations, but made sure to bring out our meal in complementary pieces -- peppers and cavatelli first, then fried duck and brussels sprouts second. The table next to us seemed to be upset over the whole "family style" concept and dishes being brought out at different times, but they were treated with a complimentary dessert and "late" dishes taken off the tab, and I overheard them mention that they felt bad for complaining after being treated so well.
author: Malaika D.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised their brunch selection was as tasty as their dinner menu.  Mind you we went on one of the busiest weekend on Mother's day without any reservation, but the staff was happy to seat us right away and provided us impeccable service throughout.  

Had the honey-thyme toast, spring peas, mushroom tempura, fingerling potatoes, and rock shrimp.  The spring peas were a stand-out w/ perfectly-cooked soft egg, smoked ocean trout & buttermilk-wasabi.  We liked the tiny honey-thyme toast w/ house butter so much we had seconds.  It was worth every calorie and of course, the cocktails were consistent as always.  Love this place, such a neighborhood gem!!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Service : 5 stars for staff that doesn't check on you every 2 seconds but were always there when you need them 

Food: We shared 5 plates between the 2 of us. We are both big eaters so I would probably recommend about 4 dishes for an average appetite. Here's the breakdown:

Hamachi crudo - At first I thought this was averagely good but then I took a second bite with those little yellow flowers and *blam* the dish made sense

Burrata - Beautiful. Tasted like high class pizza. 

Crispy octopus - Great texture and served on a bed of rice with a kick of spice. Delicious!

Fried duck sandwich - I don't like duck but I tried this anyway and I was glad I did. Sooooo delicious!! Especially the slaw that comes with it. 

BBQ pork belly - I kid you not there was a guy sitting on the table next to me that turned around 4 times to look at our plate. He then proceeded to ask the server what it was. This was my favourite dish. The pork belly was not super fatty and melted in my mouth. The peaches complimented the flavours. 

Espresso panna cotta - Genius combination of flavor and texture. We had a small battle between spoons to get the last bit of it. 

PS I asked for a non-alcoholic beverage. They have a house special that is not on the menu. It was cucumber, ginger and seltzer. It was perfect. Not too gingery. 

I will sleep well tonight thanks to 1760.
author: Jacinta H.

description: 1760 - come hungry! Leave starved! What a joke. My gf usually loves these tapas style venues (I see them for what they are: serve less charge more). The avocado toast is something I could make while running out the door in the morning. The pork sisig was so so. The ravioli was great but the quantity couldn't satisfy a gerbil. We got excited when they brought out the fried duck sandwich because it actually looked like a sandwich, but alas it was another textbook example of a chef hoping to push the boundaries of culinary exploration when in reality they just created something that couldn't hold a candle to a plain and simple In-N-Out burger. The only way places like this continue to exist is because the "cosmopolitan" urbanites of San Francisco have their heads pushed so far up their asses that they can't tell the difference between good food and kitty litter.
author: Laef B.

description: I love 1760 and will be back again. There were 4 of us in the group and we had 8 dishes. They were ALL amazing. Beef tartare, kale, uni pasta, crab pasta, fried duck burger (xs), porkbelly (amazingggg ingredients), milk chocolate ganache, etc. I love every dish and this very very rarely happens. I will definitely be back. I recommend going with 4 people just so you can try everything as the portions are small. The drinks were beautiful as I got the ginger and pear drink with vodka and not gin.
author: Lily P.

description:
Date night during the week? Sure, why not?

We were a bit early, so we hung out at the bar and had a beer and wine, respectively. After we were seated, we were pretty much ready to order. And off we went:

+Hamachi crudo with bulgogi vinaigrette, housemade Sriracha, celery, yuzu, and satsuma. A delicious dish that I could've had three more of. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=89P9HA3nxotzMJC59PCdsA#FsaDKAoouDKULAKDkZqYxg)

+Brussels sprouts with crispy onion, crumbled egg yolk, and aromatic herbs. It was a bit bitter in some bites and pure heaven in others. A bit disjointed, but mainly delicious. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=89P9HA3nxotzMJC59PCdsA#upGE_9Ii-yZs2z3dZ9c7LQ)

+Nori-roasted potatoes served with avocado, olive oil and a charred serrano ailoi. Tasty, but needed a bit more seasoning. Thankful for the jar of salt at the table. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=89P9HA3nxotzMJC59PCdsA#pE21T5jebNKB6wLia358rw)

+Maccheroni served with dungeness crab, a green-onion serrano chili pesto and lemon. Holy maccheroni it was lemon-y and very tasty. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=89P9HA3nxotzMJC59PCdsA#2IhVWzzOqUgdiU3UBAwBUw)

+BBQ pork belly with "cole slaw," a purple potato salad, and picked red onions. The "slaw" and 'tater salad weren't my favorite (too briny), but the pork belly was well charred and insanely soft. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=89P9HA3nxotzMJC59PCdsA#qgxnIeRkXlsAyhu9ORXqFA)

+Milk chocolate ganache, served with hickory ice cream, charred marshmallow, and a smear of bourbon caramel. The dish didn't look entirely appetizing (it was the ganache's fault), but that smear of caramel was heaven. I would like an entire tub of that stuff to coat my insides, please and thank you. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=89P9HA3nxotzMJC59PCdsA#_49Q4UMMEUHXQ4tFiWniwQ)

Excellent service and good food. With a glass of wine and a beer or two, all of this came to just over a bill and a quarter. A bit pricey, but it's SF: what do you expect?
author: Adena B.

description: Our new favorite place to eat and drink. Highly professional wait staff and more importantly, innovative and exceptionally delicious food. Must haves are the English peas with smoked albacore and wasabi cream and the pork ribs. I'm not a smoked fish fan, and this dish turned me into a convert. The panna cotta is hands down the best dessert in the City. Had a cocktail - garam masala cardamon bourbon- that is now my favorite. Can't wait to come back with friends to introduce them to this gem. Go now!!
author: Jennifer A.

description: Having brunch with the cousins at this great restaurant.  Executive Chef and Owner Carl Foronda has created the most exciting twist to some of your favorite dishes. Everything was simply melt in your mouth amazing. We will have to come back and try out the dinner menu.
author: Elke V.

description:
This place is really good.  Great service, great drinks, great food, great atmosphere.  

The menu is continually changing, which is good for quality control, but bad if you really want the uni pasta bucatini which is sadly not currently on the menu.

The lobster ceviche is a must.  Don't let the $19 price tag scare you away.  

The duck sandwich is also a must.  Packed with flavor.  Takes a little while to prepare, but definitely delicious.
author: mike j.

description:
YAYYY LOVEEE
This dinner tonight made me come out of my Yelp hibernation.

Cannot wait to be back.

Everything was amazing & high quality!!
author: P D.

description:
*Dear reader, you are forewarned that the below content is going to be a bit wordy and kind of excessive... Sorry in advance*

Hello 1760, you may just be my new best friend....

//& the discovery of 1760//
A month prior, I took a visit to get my steak fix at HOPR on Van Ness and parked right across from 1760. I didn't recall the name of it but recalled it being a black building and was packed so *took note in my mind to research later*.

//& the reservation//
It was my friend's birthday and a few days before, I was stressing over making reservations at a restaurant in the city for a weekend so last minute. Thankfully, I kept on refreshing and refreshing on open table and a 7:30pm conveniently opened up. SCORE! In the little note area, I mentioned that we were coming for a birthday celebration and if it was possible for them to write happy birthday on my friend's dessert if we were to order one so that I could surprise said friend. When I called 2 days before to confirm, they told me they couldn't write messages because it wouldn't go with the dessert but they would accommodate her birthday (so it was nice that they actually read the requests area).

//& the menu//
Everything on the menu is meant to be shared among 2-3 people. Communal-style.
Dish sizes range from smallest at the top to larger portions at the bottom.

//& the food//
*COMPLIMENTARY RYE CHIP WITH YOGURT & JAM (apricot?) - it produced an interesting flavor. The fusion of yogurt and a tart jam added a surprisingly nice touch.
*MACHERRONI - I was devastated that uni bucatini wasn't on the menu but I was so glad I got this instead! The lemon juice infused into the pesto created a lighter pasta that was very refreshing. Bits of mint here and there with the pasta and pine nuts created a hearty meal. They weren't cheap on the shredded dungeness crab either! YUM.
*BBQ PORK BELLY - countless and countless of times, I've been to restaurants that have not cooked pork belly to my liking at all. 1760's was solid. It had a bit of smoked flavor to it, was juicy and succulent, and had a spicy-kick to it after every bite. It sounded a bit odd that the pork belly laid on top of a bed of corn porridge but OMG I think I was in pork belly heaven when I combined the 2 items together. The peach bits were just there (I could do without them in this entree but I didn't dislike them).
*BDAY ICE CREAM, compliments of the chef - remember how I said I made a request on open table and the waitress who answered my call said she couldn't write a message but said she'll try to do what she can to make it acknowledged? Well, she brought over this dessert which was an amazing and refreshing palate cleanser. I'm not sure what kind of ice cream it was but it was light and fluffy and the combo with the raspberry granita underneath it was great! Great way to end the meal.

//& the service//
They were very attentive and nice. Our water bottle was changed constantly and our waters poured. Our dishes and utensils were changed after every dish we ate. I don't find that happening as often at other restaurants!

I had a blast and so did my friend. Impeccable service. Great food. Great location. Great atmosphere. 

Only downside I'd say is that 4% surcharge for the sf healthy workers program that they have all across sf but other than that, 1760, you've secured yourself a place in my heart! I will be back **said in Arnold Schwarzenegger voice**
author: Lisa Z.

description:
I went to 1760 last week for my second time and was disappointed in myself for not remembering what I ordered my previous visit. After the meal, I remembered why I didn't remember. 1760 was a huge letdown and I probably had erased it from my memory a la "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind."

I had forgotten at how small and expensive each dish was. The Shishito peppers & brussels sprouts were nothing to write home about, which actually worked out since I wouldn't even have enough change for a postage stamp after ordering two tiny dishes at $9 each. The coconut ravioli was a bit undercooked and the taste left much to be desired. And lastly, the calmarata pasta had very little octopus actually in it, and when I did manage to find a piece (I felt like Nicholas Cage in National Treasure), it was rubbery and tasteless.

On the bright side, the fried duck sandwich was 1760's only savior. But like a duck, 1760 may seem calm on the surface, but furiously paddling underneath to deliver a positive food experience.
author: Daniel S.

description:
i used to live 50 feet away from this place, when the space was occupied by a shitty diner. tbh, i'm a little bitter that this awesome restaurant (and tons of other great restaurants and bars) opened on this three-block span after i moved. but i digress.

i've eaten at 1760 probably 5-6 times since it opened, and it's been consistently great. the cocktails are phenom (the 1760 is one of my favorites, hold the mezcal, which - fine - kind of makes it a glorified G&T, whatever). the food is also delish! the menu has evolved over time, but i always order whatever version of the octopus is on the menu (they used to make a great octopus dish with a peanut sauce - please bring that back!).

the bill might give you a little sticker shock, but i think the prices are reasonable for the high quality food, drinks and overall experience.
author: Connie S.

description:
Just opened for brunch 1-2 months ago. Delicious. Well executed brunch. The menu has more drinks than food. See photos.

We ordered:

Drink--
Green strawberry Bloody Mary - good without the overpowering tomato flavor 

Food--
Duck sandwich - FAN-FRIGGIN-TASTIC - you must get this dish 
Spring peas - not often that you see a pea entree so we got this; appetizer size; beautiful presentation, see photo
Biscuits - really good citrus marmalade 
I have to note that their homemade pickles are cut exquisitely thin. Very hard to do and shows their attention to detail.

If you're hungry coming here, you probably won't leave full but you will leave happy and impressed.

Worth dropping by before they get mobbed as it's a beautiful place with a good brunch setup.
author: Jacquelyn K.

description:
Our group ordered everything off the menu. The favorites of the night were the  lobster ceviche, the corn ravioli, the pork belly, and the octopus.  I also really loved the Maccheroni and the artichokes. Everything else was great. 

The only things I wouldn't order again are the duck sandwich because it tasted like oversalted confit leg meat (I was expecting duck breast) and the hamachi because it's not as vivid as the other dishes (but not bad).

The cocktail menu looks amazing! Save room for dessert. I only tried the espresso panna cotta, which was phenomenal.

Service was solid. The only thing that could use improvement is the planning of the food. The last dish we received was the maccheroni, which should have been just after the cold dishes and served along with the octopus. The meats should have come at the end.
author: Marina N.

description: Great food!  We had the ribs, fries and duck sandwich.  They all came out piping hot and flavorful.  The summer salad was unremarkable.  Service was slow and inattentive.  That's the reason for the loss of the star.   It also seemed pricey, but if the service had been there, we'd be back soon.
author: Ted M.

description:
Date night again.  This place is definitely a really cute location and has pretty good food and drinks.  

Started off with 5 different dishes: 
Lobster ceviche: beautiful plating and pretty good. I've never really had a lobster ceviche - normally have it with raw fish, but I think the lobster version was delicious. Definitely cooked lobster if anyone's worried. 
English peas: Well I was on a date with an englishman so we definitely got the English peas.  It came with caviar and some shaved radishes. So pretty and delicious. 
Crispy octopus: One of the better octopus dishes I've had before. Nice and crispy, with this delicious carrot puree.  
Duck burger: This is definitely one of the best dishes at the location.  The burger was delicious and is an order.  
Pork belly: Delicious. This was one of my favorite dishes too. The pork belly was nice and tender too.  
Chocolate ganache: Was supposed to taste like smores. It did taste like it, but the smokiness from the ice cream was a bit too much for me.  It was delicious otherwise. Marshmallow dots, graham cracker dust and the the beautiful chocolate ganache decoration.  

Overall, a great location for a date.  

Protip: Duck burger!
author: Nina Y.

description:
Getting in:  Reservations (even during the week) are hard to come by.  Fortunately, there is the big communal table at the front of the restaurant.  Perfect for the pop-in or if you want to eat before 9:00 PM.  Who cares if a stranger is sitting next to you?  They're probably nice so give it a shot.

Getting fed:  The food is terrific!   The 3 of us had the signature lobster ceviche, the hamachi crudo, shisito peppers, nori potatoes, fried duck sandwich (OK, we ate a lot!  Don't judge us!) and 2 desserts.  All excellent.

Getting buzzed:  The food was 4 stars.  The drinks actually push this into 5-star territory.  LOVED the drinks!  Especially the "Dealer's Choice" (my brother had 2!) which lets the bartender go wild.  

If you're a foodie (why else are you on Yelp?) and looking for somewhere new to try (who isn't?), check out 1760.  

Bonus: Easy parking
author: Karen r.

description:
Very impressed with this place. We've been here a couple of times and tried quite a number of items on the menu. Most of the items are executed really well, with unique and unexpected flavor pairings. We love the lobster ceviche, corn ravioli, burrata, BBQ pork belly, crispy octopus, and the strawberry Bavarian for dessert. Other dishes are pretty solid. The only disappointment was the duck sandwich - too much stuff going on and the flavor was too busy to drown the flavor of the duck.

The platings here are whimsical and fun. We like the vibe of the place too. Good music, laid back but intimate setting, friendly service. Many interesting cocktails and a great selection of wine. We are definitely coming back before it becomes impossible to get a reservation here.
author: A. W.

description:
The place was packed on a Tuesday evening and I totally see why. The food here is solid and the restaurant is comfy. The dishes here are meant to be shared. We ordered:
- Lobster ceviche - yum
- Kale salad - yum! a bit salty
- Asparagus ravioli - not bad, but didn't really taste like asparagus and the texture was a bit weird
- Beef tartare - yum
- Octopus - yum
- Crab maccheroni - yum
- Chocolate ganache - yum
- Warm banana bread - yum

Everything was great. However, giving it a 4 because nothing particularly stood out as amazing and most things tasted pretty similar to other restaurants that I've been to.
author: Jeanie F.

description:
After several renditions of different restaurants and cuisines over the years, it was good to see 1760 move into this corner of Polk and Washington and that it has been doing well.  So we decided to go along to an early dinner on Friday.

I think I would go with other Yelpers who rate this place 3.5 stars and here's why.  What made it 4 stars was out server - knowledgeable, attentive and friendly.  What took 1/2 star away was the OK wine selection.  Food wise...it was 3.5 stars.

Like others have said, don't come here hungry otherwise you'll be looking at a hefty bill because the small plates are deceiving.  We had the brussels sprouts, the mushroom tempura and the short ribs taco to begin.  Sprouts were ok, tempura was good and the short ribs were alright.  

Bf went on to have the BBQ ribs which minus the usual BBQ sauce made the meat kinda dry although tender - if you catch the drift.  I had the scallops and they were good.

No dessert but 6 drinks between us, the bill came to shy of $200.  So like I said, not cheap and it was OK food.  If noise level is an issue with you, do come early because they tend to raise the level of music as the evening progresses and given it's full of concrete and hard corners...

Now for the wine, we were not impressed by the flavor profiles of the wines that were featured and their price point.  One thing I noted was that they were serving pretty "young" wines that needed a few more years cellaring (2014 vintage).  I think most restaurants are serving 2012 vintages right now for $16 a glass.  But that's my thing, I'm picky about my wines.

While it was fun and it's in the hood, we're not rushing to come back here any time soon.
author: Favoloso M.

description:
Fantastic experience... until the end.  The drinks and the food were really, really delicious.  We had the brussel sprouts (YUM!), cavatelli, and the duck burger.  

The duck burger was seasoned well, but the meat was kind of weird.  It was not a duck breast, a la a chicken burger.  Instead, it was like some minced up meat that vaguely resembled a hamburger.  The consistency was off-putting.

Our server was very responsive and on top of her game.  We wanted for nothing.  Everything was great until about 2 minutes after I signed the bill.  A man (perhaps the maitre'd?) came over to us and asked us to leave our table because people were (apparently) waiting.  We looked to our left and our right and both tables were open. There were 2 other tables open in the dining room at the time, as well.  When we walked out, there was only one couple waiting for a table. 

So rude. So SF. I really wish that we had a better last memory.
author: Deserae W.

description:
1760 is amazing! I've been here several times - delicious food, a great value for the price. It's our go-to place when we have to show off how delicious SF food can be.

The food works tapas style - so you order a bunch of different plates for the table and share. This means you get to try a variety of delicious foods to learn how consistently yummy everything at 1760 is.

Some of the dishes that are a MUST:

- caviar - caviar has a snooty blegh stereotype that is not at all represented here! Yes it has fish eggs, but it also comes with uni and other delicious flavors that inspire me to order this every time I come to 1760.

- corn ravioli - so sweet, so yum! You see ravioli with your eyes but in your mouth it's a sweet explosion of tastiness.

- burrata - so it's just bread with stuff on top, but the stuff on top makes this amazing! Again, 1760 is great at taking a bunch of flavors, mixing them, and making you wish you could eat at 1760 every night.

- octopus - I was wary of this one, since octopus doesn't always excite me, but I should have trusted 1760's skill, 'cuz this was amazing! It was octopus and paella - the paella was tasty and the octopus was cooked so it wasn't too chewy, and together they were beautiful.

- chocolate dessert - don't remember the name, but the description might say something about s'mores. This is fantastic! Take marshmallows and caramel and graham cracker crumbs and giant tootsie-like twists of chocolate, and eat them all together and it's amazing!

I could probably rave more about other amazing dishes at 1760, since they're all good, but I should also mention that the service is amazing and friendly. We were a complicated bunch, with a nut allergy and a vegan, and they did a great job of making us aware of our options and expanding them by changing the dishes a bit.

Love 1760, can't wait to go back!
author: Emily L.

description:
I was so sure I wrote a review already for 1760 but turns out I had just saved it instead of posting it *Insert rolling eyes emoji*

Must order:
shishito peppers (I order this at all restaurants I go to)
mushroom tempura (wasn't heavy at all, a very light batter)
fingerling potatoes (i always opt out the peanuts though)
cavatelli
rosemary focaccia for all my fellow carb lovers
fried duck sandwich (recommended by few of my very carnivorous friends)
corn coconut ravioli (not sweet at all!)

Next time I'm in the city I will have to try out their brunch.
author: Jenn K.

description:
Loved this place for dinner, and loved this place brunch, and loved this place for not as ridiculously crowded as Nopa (2 places are pretty similar in many ways!).

We got 3 things to share for brunch: mushroom tempura, black eyed jack with quail eggs, and crab roe congee. Also got 2 cocktails, one was with absinthe that's so creamy and nice, the other was the 1760 with mezcal, yum!

The mushroom tempura was fried to perfection, great flavor a and textures with the creamy grits.

The quail toasted was fun and tasty and not too heavy.

The congee had great consistency, creamy and flavorful. Love he poached egg in the middle. Didn't love the flavor a of tomato, doesn't go well with the subtle crab flavor. 

1760 also served some amazing dishes for dinner, the lobster ceviche was to die for, and the ribs were great.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Neighborhood gem! 

Great for after work drinks or date night, but definitely on the pricey side. Menu changes but some highlights from when I visited - include: 

Duck burger - Coleslaw was so good! Portion was surprisingly big
Ceviche - So fresh. Great if you like pina colada flavors
Ribs - SO GOOD
author: Jenny M.

description:
I made reservations on open table and the hostess was great.  She took our coats and also helped out here and there bussing the tables.  I loved the interior - it's sleek and sophisticated and has high ceilings.  All the other wait staff except our waiter were great.  The coat check guy, the sommelier/manager looking guy, and the hostess were very helpful.  There were some beautiful and well-dressed persons dining here.  

I would have given 4 stars but for our waiter.  He was this tall, skinny white guy with shoulder length brown hair.  His hair was not tied and looked scraggly.  He asked after taking our order whether we had any allergies like gluten.  I smirked and said no and he went on to give me a lecture and berate me about how gluten allergies actually do exist in celiac persons and people can choke and die (even though he has never seen this for himself).  He takes himself way too seriously and it almost ruined the atmosphere of the dinner since he was cold, unfriendly and might has well been mute.  Waiting tables at a high end restaurant is not where you choose your podium for promoting celiac disease.  I'm just there to enjoy my food and company and not listen to another person in SF on their soapbox about their cause, in this case, celiac disease.  And if I had a gluten allergy, I would've TOLD YOU.  No need to fish around "just to make sure" any gluten allergies exist.  What an effing weirdo.  Then when our waiter changed to Sarah right before dessert came out, no one told us.  Even casual establishments like BJ's and Palomino's knows to tell the party that their wait staff is changing.  

The uni buccatini was a little dry but tasted good.  I liked the crunch but it needed more moisture since the pasta dried out as we were eating it.  The maccheroni (pretentious spelling but pronounced macaroni) was sour and different.  I probably would not order it again.  The burrata was average. I probably would order something else.  The amuse bouche was a slice of cucumber with red flakes and something else (looked simple and primitive but tasted great!).  The milk chocolate ganache was overpriced for what it was compared to the desserts of Aliment, Seven Hills, Mason Pacific, etc.  It was a curly piece of chocolate with two spoonfuls of cream, some breadcrumbs and caramel.  It looked nice but not worth the money.  I think the waiter just put a damper on the dinner.  The cocktails were ok.

I would probably not come back anytime soon.  It's no wonder the reservations were easy to get here.
author: Chris L.

description:
I really don't like writing reviews less than 4 stars, but I'm doing it here because with a slight adjustment, this could be a 5-star restaurant with its eyes closed.  Keep in mind this review is for brunch only...I have not been for dinner, and I imagine some of the complaints I have are not ones I would have for dinner service.

My wife and I went for brunch, and first things first, most of what we had was EXCELLENT.  I had the 1760 cocktail, which was a perfect 10, and my wife had a Bloody Mary that she declared as one of the best she's ever had (and she is a big Bloody Mary fan).  Two of the three dishes we had were excellent as well.  The buttermilk biscuits with the applebutter were fantastic, and the pork belly/fried rice brunch dish was one of our favorite brunch dishes we've ever had.  We did not like the duck sandwich...at all...but we seem to be clearly in the minority here.  We felt it could have been any meat and there wasn't enough duck flavor there...and we love duck.

OK that said, here is my issue.  The price point!  I could be persuaded to pay high prices for dinners here, but we went on a Saturday around 12:00ish and the restaurant was over half empty.  In this area, even a moderately decent brunch (and most of our brunch was an A+) has waits out the door, and our neighborhood could really use a truly great New American brunch.  We are pretty sure its the price...we paid over $90 for two drinks, two dishes, and the buttermilk biscuit.  That is INSANE.

We just had brunch at Zazie with similar orders (two alcoholic drinks, two mains, and a side) for $65 this weekend, and that is a legendary brunch spot.  The $40-$60 price point (for two with drinks) works in the vast majority of other places in our neighborhood.  $90?  It's just too high.  Especially considering the portions for the pork belly dish were very small.  The duck burger was fairly large, however.

If this place could knock everything down a price point (even for brunch only, like I said I am willing to pay for great dinners), this place would be overflowing for brunch and we'd be back monthly.  But I can't justify paying that much for brunch, when that same $90 could get us an excellent dinner somewhere else in the city.  And we aren't really the thrify kind either...we like to spend money on good food and good wine.
author: James S.

description:
1760, the new offering from the team at Acquerello, knocks the cover off the ball with this new offering in Russian Hill. 

Upon entering, diners will be impressed with the high ceilings and airy design.  Wonderful natural light and soothing colors serve to enhance the dining experience.

The eclectic menu is influenced by Italy (naturally, since the team is from Acquerello), Asia, and Latin America.  The team strives to find the best, natural ingredients and to skillfully treat them to allow the intrinsic quality, flavors, and textures to be expressed.

The shishito peppers ($9), with Castelvetrano olive oil, hazelnuts, and smoked sea salt, are a good way to awaken your taste buds.  With roasted peanuts, avocado, and potatoes, the octopus ($18) is grilled to a crispy goodness.  Celery root, salsa verde, and Meyer lemon complement the fall-off-the-bone tender beef short ribs ($24).  With slaw, pickles, and spicy aioli, the fried duck sandwich ($16) is all that a sandwich should be: crispy, spicy, salty, rich, and a little greasy--yum.

The service was friendly and prompt.  Dishes arrive quickly, but diners do not feel rushed.  There is a good selection of wines and cocktails, and with reasonable selections available by the bottle, 1760 does not forget beer aficionados.

Worth a trip across The City, 1760 is on the verge of becoming a new classic.
author: CJ G.

description:
Ordered up a feast with some friends. Here's what I thought:

YES:
The pear-ginger cocktail: reminded me of tang, of course I'm sure it wasn't. But any cocktail that doesn't taste like alcohol is alright with me. 
the brussels sprouts: tangy, crispy and a different spin on the fall dish
the crab fat congee: rice porridge with an intense orange hue - yummy and rounded flavor
the grilled shishito peppers: just yum. I can't even describe the flavors here but it reminded me of korean banchan - this would've been fine with white rice.


What I could skip:
The hamachi crudo: meh - just a boring dish. It had acidity and sweetness that was a little overwhelming.
The corn-coconut ravioli: Delicious! But if you're limited on space, maybe skip this. I think I like filled ravioli's too much which is why I didn't love it.
author: Sung Ji C.

description:
1. Took us over 15 minutes to get our drinks menu, then another 15 minutes to get our drinks ordered, then another 20 minutes for our drinks to be served. We elected to have dinner at the bar so we could see they were not too busy.
2. Each of our main courses delivered at least 20 minutes apart. I had finished my meal before my partners meal arrived. 
3. I ordered the Pork Sisig which wasn't to my taste - it was too dry and lacking in seasoning. My partner ordered the Duck Sandwich which came with grounded meat and did not taste like duck.
4. Asked for the check twice before receiving it. They had added an extra $82 to the bill by mistake.
author: Vanesa V.

description:
Superb relatively new addition to the Polk Street area.  I understand it was opened by the family which owns Acquerello right around the corner.  The atmosphere is informal but 'cool', but not too cool that I felt foolish bring my 1yr old daughter :-)

The menu is based on small plates to share, and I have visited on two occasions and made my way through winner after winner.  Biggest winner is the duck burger!
I've moved across town, so my visits will be irregular and infrequent, but this is a great spot for drinks and great food, and a great addition to this area of Polk Street! Keep up the great work, 1760!
author: Andy S.

description:
Make sure you make a reservation if you plan on dining here, and that you do not show late for said reservation. My friends and I made reservations for a Friday night at 7:30pm, and we ran half an hour late so they gave away our table. It took at least another 30 minutes to get another table, and the bar area was also packed, so we had to sit on the ledge area by one of the server stands. Although we could still order drinks where we were sitting, it took them a while to check in with us for our drink order and actually bring the drinks that we ordered. When we were finally seated (the booth seats are nice and comfy!), we ordered:

-Complimentary Amuse Bouche (Compressed Pink Lady Apple w/Hibiscus, Meyer Lemon, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=ClqwDJf0ICOvfY5vtl43Ow#ClqwDJf0ICOvfY5vtl43Ow): Not amazing, but it was a good palate cleanser to kick off the meal.
-Shishito Peppers (Castelvetrano Olive, Hazelnut, Smoked Sea Salt, $9, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=ClqwDJf0ICOvfY5vtl43Ow#6PKShrg7gq6t2AR7Kmiirw): I loved the sear they got on the actual shishito peppers, but didn't think the hazelnut worked with this dish. I would've preferred the peppers on their own, and am not sure I would order this again with the hazelnuts.
-Burrata (Grilled Bread, Garbanzo Beans, Asian Pear, Walnuts, $14, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=ClqwDJf0ICOvfY5vtl43Ow#9R5F8FUVr8He6RTzDZBfvQ): Good, but not amazing. I liked the grilled bread a lot, but wish there was more burrata. The Asian pear taste also overpowered the others, and I wouldn't order this dish again.
-Bucatini (Uni, Garlic, Red Pepper, Bread Crumb, $21, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=ClqwDJf0ICOvfY5vtl43Ow#IBUhfwobGWTh2LCPz9tsIg): Yum, this is a must order! I loved the creaminess of the bucatini contrasted with the crunchiness of the bread crumb topping.
-Crispy Octopus (Roasted Peanuts. Avocado, Potatoes, $18, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=ClqwDJf0ICOvfY5vtl43Ow#j0yu0PRMXCMaaJ1VVM8d4A): I loved the crispiness of the octopus, but didn't think all the components worked that well together. I'm not sure if I would get this dish again.
-Beef Short Rib (Spring Onion, Peas, Peppercress, $26, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=ClqwDJf0ICOvfY5vtl43Ow#hNC1svolpZ-r0f4jPsyZCg): Yum, another must order dish! The beef short rib was cooked perfectly and super tender, and this dish overall was really flavorful. 

I thought the service was a little on the slow side here, and wish they sped things up a little here (it would also help turn over the tables a bit faster). Overall, some of the dishes were a bit uneven, but there was enough delicious food that I would come back to give other items a try. Parking in this area is really tough, especially during a weekend night.
author: Amy D.

description: Decided to try this place after a friend had a great experience. I was very pleased with the menu, food, wine and service. Our waiter was very honest and offered great recommendations. Overall a great experience and I will definitely be back.
author: Kerstin A.

description:
I'll let everyone else write their 4 and 5 star reviews - and I will simultaneously admit my review is based solely on one glass of wine, perceived cocktails, one dish, and one sad amuse bouche.

We wandered in here as we were waiting for the French place next door to open. We being my husband, his brother, and myself.

We looked at the menu, which seemed as interesting as the space was beautiful. We were informed by the very kind bartenders (as we sat at the bar, deciding whether we should decide to eat here instead) that the restau was only 2 months old. Perhaps it's come a long way since we were there in November. I very much hope so.

My glass of wine was delicious, so no fault there. The cocktails, similarly, looked divine.

We were brought an 'amuse bouche' that was basically just a slice of pear with some dollop of sauce on it.  It was not at all 'amusing.'

Having  tried beef tartar all over the US, France, and Czech Republic, this was decidedly THE worst I've ever had in my life.

Not only was the meat fatty and extremely chewy, there was nothing pleasant about it's flavor profile - read - no real flavor at all.  While the greens were nice and tart, this did not make up for the main portion of this dish being nothing short of gross.  Based on that, we decided it would be better to dine elsewhere. 

Good luck, 1760... though judging by your 4-star rating, you don't need it.
author: Valerie J.

description:
09.29.13

I took my boyfriend here for his 30th birthday dinner.  Even booking in advance for a Sunday evening, a table for two was only available at 5:00 or 9:00 PM.  So...we took the early bird special and started dinner when it was still light out.

Perhaps it's to keep the restaurant from being completely packed (which I don't understand).  Perhaps it's to allow walk-ins to get seated without reservations.  But through the duration of the dinner, I felt myself feeling cheated out of a normal dinner time - let's say, 6:30 or 7:00?  But I digress.

Onto the food.  The amuse bouche was a compressed watermelon with new olive oil and slivers of mozzarella.  The mixture of salty and sweet was a great balance, so it was a fantastic start to the meal.

The beer list looked exotic - and we both got to ordering.  Me, the amber; him, the french red.  We both enjoyed the adult beverages thoroughly.

I'll preface the rest by saying that I may be sensitive to sodium, but every dish tasted too salty to me.  Brussels sprouts: too salty.  Crispy octopus: too dry and salty.  Duck egg and salmon: my favorite, and definitely recommend.  The duck egg was fried to perfection, and the runny yolk on the salmon was a good pairing.  The bucatini: too salty, but the texture was good.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1760-san-francisco?select=3GgH01gOWK_ehp5dMzcP3A#3GgH01gOWK_ehp5dMzcP3A

It was a fine experience overall, but I'm not running back anytime soon.

Total damage: $100
author: Jenny L.

description:
Great new trendy/modern bistro done by the same folks as Acquerello!  My boyfriend and I walked in on a Saturday night around 7pm with no reservations and found a couple seats at their communal table which is first come-first serve!  Lucky us!  The modern, chic decor, high ceilings, and slightly loud (but not too loud) noise level definitely creates a trendy, but casual ambience.  The service was altogether very warm and attentive; the food and cocktails were all very tasty and presented well.   

Stuff we ordered:

  Cocktails
    1) The Yuzu-Shiso ($12): yuzu marmalade, ooba shiso leaf, prosecco, gin
          - 4 stars: tart and delicious!       
    2) The Pear-Ginger ($11): pear juice, ginger, verdicchio, Campari ice cube, gin
          - 4.5 stars: very 'gingery' which I liked and the Campari ice cube gives it great flavor as it melts 

  Dinner
    1) Dungeness Crab ($15): 'siracha', celery, yuzu, apple
          - 3.5 stars: although it was good, it wasn't my favorite
    2) Seared Tuna Sashimi ($16): green onion chimichurri, sunchoke, radish
          - 4 stars
    3) SRF Beef Tartare ($16): marcona almond, herbs, chile 
          - 5 stars: the almond paste paired so well with the beef - heaven
    4) Fried Duck Sandwich ($15): slaw, pickles, spicy aioli
          - 5 stars: brioche bun, pickles, and duck - the complete package 

  Dessert (yes we ordered two)
    1) Angel Food Cake ($8): strawberry, maple whipped cream
          - 4.5 stars: extremely moist and the maple whipped cream was divine
    2) Milk Chocolate Ganache ($9): hickory ice cream, bourbon caramel, marshmallow
          - 5 stars: a must-order; I practically licked the plate
 

I am so excited to go back to 1760 asap, and I can already tell it is going to be a hit because reservations are already tough (I think it has been open only about a month).

Try it out soon because pretty soon you are going to have to book a table weeks in advance!
author: Juliana K.

description:
Came here for dinner with a party of five on a Thursday evening. It's a very cool, trendy, tapas-style place. I really enjoyed the atmosphere. Our waitress was also very pleasant and service was good. They had a variety of specialty cocktails on the drink menu along with wines. I went with a glass of wine while some others in my group tried the more diverse cocktails. Everyone seemed to enjoy them. 

As for the food, I honestly wasn't a huge fan, mainly because the tapas are very small and the prices are high. I understand that things are more expensive in San Francisco than in my neck of the woods on the east coast, but the prices just seemed way too high for the amount of food you actually got. Every dish was presented beautifully though. You could tell they pay attention to detail when plating the food. We ordered about 9 plates for our group, and literally we only got one, or maybe two bites from each plate, which was kind of disappointing. I'm not a huge fan of mixing that many things in one meal either. The only dish that stood out as awesome to me was the ravioli. I would have liked to just have a plate of that myself. Oh, and also the banana bread desert was pretty fabulous, but again, I wish I got more than one bite of it. 

Overall, a cool spot if you're into the tapas style of dining .Great atmosphere, but the food/price ratio missed the mark for me.
author: Maryclaire H.

description: Came here for brunch with girlfriends and it was quite delicious! The chicken and waffle croquettes were the most memorable, followed by the crab fat congee. Wait staff was friendly. Would love to come back for dinner some time!
author: Jen K.
