description:
I did the math. Between Jamie W. and me, we tried 35% of the menu. I'm depressed. I felt like Chris Christie at an IHOP. But that's what they told us to do - order 2-3 dishes per person, so that comes to six out of just 17 offerings on the compact but wholly enticing menu. How could it not be enticing since it's the same team behind Acquerello, one of our favorite fine dining establishments in the city (my review: http://bit.ly/16vSWPC)? But the vibe this time is urban casual from the Nopa/Bar Agricole oeuvre of SF dining. Whereas Acquerello is hidden away on Sacramento between Polk and Van Ness, 1760 is front and center on the busy corner of Polk and Washington where hipster looky-loos couldn't help but gawk through the windows on their way to their regular watering holes (photo: http://bit.ly/1eT6fgy).

Executive Chef Adam Tortosa may have come up with only 17 dishes (photo: http://bit.ly/18lhSFP), but judging from the six we had, he's nailed them. We were told that each dish was sharable and that the menu is intentionally ordered from lightest (Sliced Hamaichi) to richest (Fried Duck Sandwich). Tough choices so we needed libations to help us make up our minds. I ordered the $10 Peach Buck, a smooth-sweet mix of peach, Angostura bitters, star anise, nutmeg and bourbon (photo: http://bit.ly/17C0cJi). It made for a puckery-good refresher that complemented the amuse bouche, a couple of cubes of watermelon pressed with smoked paprika and wine (photo: http://bit.ly/15w8BON). They popped so easily into our mouths that our response was slightly delayed on the smokiness of the paprika.

At this point, Jamie decided to get his own Peach Buck, and we indulged on our first plate, the $15 Dungeness Crab which was artfully placed in a crescent shape in a bowl of cold watermelon gazpacho that had a bit of a kick. The sea grass made a lovely textural contrast laid on top of the crab like wild sagebrush on the plain (photo: http://bit.ly/17BZFa6). The next dish was making its debut that evening, the $8 Brussels Sprouts grilled and sprinkled with particles of egg yolk and mint (photo: http://bit.ly/1aD6zgK). It was just the right note before the heartier dishes to come. The third dish was likely our favorite of the evening, the $18 Corn Ravioli, a half-dozen pillows of joy filled with corn and baked potato and sprinkled with bits of potato chips and chive (photo: http://bit.ly/1945PxM). Apparently it's the menu favorite, and we were told to pop them in our mouths whole to get the full burst of flavor. They were downright amazing...sweet, savory, juicy and gone in a flash.

I ordered a second drink, the $11 Garam Masala-Cardamom, an exotic treat with a garam masala spice blend, thyme, orange oil, toasted cardamom and bourbon (photo: http://bit.ly/18li7AY). Ed was feeling no pain. The main events came next. First came the $19 Grilled Pork Belly, four good-size slices grilled and placed atop a fresh radicchio slaw and topped with sliced baby carrots (photo: http://bit.ly/18lh43K). While I prefer pork belly braised because it ends up more moist that way, the grilling still worked, and my perpetual pork belly craving was satisfied. Finally came the $22 Hanger Steak, the most expensive dish on the menu offering eight slices of steak smoked and cooked to medium rare and accompanied by a mix of arugula, grape halves and caramelized onions (photo: http://bit.ly/14YA8VC). Tender and good though I have to admit this was the least creative dish of the quintet served.

Dinner was stellar, and clearly sampling one of the three desserts was inevitable. The choice was almost made for us since we were told they were not serving the Peach Panzarella that evening. In its place was a Peanut Butter and Jelly Panna Cotta which didn't get Jamie's motor running. We decided to try the $9 Milk Chocolate Ganache, which resembled a Michael Mina creation with a Playdoh-like log of ganache festooned with droplets of browned marshmallow, canelas of hickory ice cream (a smoked vanilla flavor), granulated milk chocolate and a bourbon caramel sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/167rumY). It made me dream of putting my mouth into the spigot from which the magical ganache came. By meal's end, we did feel like we ate 35% of the menu and in record time since we took the earliest reservation available (5PM). We weren't necessarily looking for an early bird special, although the service was extremely attentive at that juncture, a big plus.

FOOD - 5 stars...superb small plates with very few errors in execution
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...grab a table in the middle row to avoid the elbow wars that may occur at the banquette...love that the dining room is separated from the bar by a divider
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...very attentive and friendly with the daughter of one of the Acquerello co-owners serving us
TOTAL - 5 stars...35% of the menu and worth every bite...an excellent addition to the local dining scene
author: Ed U.

description:
This place is a solid 4.5 STARS.
Food was awesome, great expansive space. Although I was not a fan of their spazzy music choices (going from jazz to hip-hop to classical every few minutes).
Everything was delicious, and I wanted more....
Their grilled octopus was tender, flavorful with just the lightly charred outside to give it that crispy texture, they were best grilled octopus I've had in SF! 
Kale salad was delicious with just the right amount of tanginess...I just wish they gave us more :-( Shishito peppers and uni bucatini were both excellent. They gave us a generous portion of uni...it tasted slightly like a decadent and high-end version of mac-n-cheese. 
I was not impressed by their desserts, however...it was pretty good but not that memorable.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
SIMPLY THE BEST! We had dinner and drinks here twice and can't wait to try the brunch menu.

Awesome food (too much to mention, but the duck burger is on point) and the drink menu is intriquett and tasty. All this while listening to NWA, Tribe, Hiero etc... 

Like I stated at the beginning, simply the best.
author: SF B.

description:
It probably wasn't the best idea to visit 1760 with a few starving bodybuilding guys but I feel like I still expected a better quality and consistency for the price and portions. Every other dish was either very good or rather mediocre.

We came on a Friday night and ordered Fried Duck Sandwich, Hangar Steak, Shishito Peppers, Crispy Octopus, Grilled Pork Ribs, and Haricots Verts.

Good: My favorite was the French green beans (Haricots Verts) because they were so juicy, tender and had a great crunch to it. My inner vegetarian could probably eat that all day.

The not-so-good: Hangar Steak was overcooked. We asked for medium-rare and it was more like medium-well to well. It was kinda tough to eat certain parts of it. The mushrooms on the side were good though. Crispy Octopus wasn't that crispy. The inside was a bit too soft for my liking, but that might just be a personal preference.

No comment: People seem to love the Duck Sandwich. I didn't necessarily love it but I didn't hate it. I just felt kinda meh about the sandwich overall. The slaw that came with the sandwich was excellent though. Good flavor and kick to it.

I didn't try any cocktails but my friends did. It seemed like they enjoyed it.

Service is good, the waiters kept refilling our water.
author: Vinky I.

description:
Came back for a second time and had a much better experience now that I know what to order.

Dungeness Crab: 4.5 stars. delicious, light, and lots of crab. 

Hamachi Crudo: got this last time, was a 3.5 star. Did not get this again. 

Shishito Peppers: 5 stars. I don't like vegetables. But these peppers dosed with seasalt and hazelnuts was a total win.  Huge portion too. We only finished 2/3 of it despite this being our very first dish. 

Lobster Ceviche: got this last time. 3 stars. too sweet. did not repeat.

SRF Beef Tartare: Got this last time. 2.5 stars. thought the beef was a bit too chewy. definitely no repeat.

Pan-Seared Scallops: 3.5 stars. The black rice was actually the best part of this dish.  The scallops were ok. 

Burrata: 5 stars. This was phenomenal.  Better than your average burrata dish. definitely surpassed my expectations. 

Crispy Octopus: 4.5 stars. We got this again since it was my favorite the first time around. 

Uni Bucatini:  2 stars. This was a huge disappointment.  They ran out last time and I was super excited to see it back on the menu.  But the bucatini didn't gel right with the Uni.  Maybe my bucatini was too al dente but felt the uni would go better with a softer, thinner pasta (bucatini is a tubular pasta. stiffer in bite. and relatively thick too). 

Fried Duck Sandwich: got this last time. delicious but impossible to share without making a small mess. did not repeat.
author: Alice Z.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city at this point without having to fuss over reservations.  Inventive cocktail drinks and the food is delicious without trying too hard.

The space has a bit of industrial feel with high ceiling, wall to wall window, with clean edges throughout.

One of my favorite things is to sit at the bar and catch up with an old friend. Somehow,  the conversation just flows naturally without too much shouting, but with enough noise so you could be in a bubble of your own.

Onto the food. Sister restaurant of aquarello.  I haven't had anything that disappointed me yet.

Highly Recommended:
Shishito Peppers. castelvetrano olive. hazelnut. smoked sea salt -- beautifully put together, solid starter, as good as in some of the japanese restaurants with a bit of twist.

Burrata. grilled bread. garbanzo beans. asian pear. walnuts -- the best restaurants always nail the burrata dish and this one is of no exception. soft burrata, the bread is not too hard, everything is perfectly balanced on this one

Crispy Octopus. roasted peanuts. avocado. potatoes - delicious and beautifully presented. I am on an octopus streak and this one is on par with SPQR & Coqueta even though the delivery is quite different.

Good:
Brussels Sprouts. crispy onion. aromatic herbs - I liked this dish but you probably have had similar things before.

The wine list by the glass is not large but every one of them is hand-picked and goes really well with the food. I don't quite remember what I selected but remembered loving my wine.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I have a feeling Nopa decided to get a little sauced up, wandered over to north beach, got a little frisky and dropped the aftermath off on Polk Street.  1760 is everything that I LOVE about Nopa but with a but more of an italian/eclectic menu and a bit smaller (but isn't everything that way recently..).    I made a reservation for 7:45 on a Thursday, and showed up a little early with the expectation that the table wouldn't be ready and we could grab a drink but we were seated immediately, which was awesome :)  Not so awesome was that we were seated smack in the center of the restaurant facing out towards the street, and my ADD was RAGING the whole time (busses, crack heads, great shoes, etc.).  So my advice: ask for a seat in a booth or towards the side unless you have the ability to focus on one thing-I do not. 

WINE: good sized list with something for everyone, we went with a Zin (the BFs obsessed, I like, easy enough). 

FOOD: Amuse bouche of pressed apples with basil and garlic which was surprisingly delicious and very inventive.  We ordered from top to bottom on the meny and went with the Lobster Ceviche (my favorite dish of the night! Fresh with the perfect amount of creaminess from the coconut and citrus from the lime), the Brussel Sprouts (fried, duh), the Beef Tartare (very different than any interpretation I've had before, came with a mint leaf salad and marcona almond puree, really good), and the Uni Bucatini (the only thing I didn't love, the pasta was al dente and very warm when it came out but the Uni was cold-not sure if that was on purpose, but the stark contrast was just weird and unpleasant-flavor was great but couldnt get over it sadly). 

I live so close that this will definitely be a return spot :) cant wait to try the cocktails because they looked amazeee!
author: Raina D.

description: Came with friends for brunch and got the Avocado Toast and Hamachi Crudo.  Totally amazing.  The decor was modern minimalist with a touch of rustic.  Will be back again.
author: Erika L.

description:
We discovered 1760 by way of GiltSF.  They offered a brunch and bubbly special that appealed to us.  SO glad we did.  They had a special menu for this brunch and each item looked equally delicious.  We shared the beignets - yummy.  My husband had the french toast and proclaimed it the best he has ever had and I had the rock shrimp with polenta, oh my.  We shared the house made sausages and a very nice bottle of champagne.  We'll definitely be going back to try dinner!

The atmosphere is lovely and the wait staff just the right level of attentive.
author: Cathy C.

description:
Really expensive for what it is. We were told to order at least 3 dishes per person. We ended up ordering 8 (including dessert). We also had one cocktail each (two total). The bill came out to $150 before tip. 

I don't mind dropping almost $200 on dinner but the food and experience has to match the price. For just a little more we could have went to their other restaurant, Acquerello, where food and service is way better. And even though it would cost slightly more, we wouldn't feel like we over paid.

Our server was fine but she totally dropped the ball in terms of checking in on us. We saw her at the window people watching more than she was working.

Food was good but nothing was great. The cavatelli ($17) was the worst dish of the night. The crab dish ($15) was the best. The bucatini with uni ($19) was a close second best.

For dessert we had the peanut butter panna cotta ($8) sounds better than it tasted. Milk chocolate ganache ($9) basically was a deconstructed smore. It was good but not great.

The strawberry shrub ($12) cocktail was awesome but it's not enough to off set the other issues.

Like I said earlier, I would rather visit Acquerello next time.
author: Andy W.

description:
We shared a number of dishes. The highlights were the himachi crudo, lolipop kale, brussels sprouts, burrata, short ribs, and the cavatelli. Food was fantastic and comes out pretty quickly due to the tapas style. 

The atmosphere is very trendy...don't love the interior but it is definitely a good spot for a special occasion.
author: Derek S.

description: I would not recommend. The service was slow, they forgot several of our orders (we were a party of 6), and the overall experience was poor. The food is good but not amazing, the portion sizes are very small for the price, and the ambiance leaves a lot to be desired. I could barely hear my fellow table mates due to noise and loud dance-style music playing, and realized I had to shout to have a conversation. Few vegetarian options as well. I think the worst part is that we each paid over 40$ for a meal, and returned home hungry where we had to cook a second dinner.
author: Victoria T.

description:
My girlfriend and I thought we would try 1760 for the first time last Friday Oct. 30th. The interior was modern and classy. The staff were friendly, attentive and very professional. 

The menu is, "Family Style" (Order to share). We ordered the Shishito Peppers, Corn Ravioli, Bread, Hanger Steak and 6 cocktails. The food and cocktails were excellent. However, the food was served in small portions.

The reason I gave only 4 stars was because I felt that for the cost Vs. the amount of food was not a very good value. We walked away starving and that was after a $150.00 bill. We ended up walking over to the House of Prime Rib for more food and drinks. (I know what you might be thinking, were they chubby girls with big appetites? No! We are both 5'9" at 145LBS. We both workout and are thin). The bottom line is, if you are a heavy eater, then this place might not be for you. Would I go back? Yes, if someone else is paying.  The food was very good.
author: Kathy J.

description:
1760 is my favorite restaurant in all of San Francisco, and by far my favorite cocktail bar. I've been to Acquerello's hipper little sister probably 10 times since it opened in 2013. The drinks are herbaceous, expertly mixed and truly creative. The small-plated food is delightful, and while some dishes stay on the menu a long time, their preparation varies dramatically. One month crispy octopus will be paired with roasted peanuts, avocado and little potatoes, the next a jambalaya-like chorizo dressing.

Dishes are listed from lightest to heaviest, starting with the crudos and ceviches, which are expertly seasoned, effervescent little bites. Then come dishes like lollipop kale with guanciale and my favorite, the steak tartare spiked with Thai seasonings and Marcona almond puree. Rich plates such as uni bucatini slicked with breadcrumbs and hoisin glazed ribs round out the menu. A clear crowd favorite is the enormous fried duck sandwich - half of this could be my entire dinner.

The sweets are impressive but a little too contrived for me. They'll do like a basil sponge cake with strawberry mousse plated like a Lilliputian garden, or an impressively contorted log of chocolate ganache adorned with marshmallow droplets to evoke fancy s'mores. They always seem more like a display of technical skill than dessert, but it's a small quibble. In a town with so many forgettable New American sharing menus, 1760's taste memories keep me coming back.
author: Cecilia L.

description:
Three dishes you definitely MUST MUST try: corn ravioli, bbq pork belly, and the burrata. These three are incredible. The intermezzo dessert (balsamic peach salad with yogurt ice cream) was also perfection.

Also good but nothing hugely special: roast chicken and dungeness crab.

Skippable: Duck sandwich. (I'm a huge fan of duck, but this was just too rich.)

The service was spot on. Our water glasses were always full, clean plates promptly replaced dirty ones, and the staff was friendly and helpful. If all of their dishes tasted as good as those first three, this place would undoubtedly deserve five stars. 

Great spot for sharing and tasting with friends!
author: Megan B.

description: Love the food. Unique and delicious. Tempura mushrooms and the ravioli was our favorite. Drinks are amazing too!  We shared 4 different drinks over a couple hours and liked each one. They are small, but strong.  Service was outstanding!!  Atmosphere was pleasant and relaxing.  All around great!
author: A K.

description:
Good food, nice service and stylish decor, perfect place for a date!

We ordered: 
- Brussel spouts: nicely roasted with crispy shallots and egg yolk crumbles
- Lobster ceviche: delicate chunks of lobster with a caramelized coconut sauce, delicious!
- Caviar: nice bite of the ocean
- Beef short rib: meat was perfectly cooked and paired well with the onion sauce and tangy greens, a little on the small side, but tasty! 
- Cavatelli: heartiest of all the dishes we tried, was good but not great, wish the lamb was cut in bigger pieces instead of little cubes, the pasta and sauce were good
- Fried duck sandwich: hubby's favorite dish of the evening! We expected it to be a fried duck breast but instead its a patty, similar consistency to a crab cake, which went perfectly with the slaw and aioli, definitely worth a try if you don't mind getting a little dirty!

Staff was attentive and friendly. They also had some fun old jams playing including 2 Pac  :), definetely worth a return visit!
author: Naomi A.

description:
Accommodating for vegetarians. Kabocha Ravioli is my favorite. The Cavatelli is solid as well. 

The honey thyme pain de mie is a must and you have to get the the milk chocolate granache for dessert. 

Ambiance and service is consistently great.
author: Cassie B.

description: Best happy hour! The wine is delish! And the Service is perfect - we sat at the bar. BUT the fries and Brussels sprouts are so OVERLY salty AND OVERLY seasoned that it ruins your palate.
author: Clovo S.

description:
Our culinary advendture brought us to this gem neighborhood restaurant on Polk.  This Acquerello's sister restaurant has a hip vibe with a modern twist in their cooking technique.  Although parking was challenging even for a Tuesday night, we found a public parking lot  2 blocks away.  The cocktail was very good and so was the food.  Everything was well prepared and tasty.  We especially loved the lobster ceviche. And my husband loved the pork belly dish that he ordered. The Grill octopus was very tender and delicous as well.  I will try the uni pasta the next time as the gentleman next to us looked like he really really enjoyed it, so much that I almost order it but was too full.  For sure I want to eat it the next time.
Overall it was a wonderful experience and we will be back to try the rest of the food on the menu.
author: Toni L.

description:
Ribs were spicy good, finger licking. 
Beef tartare has great flavors and great textures. Spicy and just melty meat. 
Potatoes were warm and soft. Not much variety in texture. 

Great service.
author: Vicki T.

description:
I saw on Yelp that 1760 was the sister restaurant of Acquerello and that was what got me interested in this place.  Right on Polk St. and Washington St it is very easy to get to.  Very nice decor and a full bar.  The flavors of the small plate dining was out of this world.  Each dish was spot on and we were really impressed with the wine selection also.
I highly recommend the Scallops, Raviolli and the Har Gow Cavatelli. Don't forget to order the Rosemary Focaccia bread also.  Our server Ryan was very knowledgeable on our food questions and had a great personality.
author: GREG C.

description:
The cocktails here are out of this world, and our bartender was awesome. 

But oh my god. The portions here are fit for a bird. We, a party of two, ordered 7 dishes (yes, 7) and left unsatisfied. 

Skip the flatbread (really small and not tasty), the little gem lettuces, the lobster ceviche, and the milk chocolate ganache dessert. They are all so teeny tiny. 

The shishito peppers, the beef tartare, and the pain de mie are okay. 

Flavors are great, but nothing makes me more annoyed than leaving hungry from a stingy restaurant. 

Oh and my friend had his backpack stolen here a year ago from the storage area, so don't leave anything unattended.
author: Min L.

description: Came here when my cousins took me here for dinner. It was pouring outside when we came. When we entered the restaurant, I noticed it had a really trendy feel to it. All the dishes were very prettily crafted. We ordered the lobster ceviche, which was delicious. The beef short rib was pretty good as well. The meat of it was good, however it had a really strong celery taste, which I am not really a big fan of. The monkfish liver mousse was surprisingly good. I would recommend ordering it if you like Foie gras. Lastly, we had the chocolate ganache for dessert. It was delicious, especially with the graham cracker crumbs. Overall, it was a fun dining experience for me.
author: Celine L.

description:
I want to give them more stars, but at the end of the day, this meal was not worth 200 dollars. 

We had a variety of items. The lobster ceviche, the octopus, the ravioli, the hanger steak, the fingerling potatoes, the fried duck sandwich, and some wine. 

FIRST, the duck sandwich was hellaaa good. If I could impart one piece of advice, it was be to get a duck sandwich per person. That is all. This should not be shared. 

Second, why so many potatoes in the fingerling potatoes, when everything else that is served has the portion size appropriate for a small child. 

To sum my experience with the food, basically everything was mediocre, maybe a little better, with the exception of the duck sandwich. So the next time I'm here with my girlfriend, we are probably just going to get 2 duck sandwiches, or 3, or 4.. er maybe. 

Service was attentive. But then when they packed up our enormous portion of potatoes togo, we never received them on our way out. Oops? No huge loss I guess, as it wasn't that great. 

Long story short: just get that duck though.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Came here for our anniversary dinner. On a Friday night it was not too packed but we also had reservations. 
The cocktails were really good and pretty strong. I liked the 1760. 
For food- my most favorite was the grilled octopus. WOW I was blown away by how delicious and perfectly cooked it was. I am not a natural fan of octopus but after that dish, I can eat octopus every day if it's cooked like that haha Crispy on the outside and melt in your mouth tender on the inside. Perfection.
Second favorite were the bbq ribs, very very good.
We also had the flatbread (good) and lobster ceviche (this was good but tiny, I would skip it). Dessert was plantain with ice cream I think?
The food are small sizes but very satisfying. It's not on the cheap side either. Overall though, I recommend 1760.
author: Vol T.

description:
Dimly lit, trendy atmosphere- perfect for a date night or a small group. Definitely not loud enough for a girls' night (well, my girls at least)! They played inaudible soft music in the background, but when we were on our last dish, they played 2pac's 'To Live and Die in LA'. Not sure if that was accidentally added to the playlist (for the record, I would love to be able to eat at a restaurant with 2pac playing in the background).

Tapas style, so order 6 dishes for a party of 2. Dishes range from $16-$28. Don't be concerned by the small table, the food comes out 1-2 plates at a time. We ordered:

Hamachi crudo - Good, lots of celery to give it a fresh crunch
Beef tartare - Very good, and came with a super delicious herb salad with a thai vinaigrette
Brussels sprouts - Tasty, with crumbled egg yolk on top. You can never go wrong with roasted brussels sprouts.
BBQ pork belly - My fav of the night! Tender morsels of pork belly on top of some kind of yummy potato slaw sauce. 
Nori-roasted Potatoes - Definitely going to skip this next time. Great flavor on the potatoes with just a hint of nori, but there were only a few and I feel like I could make this at home. 
Fried duck sandwich - So yummy! Just enough bread (I hate sandwiches with too thick bread). Duck was delicious, not too much breading and didn't taste super fried. Went perfectly with the cole slaw. 

I didn't order any drinks but I heard from a coworker (also there on a date) that each one they ordered was a hit. I just might be back to try a few. 

We walked to Bob's Donuts after for some dessert.
author: Kat N.

description:
One of the best dining experiences ever! 1760 was a must try for me during my recent visit to San Francisco, based on other yelp reviews and their menu. I am so thankful that I went here. We treated our friends to an amazing dinner here as a thank you for letting us stay at their place for the week. All of us were blown away by the amazing flavorful food and couldn't stop commenting on it for the next two days. 

The Haricots Verts (green beans) with yuba, lime, and sesame was unlike anything I have tried before. This dish wasn't even on my radar and I am so thankful the waiter had suggested it. The flavors were ridiculous and it was my absolute favorite!

We almost didn't order the Fried Duck Sandwich with slaw, pickles, and spicy aioli, because my girlfriend is turned off by anything duck. I had to try it based on its popularity. Ironically it ended up being my girlfriend's favorite dish of the night and was simply amazing!

The Lobster Ceviche was also a big winner. We wish we had ordered two of these because there wasn't much and we were all fighting over it. 

We also enjoyed the Pork Belly, Shishito Peppers, and Grilled Octopus. Although I enjoyed the grilled octopus I have had plenty better. I only say this because this is the dish that first attracted me to 1760, so I was surprised that I was more impressed by most of the other dishes we had. 

1760 will definitely be a must visit anytime I visit San Francisco in the future. Or it would be nice if Chicago could steal their chef away.
author: Wayne H.

description: Service was great, but the food was extremely disappointing and over-priced. The cocktails were overly sweet and unbalanced. Steak tartare had too much spice - which made it a one note dish. The har-gow cavatelli was a gummy salt lick. Seared scallops were okay - nothing special... in general, the food was pretty one note and uninspired, with very small portions for the price. If you're going to charge so much for a dish that is that small, it has to be exceptional. Otherwise - as in the case with last nights dinner - it feels like highway robbery.  I should have known from the "welcome bite" - a stale, dry piece of granola topped by a minuscule sliver of apple- that this was not the place for us.
author: Jessica H.

description: Pretty plating but not actually that tasty. Everything was underwhelming and just slightly missing something. It's not terrible but it's not great. It's more style over substance. The hamachi was fresh. So I can say something positive for 1 out of 5 dishes. The often reviewed duck sandwich is just alright.
author: Sarah J.

description:
I don't know if its because we order the wrong dishes, but I felt that none of the plates were "mind-blowing" amazing. Everything was mediocre; but I didn't spend some much money on just mediocre plates. The most tasty thing that we got was the green beans; the sauce was tangy and had a nice kick to the dish. The dessert was good, but not for that price. 

Overall, you'll get good service, good company (I guess that's if you bring enjoyable people), drinks were decent, and food a-ok. 

P.S. there a $4 cake cutting fee per person if you bring your own cake.
author: Mo W.

description:
When I think of Polk Street, wild partying and 4am donuts comes to mind. That's why I was pleasantly surprised to find such a delicious restaurant amongst the madness. 

Not only was the food amazing, but the presentation was very unique. Even the $4 bread came out looking fantastic. The menu is a little confusing, with no separate appetizers and main entrees but instead a lot of small plates that vary in size. The Corn Ravioli is easily one of the best things I've ever eaten, an inexplicable combination of cheese and soup (I know it sounds weird, just trust me). The Grilled Pork Ribs and Uni are other personal favorites. Everything is a little overpriced, but I think the quality of the food warrants the price. 

Because of the sleek decor, I would recommend this as a date spot. Reason I would hesitate though are the tables are placed very close to one another and it is quite loud. Tables were so close in fact that I could literally hear the conversations of all surrounding tables.
author: Ashwin S.

description: I've been wanting to try 1760 for awhile-- i've heard only great things and wanted to see what the fuss was about. Luckily, we got in on a Thursday without too much trouble. It's a small plate thing, so for two people, doing about 3-4 dishes should do it if you aren't super hungry. We did the fried flowers, octopus, raviolis and drinks to start with. Everything was great and the service was super friendly. It definitely filled up fast, pretty much as soon as we arrived, so would highly recommend reservations (that's how we got in) and to try out weekdays if the weekends aren't working for ya :)
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
Hmm.  Just a skosh overrated but still a nice experience.  Floor-to-ceiling, glamorous windows overlooking the not-so-glamorous corner of Polk and Washington made us giggle. The bright, "it's last call!"-esque lighting made us giggle.

As for the food, it's certainly all about the presentation here because portions are quite scarce. We had the Lobster Ceviche, Burrata on grilled bread, Crispy Octopus, Uni Bucatini.  Tasty, but none really blew our socks off, and were pretty pricey when all was said and done.  Service was attentive and we definitely felt we were at a trendy li'l joint in the city but I'll go with 3 stars. P.S. Can we talk about how terrified I was approaching the restaurant when I saw the throng of 20-somethings smoking cigs outside before I realized it was spillage from the bar (Cabin) next door?
author: Jen E.

description: I don't normally like large restaurants but 1760 is great. Simple dishes like the Little Gem Salad were fantastic. Gluten and alcohol-free, I had no struggles here and the bartender made me a fantastic 'mock tail' with fresh herbs and no attitude! I'd return any day.
author: Barbara O.

description:
Returned after a long gap, alas we were overall disappointed both the service and the food. Spending a lot on small plates means you expect each to be tasty and fulfilling. This was not the case, hence I would say this spot is average at best. We left regretting the money we wasted on subpar food. While we dined at the common table, we felt the service was poor, with the waitress bumping us by mistake or taking the kitchen forever to bring over the dishes.

No bueno
author: Sharon M.

description: Of the dishes we had, the Bavette and pork ribs were the best- really good. Service was attentive and the wine was fine.
author: Cathleen T.

description:
I showed up alone and ate at the bar.  At least on a weekday, the bar was crowded; at 6:00 p.m., I was lucky to get a seat.  The dining room was less crowded.

The food was outstanding, in an artsy-fartsy way.  I had the olives, the mushroom tempura, the kabocha ravioli, and the chocolate ganache.  The olives were practically life-changing.  I must research where to buy Castelvetrano olives!  Everything else was similarly outstanding, but the portions were small, and they left me wanting more.

Cocktails were tasty, but more forgettable than the food.

Service was extremely attentive.  The total damage (with three cocktails) was $81 for one.
author: Sparky H.

description:
Our meal had its highlights but I think there are some dishes that are overrated.  Best dish was the pork belly by far.  It's fatty and crispy - if you don't want fatty them don't get pork belly.  

The other dishes we tried were the lobster ceviche, crispy calamari, flank steak, flatbread, and duck sandwich.  Those were all not bad but nothing to rave about.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
In reality a 3.5 star rating. I'm a BIG fan of Acquarello, so I was very interested in trying out their new casual spot. Ultimately, the food leans toward "asian fusion" and while dishes are exquisitely plated and sound creative and intriguing, the flavors don't always come together. Taste is sometimes sacrificed for beauty and novelty. It wasn't a bad meal, but I wouldn't actively recommend it or go back and I think for the price there are many other really excellent places in SF to go to. 

I went with a group so we were able to try a bunch of dishes:

Winners: 
- Carrots: Best dish of the night. Really. They were almost black in color but they were perfectly roasted and spiced. 
- Short rib: I always love short rib and they did a good job here of making it nice and crispy.
- Burrata: can't really go wrong with burrata, ever. Good, though I wasn't sure what I was supposed to do with the pieces of asian pear that were beautifully leaning against the bread - put on top? eat after to cleanse the palate? but it was gorgeous

Meh:
- Shishito  peppers: I adore grilled shishito peppers, but for my taste these weren't quite done enough - they were still some that were a little raw and crunchy, not that soft, charred flesh. I also needed to add more salt. But I loved the excessive amount of hazelnuts on top
- Crispy octopus: I found the avocado puree on this kinda weird, like with the ceviche. The portion of octopus was nice though, and it was very meaty. It was crispy, but that did mean the meat was a little dry and tough - but that's to be expected. Satsifying, but not a winner
- Warm Banana Bread: Good but not great - I liked the chunky monkey ice cream, but the banana bread itself was just good. 

Skip:
- Lobster Ceviche: the coconut and pineapple were just too sweet for the lobster, the subtle natural sweetness of the lobster was lost. Beautifully plated though.
- Brussels Sprouts: I normally adore brussels sprouts, but I found these a little soggy with the fish sauce dressing. 
- Carrot Cake: This is a "deconstructed" carrot cake with carrot cake crumbs, strips of carrot, dots of meringue, carrot gelato, and a cream cheese mousse. If i had known, definitely wouldn't have ordered. The cream cheese mousse was nice, but the whole dessert  felt overly designed. 

Overall: 1760 has a very New York-y kind of vibe, which is unique in SF, so I can see why people like it. And many people probably appreciate the creativity in flavor combinations. The dishes certainly look impressive, I just wasn't all impressed by the taste (and price).
author: dana n.

description: Been walking past this restaurant and finally went in to try it. I have to say not worth the value. Service was excellent but the food was not anything amazing. I had the duck sand which and it was salty! My friend had the lobster ceviche which was pretty good but small. Maybe I'll try it out again but not anytime soon.
author: Jennifer U.

description: First, when my mom and I went to go sit down on a Tuesday night the hostess was almost reluctant to put us in a booth because of reservations and the place was not even half full. Secondly, wine was ok but if I'm paying $18-20 a glass it should be a decent pour. Pours were very light. Food was just ok nothing to rave about at all. Would get two stars because our waiter was a nice guy and so was the ping lady busting the tables. Advice to the owners would be to make sure the hostess who seemed she could have been even a manager to seat people without question on a Tuesday smiling and if you did over book booths deal with it as it comes don't make the people trying to eat at your feel restaurant unwanted or unwelcome.. next, if you're going to charge san Francisco prices it's got to be up to San Francisco quality. This was not up to par.. Small portions not very good Brussel sprouts over powered. The octopus was good and the avocado toast with lard was also good. Once again portions were super small overpriced. Not a great experience.
author: William M.

description: The food is tasty but the portion size is just silly. Really. Seared scallops with parsnip puree and rainbow chard for $24. OK. Four small scallops with no more than a tablespoon of parsnip puree and half of one leaf of rainbow chard. Not exaggerating here. I'm sorry, it's just ridiculous, even for "small plates." We ordered the carrots too and they were fine. But hey, the appetizer was gratis. Honestly, it took the waitress more time to describe it than it did to eat it. Four ingredients about the size of your thumbnail. I actually posted a pic of it on FB because it was that comical.
author: Barbara G.

description: We had excellent service from all of the staff at 1760. It was the perfect spot for night out catching up with friends while sharing delicious food together. My favorite was the corn ravioli. We will be back again soon!
author: Kavitha L.

description:
I came to 1760 on the recommendation of a friend who had dinner here and RAVED about the food.  My friend and I came in for brunch.  It has not very busy, and we were very welcomed by the gentleman at the front.  The restaurant is very roomy and open, which I loved.  Our server, who was very personable, came to the table right away to see if she could get us something to drink, which was wonderful.  We decided on a bottle of Prosecco with OJ for mimosa's.  The OJ is brought in a mini pitcher, which is about half full.  The waitress explained the menu is setup to be shared, so we ordered the Brioche French Toast, Squash Blossom Tempura and the Fried Duck Sandwich.  She also confirmed that neither of us had any food allergies, which both my friend and I appreciated.  

I must say that the first two dishes were absolutely amazing.  The flavors and the textures, all so good.  The Fried Duck Sandwich was beautifully presented, and it was good, it just didn't knock my socks off like the first two dishes did.  The food, the service, the restaurant all highly recommended.  The ONLY complaint I had about the entire meal, was that the tiny  1/2 full pitcher of OJ for our mimosa's was not very much at all.  We asked if we could please have some more OJ, which the server gladly brought us, and didn't realize until we received the bill that she also charged an additional $5 for the extra OJ.  This won't keep me from coming back, but I would hate for anyone else to be blindsided by the extra charge.
author: Jules J.

description:
Excellent food and service.  I was disappointed that my reservation was not fully honored. Even though we were early for the  reservation, we had to wait an additional 20 minutes after our reservation time to get a table. 

I would go back.   Tartare, green beans, chicken and octopus were all excellent.
author: Ed G.

description:
This place lost 1 star for service (we waited 15 minutes for our drinks and ~25 minutes for our food which came out lukewarm)... even the couple sitting next to us was complaining. And 1 star was lost for the portion size. The food was good... but not good enough the validate such small portions.
Lobster ceviche was yummy... the coconut aioli was amazing.
Pork Sisig was also delicious... but not exceptional. For those prices and portion sizes you would expect something more.
author: Ann B.

description: Knowledgable mixologists, great flavors to the food, reasonable prices, and friendly atmosphere even for folks that aren't hoity toity.
author: Josh F.

description: Been here a couple times and recently celebrated my birthday here. Some highlights: corn and coconut ravioli, octopus, and Brussels sprouts! Definitely love the energy and aesthetics of this place. Would recommend for a last min dinner decisions as reservations on open table are usually fairly easy to snag! Will be back!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
SF is one of the best cities in terms of dining out. There are endless options with varying degrees of inventiveness.  And you pay for it.  For the most part, if you want to try these places you simply need to accept that and I do. I understand that at times you pay for the creativity and the quality. 

The city has pushed the limits in many ways, and one of them is pricing.  The continuous nudge upwards has made people accept it as the norm. The small plates/tapas style of dining starts feeling a little gimmicky and like a joke on us - like the fact that it is under $20 makes it reasonable for the childlike portions. By no means is this just something that happens at 1760. But even by SF standards, the last time I was here it was on the slightly insane side of the spectrum.  At $80 per person, we left feeling like we grazed a few tasty plates, rather than feeling satisfied by our experience dining out (though the service was decent and well-trained). But honestly, who thinks anymore that our reviews change anything? ;)
author: whatever I.

description:
I was kind of torn on the rating because I actually thought the food was 4.5- 5 stars.  So I'll start by saying that we had a rather erratic experience, largely because they had some staff issues that night, so our first dish didn't come out for 45-50 minutes after we ordered, they served us the wrong dish, then didn't remember to serve us another dish that we had actually ordered because their expediter got confused.   Having said that, I think they did a great job making  it up to us because the chef (pretty new chef to 1760 I think) came out twice to greet us personally and apologize for the logistical issues, our server was genuinely apologetic, plus they comped us on a dish or two.  So all in all, I really appreciated their recognition of our bizarre experience and thought they did a great job making us feel special.  More importantly, I thought the food was excellent.  

The first dish was Caviar, which was a bit of caviar on a hokkaido scallop with a bit of uni and chives.  Given that each portion fit on less than half of a porcelain spoon, this was $9 apiece and we had been patiently waiting for 45-50 minutes already getting increasingly hungry, we were a bit nervous that we wouldnt have enough food.  Luckily, that didn't turn out to be the case.    Next up were the spring peas, which were delicious and served with a smoked ocean trout, egg, and buttermilk wasabi sauce.  We also got the fried duck sandwich, which was an entree sized course with brioche bun, slaw, pickles and a picy aioli.  We also got the grilled pork ribs, which was delicious, and came with hoisin bbq sauce, peanuts and radish.  Everything was presented beautifully, the flavors were all fantastic, and it really would have been a 5 star meal if it weren't for all the hiccups.  And finally the Willet manhattans  were good. Great date place.  

All in all, I would love to go back.
author: Vivian W.

description: We loved this restaurant. We try to go to small plate restaurants because you can try so much more food. The atmosphere was great. There is a huge wine list and we tried a domestic Chardonnay that we loved. We had the avocado toast-yum, the tempora-- the lemon foam was awesome, the cavetelli--the reason it's 4 stars and not 5, the ribs--spicy, meaty, best dish of the night, duck burger--yummy, and the milk chocolate ganache with hickory ice cream-- I'm going to try to make this!
author: Dawn A.

description: This place is a real winner! The cocktails are delicious and clearly crafted by expert bartenders. I'm a big fan of small plates eating for the variety you get and these do not disappoint. I've been here a few times and each time the quality is always on point. One my favorites is the octopus which is nice and tender. All the whiskey cocktails are delicious as well :-)
author: Daniel S.

description:
Skip this one. Really.

The problem with 1760 is that they take some amazing ingredients and then mess them up. This goes all the way from the amuse bouche to the mains. The amuse bouche was a "Spice Pressed Apple Slice". Seriously. it was just a slice of an apple. What restaurant does this?

We had:

Crispy Octopus - flavor wise this was nice, a Spanish style tapa. Too bad the octopus was significantly over cooked (= rubbery). 
Umi Pasta - Also under-seasoned, single dimension dish. It was average.
Grilled Mackerel - this was nice and simple, well seasoned and fresh. Liked this one.
Fingerling potatoes - these were regular potatoes with some avocado pieces. This was under seasoned. You can make better ones at home.

If you've eaten at great restaurants (Frances, State Bird, Coqueta, Bouche, etc) you will be disappointed here.
author: Artur R.

description:
Great place for contemporary American food - beautiful dishes with great taste combinations. All the dishes we had was very good and well prepared. It's great to get many dishes to share around 3 per person will be enough

We had:

- Lolipop Kale
- Crab Ceviche
- Beef tartar
- octopus
- BBQ ribs

The top one was for sure the Octopus
author: Petter B.

description:
Delicious small plate cuisine! We came here with a group of four and ordered 8 dishes, which was about the right amount. The service was great. I'd come back here again.

Favorites:
--Poppy Seed Pain de Mie 
--Fingerling Potatoes 
--Pork Ribs
--Fried Duck Sandwhich

Pretty Good:
--Ravioli
--Crispy Octopus
--Hanger Steak

Nothing Special:
--Marinated Olives
author: Sarah S.

description:
My girlfriend and I were really looking forward to coming here and we were sadly disappointed. What went wrong:

- We made a reservation for 9:30pm and after a long wait the only table open was next to the door and really cold. We ended up at a crowded community table. So much for a romantic intimate dinner.

- The decor in the place was cold and barren. There are so many restaurants and bars in town that manage to make a place feel warm and friendly without spending a lot. The room at 1760 felt like eating in an office.

- The food was consistently oversalted. We found ourselves gulping down water we got so thirsty. Especially bad was the kale. The chorizo / octopus, lobster and uni buccatini dishes were decent.

- The drinks took forever to arrive and food got to our table first.

1760, congrats on your buzz so far but we are definitely not coming back.
author: Rob B.

description:
Castelvetrano Olives, Shishito Peppers, Crispy Octopus, Fried Duck Sandwich, Honey-Thyme Pain de Mie, and Milk Chocolate Ganache were the food highlights. That dessert includes amazing and crazy hickory smoke ice cream! 

Cocktails were delicious. Very inventive flavors and super well balanced. Most were not very spirit-forward, but unlike most restaurant cocktails, they weren't overly sweet. My favorite was quite spirit-forward, though, the Garam Masala-Cardamom - thyme. orange. toasted cardamom. bourbon.

Great nice but casual atmosphere and service.
author: Deva H.

description: Omg from the time we walked in the door it has been amazing service & such great food! All the drinks were so divine! I was blown away! Alison is just the sweetest server, Kyle is a amazing bartender, & the Somm was extremely attentive and bright and shining!
author: T L.

description: Amazing, amazing, amazing drinks!!! The bartenders here make some of the best drinks in the city. All fresh ingredients which balance out the alcohol, so much that you can't even taste the alcohol. Oh, and the food here is amazing too. Highly recommend this place, and sit at the bar.
author: Ashley A.

description: The manager at this restaurant is doing something right!  Every server we encountered was so helpful and polite.  It seemed like the entire staff was taking care of each table together as a team.  It was just a really nice experience. The food was excellent too!  I live nearby and will be definitely going back!
author: Colleen L.

description:
OBSESSED with 1760. I wasn't in love with the menu and the idea of small plates before tentatively coming in, but was completely blown away with the depth of flavor and deliciousness of everything we ordered.

So much that I had to return with my boyfriend two nights later to do it all again. Perhaps I was a little tipsy the first time (or someone threw a flavor-enhancing roofie into my cocktail), as everything was just a NOTCH less good on my second visit (hence the 4 stars instead of 5). Not to say I wouldn't return, but it wasn't as mind blowingly amazing as it was the first time.

First, let's talk service. Everyone's super friendly, perhaps a little distant and slow, but overall very nice and helpful.

Food:

--the corn ravioli: OUT OF THIS WORLD. If you order one thing at 1760, order this. It will  blow your mind. In fact, I'm not going to give you any further details so you can experience the magic for yourself.

--the ribs: I must say I am NOT a huge rib person but these totally impressed me. The flavor was addicting: a semi-spicy Thai sauce topped with chopped peanuts. The meat: tender and flavorful, so soft it fell off the bone at first touch.

--the pork belly: outrageously flavorful and juicy. I have never had pork belly so juicy and delicious.

--the fried duck sandwich: oh heavens this was wonderful. I don't LOVE duck so was kinda wishing the whole time I ate this that it was chicken, but regardless, it was killer. Flavorful, crispy, and doused in a creamy aioli with crunchy cole slaw.

--the Hangar steak: while perhaps the least exciting thing we ordered, it was perfectly cooked and delicious. Just not nearly as unique as our other dishes.

I would also highly recommend the blackberry cocktail (forget the exact name) and the decomposed s'mores dessert.

All in all, 1760 is a trendy and equally delicious spot to check out with a well-dressed date or group of friends. Prepare for your palate to be rocked.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Had a late night dinner at 1760. It was my third time here and the food was just as good as I remember. Always a good ambiance, even for the late-night crowd - our reservation was at 10:30 p.m. The service was interesting...our server was quite awkward, but very nice and attentive, and kept reminding us that all alcohol had to be off the table by midnight. Though somewhat of a strange rule, we appreciated that he let us know before we ordered a bottle of dessert wine.  

The brussels sprouts with black vinegar, hazelnuts, prosciutto, uni bucatini and the crispy octopus with chorizo 'paella' and lemon-mussel were my absolute favorites of the evening. All had rich, well  balanced flavors and the portion sizes were perfect to share. We also enjoyed the lollipop kale and coconut-satsuma panna cotta. Would recommend going in a group - I believe that all the dishes are meant to be shared due to their richness. Overall, the food was great - will be back to more of their pastas and that duck sandwich!
author: Elisa P.

description: Very pricey and the menu is kinda confusing as you don't know what an appetizer is and what the main entree is. The food however is delicious but nothing too amazing.
author: Alice C.

description:
Delightful brunch venue on a rainy Sunday afternoon. Loved the art-deco inspired décor and really attentive service. Sat in a booth by the window, and liked that the menu, from top to bottom, started out with more simple items (seasonal fruit ($5) for example) to more savory items like a fried duck sandwich ($18) with slaw, pickles and spicy aioli. 

The dishes are meant to be shared, so think of this like brunch tapas, minus the hot Spanish waiter. Avocado toast with pickled onions, radish and lime ($7) was expertly grilled and cut into several pieces, which was appreciated for my brunch companion and myself. Mushroom tempura was one of the best items on the menu, with a celery root, Meyer lemon and fennel frond frothy mousse for dipping. Along with the mushrooms, the fingerling potatoes with charred avocado, cilantro, and roasted peanuts was also outstanding ($9). I had an egg added on top as I was pretty hungry, so that added an extra two dollars to our bill. The one-eyed jacks were also incredible, of course it was simply a snazzier version of toast with a hole (and egg inside) with the chef using a quail's egg, crumbled bacon bits and a delicate lemon-mustard sauce drizzled over the entire dish. I liked the sweetness of the brioche bread. The accompanying side salad added green flair to the dish, but I didn't partake of its fibrous goodness. 

Convinced I needed dessert, and since they were out of the cardamom beignets with Thai-basil chocolate sauce ($8), I opted instead for the cinnamon Babka with vanilla cream cheese mousse and apple chutney ($7). Loved the old-world cinnamon goodness and the mousse wasn't too cheesy, which I liked. 

They have a full bar, so in addition to the copious amounts of water I drank (our waiter did an amazing job of refilling our water glasses) I ordered a black iced tea with a shot of Cointreau (an extra $7 for a glass of iced tea that was $5). Service was, as mentioned earlier, really outstanding. In addition to changing plates throughout the meal, there were many times while ordering the waiter suggested various dishes to try, without being overly pushy. I'll definitely come back from dinner.
author: David G.

description: Yum. Seriously. I did not know what I was getting myself into and the food coma that would ensue. But it was fully worth it. We ate brunch, and everything was amazingly flavorful and tasty. I decided to try a little bit of most of the items on the menu and I was in love, with food. And the servers, they were all so nice! My favorite was the Kimchi Fried Rice, ohhh and the Fingerling Potatoes were soooo good too. I would highly recommend this spot. Word.
author: Sonya D.

description: Food was exceptional Mushroom Tempura, Pork Something a rather, Beef Tartar all delicious. We ate at the bar and were dazzled by the friendliness and professionalism of everyone we came across. Highly recommend this to anyone, well done Chef Carl and team!
author: Matt H.

description: The drinks here are outstanding, and the tapas were equally amazing. Service and ambiance are also superb; you get what you pay for.
author: Diane W.

description:
mmmMmm this place is pretty delicious - def a fan!

came here on a random tuesday evening, and the place was PACKED! we grabbed two seats at the communal table, which was perfect for us - its always fun to observe what's going down in the restaurant and to preview the food plates! teehee.

we got - peppers, fried duck sando, uni, and the pork ribs. the fried duck sandwich was definitely my favorite, but boi didnt like it at all, saying that it was a bit bland, etc. etc. butttt i thought the flavors were great, and the slaw on it was the perfect touch. he reallllyy enjoyed the pork ribs, which i liked as well. tender, and perfectly saucy without being overwhelming.

we tried a glass of wine each, and also 2 cocktails each. everything we ordered was delicious, albeit probably on the sweeter side each time. meep! haha..

overall a great experience! and good for families and friends :)
author: Christina L.

description:
Cocktails were interesting (way better than most, to be fair, but I wouldn't order either again). 

Wine list is awesome. Particularly neat to have a lot of half bottle options.

Food was a mixed bag. Bread was super stale (or maybe heated up and left sitting out?), which was a bummer. Peas were awesome. Other dishes I thought fell flat for a variety of reasons; mostly just thought the flavors were off (some too spicy, some too bland). In general, I see how this place could be awesome. But at least this night, there were more misses than hits.
author: Amjad S.

description:
If you want a place where you can talk and drink..... Then wait....and wait...and wait....and wait....and starve then this is the place for you!

Service is nice, food is good, but get some people in your kitchen for goodness sake.

I'm hangry!!!!!
author: Steph Q.

description: Went for Sunday brunch with a group of six. We made our reservation two days prior via Opentable. It was a nice setting with a rustic/laid back ambience. We particularly enjoyed the drinks menu, featuring an eclectic selection of cocktails. However, the food menu was quite limited in options. We ordered a variety of items such as chicken waffles, beignets, fingerling potatoes, French toast, shrimp polenta - all of which were perfectly prepared. The menu changes frequently, so I would like to go back again and try out some of their new additions!
author: Shruti G.

description:
Heading to 1760 for our first meal in town was a little scary. We were excited to be out and about, but also starving and exhausted from flying all day, so the 9pm reservation couldn't come soon enough. When we started looking at photos of the food on Yelp, we got nervous about how hungry we would still be after the meal here. We were also a little worried that we were out of our element going to what seemed like it would be an uncomfortably upscale restaurant. Luckily, the wait was worth it and the food was not only delicious, but sufficient. Also, while being just fancy enough, this place was pretty relaxed. 

There were four of us and the waitress explained that the idea was to share the plates. That's always a wonderful idea to me, because I have so much trouble deciding all the time. We started with the lobster ceviche, which was fantastic! There was only a little bit, but the proportions were perfect for all of us to get a taste and still be hungry and even more excited for the rest of our meal. I had my sights set on the corn ravioli, but they were all out of that as well as the, crispy octopus, burrata, and bucatini. We settled on the grilled pork ribs, cavatelli, fried duck sandwich, and the hangar steak. 

The cavatelli came first and I was enamored with the lobster mushrooms. I need to get my hands on some of those. The pasta itself was OK, but nothing too crazy for us. Then came the duck and ribs. I don't eat either of these meats generally, but I can say that they were prepared perfectly. This didn't change the fact that I am not a duck or pork fan, but I can say that I wasn't upset for having eaten my 1/4 of the dishes. Then, surprisingly, the octopus came out! Apparently, they had some extra floating around and I'm SO INCREDIBLY THANKFUL for that because that octopus was a dream. It's been a week since I ate it and I can't stop thinking about it. The hangar steak was also perfectly prepared and flavorful, but nothing will overshadow the octopus and lobster mushrooms. We had the milk chocolate ganache for dessert and were equally impressed with the presentation as well as the taste. Overall a perfect meal.

I had the sugar snap pea cocktail, and wow, was it a strange experience! I loved it! 

The service was fantastic. Our server was enthusiastic and everyone that came by our table was incredibly nice without being annoying or pushy. Shout out to the guy that was clearing some dishes and broke one of the super fragile beer glasses on our table. He dealt with the break so smoothly and, even though it wasn't upsetting or an inconvenience to us, we appreciated how apologetic he clearly was.
author: Kaitlin D.

description:
Love the food, the mixology and the service! This is our favorite neighborhood restaurant! It is a true neighborhood place run by its owners who know excelence! 

Thank you for making us feel special each time we dine with you!
author: Mariela G.

description:
Within  15 to 20 minutes of beginning my meal at 1760, I decided not to write a Yelp review because my experience was on-par with my expectations and experience of any good restaurant in San Francisco. The place was stylish and abuzz with lively energy from the guests, hosts, servers and bartenders.  The music was playful and soulful; I recall hearing Tom Waits, Talking Heads and a long-forgotten song called Walking in the Rain by Oran "Juice" Jones. The server was knowledgeable, friendly and  attentive. As I watched plates being served to other tables, the food looked good.  When my first plates arrived - Shishito Peppers, Hamachi Crudo and Burrata, they were well-presented and tasty.  This is exactly what I expected.  A solid 3 stars.

But then, something unexpected happened.  The Grilled Pork Ribs arrived.   They were better than delicious.  They were delectable.  Tender. Juicy.  Perfectly Spiced.  PERFECTION.  I was born in the south and I'm a snob about ribs.  I have never had ribs this good in San Francisco and I have tried them nearly everywhere and I'm usually disappointed but, not this time.

Then the BBQ Pork Belly arrived and I thought I'd died and gone to (hog) heaven.  The corn porridge, peaches and frisee accompaniment put this dish over the top.  

These final dishes - the Ribs and Pork Belly - will make me a repeat customer. So what started out as a solid 3 star experience turned out to be a bright 5 star surprise.
author: Jamie A.

description:
This may be the most expensive brunch I've ever had, but I'd say it was worth eating ramen for the week after. I didn't realize it was small plates until we sat down, which changed the price calculation considerably, so bear that in mind when you're perusing the menu online. 

Every dish was amazing. From the peach-coconut mimosas to the tiny bites of joy that were the buttermilk biscuits, to my favorite, the super trendy pork belly, we ate our way through what felt like half of the entire menu and it was glorious. Save this place for a splurge, but when you do get there, you will love every single bite.
author: Chaney K.

description:
I had made a 9:30 reservation to celebrate my birthday, and it was fairly disappointing that we were not seated until 10:40.

We stood at the bar (as there were no seats available) and watched several tables sit absent-mindedly, having already eaten, and waited patiently for an hour and ten minutes for our table to be set up. Yes, we could have sat down after 40 minutes, when we were offered a spot at the community table, but it was my birthday and we wanted our own table. I don't think it's unreasonable to expect a table to ourselves at the agreed-upon reservation time.

So we sit down finally, and we order, seeing as how we had plenty of time to look at the menu. 1760 does a lot of shared plates, so we ordered some items, and asked if it would be enough for us. The server said she thought so, but if we wanted we could always add more. Two minutes later she returned to the table and said "The kitchen is closing, so if there's anything else you want, or if you think you'll want dessert later, you'll have to order now." We didn't order anything else.

During dinner, we were given a complimentary order of the fingerling potatoes, which were delicious. By the end of the meal, we were stuffed, and even left a few bites on the table. And then we were given two desserts that we hadn't ordered, also complementary. Of course, we were full, so they were partially eaten. While the gesture was appreciated, it seemed it would have made more sense to comp either the cocktails we ordered while we waited, or the corkage fee for the wine we brought, or any one of the items that we actually ordered, rather than offering us something we didn't order to begin with, or couldn't finish at the end of the meal.

In the end, the food was great, particularly the uni pasta. But the overall experience turned me off a bit. I know restaurants can't control the behavior of their guests, but surely it's within their power to suggest other reservations are waiting, and move them to the bar?
author: Will G.

description:
You absolutely MUST get the Lobster Ceviche! The curry and coconut give a perfectly balanced sweetness, and the lobster itself is quite good. 

I also recommend the Pork Sisig. Good quality, crunchy pieces of pork (not overly fatty or salty). And I'm impressed to find a Filipino-inspired dish well done!

Unfortunately I was underwhelmed by the wine, so I had to subtract a star. Next time I'll try a cocktail. But overall good experience and trendy ambiance.
author: Riz W.

description:
Big, big fan. The food is well thought out and the service is absolutely top notch. I've eaten here twice now and while it's a bit pricey, they take each dish on the menu seriously and use fresh, delicious ingredients.

Standouts: Octopus, Fingerling Potatoes, Skirt Steak.

Highly recommend.
author: Derek S.

description: I love it here. Consistent good food and good service. Everyone knows this is the ultimate recipe for a great experience. I recommend this place to anyone I come across. Lobster ceviche is a must have and order at least one if you're a party of two or more! The ever changing complimentary snacks are a nice touch. The changes made to the uni bucatini since the beginning is even tastier. Basil drink is the fave on the menu. You really can't go wrong with ordering. I just tend to over order and rarely get to dessert. Enjoy! See u again soon 1760!!
author: Marilyn N.

description: When you come here- GET THE BRUSSELS SPROUTS!! I would have taken a picture- but we at them too quickly!
author: Lauren L.

description:
I went here for my birthday dinner with my family and we ordered every single item on the menu.  I would have to say, everything was good.  Here the breakdown:

Must Order Items (excellent):
Caviar - it's just one small spoonful of deliciousness
Lobster Ceviche (so good, we ordered 4 of these)
Fried Duck Sandwich - my husband and brother in law don't like duck but they loved the sandwich.  Similar to a pulled pork sandwich but with duck.  Excellent.
Pork Belly - very tender and tasty.  I liked the fact there wasn't an excess amount of fat that a lot a pork belly dishes have.
Corn Ravioli - as recommended by our waiter, you have to put the whole thing in your mouth to really experience the filling.  Yummy.
Crispy Octopus - very tender and tasty
Hamachi crudo
Della Fattoria Bread with whipped pork fat (perfect alternative to butter)

Must try at least once (good to try):
Pork ribs
Beef tartar
shishito peppers
artichoke hearts
burratta
fingerling potatoes
maccheroni with crab
bucatini (wish they would use a different pasta with this dish to soak up the sauce)
whole roasted chicken - I typically never order chicken but this was pretty good.  very smooth and delicate with a really tasty dipping sauce.

As for desserts, they were all good.  None blew me away but they were good.  Intermezzo was light and refreshing.  The chocolate ganache was good.  The strawberries and cream was my least favorite since the basil ice cream and sponge cake overwhelmed the delicate dessert.  The banana bread with chunky monkey ice cream was a surprising favorite.
author: Shelly W.

description:
I'm very impressed the food was phenomenal! 

Fingerling potatoes-addicting 
Beef tartare-seasoned to perfection
Steak-awesome
Lobster ceviche-so refreshing 
Ravioli- delicious 

We ordered the county line rose to start, but for once we were so focused on the food we forgot to drink. Luckily I remembered to move into a Nebbiolo for the steak. Everything was amazing 

I dine out a lot, and I don't usually go back to the same restaurant unless it was truly amazing, but 1760 look out for me, you won me over. Service was fantastic, thanks for hosting and laughing at my weak jokes!
author: Leo T.

description: We have been going to 1760 since it opened and we absolutely love the restaurant! It's our go-to restaurant in SF for celebrations and family dinners. Their food is meant to be shared and the variety is expansive. Their duck sandwich is incredible, the steak tartar is amazing, the tempura mushrooms, the ribs, the avocado toast, the chicken and waffle croquettes, are all great. The menu changes frequently, which is nice although we wish some of the old dishes, like the crispy octopus would return to the menu. You won't be disappointed.
author: Phil G.

description:
2.5 stars

**Long story short**:
Don't come here for tapas. But get the duck burger, and only the duck burger if you insist upon eating here even after reading my review. The octopus is worth trying too if you're feeling adventurous and must have an appetizer. 

**Full story**:
I love tapas. They're fun and whimsical and great for conversations with friends because you share everything. You get a chance to talk about the cool flavors that are introduced to your palate with everyone. So, I was really looking forward to a great experience at 1760 which unfortunately did not occur foodwise. 

Our group of 4 was seated at the communal table after about a 10-15 minute wait with no reservation on a Saturday night (which I gave an extra half star for). 

Our overly eager waitress recommended us to order around 7-9 plates to ensure our satisifaction by the end of the meal and kept badgering us to order more, which I honestly did not appreciate. I understand that maybe she didn't want us to wait on the  kitchen by waiting to gauge our appetites after the first few tapas but she was pretty persistent to the point of annoyance. 

Anyway, I could've overlooked the service for a better rating had the food been worth it but sadly for the price that 1760 charged, I don't really recommend this place at all. 

We ordered the octopus, nori-roasted potatoes, burrata on grilled toast, short ribs, duck sandwich and carrot cake. The octopus was tasty and had interesting seasonings. The nori-roasted potatoes were nothing special. Just slightly crispy potatoes with an avocado mousse sauce that was very lacking in flavor. The burrata was one of the better tapas although it didn't wow me either. The short ribs fell short for me as well. Yes, they were tender and falling apart but there was so little sauce on the plate and it was all centered around the roasted veggies so I didn't really get to marry the two as much as I wanted. 

The most interesting dish that I think would be worth getting if you decided to come here was the fried duck sandwich which was more of a burger. It is a large portion and worth your money. The fried duck is rich and succulent and juicy when you cut into it. However, the slaw was overly acidic for me. It didn't pair that well with the duck but it did help cut the richness. 

Also, the pink lady apple in some sort of hibiscus concoction that we received before the rest of our tapas at the beginning of our meal from the kitchen was a joke. It literally tasted just like a plain pink lady apple. There was no contrast in flavors or textures or anything. That should have already been a huge indicator to me but I decided to overlook it since it was free.

The carrot cake dessert was also such a horrendous dessert. The carrot gelato was good but should be renamed pumpkin pie gelato because that's exactly what it tasted like. I did not appreciate the bland, unseasoned, shaved carrot in the dessert at all. The cake portion was kind of like what I'd imagine eating hamster bedding would be like. I was eating shreds of moist and unflavored cake. 

All in all, 1760 had all the right fixings to be a great tapas restaurant. The drinks menu is 3x longer than the actual menu. The decor is hip and trendy yet still very classy, perfect for pulling in both the younger and older crowd. And the restaurant is situated in a popular street and neighborhood of SF. However, when I come to a tapas restaurant, I expect the food to be explosive in flavor to make up for the small portions and high cost. 1760 just did not fare well in this category. The food was not exquisite. My expectations for tapas bar jumped to the roof after dining at The Playground in Santa Ana just about a month ago and 1760 was the unfortunate first victim for comparison. 

In my opinion, you would be better off dining anywhere else in SF.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I would use this place as a wine bar. The food is very good and so called tapas style, so you can enjoy different yummy dishes with different kinds of glass wine.
Service was very nice as well.
author: Ted H.

description: I have celiac disease and this place always makes me feel safe and comfortable. They are always clear about what is celiac safe on the menu. I love it here. Food is delicious. Brussels sprouts are awesome.
author: Esther J.

description:
LOVE, LOVE, LOVE! My new favorite place! Parking sucks, but the food is well worth it. The service was great and the food was excellent. I loved everything we ordered. 

Shishito Peppers. castelvetrano olive. hazelnut. smoked sea salt-seasoned well and the nuts gave it a great texture

Lobster Ceviche. caramelized coconut. pineapple. kaffir lime-cooked perfectly and very tasty. Not over powered by anything and I can taste the lobster flavor.

SRF Beef Tartare. marcona almond purée. herbs. Thai vinaigrette-this tasted like Vietnamese beef carpaccio 

Brussels Sprouts. crispy onion. aromatic herbs-comes with other greens and crumbled egg yolk. Very good.

Fried Duck Sandwich. slaw. pickles. spicy aioli-this was huge and the heaviest dish off the menu. Super yummy

Can't wait to come back and try other stuff, especially the Uni pasta.
author: Karen H.

description: Fantastic cocktails and creative menu.  Food is good but this place is way overpriced for the quality and quantity of the dishes.  The coconut ravioli is a perfect example of this
author: Samir K.

description:
Holy shit! This place is mind blowing and I can't believe it only has four stars on Yelp. The food is to die for, the ambiance is trendy and romantic, the service is prompt and friendly. 

We had the shishito peppers, lollipop kale, eggplant. The lollipop kale with red currant sauce is out of this world, and I'd never had anything like their mackerel with eggplant before. 

The drinks are great too. Try the blackberry mint drink or the lavender mint tea if you're looking for something non alcoholic.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Second time was the charm!

They've changed up the menu just a bit and it definitely does not disappoint.

A must:

-Lollipop Kale

-Fried Duck Sandwich

-Grilled Pork Ribs

-Basil Mezcal Cocktail

-Pear Ginger Campari

The sommelier here is also amazing.


As always - service is 100% on point. Everyone is cordial and genuine. The high ceilings make the space feel open. The dark interior gives it an intimate and chic ambiance. Make a reservation - you won't be sorry.

I came with my friend from out of town and I will definitely be coming back ! Thank you for a wonderful, delicious meal 1760!
author: Selina W.

description:
Wow, with the accompaniment of a special girl, this pescatarian of 15 years broke bad for the pork belly. I have to say regret was by far the last thing on my mind. Hand's down the best upscale bang for your buck in San Francisco. Wonderfully memories! 

Great staff as well.
author: Robinson P.

description:
Best dinner I've had in a long time. Blew my mind and even happier this is around the corner from me. 

Perfectly cooked food, good food, and not-trying-so-hard food. 

Pricing is reasonable and in line with what I would expect for the type of food served and how good it was. Whereas a place like State Bird Provisions felt like a waste of money.  

Wow. Also the food came out fast!

Impressed with every dish. I went in with no expectations and left extremely happy. 

All the dishes were great that we had. The dungeness crab, pork belly, fried duck sandwich, corn ravioli, ribs, octopus, buccatini, desserts blah blah. 

Try it.
author: Mimi C.

description: I purchased a Gilt City coupon for this place and I had high hopes. We started off with the biscuits which were absolutely delicious, however our meals were disappointed. I got the Rock Shrimp brunch entree and it was the smallest entree I've ever seen. We had to get another order of biscuits because I wasn't remotely full, I'm just glad I didn't have to pay 18 bucks for it. We got a bottle of champagne that was supposed to come with a "carafe" of juice, and instead we got approximately a cup of juice in a carafe that wasn't even a quarter full. We of course ran out of juice, and we when asked for more we were charged $3. I enjoyed this meal simply because I didn't pay much for it, but I won't be back.
author: Caitland B.

description: I love the ambience of 1760. I took my boyfriend here for his birthday. Reservations can be made pretty easily online @ open table. I made reservations for 2 the night before and they had our table waiting for us when we got there. we ordered 5 items. At first I thought we might not have enough food, but we were definitely stuffed! the uni Bucatini and gnocchi dumpling were super heavy. The pork ribs were pretty tender but they were super saucy so I wasn't as big a fan. Overall, the experience was great. I thought their prices were also quite reasonable compared to other SF restaurants. It's a nice upscale place, but not as fancy as fine dining.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Didn't have a chance to try the food there.

How often do you make a reservation and once at the restaurant are being said by the waitress every 5 minutes - for at least 30 minutes - that your "table is paying right now and should be ready in 5 minutes".
After 30min and no apologies or what's however we simply decided to leave.
