The vietnamese place next door, Co Nam (on Polk & Clay) is awesome, I highly recommend it!
author: Morgan L.

description:
I don't really have much to say about this place since it didn't really impress or disappoint me. My whole dining experience is good, but non-impressive. The food here is decent, but nothing spectacular. I have to say though- I do the love their Lobster Ceviche. 

Service is friendly and nice and the decoration/ambiance is lovely.
author: Becky W.

description:
Wow. Food was spot on. Cocktails were delicious. Must order the uni buccatelli, pork belly, lobster ceviche, fried duck sandwich. We also ordered other dishes, however, I can't remember which ones. It's not cheap but I find it worthy. 

The food servers described what was on the plate before eating. I feel like the pictures won't do the dishes' justice. One disappointing dish was the potato dish. It was SO tiny. One bite and you're done. We had 3 people total sharing lots of food and I remembered this one being the awkward one of who should even attempt taking a bite. We shared one dessert; dissemble banana peanut butter bread with ice cream. I was so full that I felt like I didn't enjoy it to the fullest, but damn, it was a cool dish. It wasn't your typical dessert plate. 

In conclusion, I'd love to come back here with other friends. I'd recommend at least 3 to a group so that you can try everything without over stuffing yourself. I saw couples in the center isle. It made the restaurant romantic.
author: Margherita S.

description:
Very impressed! 

One of my good friends and I went to dinner at 1760 last night and absolutely loved everything about it - from the modern and completely-open classy ambiance to the friendly and extremely helpful service to the delicious and avant-garde food. I was smitten and will definitely be back for more. 

Now let's dive into the good stuff - the food and cocktails. When I head to a somewhat upscale restaurant, I usually prefer to stick to wine instead of cocktails. However, don't make that mistake and miss out on these divinely concocted delicious drinks. Each cocktail is made with such effort and specific ingredients to cater to your mood. I asked for something refreshing to remove the stress of a tough day and the waiter recommended a Black Current Bramble - wowza! And for my second drink, I asked for something with a bit more pizzazz yet refreshing Kumquat-Coconut - also wowza! My friend got the 1760 and the Pear-Ginger and loved them as well. 

As for the food, I highly recommend ordering ~ 3 items per person (1 heavy one and 2 lighter ones). Our favorites were: Brussel Sprouts (this isn't your everyday brussel sprouts with bacon... the texture alone makes this dish worth trying!), Cavatelli (one of the best pastas I've had with tender pork cheek meat!), the Fried Duck Sandwich (tender duck meat with a plethora of spices and delicious spicy aioli), and the Lobster Ceviche (it's actually not raw unlike most ceviches. It's slightly cooked and very yummy).

My friend had dined here before and also recommended the Octopus and the Hamachi Crudo. 

So on your next stroll on Polk Street, if you're looking for a delicious and classy dinner without any pretentiousness, definitely check out 1760!

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
1760 for the win! 

I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here - from start to finish.  We had to wait quite a while for a table, but the hostesses were sweet and consistently checked in with us.  

The cocktails should not be skipped - they are hand crafted and beautifully presented. Particularly noteworthy were the pear ginger, garam masala, and peach buck - amazing!

I recommend going with a group so you can taste multiple dishes, you will not regret it. We tried the lobster ceviche (stellar), hamachi crudo, burrata, nori potatoes, fried duck sandwich (so good), cavatelli, and beef short ribs.  All were outstanding.

Props to you 1760 for delivering on all aspects - the friendly, attentive, and engaged staff, the brilliant cocktails, and the exciting, perfectly executed food won't soon be forgotten!
author: Brianna M.

description:
Ok, so you know that 'hot new guy' in the office that could get away with stealing your lunch and cutting you off during a meeting? Well I feel that's how 1760 is right now. 
It's the handsome new guy on Polk street, and boy does he stand out. 
The interior is clean and modern. With high ceiling and glossy counter tops with ample spacing between seats. 

However, the food and service lacks 1769's authentic charm. The food is good, but portions are small than expected and costly. There's no "wow" stand out dish but everything is decent. 

The service on the other hand seemed not in sync. I get that they are new and trying to find a rhythm that works but they will need to find it soon. For example, my friend who ordered the fried duck sandwich was patiently waiting for her meal while i got the Uni pasta first. As we sat at the table with the Uni pasta dish in front of me, no server stopped to ask if they would like for us to bring out the sandwich. Instead, when we flagged down our server to ask where her meal was, he replied "oh we like to pace our meals and didn't want to crowd the table".
author: Youna K.

description:
A neighborhood knockout.

From the magnetic minds of Acquerello, comes a perfect sister addition that Polk desperately needed. 

The space is open, inviting, and exudes of sense of understanding of the people it serves.

A long bar runs down the line while seating dots the larger half of the restaurant.

Christopher Longoria spearheads the bar and has developed a confident and imaginative drink list. Allowing each of the spirits to shine, there never lacks a desire to continue to sip down the list.

Personal favorite: The Peach Buck. 

The food is playful, and can be correlated to the appetite of your choice. Small dishes allow you to cultivate your own playlist with the Fried Duck Sandwich as the crescendo. This sandwich is lethal. Incredibly rich, with a strong spicy kick with the slaw, it has easily become a weekly tradition. 

1760 has been a long time coming. As a resident of this neighborhood for years, I am thrilled to have this addition to an already incredible location.
author: Mike K.

description:
Brought my husband here for his birthday on a Thursday night for dinner! Everything was delicious!!! 

The restaurant doesn't have a big menu, mainly dishes to share. Our waiter suggested 3 dishes to share for 2 people but we ended up ordering 5 dishes and 2 cocktails with 1 dessert to share. The dishes were excellent but not very big. I loved munching on the shishito peppers- they were so addictive and yummy! The nori crusted potatoes, Hokkaido scallop with uni and caviar, crispy octopus and beef tartar were simply AMAZING! 

To end our delicious savory food we shared the milk chocolate ganache, it was sooo good!!! 

Definitely recommend this place and will be back for more :)
author: Vickie Z.

description: I was here on Halloween so as you can imagine, there were a lot of interesting characters inside and outside. I had a strawberry cocktail as well as a slew of dishes. They had this crab avocado dish which was delicious. Everything else was just ok. Service was lacking. Our waitress was nice but was much more interested in what was going on outside. She spent about half or the time we were there standing in front of the window like a cat starring outside. She would be there for 15 minutes without moving. I was a bit surprised that after doing that repeatedly, management didn't say something to her.
author: Diane M.

description:
Overall, nice addition to the SF scene. Great cocktails and well priced menu. 

We tried the lobster ceviche, uni bucatini, brussel sprouts, beef tartare, and duck sandwich. The only slight miss was the duck sandwich, partly because it took so long to get after the previous course and the slaw in sandwich was refrigerator cold.

The 1760 cocktail was really interesting, never had cumin in a drink before. 

Great service and I liked the layout of the restaurant.
author: Derrick V.

description: Love this spot - super tasty small plates menu. Can easily rack up a pricey bill but that seems to be the case at most places in SF. Ambiance is nice too - highly recommend the bar if you don't have a reservation and the hostess manages it well so you know wait times and it's never overcrowded.
author: Maya C.

description:
Possibly the best restaurant I have ever been too. The food was BEAUTIFUL AND DELICIOUS! If you were only going to get one thing here (then you're missing out, but anyways..)GET THE SHORT RIBS. WOW. And the mixology bar is cool too, but I'd stay away form the house cocktail that has cumin in it. Not a fan of that one, but the blood orange one was great. 

Also, the carrot cake = MONEY.
author: Nicole O.

description:
1760 elevates the Polk Gulch food scene with innovative takes on Italian classics and a world-class bar and wine program-- it is truly not to be missed. 

From the moment you check in with the hostess, Isabella, you are transported to a warm, yet unmistakably stylish dining experience that could easily be in Milan, New York, or Tokyo. How fortunate for San Francisco that this treasure is here! The service is impeccable and attentive, with your needs tacitly intuited. Coursing is appropriate and not rushed.

The seasonally-inspired menu is delicious and changes often, so I can't comment on particular dishes, as I haven't been back to 1760 in a few months due to travel. Whether you're a pescatarian, staunch carnivore, or vegan, 1760 easily accommodates your preferences. My husband had his bachelor party dinner here [at the communal table] and all attendees were delighted with their experiences, despite their varied palates and dietary needs. 

In addition to being a lifelong gourmet, GianPaulo, the proprietor, is one of the most knowledgable, yet unassuming oenophiles and happens to be a trained sommelier. Don't hesitate to consult him on your wine selection-- he is a wealth of information without any snobbery whatsoever and will be mindful of your budget. 

In short, head to 1760 for any and all conceivable occasions. I think I'll make a reservation for this evening myself!
author: Le S.

description:
RAVIOLI! You must try it! I've been here 2x now, the staff is fantastic, the vibe is casual but also good for a nice dinner/date. The cocktails are delicious and the bar staff is super friendly.

The place is always packed so get a reservation (even the bar is always full). Get a few things to share but make sure you get your OWN ravioli, trust me on this! It is TO DIE FOR.

For as good as this place is the pricing is not bad. We shared 5 items + a drink each for 2 people and the bill was about $110.
author: Amber M.

description:
Wow, wow, and more wow. We ordered seven dishes, and all were perfection on a plate. I really don't think there is anything on the menu that we wouldn't have swooned over. Hard to pick a favorite, but the lobster ceviche was pure rapture. 

And if the food weren't enough, our waiter threw it way over the top -- so knowledgeable, attentive, and beyond darling. I don't know his name -- but you know who you are, you tall, slim, shoulder-length light brown hair, adorable person, you. 

Cocktails delish, too. Go for the Stirring Hour, and stay for dinner. I promise you won't be disappointed!
author: E. G.

description:
1760 was one of the final stops on my birthday train.

We came in on Saturday, 9/14 and found out they just opened that Monday. WHAT?! With almost every table full, and the professionalism of their staff, you would have thought 1760 had been established for years. 

Caro S. & I were sat at the large community table at the front of the restaurant. Community tables are my new favorite thing. I love to people watch, and this is the perfect excuse to do so. 

Because we were celebrating, we started with drinks. I enjoyed the Strawberry Shrub so much, I stuck with it for the evening. It was not as fruity as the cocktails I typically drink, but really refreshing. Caro opted for the Mango & Spice. I think our drink orders fit our personalities pretty well.

I let Caro take the lead when ordering, because I'm definitely known as the picky one. She did not dissapoint. While I didn't have any of the ceviche (see her review for more on that), and didn't care for the greek yogurt with sauteed peaches, I did enjoy everything else-

Salad w/hanger steak, caramelized onion, grape and arugula: pretty sure we were fighting for bites at the end. I think next time, we'll have to each order our own. 

Gnocchi: So good, I practically liked the bowl. The gnocchi was accompanied with pork belly and a red sauce. For my humble pallate, it was a nice spin on spaghetti and meatballs. 

Then Robert, our server told me that since it was my b-day, dessert was on the house. Say what?! I ordered the Angel food cake with strawberry and brown sugar whipped cream. You read that right... Brown sugar whipped cream. Before we dug in, we both sampled the whipped cream to test the potency of the flavor. Three words- Oh. Em. Gee! SO good!! There was a strawberry drizzle with basil seeds over the angel food cake. The flavors complimented each other amazingly. 

Thank you Robert, 1760, and Caro S. for making my birthday so special.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Yum! Great service and delicious food. We tried the Della Fattoria Bread, Bucatini, and Grilled Pork Ribs. I was highly skeptical when the waitress said that their dishes were good for sharing, but she was right! We left SO full. 

We started with the bread which was toasted and very tasty paired with the toppings - I found the toppings to be a little bit oily but I still really liked it. The Bucatini was amazing! Creamy and heavy but incredibly flavorful - I'm so happy I tried this dish! We finished with the ribs which were average; the meat was cooked well but I didn't enjoy the taste as much as our previous dishes. I'd love to come back and try the lobster ceviche (with of course the Bucatini again!)
author: Jamie B.

description: This place is a nice surprise. Great corner location, open kitchen, wide selection of libations. The extra bonus: the staff. The staff are super friendly and attentive. I had the pleasure meeting Uuzi (bartender with glasses and amazing dark hair) for my first visit. The atmosphere is very laid back and this place can easily be anyone's local go to if they lived in the neighborhood. I had the Har Gow Cavatelli, a nice light shrimp pasta dish. The pasta is hand made in house, the portion was perfect and seemed light but I was completely full/satisfied after my last bite. My first cocktail was uniquely made. That to me speaks volumes when it comes to a great bartender. Customer comes first and to meet their needs. Remix on a bourbon cocktail but was tailored specifically for what I wanted. The next cocktails were the blueberry sage, that drink was tasty but damn it creeps up pretty quick. Thank you 1760 for a nice Sunday night cap! I can't wait to come back and try the pork belly!
author: Trish Z.

description:
Made a reservation for 4 ppl on a Sat. night. Only options were for a 7pm reservation or something for 9pm so I think this place is getting pretty popular so be sure to make reservations ahead of time. 

The menu is mostly small bites/sharing plates and it is listed from lightest to heaviest (starting from light appetizers to more entree/heartier items). All the items on the menu sounded delish so we all got a cocktail and ordered some appetizers to share. Here's what we ordered and what I thought:

To Drink:
-Pear-Ginger 
-The 1760 
-Mango And Spice 

How were the drinks?
-Pear-Ginger: This was my drink and I really liked it. I think they infused the pear with the ice cube so as it melts, it doesn't water down the drink but more pear flavor is released. Really refreshing!
-The 1760: My bf had this *i think?* It was ok. Mezcal always has a band-aid like taste to me. This was ok as it was more of that "smokey" flavor mezcal has and the mint helped lightened this flavor up.
-Mango And Spice: My friend had this and it he said it was good. I only had a sip and it tasted sweet and mango-y.

To Eat:
-Lobster Ceviche caramelized coconut, pineapple, coriander
-Brussels Sprouts crispy onion, aromatic herbs
-SRF Beef Tartare marcona almond, herbs, chile
-Grilled Pork Belly gigante bean, radicchio slaw, carrots
-Fried Duck Sandwich slaw, pickles, spicy aioli

How was the Food! 0_0
-Lobster Ceviche: really good! Although the portions seem like its more for 2 people? We had 4 ppl fighting for bits of lobster but it had lots of that good creamy coconut flavor.
-Brussels Sprouts: I love brussel sprouts by default but these were really good! Something about those aromatic herbs made these taste heartier, I would go back for these sprouts!
-SRF Beef Tartare: Very delicate flavors but so yum! Again a little bit hard to share with 4 ppl but we all had one bite and it was delish.
-Grilled Pork Belly: Was highly anticipated but I think this was just ok? I didn't care for the bean mixture the pork belly was sitting on. 
-Fried Duck Sandwich: HIGHLIGHT of the dinner. We ordered two of these so us couples can share. Honestly I think I could have ate 2 of these myself. the duck was savory and soooo good. I would go back again and again just for this! 

Overall, nice place to catch up on drinks and sharing plates. It is a little pricey, I think we tried like half the menu but if you stick to the duck sandwich and one appetizer and one cocktail its not that bad price-wise.
author: Christine W.

description:
fantastic. fun. delicious. trendy. you won't regret it. 

one of those gems that makes you justify living in SF and paying crazy rent and everything else. "i live in sf for the good food!!"

great to go with a group of 4 so you can try more dishes. they recco 7-8 dishes for a party of 4, we were eager to try more and got 11 and were too full to finish the last 3.. but i love leftovers so not a big deal for us.

ambiance/decor: trendy, chic, dark. good ((double)) date or date spot!

outstanding dishes:
** LOBSTER CEVICHE*** i couldnt stop raving about this for the rest of the night and im not typically big on seafood.

all very good
Lobster Ceviche. caramelized coconut. pineapple. kaffir lime     17
Brussels Sprouts. crispy onion. aromatic herbs     9
Crispy Octopus. roasted peanuts. avocado. potatoes     18
Nori-Roasted Potatoes. charred serrano aioli. avocado. olio nuovo     9
Roasted Carrots. coriander honey. goat cheese. pistachio     9
Hamachi Crudo. bulgogi vinaigrette. 'siracha'. celery. yuzu. orange     17
Maccheroni. dungeness crab. green onion-serrano chile pesto. lemon     19

only disappointed/underwhelmed by the following 2.  FRIED duck sandwich?? I was hoping this was my new jam.. but I think my imagination of the magnificence got the best of me. ((Fried chicken (not duck, I know) @ Naked lunch -- AHMAZING).
Fried Duck Sandwich. slaw. pickles. spicy aioli     16
Cavatelli. vinegar-braised pork cheek. scorched tomato. parmesan     17
author: Melody T.

description: The cocktails were really light and refreshing -- very summery. All the dishes were amazing. The brussel sprouts were the best I've had. The duck burger is a must get.
author: Thomas C.

description: Fun place for a weekday unwind. I'd say it vibes Nopa, but with convenient location and easy reservations. Make sure to try the peppers and the pork ribs!
author: Linda X.

description:
It's definitely worth making a reservation for 1760 on Open Table. 

Fans of duck swoon over the duck sandwich, but for vegetarians/pescatarians, I can recommend instead the Lobster Ceviche, Brussels Sprouts (yay, no bacon!). Crab Maccheroni, and the Warm Banana Bread with Chunkey Monkey ice cream. All standout dishes. Service was attentive, and the sommelier was helpful. They sell 375 ml bottles, which are perfect for sharing between two. 

A tip: like at many establishments, the dishes are listed in order of "lightest" to "heaviest," however, it can be deceiving. The Brussels Sprouts were actually quite large, and could be considered an entree size even though they are one of the least expensive items on the menu and considered a small plate. It's worth asking your server to give you a size estimation of dishes, versus blindly following the "2 sides, 1 entree per person" scale.
author: Marie F.

description:
Lobster ceviche, lollipop kale, crispy octopus, and the uni pasta. Everything was delicious, though the kale was on the salty side (even for me, and I love salt).

Cocktails were delicious, too - the garam masala & cardamom was a highlight. Overall, one of the best dinners we've had in San Francisco.

Be warned that parking in this neighborhood is a nightmare.
author: Akshay S.

description: Nice place, easy to reach, parking can be problem like all over in SF. Seating looks like it is not good for groups but I am sure they can arrange it, too. Staff was helpful and nice. Food is to share, but if you're looking to get full, here is not for you! If you dont like raw meat, dont order the beef! I think, duck burger was quite delicious, presentation was interesting too. Duck meat is however a bit different than I ate before, but I like it this way. Roasted chicken and pesto souce was the best one between our orders. If you want to try different place and wnjoy your night, give here a chance
author: Angela K.

description:
This place was a great find!!! They have really delicious and fresh food.  My only qualms were that I do wish that some of the portions were a bit bigger (tartare).  The lobster ceviche was delicious, short ribs were my bfs favorite, macherroni was good with bits of crab meat, LOVEEE the chocolate ganache dessert, tartare...wish they had more meat hidden under all that salad...salad was not that tasty..had inedible greens like basil leaves.  REALLY wish they had the bucatini...cries...  ALso octopus was dry and chewy...would not order again.

Great service and great decor. Wide open modern space.
author: Em F.

description:
Went for a friend's belated birthday dinner.  Here are our thoughts:

PROS
- Lovely interior.  Layout was great: long bar, communal table, dining area, additional wash station OUTside of bathrooms.
- Noise level was fantastic.  My friend and I could hear each other without having to shout and/or lean in for the whole meal.  You can hear the excited hum or the other diners (pretty busy for a Monday night) without it being a deafening roar.
- Attentive waitstaff.
- Full bar.
- Good-sized wine menu, including half bottles.
- THE FOOD.  Amazing!  

Sliced Hamachi. pluots. yuzu kosho. puffed rice: Hamachi was fresh and was an interesting pair with the thinly sliced sweet pluots.  Not sure that the yuzu kosho or the puffed rice really added anything to the plate.

Dungeness crab. watermelon gazpacho.  finger lime. sea grass: Fresh crab, slightly spicy, not too sweet.

Hanger steak. caramelized onion. grape. arugula: One of my favorite dishes of the evening.

Ravioli with sweet potato and brown butter sauce: The other favorite.

CONS
- Each shared plate probably had (at most) about 6 small bites of food.  The server recommended 4-5 dishes for the 2 of us.  Thank goodness we had eaten full meals throughout the day.  Otherwise, we could've left still starving at the end of the meal.
- Small list of available wines by the glass.
- Dessert menu was... meh.  Nothing really tickled our fancy, but we ordered the milk chocolate ganache.  It was a deconstructed milk chocolate s'more.  Meh.
- Our (young) server spoke to us like we were 5-year-old children (slow and kind of patronizing).  Perhaps she thought we had never eaten out at a fine dining establishment?  

TIPS
- Take a cab/Uber/Lyfft/etc.  Parking in this part of town SUCKS ASS.  
- They only serve espresso drinks.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
My husband and I were visiting from L.A. and decided to stop by 1760 for a "quick bite and a drink". We were immediately in love with the great ambience and vibe of the place as soon as we walked in the door. 
The food was excellent, the cocktails were superb and the mixologists were incredibly knowledgable, outgoing and genuinely friendly. The variety on the menu was so appetizing that our "small snack" turned into the Sunchoke Soup Shot, Hamachi Crudo, Beef Tartare and Brussel Sprouts. I highly recommend them all.
To top it off, the cocktails were insanely delicious and the mixologists behind the bar took the time to not only recommend different drinks, but also break down the different ingredients and concepts behind each drink. You don't get that type of service and friendliness anywhere nowadays. Needless to say our "quick bite and drink" turned into staying the entirety of the evening, until last call. 
GO TO 1760. YOU WONT REGRET IT.
author: MEGAN T.

description:
Super happy I finally made it into this neighborhood gem! My roomates and I were able to walk-in at 7pm on a tuesday and get seating at the communal table. We decided to split the brussels, crispy octopus, BBQ pork belly and duck sandwich. Everythind was DELICIOUS and nothing was ordinary. Even the brussels were special with the addition of crumbled egg yolk and crispy onions. The pork belly was a flavor explosion in my mouth. The octopus was simulatenously juicy and crispy and I loved the addition of the peanuts. My least favorite was the duck sandwich just because I thought it was incredibly rich, but it sounds like that is everyone else's favorite so what do I know?? 

What a great addition to the neighborhood! Polk street definitely needed a little class and 1760 is serving it.
author: Molly S.

description:
There are few times when great service is paired with great attention to detail in service. Dinner menu host's wonderful wines, cocktails, appetizers, and shared entrees. We were celebrating that evening and they really made it special. You will be missing out if you don't make time for this experience.
Thank you 1760! We had a great time and many compliments to the chef and wait staff.
author: G A.

description:
We really enjoyed our experience at 1760. The menu is fascinating and meant to be shared. 

Hamachi crudo, lobster ceviche, roasted carrots, Nori roasted potatoes, and bucatini (uni). Warm banana bread w/chunky monkey for dessert. 

Everything was really tasty. I could eat the lobster ceviche everyday all day. 

The atmosphere was classy yet casual and had a younger vibe. Service, top notch. Highly recommend!
author: Brad C.

description:
I'm giving only one star because no matter how many I order I will be still hungry. The price is too too too high for the amount of food I get. It tastes good yes but it's not filling at all. $16 for a tiny amount of ceviche!!!! Come on!!!! Then come the small warm tasty peach, it was more of a tease than a meal!!! Then the $22 hanger steak, then the $19 pork belly, then the warm potato salad... I'm really still hungry. 
I won't come back.
author: Cristelle M.

description: Great atmosphere, wonderful service and fab food. I personally love tapa style dining where you can try different things and share them so 1760 is right up my ally.
author: Kristan B.

description:
This place offers one of the hippest experiences you would expect from a new San Francisco establishment. They offer a lot of creative (and delicious) cocktails, and the decor while minimalist is very modern and not caught up in the cliches of Edison Bulbs, Mason Jars, and Rag Napkins.

What really sets this place apart from the rest is their treatment of flavors. While other restaurants seem to be drawing inspiration from the same playbook, 1760 is offering something new kind of like how the Read Option was a new offense that took the NFL by surprise. The other restaurants all seem to be offering similar takes on the new "it" proteins (Braised Short Rib much? for example), while 1760 isn't afraid to take an ingredient and prepare it in a more interesting way.

Here I feel like they are a lot more experimental with their flavors, which might be a little bit of a shock at first and dare i say, maybe a little offputting. But this is where I'll defend it as a place that "underground" foodies should go. Where a place like NOPA might be upfront and obvious with its use of flavors, so that even a diner who only goes out for special occasions can appreciate the use of new and interesting ingredients, a place like 1760 might be more suited for someone who understands subtlety and unconventional combinations a little more. (No knock to NOPA, I think that place is fantastic but I think might be for a different audience)

For example, for our complementary bite, we received a slice of apple that had been prepared with a dash of tamarind sauce. In my mind, I thought that this would have gone down the tart direction. But instead they flipped it around and actually highlighted the sweetness of the apple. If blindfolded and not told what I was eating, I could've sworn I was eating persimmon. That really got me on my toes and prepared me for the rest of the meal. The short rib I had was so tender, but at the same time browned to create a nice almost crisped texture. The last time I had something like that was at Benu.

The prevalent theme I discovered across all the dishes we tried (the Scallops, the Fried Octopus, the Short Rib, Ravioli Uovo) is that they were all elegantly plated and their treatment was more of an approach to flavors that homogenized them instead of having certain ingredients dominate as the overarching flavor. It was a subtle approach that challenged me as a diner and left me wanting more. I will certainly go back and recommend this place to anyone who is sort of jaded by some of the other dining options that are out there, but still looking for that cool and upbeat city vibe.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
i have wanted to go to Acquerello for a while now but have been waiting for a justified reason for going to such a fancy restaurant. lucky for me, their sister restaurant has recently popped up and is has a more bistro like setting. being the sister restaurant to Acquerello was already hype enough for me to get excited about 1760 but then i learned that the chef,  prior to coming to SF, worked with Michael Voltaggio (of Top Chef fame) at Ink as well. i had high hopes for 1760 and i'm happy to say that they delivered. aside from such well conceptualized and executed food, the ambiance is sleek and unpretentious and the service was stellar. the staff, from the host to the busboy, were super friendly and made the experience even more pleasurable. i cannot wait to go back! 

especially notable is the lobster ceviche (so many different complimenting flavors) and the beef tartare (super marbled meat paired with marcona almond butter and fresh herbs...mMmmmm). we also had the uni bucatini and the brussel sprouts. all very good!
author: Regina C.

description:
Eh, I'm conflicted. I'm thrilled Parrilla is gone and a beautiful new restaurant took its place. 

PROS:
It isn't Parrilla.
Beautiful restaurant.
Friendly, knowledgeable wait staff, bar included.
Interesting, well balanced cocktails.
Tasty food

CONS:
WAY overpriced. I'm not cheap, but the prices, for what you get, are ridiculous.
Very limited wine menu, and nothing under $11 a glass.
Teeny tiny portions. Like, SUPER small. 
Really loud, difficult to carry a conversation.
No Grey Goose or Bulleit. For shame, people.

We had 2 cocktails each, two plates and a dessert, had a bill of $100 and left hungry. 

In summary, I would go back if:
A., I wasn't very hungry and 
B., I wasn't paying the bill.
author: Gina L.

description: Very very good food! Make sure you make a reservation. We ended up sitting at the "community table" which was fine but it would have been nice to get our own table if we planned ahead a little bit better. Everything on the menu is crafted with care, I love how the menu is layed out too from lightest to heartiest, smallest to biggest. The brussels sprouts were some of the best I've ever tasted (and I barely like them in the first place). The place is a little bit pricy, but if you're in the mood to splurge on some great food you should definitely check it out!
author: Stephen D.

description:
Went  here on a Thursday night around 6:45. We were seated right away with the stipulation that we would be finished by 8:00 for their next reservation.  The place was about half full when we were seated but was completed booked when we left at 8. The kitchen is an open kitchen which makes it fun to watch. 

The cocktail list is very unique and they had an adequate selection of 'by the glass' wine,  The menu had small plates and a handful of larger plates. I did do some research to translate the menu before we came so I knew what everything was. We had the Hamachi Crudo and the burrata cheese as appetizers. The crudo was light and amazing. The burrata was good but nothing special. We finished our meal with the fried duck sandwich. It was AMAZING. I would definitely come back to get a whole sandwich to myself.  

The service was excellent from the hostess, to the waiter, to the wine pourer, etc.  Everyone was extremely attentive and pleasant.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I was super excited to check this place out.  It certainly did not disappoint, although my mother was a little criticial about the portions and prices, she did enjoy the food and the drinks.

We didn't have the duck sandwich.  Yes, I ruined it for my mother and brother because I don't like duck.  But we had about 6 items, and though they were all tasty, some stood out more than others.  We really enjoyed the lobster ceviche, tuna sashimi and bucatini.  The peanut butter and jelly panna cotta was so good it made you want to lick the bowl.

The place is like a concrete box, so it does tend to get loud, but I loved the sleekness of the space adn the giant windows, and service was really great too.

P.S.  Do not dare leave without at least trying 2 (not one) cocktails.  I don't know who is in charge of the cocktail "program" there but they are on point! 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Jennifer H.

description: One of our favorite restaurants in the city. They no longer serve uni pasta but that was by far the most delicious plate I've ever tried. Nice staff friendly ambience.
author: Sophia N.

description:
1760- a perfect addition to the already amazing Polk street.  It adds such an eloquent touch.  
Service-perfection-attentive and friendly just enough attention but not overwhelming 
Ambiance-low lighting, perfect for romantic dates or just intimate for a nice dinner out with friends, can fit large parties, nice layout can get extremely packed 
Food-ahhhmazing each dish is flavor-fully packed! YES flavor-fully! :) lol 
2 dishes were complimentary which were great:
Pears marinated in lychee juice-yum &
A Brussels sprouts concoction that was to die for! 
Was with a group of 4 and we each got an appetizer and main entree and shared all.  My personal favorites were the burrata-grilled bread with garbanzo beans with a sliced pear on top but full of so much flavor, every bite was melt in your mouth good.  The fried duck sandwich was also a must eat at this place.  Bun soft n grilled to perfection topped with slaw spicy aoli and of course fried duck.  I left 1760 so pleased and full, wish I would have saved room for dessert.  I hear it's amazing. Most importantly lets not forget the dranks...a little pricey but worth every penny.  Quality, Strong, and Tastey! 
Highly recommend and don't forget to make reservations!
author: Adrianna P.

description:
Hamachi crudo was the absolute bestest dish! Seriously! We ordered 5 dishes for 2 people: octopus, fingerling potatoes, hanger steak, hamachi were all cooked to perfection, incredible fusion of flavors.
Def 4-5 dishes is good for 2 people as they are tasting plate sizes.
Highly recommend the 1760 cocktail too. Cocktails sit around $12-$14.
Definitely coming back. Reservation is recommended.
author: Van-Anh N.

description: Yeah, this place nailed the cocktails we ordered--and we came back for more.  We stopped by here before our reservation at their sister restaurant, Acquerello to have a cocktail.  The cocktail menu was creative and the flavor-meshing was inventive as well.  Plus they were just dang good!  We didn't order food because of a big meal ahead of us.  After dinner we decided to come back and get another cocktail to finish the evening--we weren't driving, so why not?  The main bartender asked questions and made a drink on the spot for one of my friends who wanted a digestif.  Very nice.  Just a great spot--yes the cocktails are expensive ($13-14 per) but I think that's the going rate for nice bars/restaurants in the city anyway.
author: Brad D.

description: Slow slow slow and everything is so mini. Server was not being cool either as if us waiting 30min in between each dish is normal.
author: Oanh N.

description: We liked a lot about 1760 -- great looking space, lovely waitress, sexy booth. The cocktails tasted good but had so little alcohol that I didn't get tipsy after one -- probably good for my early wakeup tomorrow, but a little disappointing.  We LOVED the crispy octopus; most of the other dishes (burrata, hamachi, kale) were good but not great.  However, I give them points for originality.
author: Robin W.

description:
I've been to 1760 twice.  Both times I was delighted with the intoxicating meld of Acquerello's unique Italian sensibilities, and a more casual "tapas" style of dining.  Chef Tortosa is a master of flavor. The beef tartare was out of this world good, as was the duck sandwich.  But everything we tried was so unique in flavor that I really can't pick just one dish to say "that's it" - that's the one.  They are all so good.

The restaurant is not inexpensive, but neither is it unreasonably priced.  The menu consists of "small plates" which can be shared; some being a bite per person, others being heartier in composition.  When I took my family of four, we ate through the entire menu and spent only $400 or so with tip.  The.  Whole.  Menu.  And I plan on doing it again soon.  Wine list is stellar, as is the service. (No really, they are flawless)

Tortosa is a genius in the kitchen. The blackened brussel sprouts are magnificent.  First tried this dish (or a version thereof) at Frances, and fell in love.  Each new iteration brings delights in caramelized green goodness and varietals of bacon product.  Then there's the corn ravioli...  I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.  

And then there's the cocktails!
author: Angela L.

description: Solid food but nothing mind blowing.  Would return only for the strawberries and charcoal sponge cake dessert.  Hit or miss on the service:  first time visiting had a great waitress, second time waited 15 mins for a initial table greeting and then 30 mins for drinks to arrive.  Drinks came during the second course and waitress curtly said "our ingredients are fresh and drinks are hand muddled".  Meh.  Not worth the $$$, I much prefer stones throw, nopa, etc.
author: Courtney C.

description:
Trendy, foodie comes to Pulk Gulch. 1760 delivers on taste and atmosphere; it's clear by the packed spot that the residents in this hood have been craving a place like this. 

Do make a reservation in advance!

Plates average around $19, the staff recommends family style and 2-3 plates/person. The servings are definitely on the small side so this actually seems spot on; if it's you and another person, you'll need at least 3-4 plates.

What we tried:
1. Pan-fried duck egg. Skuna Bay salmon. meyer lemon crème fraiche  
-My notes: delicious, great complement between the egg and salmon. Light yet rich in flavor.

2. Grilled Pork Belly. gigante bean. radicchio slaw. carrots
-My notes: very tasty, good balance between firm yet soft pork, nice bean puree on the bottom.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Came here opening night with my boyfriend yesterday on 9/9/13 and had a positive dining experience!  We will definitely be back.  As one of the most anticipated restaurant openings in fall of 2013, it has the potential to be comparable to other great  New American/Californian Cuisine  restaurants in this city. As my boyfriend being a Chef who works and knows this industry VERY well, and being a food enthusiast at heart, we both combined have VERY high expectations when it comes to our dining experience.  

   The menu opening night started with lighter more refreshing dishes then moved into more savory options.  He and I had about 9 dishes total, out of 16 dishes and maybe would of ordered the whole menu if they didn't run out of some of the options. All of them were great as a whole. 

   Cocktails were great, we both had Old Fashioneds  but were disappointed to see ice machine(small) ice cubes that watered down the cocktail. 
Other great cocktails we tried were The Garam Masala and Cardamom Cocktail, and the The Yuzu Shiso Cocktail both were distinctive in flavor, and unique in their components. 


Sliced Hamachi; with Granny Smith apple, fennel and radish - was very light and refreshing dish. The ingredients blended well together and both the granny smith apple and fennel were light flavors that didn't overpower the taste of the Hamachi.
 
Lobster ceviche with caramelized coconut, pineapple, corriender:   Probably the least of my favorites, it's a very testy dish if you love coconut and fruity flavors. 

Beef tartare, Marcona almond, herbs and chile- a very unique twist on tartare, the different herbs in this dish packed transparent and well paired flavoring with every bite of beef. Although the dish said it had almonds, the almonds were butted and not as flavorful as anticipated. 

Corn Ravioli, baked potato, potato chips chives-  Overall winning dish. Executed well and can definitely  taste the sweetness  corn in the ravioli, the corn was sweet , smooth and savory. 

Grilled Pork Belly with gitante bean, radicchio slaw. and carrots : Delicious dish , raddiccho slaw seemed to be the prominent  flavor in this dish. Didn't really catch the gigante beans . As for the pork, you can never go wrong with ordering a pork belly!  

Warm potato salad with  pickled cucumber, apple and marinated soft boiled duck egg- I have never had warm potato salad, and the ingredients in this dish fused well together. No ingredient over powered another. Balanced, savory and delectable. 

Bucatini with uni, garlic, and red pepper bread crumbs: - Pasta had a great bite to it, but the taste of the Uni was over powering the rest of the ingredients. But still delicious. 

Fried duck sandwich with  slaw,pickles and spicy aioli  -THE BEST DISH OF THE NIGHT!! Duck was seasoned well and cooked perfectly. The bun for this sandwich was toasted to the right consistency. The slaw, pickles and aioli packed a punch of strong flavor with every bite. Mouthwatering, and over all my  favorite dish! 

Milk chocolate ganache, hickory ice cream, bourbon caramel and marshmallow- Perfect for the chocolate lover, hickory ice cream was smooth, delectable and married all the other components of the dish to compliment one another. 



Overall, I really like this place! I recommend giving it a try, there is something for everyone, especially with the adventurous palate. You wont be disappointed.  Staff is friendly, and the atmosphere is inviting.  We cant wait to be back again soon.  Excited to see where Chef Adam will take the menu and the concept as this restaurant establishes its unique identity in the upcoming months.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
Came here last night for a friends birthday dinner. We ordered a total of 8 dishes (including 2 desserts) for 3 people. None of us being overly famished, this was the right amount of food. 

Now granted conversation was so good, it does become hard to concentrate on the food. But I will say nothing really stood out to me. There never was a pause of..."Wow, that was amazing!" As a matter of fact the opposite in 2 cases. But I am still giving 4 stars for good reason, and I do recommend this restaurant. 

I wasn't a fan of 2 dishes: The brussel sprouts were a little too drenched in soy sauce and became soggy. Although good flavors were there, they need to work on the sogginess factor. 

The second dish that no one at the table enjoyed was the Bucatini uni. I ordered this because I read good reviews for it on Yelp, but I must say it was excessively fishy and really lacking another other flavor besides the ocean. Maybe we had a bad batch of sea urchin, I don't know. 

We also had the smoked pork belly, which was very good. The hanger steak with arugula and grapes, which was probably my favorite for the night. Whatever that brown puree was (caramelized onion maybe?) with the steak was phenomenal. And the grapes were a nice way to freshen up a traditional steak dish.  

We also had the hamachi dish, also good. The steak tartar, although not my favorite steak tartar in the city (Wayfare Tavern holds that record), it was still delicious. 

We couldn't decided on desserts so we ordered whatever the chocolate option was and the panna cotta take on PB & J. Both were good. 

Wine selection (by the glass) was limited, but the options were enough. Service was on point all night. The staff there really know what they're doing, I appreciate that. 

Overall, I had a good experience. None of the dishes really blew me away, but I will come back after they have been open for awhile. Give them some time to get into a groove and perfect the dishes.
author: Carlynn A.

description: Excellent food and drinks.  Service was great too. The website looks like its a fancy and potentially stuffy place but it's actually just very cool and polished inside.  The food was all good but the beef tartare is what really stood out to me. So amazing. The peppers were also good as well as the bruschetta. I can't wait to go back and try other items
author: Debbie L.

description:
If you had a big lunch and need a small dinner to close out the evening, head over to 1760.  Don't forget your expense account *wink wink*.  Fresh, creative blends of flavor await you!

We had:
Fried Duck burger - very tasty and flavorful!  A bit heavy though.  I liked the taste of the  sauces, but didn't really taste the duck itself.
Brussels Sprouts - it was fried nicely - the sauce was a bit too sour for me (from the soy-lime marinade)
Butternut Ravioli - YUM!  My favorite of the night.  Perfectly cooked ravioli with butternut cream inside.  When you bite into it, it pops in your mouth.  Not too heavy, not too water.  Sprinkled with some apple trips.  Just perfect flavors.

They did not have the Uni Bucatini - guess we will have to try that next time!

The service was excellent.  Our waitress and hostess were so accommodating!
author: Nutmeg Y.

description:
Enjoyed a beautiful birthday dinner here tonight.  But we didn't tell them.  The service was great.

The amuse bouche was a slice of apple infused with some delicious flavor.

We ordered everything in stages so it wouldn't come at once.  Up first was:

Caviar:   scallop  tartare with uni and chive.  Comes in a spoon. One bite.  Fantastic

Lobster Ceviche:  the hubby didn't care for the coconut cream, but I loved the whole dish.  We both loved the lobster itself, which seemed poached.

Lollipop kale:  bits of bacon ( guaniciale) was a great salad, served warm

Corn ravioli:   (server said this dish is seasonal and would end soon). It's very good with a creamy corn kinda soup in the middle of pretty firm pasta.

BBQ pork belly, sitting on corn porridge, peaches and charred frisée, Mr. Foodlover wanted to come back tomorrow night and have this dish again.  He loved it beyond belief.  He couldn't even enjoy dessert because he was STILL savoring the memory of this dish 

I enjoyed the milk chocolate ganache, with hickory ice cream, bourbon caramel, and marshmallow, it was kinda a fancy s'mores but not really,,it was so good.

Cocktails:

The 1760.  Mint cumin mezcal, gin (too sweet for us)
Watermelon.   Bitters, tequila (enjoyable) 
And a drink that was on the happy hour menu only:  gin and vermouth drink  (this was the favorite of the night)
author: Foodlover B.

description:
People, this place has got it going on. New favorite spot. Beating out Range in the mission. 

FAVES
lobster ceviche
BBQ pork belly
Short rib
Seared tuna sashimi
Brown butter cake thing 
Choco ganache 

SOLID, BUT NOT AMAZEBALLS
fried duck sandwich
Octopus

SKIP
shishito peppers
Uni pasta
Cavatelli
Green tea cheesecake

Loved all 5 drinks we had. Can't wait to try the rest of the menu.
author: Shaily K.

description:
Just moved across the street from this place a month ago.. Now I can have the Corn raviolis nightly if I wanted to.  MUAHAHA.  Its still delicious and I bring all my friends here for the nice cocktail drinks and ravioli.  

The girls that work here are also very sweet, friendly and attentive.
author: Vicky T.

description: My experience here was definitely a mixed bag. We had a reservation at 5:30 PM last night and we arrived a couple minutes after to check in for our reservation. Unfortunately one person in our party was running 20 minutes late so after we checked in told the hostess we'd just stand outside and wait. So there we were, standing right outside the big glass door, in front of the hostess, in broad daylight until our friend arrived. When we walked inside a different girl walked up to greet us and told us our reservation was "marked as lost" because we didn't show up. After explaining to her what happened, she was very accommodating and found us a table. The girl who helped ended up being our server and she was fantastic. Very attentive and knowledgable about the menu and different wine pairings. When it came to the food I can say it was very good, but I wasn't blown away by anything I tried other than the Fried Duck Sandwich. The duck was incredible and I'd highly recommend it. This was a business meeting of sorts, and we'd built up quite a tab by the time was all said and done. When we paid it came out to around $300.00 for 3 people. Not excessive, but it definitely wasn't cheap. What really topped off the whole night... Right when we paid, the hostess who checked us in and "no-showed" our reservation walked to our table and said "If you guys would like to move I have a community table open but I'm going to need to seat my next reservation here." I mean I'm sorry but I was still drinking my glass of wine and just paid nearly $100 per-person to sit here and eat and now I was being rushed out of my chair. I understanding keeping to a schedule but overall the hostess at this place last night was just terrible. Zero patience and people skills. I really hope it's not this places vision to move her up to being a server. The service was actually really good and I'd hate to see someone like her helping tables.
author: Joshua S.

description:
I was super stoked to try this place after hearing all the hype about it and finally getting a reservation, but it actually didn't meet my expectations. 

The space is gorgeous, and the service is good, but the food wasn't as amazing as I expected it to be. Don't get me wrong, it was tasty, but just not as great as the hype let on. I ordered the hamachi crudo, the uni pasta dish, the brussel sprouts, and kale lollipops. The vegetable dishes were very flavorful, but the hamachi crudo didn't wow me, and the pasta was a tad dry and lukewarm. I won't completely write it off and am willing to try it again, but this time around I wasn't too impressed.
author: Samantha C.

description:
I made a last minute Rez on a Sunday at 8:30 on open table for me and my boyfriend. We've been curious about this place since it replaced La Parilla. 
We sat down and a friendly waitress came to  give us menus, she explained we should order 2-3 items per person etc. A few minutes later a different waitress came to take our order. We ordered Tuna Sashimi, Brussel Sprouts and the Duck Sandwich. The waitress brought over a silverware holder with tons of forks, spoons and knives...that's weird...why not just bring us 1 each??

The Tuna Sashimi was really good! It was super fresh and seasoned perfectly with a little salt, citrus and shredded radish.(I think it was radish)

The Brussels were good but good if you like really salty, oily, very brown Brussel sprouts. Which for some reason I really liked. My bf hated them and said we make them better at home, which I had to agree with. His point was, this is a high end restaurant and they are relying on too much grease and salt to make it good. Makes sense. I recommended the Brussel sprouts from Park Tavern instead!

The Duck sandwich was sooo good! It definitely was overpriced though. I mean it tasted like really good food truck food, greasy and salty and delicious but $15? I think $8 would be more like it. 

Oh I had the Fondantel wine which I thought was excellent! 

Overall the service was great, some of the dishes were good but the price was a little too much for what was served.
author: Joshua M.

description:
This place is a great "go to" as it ticks all the boxes. Good service, good ambience and good food (loved the potatoes). I felt it was also good value for money. The key word for me clearly is "good". It is a good place for casually sitting at the bar or dining at a table with friends. The waitress was very mindful to cater to our needs and make sure everything went smooth. It's not a mind blowing rave about experience, but I think it's one of the better restaurants in SF. Would confidently recommend to our friends. 

Sarah
author: Sarah H.

description: My husband and I love brunch and came here with a gilt city voucher. After initially looking at the menu we thought we were going to leave hungry so on top of the beignets, fingerling potatoes, burrata flatbread, side of bacon, and bottle of sparkling wine with orange juice we ordered the charcuterie plate. Boy was that a mistake! The plates are meant to be shared and we could have ended the meal happy and content. Everything was delicious! The charcuterie plate on the other hand was not. For 22$ we expected something more than tiny pieces of saucisson, breakfast sausages, and fried pancetta.  At that price at Spruce you get pate, rillettes, bread etc. This was a major disappointment especially at their high price point. Service was excellent and this would have been a 5 star review if we didn't end our meal with the appetizer and if it was more of a charcuterie plate. The restaurant also looked great.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Great ambiance place.  A nice but not too pretentious place in a convenient location at Polk.  Best analogy is sort of the Polk Street version of NOPA I think.

Service was really awesome.  Five stars just for that.  

On the dish side, wasn't the biggest fan of the dungeness crab + sorbet + basil dish, but the whole roasted chicken + fingerling potatoes made up for it.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Normally, the words "small plates" send me out the door of a restaurant faster than "salmonella." But I am forced to make an exception when the food is unique, gorgeously presented, and absolutely delicious. This is the case at 1760. 

For several months, my husband and I waited with our noses pressed to the glass, in hopes of a great new restaurant in the Parilla space. We weren't disappointed. Everything we ordered was outstanding. Also has a very good bar - special shout-out to the Yuso-Shiso (I probably spelled that wrong) drink - a distinctive taste you have to experience for yourself. I could have knocked back five of these. They can make them in an equally (okay, *almost* equally) tasty non-alcoholic version. It's hard to get a table here, but if you arrive early enough on a weeknight they may still be able to help you, or possibly seat you at the community table. We don't love the famous duck sandwich - too gamey tastes, but everything else is phenomenal. Definitely get the s'mores dessert, and enjoy a "small plate" dinner worthy of your money.
author: Christina P.

description: This place has huge issues. If you intend to run a small plates shop you must have a handle on timing. The kitchen here has no management, The wait between dishes is excruciating. They have no idea of the importance of a capable bar,(  that's their only hope to make money). Salt is extremely important in their presentation. This is a stumble in drunk Polk Street restaurant.. i'm sure that was not the intention and regret it very much. The Grubstake will always be alive at the corner of Washington and Polk.
author: Robin P.

description:
Trendy and open layout of a restaurant with a very cool bar area and giant windows lining the entire exterior of the place. Our waitress was fantastic and was always around but never over-bearing. She offered some helpful and honest suggestions on drinks and food. 

The food: some dishes were world-class, while others fell very flat, especially for the high price. What we loved: the Caviar, the Lobster Ceviche, and the Crispy Octopus. The Caviar came in a spoon and melts in your mouth. The Lobster Ceviche was a very light and fresh dish and was a great transition into the rest of our meal. The Crispy Octopus was tender and crispy, not tough at all, and came with what I would describe as a mildly spicy jumbalaya filler. 

What we would avoid if we came again: the Buccatini and the Hangar Steak. The Buccatini just tasted like glorified mac and cheese and the uni really didn't go well with it. The cheese was very over-powering. Hangar Steak was probably the most disappointing dish. You only get 6 thin pieces of steak with a side of arugula. And the steak was a bit overcooked in my opinion. 

The price: This is my problem with the place. It's very over-priced. I'm ok with spending some extra money on caviar and lobster because I know that doesn't exactly come easy or cheap for a restaurant. But what really sent me over the top was the $28 for the Hangar Steak. 1760 are you really going to charge us that much for 6 slices of mediocre beef and then only give slightly-dressed arugula as a side? Either replace the steak with Kobe Beef or give me some more caviar with it if you're going to charge $28. 

Our meal for these dishes and 2 drinks came out to be $160 before tip. In my mind it should have been about $50 cheaper for the food that we got. 

We both decided that we would come back for drinks and maybe a quick bite if we lived in the neighborhood, but wouldn't go out of our way to spend that type of money again.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I grabbed a seat at the bar for cocktails and bites with 2 friends and it was perfect. We tried pretty much the entire cocktail menu and decided that the basil,  yuzu shiso and peach buck were the best of them all. 

As far as food goes, I challenge anyone to find Brussels sprouts as delicious as these ones. Heads up to vegetarians that fish sauce is used in them, so they're not entirely veggie (also the case with most of their vegetable dishes so make sure to ask your server what's safe)

The lobster crudo was the surprise hit and paired so well with the coconut cream it was served on. Super clean and fresh. Crispy octopus was a knockout and the steak tartare and Dungeness crab were tasty too but a bit more conventional.

My only negative comment might be about the amuse bouche of compressed honeydew with raspberry vinegar...I've had some pretty ridiculous amuses in my lifetime (i.e wee smatterings of ingredients tossed on to a smear of sauce and served in unreasonably massive bowls) but let me just say that 1 tiny piece of honeydew melon for each of us served on a massive plate and without anything else on the plate does not make an amuse bouche. Come on now.

Otherwise, there is an almost clinically precise execution of the food and flavors that I can imagine some would not be into, but when presented in such a low key fashion with top notch service, I find it hard to not love.

I don't often find myself hanging out around Polk, but I would absolutely come back here time and again to frequent this spot.
author: Clarissa S.

description: Second visit to this excellent restaurant on Polk St.  We had a birthday and engagement dinner with family.  I have to say this menu is really fun to order from.  Share plates are delicious and fun for a group of 4 or more.  The shishito peppers with Yuzu sauce are down right awesome as was the ravioli and ribs.  Monday night is Champagne night... and we were given a nice 20% discount on a bottle.  Made the night.  Great service and attentive staff.  The owner is from the family who owns Acquerello Restaurant, probably my favorite Italian food locale in SF. But this location represents a fun, more casual bistro American fare.
author: Brian M.

description:
Sprucing up Polk Street...

Had a fabulous dinner date on a Friday. With no rezzies we chose to sit at the communal table and enjoyed the pleasant service just as much.

For starters we went with two varietals of Pinot Noir, brought over and served by their in-house som who was fantastic.

For grub we went with:

- Lollipop kale (green crunchy goodness)
- Hamachi crudo (topped with orange- tasty but I'll probably order the lobster ceviche next time)
- Corn ravioli (a party in your mouth)
- Crispy octopus (tender and savory)

Presentation was elegant yet not ostentatious and the flavoring was on point throughout the meal. Four stars in my book!
author: Caroline S.

description: Everything we sooo delicious! Cocktails are prepared with such care and precision, just like the food. Menu changes regularly; dishes look simple but everything is flavor packed with unique flavor combinations. So delic! Kinda pricey, but the food is worth it. Shout out to Mr. C who always comes correct with the cocktails.
author: Gina R.

description:
I loved the menu and the restaurant had a great ambiance. Very cool, upscale but relaxed. Our waitress suggested that my date & I split four or five plates, but we weren't super hungry so we got three - the shishito peppers, burrata, and crispy octopus. It turned out to be just enough food - when they say small plates they mean SMALL. If I'd actually been hungry I might have left unhappy. Or broke. Definitely plan to get a lot of dishes. The shishito peppers were my favorite - they were nicely charred and had a good kick - but the octopus was also amazing. Everything was cooked perfectly and was full of flavor.

We had a few of the pear-ginger and peach buck cocktails too and those were both excellent. Our waitress was attentive and I liked that they brought out one dish at a time. Knocked off a star because portions are small for the price (even considering how good everything was. It really isn't more than a few small bites of food per dish), but the food was very creative and they use a lot of ingredients that I don't encounter often. I really, really like this place and will definitely be back to try a few more things.
author: Jaleh B.

description:
I have been to 1760 four times now! Each evening has been amazing, with great cocktails and wonderful service.

i did have a moment worth telling
we arrived without a reservation 
they were able to seat us in short order
then-  i received a text saying i needed to be at sfo within an hour 
the service person expedited our order; gave us the check; and was absolutely sweet about the whole thing.
we were able to have the most time possible at the table
without worrying about dashing 
and off to the airport with good time 

i will return 
(if they will have me) 
joel
author: Joel R.

description:
Highly anticipated? Yes, especially since 1760 is such a refreshing change after Parilla. Showed up for opening night. 

The restaurant itself is beautiful. Unfortunately the bar area is a bit narrow which pretty much means you aren't getting a seat unless you show up early. Very crowded.

Service was great. Either the manager or the sommelier was incredibly helpful in picking out a great bottle of wine. The corkage fee is outrageous ($35) but the wine list is substantial. Would be nice if there were more moderately priced bottles but there is still something for everyone...mostly. 

Small plates ranging from $9-22. Lots of choices for the meat and seafood eaters. We enjoyed everything we ate but you definitely need to order at least two plates per person. 

Had a great time but it will be a while before we return for dinner. Probably try the cocktail menu next time. Very expensive meal for two. Looking at around $200. 

Great addition to the neighborhood regardless.
author: Heather L.

description:
3 Words. Fried. Duck. Sandwich.
That is all you need to know if you are considering making a trip to1760.

1760 is quickly building a great reputation in the city. With a great cocktail program and a solid wine list, your adult beverage cravings will not go unsatisfied.

For the food - I'm not sure where to begin. 1760 is focused on small to medium size plates that are meant to be shared. On our most recent visit we had the brussels sprouts, the octopus, a salad and the fried duck sandwich. All of which were excellent. The duck sandwich definitely made me want to come back the next day.

One thing to note: the menu is set up well for a table of 4 to share a lot of food. 2 tops will only be able to try 3-4 dishes and after you stare at the menu for 10 mins, you'll have a really tough time making a choice!!!!
author: Justin O.

description:
Stirring Hour 5-6, few apps a few dollars off
nice date spot with strong underlying cooking fundamentals. hip in contrast to the more formal big sister restaurant.
started with thyme honey crostini with mushroom butter.
*Brussels Sprouts. black vinegar. crushed hazelnuts. crispy prosciutto --  nice combination with a citrus soy vinaigrette  
*Kabocha Ravioli. coconut broth. brussel leaves. pepitas -- top dish with very creamy smooth but thick golden squash filling inside al dente ravioli, small spice broth light on the coconut completed with the addition of pumpkin seeds.  interesting and delicious, favorite dish.
*Crispy Octopus. romanesco broccoli. carrot-tamarind puree. coconut with chicken skin chips -- the octo wasn't always crispy, though pounded soft, thus sometimes a bit mushy.  had more of a parsley cilantro taste.
*Hokkaido Uni. bucatini. ikura. red pepper. garlic. -- unfortunately too much red pepper which overpowered the delicate uni, ikura also slightly fishy and overall expensive.
*Grilled Pork Belly. parsnip purée with mustard seed. braised chard with mayo. sunchoke chips -- sweet and spicy with bbq grilled pork belly chunks.  good elements.  enjoyable meal and menu lists small items at the top, larger items at the bottom, but takes some sense to divide it into your own coursing.
author: Rob C.

description:
It's easy to review 1760: very good food; very good service; very nice venue.  

More specifically, 1760 is the up-tempo and less expensive offspring of Acquerello.  Despite being new on the block (Polk St), my server was very knowledgeable and able to help me put together a very nice meal.  Thanks to her.  

An amuse of compressed watermelon with lime and vanilla was a wee bit of  
watermelon.  Not much more than that.  But everything that followed this was much better.  

Dungeness crab with watermelon gazpacho, finger lime and sea grass  was very nice; however, the crab seemed a bit dessicated, perhaps it had been prepped too long in advance.  

Bucatini with uni, garlic, red pepper, and bread crumb was very, very good.  Super fresh, sweet uni and perfectly al dente pasta.  

I finished off with a yummy fried duck sandwich that came with slaw, pickles, and spicy aioli.  This is their Marlowe burger: filling, tasty, and the kind of thing you get knowing that even if it isn't good for you it tastes great.
author: David D.

description: Great spot for tapas style food. They have a good selection of plates. I highly recommend the duck sandwich. It was really delicious. We had the cavalletti which I don't recommend. Get the corn ravioli instead. We really enjoyed the shishito peppers. All in all great atmosphere and service.
author: Yasi N.

description:
The restaurant was pretty modern and trendy. Do love the atmosphere and the big communal table up front.


Monkfish Liver Mousse. citrus compote. squid ink brioche- Reminded me a bit of foie gras, however I prefer this in its original and dense texture than mousse for,. Despite the texture, this was pretty freaken amazing.

Brussels Sprouts. crispy onion. aromatic herbs-  How can you go wrong or messed up on brussels sprouts?! Seriously, this was good. A tad bit salty.  I think if they add something a bit sweet, yet citrus-eee; would tone down the saltiness and give it an extra flavor (perhaps grapes?).

Burrata. grilled bread. garbanzo beans. asian pear. walnuts - Hmmm, a bit too heavy because the bread. I think we were carb overload by the end of the night.  I have had something similar, but better in my opinion. It was walnut crostinis with burrata, truffle mushroom, almond flakes, finished with a honey drizzle.

Bucatini. uni. garlic. red pepper. bread crumb - Ok!! Sounds a bit strange, but it was phenomenal.  My FAVORITE dish of the night. I highly recommend this.  Its not an ordinary red or white sauce pasta; it was UNI, quite pleasant.  The bread crumb gave it an extra crunch, which was nice.  

Cavatelli. 48 hour lamb shoulder. green garlic. burnt rosemary oil - A bit disappointed with this dish because the lamb was in small chunky cube bites.  Flavor was not all there, but that's just my palette.  

Milk Chocolate Ganache. hickory ice cream. bourbon caramel. marshmallow  for dessert... Ugh pretty damn good and a great way to end the night.

I would definitely come back to try the Fried Duck Sandwich that everyone was raving about.
author: Jessica P.

description:
So happy our sommelier friend from Acquerello recommended this place to us!

I'm giving 1760 4*stars because they are still new and there is definitely room for improvement. For example, their lighting could be a little dimmer as it struck me as being quite bright when I sat down. Tables are quite close to each other, but at the end of the day its a casual restaurant and as long as the food and service is good, who cares?

For someone who is not a big fan of Gin, I would love to see at least one more vodka based cocktail on the menu. With that said, their cocktails and food are both delicious. There was not one thing I disliked, which is always a good sign. 

Memorable dishes*:

Cavatelli with pork cheeks in tomato sauce - this was a WINNER for me and I would come back just for this dish.

Uni Bucatini - I've had hundreds of uni pasta dishes and this was one that I actually thought was executed well and tasted delicious. The Uni and pasta ratio could be improved by adding just a little more uni so you are not left with plain bucatini - albeit cooked perfectly. Wouldn't expect any less from Acquerello's new gem.

Dessert - Milk chocolate ganache - this dish was basically a play on deconstructed S'mores but with caramel and bourbon ice cream. Need I say more? The presentation was creative and I loved the addition of a few mint leaves on the ganache so you can get minty smore bites as well! Pure genius.*

Will definitely be back to try the fried duck sandwich sometime.
author: Amber S.

description:
I came here for my 21st birthday dinner with my father and one of my older sisters. We ordered about 6 dishes. The price for three people came out relatively reasonable considering the extremely high quality of food, service, and ambiance. 

EVERY bite of EVERY dish wasn't just tasty, it was like art. I can't stress this enough. The first bite of every dish forced the corners of everyone's mouth to curl up in a tiny, involuntary smile, which then made us burst into smiles and laughter because we all noticed eachother's similar reactions. That's how a proper dining experience should be. 

Service was sweet and friendly and super helpful. Our server walked me through all the drinks on the menu and explained each dish as they came out. They all had a really good sense of humor while maintaining super high standard of professionalism without being super stuffy and snooty. The drinks were bomb too (although they were not cheap). 

They bring out a pallet starter (can't remember the exact term they used for it) beforehand. Can't remember exactly what it entailed, but i remember there being an edible flower involved, so I was all about that. Actually, a lot of dishes had edible flowers, which, like i said, are super cool to me personally. 

We ordered: lobster ceviche (omg just saying it makes me emotional/nostalgic), brussel sprouts (super noms), artichoke hearts (ughh yes please), the crab (double ughhh yes so lemongrassy and flavorful), burrata (super good, but then again, I've never been disappointed with burrata before), and finally the asparagus ravioli. I feel like I'm forgetting something important here. Oh well, whatever it was, I know it was great because nothing I ate was just "oh this is pretty good" it was all "WTF IS HAPPENING TO MY MOUTH IT FEELS LIKE A SUNRISE."

Actually, we didn't order the asparagus ravioli, but I think because they weren't ready at 8pm on the dot (they were only like 5 or 10 minutes late to seat us though)/it was my birthday/the chef was feeling "generous" we got it anyway. That was probably the best thing besides the ceviche. It was like a soup dumpling, except ravioli. You put the whole piece in your mouth, you bite down, and ravioli explodes (not violently or messy or anything, but in the best way possible) in your mouth and every corner of your tongue is covered with the creamy, yet light flavor. 

Anywho, my father, my sister and I are definitely coming back here again, but next time we're bringing my snooty foody sister from NYC because she saw all our pictures on instagram and facebook and got really jealous and requested a visit. We're also bringing our cousin from NYC, but I don't really know his standard for food so I guess that's an insignificant detail. 

Overall, it's a high ranker in my personal top 5 favorite places I've eaten at in SF.
author: Deborah R.

description:
Went to 1760 the other night with fairly high expectations since apparently it is the sister restaurant of Acquerello. We enjoyed ourselves but the food was hit and miss. I'll start by saying I really liked the vibe in the restaurant. A lively and diverse crowd gave the place a fun energy. Our waitress was very helpful too.

We came with a group of four and started with drinks and beer. The cocktails were fresh and different, we thought they were really great and a good way to start the meal. The wine list is great but many of the wines are pretty expensive, at least 75$, which seems outrageous I would not expect that going to a small plates restaurant. Way overpriced. Oh the tech boom in SF. 

As for food, the lobster ceviche was outstanding and probably the best thing we ordered all night. The peppers were a huge disappointment, so bad we sent them back, something I haven't done in years. We also shared the corn ravioli, ribs, duck sandwich, octopus, and baby artichokes. Everything besides the baby artichokes I'd rate as 4 stars. Nothing really to knock your socks off but good flavors, and I'd probably order all again. A little strange they put peanuts on so many dishes here, like peppers and ribs, didn't care for the peanuts at all, very bizarre.

Overall I'd say it was a solid 4 stars. The food was unique (almost to a fault) and the cocktails were great. If we go back I'd just be a bit more conscious of the alcohol tab, it got a bit overboard.
author: Kate N.

description: Great food, great service.  The meal was very well 'managed' i.e. the wine was not brought to the table until we finished our cocktails, the courses were brought in rolling succession upon completion, very professional. Portions are small and meant to be share, if you're expecting a 20oz steak for your $30 you'll be disappointed with the 'value' but not the flavor.
author: Drew Z.

description:
I've never been to Acquerello because the bank keeps turning down my loan request. That's why I was excited to hear they were opening a more "neighborhood" spot.  1760 is right across the street from my house so I've been anticipating their opening for quite some time.  I go to Bell Tower so much that I don't even have to look at the menu.  I used to watch sports at Parilla all the time because no one was ever there.  My hood needs another restaurant that serves good food and a stiff drink at a good prices.  I was hoping for a "Nopa" type spot.  That is not 1760.

Bring your wallet, but not your appetite guys.  This place is tailor made for foodies.  All the food and drinks are flavorful, but you'll pay for it.  Save your money and bring a date who loves food and cocktails.  That's what I did and it was worth every penny.  I sure won't be bringing the fellas here for a beer anytime soon.
author: Corey V.

description:
meal type :: dinner

reservations :: recommended, but not difficult to get (you don't have to book a month in advance or have the first available table at 10:45 PM)

ambiance :: simple, modern, doesn't get too loud w/the high ceilings

{ FOOD }
^  amuse bouche :: 5/5 stars, not sure what it was, some type of corn bread, so dense and good!
^  lobster ceviche :: 4/5 stars, very good and clean flavors. i'm not a huge coconut fan, which was only reason i didn't give it a 5/5
^  beef tartare :: 5/5 stars, great flavor.  at first i was worried the thai vinaigrette would overpower the meat, but it didn't!
^  bucatini :: 10/5 stars!? definitely my favorite.  next time everyone gets their own portion!
^  pork belly :: 5/5 stars, so much flavor.  fairly unique.  i even loved the charred frisee

{ SERVICE }
* hostess greeted us immediately and seated us promptly 
* waiter had great suggestions and didn't encourage us to order more than we should
* food runner was super friendly and sooo happy, he put a smile on my face.  after all, happiness is contagious (well it should be)
* water, wine and condiments were promptly refilled/delivered, but not so often that it interrupted our meal
* we did not feel rushed and was able to enjoy our meal

price was reasonable... considering 2 people, 4 'entrees' and a bottle of wine - $175 before tip.  one of my new favorite places in SF.

happy eating!
author: Tina F.

description: This place was good 2 years ago when it opened, it's now been far surpassed in quality, price, and value by Lord Stanley down the street and other new offerings in the city.
author: Paul C.

description:
Wow wow wow! Definitely worth the hype. This place knows what they are doing! We had a lil bit of a wait last night although we had reservations, but the hostess kept us posted every step of the way and even came over once we sat down to apologize for the delay and chit chat a bit. This is how you treat your guests! 

It's a well designed and decorated space that is simple, chic and modern without being cold. Lighting is by far the most important element for me in any setting and it was perfect here. 

The food was spot on. Amber M., I really wanted to try the ravioli, but it was sold out by the time we made our way to the table :(  I'll have to get the next time I'm in town.
