Everything from the staff to the cocktails, to the dishes to the desserts...wonderful, flavorful and creative.  My favorite way to dine whether in a formal or informal setting is to share small plates; and with a menu that is as diverse and smart as 1760, what a privilege.  

Thanks for a lovely evening. 

p.s. we noticed what looked like a lot of first dates...definitely a good spot for that!
author: Dee S.

description:
Before I went, I read through some of the Yelp reviews and it seems that the most complaints come from the price/portion ratio.  This made ordering difficult: should we order 2 plates each and starve, or 3 plates each and cry over the bill later? 

Well, here is what I found out: first off, a party of four is the optimal size.  We ordered about 8 dishes plus one dessert, allowing ourselves to try most of the items on the menu.  We were pretty full by the end, but no one died from hunger or starvation.

Nothing was disappointing. To start with amuse buche - a slice of summery peach - was genius.   Nothing heavy, nothing complicated, simply sweet and divine. 

Then we shared the lighter dishes: octopus, ceviche, crab gazpacho, shishito peppers.  Everything was good and well balanced, but I loved the octopus the most.  Really tender, really flavorful. 

Now save some room for the heavier dishes: bucatini with uni, squash ravioli, pork belly and duck sandwich.  Everyone agreed that the bucatini with uni was amazing.  Pork belly was really awesome too.  Not dry, not too fat, just perfectly cooked. 

By comparison, I wasn't that crazy about the chocolate ganache we had for dessert.  The plate presentation was gorgeous, but the burnt marshmallow made me feel like I was eating a candle.  (I know, weird, but it had that scent.)

In the end, we paid 55 each after tax, tips, and a few drinks.  Not bad, considering the quality of the food.  It felt like going through a well thought-out tasting menu without paying the high prices.  We were able to try a little bit of everything without stuffing ourselves silly.  

Judging from the crazy wait on a random weeknight, I predict getting reservation here will become harder and harder.
author: Candice B.

description:
I'm really impressed with the beauty of the space and the quality of the service. The decor is modern, but warm and comfortable. Lots of windows let in just enough light at night, and the very tall ceilings make things seem less cramped. The bar looks great too. Our waitress was so friendly and helpful. She definitely went above and beyond.

The food was excellent. The two main dishes we ordered were the Pork Belly and the Lobster Ceviche. Both were awesome, but I especially enjoyed the Pork Belly. Everything we ordered was very good really. Great place to take a date.
author: Don W.

description: One word - AMAZEBALLS!! Is that even a word? Well now it is. And it describes 1760 perfectly. The staff is great and the menu is simple and straightforward. We got the beef carpaccio and hamachi to start off. The duck burger is very juicy and delicious!! I'd definitely come back!
author: En L.

description:
I am a Polk resident and was very excited to try this place out. When we first arrived we were seated right away (we had reservations) however the hostess forgot menus. We sat there for about 5 minutes with no menus and no silverware. I ended up asking one of the bar backs for a menu. When our server finally came we ordered 2 specialty drinks. I got the Strawberry shrub and my boyfriend got The Garam Masala and Cardamom Cocktail. The Strawberry shrub was NOT good. Super sugary and just not pleasant. The server ended up comping it but no one order it. My boyfriend enjoyed his drink though. 

For our meal we started with the Shisitos peppers which were good but kind of a pointless appetizer I think. They have some strong entrees but appetizers I think they can do better with. I know there "tapas" style but still if your going to have something on the menu like small quarter size peppers you can think of a better app.  Then we got Corn ravioli which was my favorite. The corn filling is incredible but please give us more. For $18 dollars there about 5 maybe 6 small little ones. Either make them bigger or cut the $18 dollars. Next we got the Hanger steak. Phenomenal. Lastly we got the Cavatelli. vinegar-braised pork. This is a pasta dish in case no one knows what Cavatelli is. Its pretty good as well. 

For dessert we got the angel food cake. It was good but I herd the table next me to raving about the Milk chocolate Ganach so next time I'm trying that.
author: Jess O.

description:
Last night the bf and I stumbled into this place when the Thai spot across the street closed at 10 pm. For a Saturday at 10, this place was pretty crowded, but they conveniently had 2 open spots at the end of the bar - perfect spot. 

The service was pretty good, the drinks were UNREAL - I had the blackberry mint with tequila, seriously one of the best cocktails I've had in a while. 

We ordered the Brussels sprouts, octopus pasta and steak. For the prices, the food didn't totally blow me away - except for the Brussels sprouts which were unreal. 

Overall I would definitely come back for drinks and some appetizers - I would probably head somewhere else for the main course though.
author: Sophie I.

description: My favorite dish would be the lobster ceviche ! Yumm. Atmosphere is not bad. Love the high ceiling. The only complaint that I have is that their menu is a little small for me. Went there for the first time between 2 people and I think we tried about 70-80% of their menu already. They say that their menus changes but I'll have to see the next time I go back. Heads up parking in tough this area.
author: Karen M.

description:
Yum yum yum...
This place is an experience for the taste buds...
Checked out this spot with couple of gf's after we all heard good things from others..
We started out with the lobster ceviche which was a refreshing cleanse for the pallet .....
The uni pasta was a full mouth of buttery richness and the octopus was a flavorful chewiness....
Our finale was the duck sandwich which was less memorable after all the previous stimulus...

I do recommend talking to the sommelier as he provided us with a well balanced fruity Italian red that was within out price range and complemented our food.

Overall a experience worth coming back to...
author: YC L.

description:
First off, the food is insanely good -among the best food in SF, hands down. For us, the food was  the most memorable part of my experience and the main reason I will be coming back to this new Polk St. staple. We ordered a bunch of dishes- my personal favorites being the corn ravioli and the lobster ceviche. The dishes are served tapas style and are good size portions.  Our server recommended we eat the ravioli whole and it was an extraordinary experience! The deconstructed s'more dessert was mouth watering!

The design is California modern and there is a large community table at the front of the restaurant. The open kitchen is gorgeous and practically glows against the dark interior. 

The service was fantastic. Our server was very friendly and knowledgeable about all the dishes. Even though the restaurant was full, we didn't wait for our food. The signature cocktails from their mixologist are delicious and you must try at least one! We tried the 1760 and the Cardamom cocktail (can't remember the exact name) and would recommend them both. 

I can't wait to bring friends and guests to this spot! We are already planning our next trip. FIVE STARS ALL THE WAY. Excellent service, unparalleled food and urban atmosphere=== the perfect SF experience. Thank you!!!!
author: Scarlet F.

description:
Delicious food- crispy octopus, brussel sprouts, duck sandwich, shishito peppers, lobster ceviche. Amazingly intricate flavors in all the dishes!

Great service- attentive but not over attentive, friendly and helpful
author: Natalie R.

description: Food was decent, nothing extraordinary.  Food portions were really small, but worst of all, the timing of plates and service.  I went with 4 girlfriends and we ordered around 10 dishes.  They brought out 2 at a time at least 15-20 minutes a part which resulted in us being starving!  Server got attitude when we asked for our food...save your brunch money and eat elsewhere.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Cute place!
Fried Duck Sandwich - Amazing
Ravioli - To die for

Great service, good drinks. 

4 starts because portions were VERY TINY
author: Maddie N.

description: One of my favorite spots in the City!  I have been so many times I once went three times in one week.  I love the steak tartare.  I love the Hamachi.  The lobster ceviche is amazing.   I love the drink with the giant ice cube--the pear ginger cocktail.  It is has an excellent wine list and attentive service.  And then I wish I could resist the ganache for dessert, but I can't and enjoy it every time. This is a great spot to go out with friends, on a date, or with just about anyone.  There was some snooty reviewer who tried to insult this place when it first opened and I am so thrilled no one listened.  Long Live 1760!
author: Erin R.

description:
Was enjoying a somewhat mediocre meal, great environment, cocktails and staff!!! But...... In the middle of our meal when we asked for an extra rib to be added to our order, our waitress came back saying "the only way the chef will do it is if we bought the whole kitchen a beer"...... Are you kidding me? What a joke! Your a mediocre chef at a sub par restaurant and you want us to buy your staff a beer to add an extra rib? Your in the service industry try acting accordingly.... Stroke! 
Ewww and they give you the same wet wipes you get at original buffalo wings and joes crab shakes!
author: Matthew R.

description:
1760 is fantastic; from the hostesses, to the waiters, to the servers, to the bartenders, to the atmosphere and most importantly to the food.  

Every single time my boyfriend and I have gone here (which is many over the past year) the food and the service has always been awesome.  It's nice to know they remember us too when we come in!  

Their food is served tapas style (for the most part) and many of the dishes are best shared between two people.  (Hint: This is a perfect place for a date!)  They have a great little beer list and a huge wine list.  The food is always good, and the unique flavor pairings of the dishes make each one stand out.  

But to anyone complaining that the food servings were too small for them, they should look somewhere else because those people are obviously only interested in quantity over quality, because I can guarantee that if you order two small plates with one large plate to share with one other person, that you will be full by the end of the dinner, and not feel guilty about it!  

It's best to get a reservation if you want to guarantee seating at a table here; but if you show up without one, eating at the communal table or at the bar doesn't take away from the experience at all (and it's nice to actually sit next to the person you're there with!).  

1760 is fantastic.
author: T C.

description:
This place was amazing.

The environment is super hip.  They have an open kitchen, great decor, and really high ceilings.  Their drinks were fantastic.  I tried the 1760 drink (the one at the top of the menu) and it was really unique.

For the main dish, we ordered the Fried Duck Sandwich.  It was HUGE - I would definitely share this.  Do not underestimate it.  I only ate half and I was uncomfortably full for about an hour.

I'm definitely going to be coming back here to try their other dishes.  This restaurant comes highly recommended.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Wow - this was probably some the best food I had in SF this last year (and hells, I was not even hungry).  I feel like downgrading all my recent 5-stars to 4 so to make it clear they run a notch higher.  The cocktails were good (though all of them a bit on the sweet side, would be nice to see some "manly additions"

I am personally not a big fan of the interior, but my wife was .. and you know she's always right.
author: Philip I.

description:
After months of hype from friends and reviews...1760 lives up to its publicity. Supurb. 
1. Ambience is low key and not to high noise, quintessential Polk Street fun. 

2. The first end-to-end meal that forced my companion and I to reread the menu, ask our server, and use other means to try and determine what flavor combos were going on.  They didn't even phone it in on dessert - which was just as complex as the small plat offerings.  Foodie heaven. 

3. Service is solid. No complaints, but nothing top tier comes to mind, either.  But with this level of food, service is almost anathema to the savory experience.

3. Yum standouts:   BBQ Pork Belly, Corn Ravioli in a baked potato broth, Crispy Octopus with ground chorizo. 

Another gem of a discovery.
author: Chaz S.

description:
Disappointing and over priced are probably the words I would use.  As my friend who I took to celebrate his birthday said, it better be the best food (he circled for 45 minutes before finding parking).  First of all, parking is going to be an issue so maybe carpool if you don't live in the city.  There's been a lot of talk about how the cocktails are amazing but the one we ordered, 1760, did not work at all.  

We ordered a bunch of plates since they are for sharing.  Uni bucatini, cavatelli, pork belly, short rib, beef tartare, grilled octopus, fried duck sandwich and green tea bavarian.  The uni bucatini was the best dish, it did have enough uni and flavor but the rest of the dishes were disappointments.  The cavatelli had too much acid in there, the fried duck sandwich, you could not taste the duck, the pork belly tasted too much like pork from a Chinese deli market, the tartare was not memorable.  The worst dish we tried was the green tea bavarian.  The dish had too many notes, had such an awkward taste, it was not good at all.

Wait staff started out okay although because I was circling around, and ended up being a bit late while my wife waited, the hostess came over and told my wife we had to give them the table back at 8pm.  That started the meal on a somewhat negative note because I was never told when making the reservation we have to give the table back at 8pm and it's not like I didn't want to park my car.  The waiter started out okay but towards the end of the meal, it felt as if he was trying to rush us through.  The last thing that irked me was it was my friend's birthday and he knew it but they couldn't even put a candle or write happy birthday on the plate (which I think is pretty standard for restaurants to do nowadays).

Would I come back?  Just for the uni pasta that is about it.
author: Pierre L.

description:
Overall.... meh.

The drinks - super dank.

The duck burger is pretty Po - tastes like a salmon patty. 

Shishito peppers - delicious.

Let's just say that a trip to Soda Popinski's after was extremely necessary, and because the only thing we ate were vegetables, things escalated quickly.
author: Heather O.

description:
I was unexpectedly surprised by 1760. While I can't say there was one thing that really blew me away about this restaurant, I must say that it had all of the elements that make a great night in my book.

The EATS: Everything we ordered was really good: Crispy Octopus, Cavatelli, Lollipop Kale, BBQ Pork Belly, and Brusells Sprouts. Roasted Brussels Sprouts are always good, but their addition of aromatic herbs, crispy onion, and egg yolk was like crack. The dishes may have been a *tad* over-seasoned, but it was also tasty, so no complaints here.

The VIBE: This may turn others off, but I loved that this restaurant played hip hop. Not loud trashy radio or booty shaking hip hop, but old school rap/hip hop with enough melody to blend in as "background music" to those who won't recognize it. Keith Murray told me "The Most Beautifullest Thing In This World".. is just like that.. uni bucatini. But sadly, this wasn't on the menu when I went. The menu is somewhat seasonal, but I hope they bring the uni pasta back soon!

The SERVICE: Our server was young and rough around the edges, but what he lacked in finesse he made up for with friendliness. I'm not sure I agreed with his drink recommendations, but that's somewhat subjective, so no hard feelings.

With so many restaurants in the city to try, I rarely ever go to the same place twice. But I may just have to make a repeat trip to 1760 one of these days!
author: Amy M.

description: Duck sandwich here is amazing along with the octopus and appetizers, their happy hour is really inexpensive so i'll definitely be making it back here!
author: James H.

description: Everything was great but honestly think this place is a bit overrated. Portions were French Laundry small. Great vibe and bar. Kind of felt like NoPa but the food wasn't as good and the bar wasn't as fun.
author: Alex H.

description:
Wow, a fab dinner right in my hood.
There was a long wait , so I recommend reservations.they squeezed us inbetween reservations. 
My son took me here for my birthday.not exactly a 12 year olds dream.but he really enjoyed the grilled octopus and the lobster cervevichi. 
All the it.ems are small tapas style meant to be shared. Very tasty food.
Laxed semi dark warm lighting and a bar area for other seating.
We had people checking on us regularly and they even made our I order without peanuts because of barretts allergies
Great place FOR you and your special one...friendly wait staff.
author: Connie B.

description: Was very pleasantly surprised with this place! I was expecting some hipsterry place with mediocre food, but this is probably one of the most inventive and fun and different menus (including cocktail menu) that Ive seen in a while, which I find has been slowly dying in SF. Fun and modern atmosphere, definitely a place for foodies!
author: E B.

description:
Excellent. The octopus was the best I've tasted - perfect; light crunch outside, amazingly tender inside; paired with chorizo paella - delicious.

Chocolate ganache also excellent - icecream, crumble, mallow to assemble a very posh smores. 

And very intriguing cocktails - tried a couple, both very good.
author: Lir C.

description:
Really good! Original and flavorful. Going back for sure!
Best tartar I've ever had and great octopus.  Service is solid too.
author: Taylor J.

description: I think I just found my new favorite restaurant. There's so many places to try in SF but this is a place that I would definitely come back to again and again. Consistency is key for me and every dish we ordered was continually better than the last. Their popular Fried Duck Sandwich was actually my least favorite (but still very good!) and it looks like they change their menu seasonally. It's always a good sign when there's so many appealing things on the menu that you're having trouble narrowing down what you want to order. Service is also very attentive and friendly. Be sure to make reservations.
author: Diana Y.

description: This place was pretty good - small portions and expensive prices, with the food being not anything special.
author: Jenny E.

description: We enjoyed our meal at 1760.  As usual for our first time at a restaurant, we tried as many small plates as possible to get a broad sampling of the menu.   Everything we ordered was really good, the highlight was the Uni Bucatini.  For our next visit, we'd like to try the bar/cocktails ahead of our meal.  Parking is a little tricky, but well worth the effort.
author: Tom S.

description: This is hands down one of the best restaurants in Nob Hill, maybe even in San Francisco. I've eaten out at my fair share of restaurants and this one is definitely my go to. They change the menu with the seasons and are constantly coming up with fresh and innovative new dining options. (They also recently opened for brunch on the weekends and the french toast is incredible!) Mr. C makes incredible cocktails, seriously...they're all amazing! It's a very fun atmosphere and you can tell their entire team genuinely enjoys working there.
author: Sarah M.

description:
American tapas, I want to call it. Basically small plates with fresh ingredients and made with care. The place is small and cute, and they seemed to pay attention to the food. I had several plates to try and share: 


Dungeness crab -apple, celery, yuzu, 'siracha'
Lobster ceviche- caramelized coconut , pineapple, coriander 
Brussels sprout - crispy onion, aromatic herbs
Crispy octopus -roasted peanuts, avocado, potatoes
Hanger steak- caramelized onions, grape, arugula 
Grilled pork belly- gigantic bean, radicchio slaw, carrots
Bucatini- uni, garlic, red pepper, bread crumb
Fried duck sandwich- slaw, pickles, spicy aioli 

Peanut butter panda cotta- berry jam, milk crumble

Every thing delicious, with the few exceptions: 
The fried duck sandwich was good, but not the greatest at all. I just didn't like how it was tasting, it was heavy too. Uni pasta was only okay, not the greatest I had. The panna cotta, I thought was a disaster, the flavors just didn't meld well together. 

Overall, great food, not sure if it hits five stars.
author: Katy C.

description:
Went there for girlfriend's birthday.  Greeted her with Happy Birthday as soon as we got in and also comped our dessert at the end of the meal.  Service was excellent overall.

Drinks were excellent:
--1760
--Domaine Fontanel red wine
--Garam Masala-Cardamom

We loved:
--Lobster ravioli
--Octopus
--Duck sandwich
author: Andrew H.

description: Nice atmosphere, solid service and decent food. We know SF isn't cheap so we are always looking for VALUE at the end of the day ... At least I am. So when I'm served tapas at almost entree prices, I better be blown away. Unfortunately I wasn't and that's why I won't be coming back. Mind you this place does not sucks, I just have better options in this foodie city.
author: Victor M.

description:
Awesome food in a relaxed/casual atmosphere with great cocktails.  

We tried the Hamachi Crudo, Shishito Peppers, BBQ Pork Belly, Lollipop Kale and Whole Roasted Chicken.  The Pork Belly was the winner, with the Chicken a close second (pepers and kale also very good!).  

For the cocktails --- try the "Tequila" off the happy hour menu.  It is awesome.
author: Oleg O.

description: The best dining experience! From beginning to end. EVERYTHING we ate was amazing. The best is that everything came with enough for the 4 of us to share a taste. It was so fun to talk about how delicious everything was and why. We ordered caviar (a must), lobster ceviche, corn ravioli, artichoke, pork belly, octopus, duck sandwich. We each had several drinks and shared 3 desserts. Portions are made to "taste" so don't be afraid to order a lot. This is worth every penny...
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Small plates, a little pricey but overall a great experience and I would head back for dinner next time in town. 
The waitress was very informative about the dishes and wine. I think the best part was ordering the "dealers choice" from the bartender. The waitress asked about 5 questions about your drink of choice and the bartender mixed it up. It was a HUGE hit and the drinks were spot on. 
Also, we informed the waitress we had two people that were Gluten free. They wanted to let us know that certain dishes had soy (which has traces of G in it). She informed us which dishes they can change, which ones they can't. 

Ribs were amazing
Octopus was amazingly good 
Desserts were to die for 
Avoid the green salad ( its small and not worth it)
author: Amanda H.

description: Absolutely incredible great new restaurant on Polk food was insane one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco now
author: Tony G.

description:
Fantastic! We came here last night as a belated Christmas present and I couldn't have been more satisfied with my choice! Everything we tasted was EXCELLENT! I appreciate the level of attention our waiter gave us (including remembering to ask if either one of us had a food allergy). We started the meal with a couple cocktails and then immediately dove into some small plates. 

For "not dessert" we split the tartare, crudo, maccheroni, carrots, and lobster ceviche and for later we each ate or own sweet (ganache for me, and warm banana bread for him). Honestly, the flavors were so complex and delicious my mouth was watering after every bite. I would say the chef has a strong affinity for citrus in each dish so if you are not keen of lime/lemon I would urge you to try a different restaurant.

My personal favorite plate was the maccheroni; my god, the intensity of the crab and lime was tongue tingling; I literally cannot stop thinking about this dish. Plate to skip would unfortunately be the tartare; while I feel like it was good, I don't believe it brought anything to the table I hadn't tried before (but don't get me wrong, still delicious). 

Price point wise, I thought it was a tad on the expensive side for a 23 year old who is not making 6 figures in San Francisco but still completely reasonable. 7 plates, 4 drinks, and tip coming to just under $200 really isn't that bad. I would love to come back again!
author: Tommy C.

description:
Great food and great service by Chelsea. I highly recommend the lobster "ceviche" (actually a sous vide) and the crispy octopus, as well as the chocolate ganache. I wished I had room to try out the other dishes too.
Also, an extensive bar with great cocktails.
author: Dennis K.

description:
Corn ravioli is the star. It is a must have. About 7 one-bite raviolis come in the order, they burst with a creamy corn filling that is on another level. I gave my boyfriend the side-eye for asking to have another one off my plate. Brussels sprouts, duck sandwich, and watermelon gazpacho were all winners too. I loved the basil punch of their 1760 cocktail. Small portions but the flavors are stellar and worth the price. Cool modern vibe and decor.

Oh and the milk chocolate ganache dessert had me ready to lick the plate. Still in a food coma from this dinner, will come back with more friends.
author: Halley S.

description:
Wow a great new American restaurant in the Nob Hill area. Came here to catch up with a friend on a Thursday night, and this place was packed. Be sure to make a reservation in advance. But, if you are planning to do walk-in, there looked to be a large communal table at the front of the restaurant, which helps your chances.

1760 suggests sharing dishes family style and for my party, they suggested doing around 4 plates. That being said for two people, unless you have extremely large appetites, I think you will be quite satisfied with 3. 

We started with the lobster ceviche. This dish had a good size helping of lobster, perfect to share between two people. Nice acidic flavoring, but could have used a little more spice. Overall a nice light dish to begin the evening. Following, we had the crispy octopus. This was my favorite dish of the evening. It helps that I love octopus, but the portion-size was perfect. We were given a good amount of octopus in addition to a nice pad of rice underneath. If you are familiar with grilled octopus, this is the flavor and type of dish you should expect when ordering this item. It is not truly a crispy octopus (suggesting fried). Next, we had the uni. This was an interesting dish for me. It is very rich, and was a bit much for my palate. However, the first couple of bites were excellent, but the quantity is so large that after a while it lost its appeal and became overwhelming. We ended the night with the fried duck sandwich. This was supposedly the fan favorite dish, but I must stick to my guns and say that the octopus was the best. The fried duck sandwich was good, and reminded me of a crab cake sandwich. However, if I had one critique, I wish that the duck flavor came through a little more as it was a bit overpowered by the slaw. 

Overall, the food had great taste, but 4 stars as there are some improvements on flavoring that could be made. The environment is awesome, modern and chic, but you may find it a little loud, so don't plan on having an intimate quiet night out here. I will definitely add this to my list of places to revisit. I enjoyed the menu composition and saw a lot more dishes I hope to try. 1760 looks like it will be sticking around for a while.
author: Alex L.

description: Loved the food, the wine pairing and the ambiance. Neighborhood treasure! 2-3 dishes per person should be an ideal amount of food. Highly recommend the lobster ceviche, shishito pepper, brussels sprouts and pork belly! Definitely going there more often now I know how good the food is!
author: Anji S.

description:
Oh my goodness the food here!
I've found it's rare to find a restaurant where every dish you order is just as delightful as the last. We ordered the following:
lobster ceviche, hamachi crudo, fingerling potatoes, burrata, corn ravioli, and bbq pork belly. My two favorites were the corn ravioli (surprising explosion of warm sweet flavor) and the pork belly. The flavor in all of the dishes was very unique...and so good!
For dessert we had the strawberries and cream...very light for a dessert, but packed with a lot of flavor! Perfect ending to a wonderful meal.
The service was also very good...the dishes came out one at a time in a very timely manner. We rarely waited very long in between dishes. All of the staff was pleasant and very knowledgeable about the menu.
We will definitely be coming back!
author: Laura M.

description: Overpriced, confusing food that's just so so. Their duck burger is alright.
author: Sanjay Patel P.

description:
We ordered the following dishes:

Brussels sprouts:  cooked to perfection but a bit pricey
Pork belly: DELICIOUS & succulent
Corn ravioli: was perfectly al dente and a bit sweet

This place has a great ambiance and the bartenders were very friendly and provided great service. They serve full menu at bar and bc we couldn't get reservations, we ate at the bar. 

My only reservation is that the menu for small bites is a bit pricey but worth every penny.
author: Kristina P.

description:
Invited to 1760 for cocktails and appetizers. We sat at the community table.

The cocktails were great and the bartender was friendly. Food was for the most part delicious, just not quite worth the high price tag. Very small portions. Octopus was the highlight.

Our waitress however was pushy and abrasive. She pretty much ruined the night with her obvious upsells and constant hovering for ordering more food/drinks.

Would not return.
author: Dave N.

description:
A new gem in the Polk Gultch...

Neat Menu Modern Look and worth checking it out.

Without a reservation seems the wait is a while, we sat at the bar that seemed to have 2 stools with our names when we walked in.
author: Madhusudhan R.

description:
This place is just what the doctor ordered for Polk St. The place is upscale but comfortable.  The menu is creative and delicious but the drink menu is what is truly out of this world. 
Excellent place if you're tired of the same ole same ole bar scene.
author: Fred E.

description:
First off, service- awesome!
Maybe I went on an off night but comparing this to ink in la( they are train by ink in la) food didn't come close. 
Dishes we're too salty.
Drinks we didn't have but we hear it's amazing.

Services made it worth while, we might give it another try.
author: jasmin t.

description: This review is based on two visits: Stirring Hour and Brunch.  First, stirring.  Popped by on a Friday and loaded up on three very strong $8 cocktails (that is a bargain in this town) and tried the amazing Korean hot dog, green beans and squash blossoms.  Would recommend all these items.  I went back the following Sunday because I was nearby and specifically wanted to try the fried duck sandwich.  This item was even more rich than I anticipated and think it needs to be split with someone or others, it's just too much on it's own.  The service was also not quite as sharp as on Friday.  I do want to go back and try another handful of items on the dinner menu.
author: e w.

description:
The presentation in every dish is beautiful 
The food itself is good
Drinks are OK
Service is great
Prices of each dishes not cheap
Only one thing left is...Why do we have to pay extra for the employee health care.   It's extra 4% each bill.  You do the math when the restaurant is so pack everyday.
author: Angkana P.

description:
We have been waiting for this restaurant to open for a long time.  We live down the block so we went in slow hoping we will need to make several trips ;)
We had a couple of drinks, the bourbon garam masala and the mescal drink.  They were both deeeeeelicious!!  Then just one snack, the lobster ceviche, it was very beautiful.  The favors were light and meshed very well together.    We will be back over and over again...  Hi neighbor!!!!!
author: Nicole q.

description:
First time here and we really liked it.

Great food in a terrific space; my only real complaint is the drinks are on the small side, otherwise it would have gotten 5 stars.

Very creative menu and everything tasted really good.

Give it a try; you won't be sorry...
author: Richard F.

description:
absolutely loved this place. came here with 4 other friends. I def think the more people the better in order to try more dishes. 

lobster ceviche
brussel sprouts
beef tartare
octopus
bucatini
fried duck sandwich -- only one that i thought was a bit overrated

all the cocktails were really good too
author: Janet Y.

description:
This place is great. Ladies night with the girls, we got a table for 4 on a Saturday night no problem. Everything the server recommended was amazing (food + drinks!) and we had just enough food for all of us. 2 of the 4 are vegetarians and there was plenty of option for us all. I find it oddly difficult to find good vegetarian food in the area so I will for sure be back here. 
Looks like it would be great for a date night as well!
author: Kristin R.

description:
1760 is a promising restaurant with the potential to be a great one.  First off, the space is fantastic with high ceilings, lots of natural light, and comfortable seating.  The servers are also excellent, knowledgeable about the menu and very attentive to every detail.  The drink menu is relatively short but seems well put together - love the Gavroche being offered. 

However, the food seems pretty hit or miss - some dishes just blew us away with the flavors and creativity while others just seemed like a muddled mess.  We started out on a high note with the Lobster Ceviche, which is the best dish I've had in a long time - very fresh tasting, great mixture of flavors, and excellent presentation.  This was accompanied by the roasted Shishito Peppers an enjoyable but unremarkable dish - you generally can't go wrong with Shishito Peppers but I'm not sure the hazelnuts and olives did anything to enhance the dish.  The Fried Squid was an interesting dish, soft on the inside and crunchy on the outside - I really enjoyed the flavors but would of preferred if it was more chewy instead of soft like scallops.  

Finally, the two disappointing dishes were the Hamachi Kama and Crab Macaroni.  The Hamachi Kama was a large portion but not strangely seasoned - the flavors generally didn't seem to compliment the fish and overall gave it a very "fishy" taste.  The Crab Macaroni was far too rich without much complexity - think white sauce with crab.  I could see some people enjoying this but it didn't work for me - I would skip both of these in the future.  

All in all a promising restaurant.  I could see heading back in the future but probably not anytime soon - given the $100+ bill at the end of the night, I'd rather wait for them to work out the kinks before heading back!
author: Rosers M.

description:
Went on a last-minute res on a man date with a friend from the area.  The place was quite good - both the food and the service - but still has a few operational kinks to work out.

Took a bit for us to be seated, despite our reservation.  That's par I would say.  But while waiting we ordered drinks, and those took 30 minutes to get to us (and it's not that big of a place).  That said, the drinks were quite good - and I can say that all of the drinks looked very good.

For the meal, we did the lobster ceviche, brussels sprouts, and burrata.  They gave us the shishito peppers for the inconvenience (a sign of awareness).  Ceviche was fair, brussels were good, burrata and shishitos were quite good.

For mains, we got the bucatini, short rib and fried duck sandwich.  Bucatini was quite rich, but very good, duck sandwich was very good as advertised, short rib was pretty good.

All-in-all, I'd say it's worth checking out.  Food will be at worst very good and the place also has a pretty decent scene.
author: Athan S.

description:
Looked forward to a wonderful dining experience based on all the Yelp reviews.  Our favorite SF restaurant is Acquerello and had  Holiday staff dinners, family dinners,  and  many special occasion meals there.   Food, service, atmosphere was always consistantly 5 stars.  So we knew with that expertise of ownership, it would be a fine evening.  I never write reviews, especially if I can't be positive.  But customer service was so poor on Monday night, that hopefully it was just an off night for the staff.  

Shishito peppers (large amount and charred perfectly)
Beef Tartare (Beef lost in the strong flavored greens, overpowered tartare) 
Octopus (should be crispier, interior was mushy) 

Chicken (moist with mild sauce and cabbage slaw)  
Asked waitress if pastas were still coming.  She said yes, but menu goes from lighter to heavier and that is how it is served.  (Chicken is last on the menu.)  Considered canceling pastas, but decided to be nice and go with their flow.  

Cavatelli (pasta was heavy and pasty with heavy tomato sauce that covered it like tomato beef chow mein....could not eat it.  Luke wam...was it sitting in the kitchen?
Bucatini with Uni (bland mac and cheese-like, luke warm, and plain on top.  Picture on restaurant site has pieces of uni on top)  

Before pastas came out, Chelsea asked if we wanted clean plates. Our plates  had remnants of the first courses and chicken bones and of course we said yes.  The bus boy picked up our dirty plates and our bread plate, which we asked to keep.  The bread is $4 for a tiny loaf of 4 slices.  We were not finished with our bread and would have it with the pasta.  Food and crumbs were  on the table, but they put clean plates on it then wiped around it.  Not a big deal, but not professional.  

After having the luke warm pasta, my husband spoke to Chelsea very nicely about how it is not her fault as to sequence, but the kitchen or manager should be aware of it.  I asked if there was a manager on duty and she said yes 2 of them were there.  She went about her buisness and never seemed to care.  After appetizers, usually pastas would follow and ending with the entree.  We were told the chicken would take 35 minutes, but figured the kitchen would time the meal accordingly.  There was no apology and asked if everything was okay and offered the dessert menu.  Needless to say we left.  There are too many restaurants in SF with better attitudes.
author: Anne H.

description: The food here is pretty good as well as the service.  I wasn't too amazed at any one dish I had there and it wasn't memorable - I've tried at least 5 things.  The cocktails are good too and great that it's seasonal.  Unfortunately, they reserve the bar area and communal table, so it's not walk-in friendly and some of the bartenders are knowledgeable about making drinks while others are not.  Great music!
author: F K.

description: Wanted to love this since I live nearby, but wow what a disappointment.  Everyone in my group felt like we paid way too much for what we ended up eating, and some of the dishes (for instance the pork sisig) were actually terrible.  So terrible I still had an awful taste in my mouth for hours after.  I was entirely surprised at how little taste most of the items had based on the high Yelp scores for the restaurant! Service was nice, which helped.  The fried potatoes and avocado toast were fine, but hard to mess those things up.
author: Emily E.

description: I loved everything I ordered.. intermezzo for dessert..lobster cebiche..potato fingerlings..flatbread..and the pork belly were all very good. The waiter was attentive . It was a little too loud and very crowded and you definitly need a reservation or your going to wait a long time.
author: Corrine D.

description:
Drinks were fantastic - The 1760 is probably the best cocktail I've ever tasted.

Food was very good overall.  Shishito peppers and Hamachi crude appetizers good. Cavatelli and beef cheeks excellent. Didn't like crab maccheroni - sounded good, but way too much lemon.
author: Bib G.

description: Came here to meet a friend at the bar - great selection of wine and liquors on the shelf! Definitely one of the better places for cocktails - lovely attentive service & genius concoctions ! Would love to come back for more!
author: Angie B.

description: It's easy to scoff and say this place is overpriced when first looking at the menu.  However keep in mind that this is SF, and the culinary experience you undergo while visiting 1760 is reason enough for defending their price point.  I took someone on a date here and would gladly come back to celebrate a special occasion.  We started with the Lobster Bisque, which was aromatic and creamy, but not overpowering with flavor.  We then ordered four dishes to split,  the Brussel Sprouts, Pork Sisiq, Octopus Pasta, and Half Roasted Chicken.  The Octopus Pasta was my favorite, and the Burssel Sprouts were flaky and not too salty.  I'm not a huge pork fan, but the Pork Sisig definitely has me reconsidering my stance as it wasn't too fatty and possessed a delicate texture with each bite.  The Half Roasted Chicken was what you would expect so take that as you may.  We were given generous pours of Bedrock Zinfandels, which was recommended by our waiter/bartender after I expressed my love for Zins.  The dishes were well-portioned, and my date and I left without feeling the need to carry ourselves out in a wheel barrel.  Beyond enjoying the food, I appreciated the the attention to detail and presentation of the dishes being served.  The decor is modern and not too flashy; the pace and layout of the restaurant makes you feel relaxed and not too crowded; and the noise level is comfortable and does not require you to speak or yell over anyone to have an intimate conversation with your company.  Kudos to the entire 1760 team making our visit an all around memorable dining experience.
author: Anthony R.

description: Great drinks and atmosphere. Seated promptly on arrival, with good menu suggestions. Price may be a bit steep for some, but you def get what you pay for and the $$$ is appropriate. I spent a little above $60/person for a dinner with drinks (appetizers, main course, dessert), excluding tip.
author: Conor M.

description:
Service was stellar. Ambiance was fun and flirty. Cuisine was good... not great. Had the hamachi, brussel sprouts, crispy octopus (best dish) and bucatini with uni. 

Would stop by again if we are in the neighborhood but not dreaming of returning anytime soon.
author: Maria C.

description: Very disappointing experience at 1760. The food was mediocre at best and the service was absolutely horrible. Got the feeling like they are all trying to act pretentious ... From the host to the servers.  I was very much looking forward to finding a new local restaurant. This is not it.
author: Jacqueline G.

description: Love love love! Food is amazing. Bartenders are outstanding. Drinks are original. Doesn't get better than this and I am a fussy one to please. Thank you for an amazing neighborhood restaurant/bar!
author: Wendi K.

description:
I am impressed. (4.5 stars)

I gotta say I wasn't a huge fan of Acquerello due to their lack of.. imagination and some questionable choices on their tasting menu that I had last year. But because I enjoyed their pasti and appetizer-like dishes so much, I was pretty pumped about their new casual spot right around the corner.

A friend of mine and I ordered totally of 6 dishes (5 main + 1 dessert): 
Bucatini with uni, cavatelli with pork cheek, ravioli with corn, duck sandwich, dungeness crab gazpacho.
The ravioli and duck sandwich were out of this world good. I mean, thank god their octupus was out of order, because we asked our awesome server for a recommendation and she picked the ravioli.. 

The atmosphere was really nice, and the service was tight..

The only reason why I am not giving 5 stars is that the dessert wasn't really up to expectations. I actually remember getting the same dessert at Acquerello, and their desserts were our least favorite parts of the whole dining experience. 

I will definitely go back to try other dishes!
author: Sung C.

description:
Nice atmosphere here and great location off of Polk. Obviously a very busy and trendy place currently. The food was excellent and the drinks were delicious. Everything is a small plate so you need to order 4-6 items for a group of 2-3 people.

I minus two stars for service and flow:

-Things started poorly at the bar as we ordered our two glasses of wine and it took over 10 minutes even though the bartender acknowledged us waiting way too long. They were waiting for their "wine guy" to come over and pour us. How about you not make me wait 10 minutes and just pour me a glass of wine?

-As we sat down, our server was obviously flustered (although very sweet) and throughout the meal things just arrived late and out of order. This was exemplified when our waitress forgot our crab dish which came out 15 minutes later than everything because she acknowledged that she forgot to put the order in. Mmmmm...okay. 

Dessert was excellent. The strawberry and chocolate dessert was ridiculously good.

Overall, I understand being overwhelmed and making mistakes but I feel it would have been appropriate to acknowledge the issue further and comp a dish or a drink along the way. Taking $10-$15 off for multiple mistakes isn't anything off your end and the thought always goes a long way for me from a service perspective.

$200 out the door for 5 main courses, 2 desserts, and 2 glasses of wine.

Might try this place again in the next year but not jumping out of my seat with some many other great places in town!
author: Jeff R.

description:
Polk Street continues to transform (for better? for worse?) with newly-arrived 1760, the sister, more "casual" dining experience to Acquerello, a restaurant I have yet to dine at. 

The place was abuzz on a Wednesday night, as many people wanted to check out the venue. My table of 4 was told that the menu was meant for sharing, and the menu was organized from "lightest to heaviest." We all started off with drinks, but I was the only one to have a cocktail. The sommelier was knowledgeable and rattled off facts about my dining partner's wines, which was pleasant. My cocktail, the Basil Mezcal Sour, was absolutely delicious, and is definitely getting me on the Mezcal train.

We ordered quite a bit- 2 plates as appetizers, then with each person ordering 2 plates (a total of 10). The shishito peppers were deliciously salted and blistered. I personally had the brussel sprouts and charcoal raviolo. The first was delicious-- super crispy, and topped with a crumbled deviled egg. 

However, the raviolo was a bit underwhelming. I learned this from another fine-dining experience, but in case you didn't notice, "raviolo" means you are only getting one piece of "ravioli." Yes, it's a larger piece of pasta, but just don't be surprised if you order it. The pasta itself is gray (Charcoal?) and filled with a nice, runny egg yolk. While it was very satisfying to break into the raviolo to get to the runnyness inside, I have to say that the pasta itself was a bit too 'al dente' for my liking. Another friend got the raviolo, and mentioned it was her least-favorite plate. The meat-eaters in my group got everything from ceviche to tartare and the duck sandwich, which they all seemed to enjoy.

We also split 2 desserts, which was another mixed bag. We all loved the Brown Butter Cake, but felt that the Peanut Butter Panna Cotte was a bit weird, texturally. (It's served with Jam and white chocolate, so almost like a PB&J?) 

The service was decent, and we weren't made to feel rushed, as we were able to sit around and have conversation, even after the check was all paid. Overall, it was a satisfying meal. I didn't leave feeling hungry (as others had mentioned) but in all honesty, nothing wowed me enough to necessarily say I would go back, unless it was for a cocktail.
author: Bryan B.

description:
Delicious cocktails, food, and great service!  

Why only 3 stars?  Because I don't feel like this is a place I would hurry to rush back for therefore not considering myself as a fan of this place.  This is definitely a place I would stop by if I'm in the neighborhood.  

I had 3 cocktails, pear ginger, peach buck, and pineapple coffee.  All delicious but not as complex as my favorite cocktails at Saison.  

What we had:

Watermelon amuse bouche -  to me just bite sized watermelon, no surprises

Crispy Octopus - tasty

Grilled Pork Belly - very tender and flavorful, delicious!

Cavatelli - the pasta was al dente, excellent!  didn't really taste much flavor from the pork cheek

Squash Ravioli - it's a bit on the sweet side for us.  

**  Wanted to try uni bucatini but was not available.  :(
author: Gina W.

description: I loved the unique menu concept of bites/portions get larger as you work your way down the menu. We enjoyed all six of the dishes we tried. Great service and drink options.
author: Vicki L.

description:
My fiancé and I recently dined at 1760. It was our first time in San fran (we are from Chicago)  and we decided to try 1760, due to its high rating in Yelp. 

Unfortunately, we did not like this place. First, the menu is very small-- there is a burger in the picture here on yelp, but no burger on the menu. Second, the portions are shockingly small and overpriced. Third, we were placed at a community table which was awkward and uncomfortable. Despite all of that, the food was just not very good. Honestly, as soon as we tasted the entree I asked my fiancé to check the area for somewhere else to eat. I hope this review will help someone save $150.
author: Jeff O.

description: Definitely not worth the 3 hour it took to receive our order. Also just unnecessary to need to be so "creative" with the combos. Not my favorite at all.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Food was good but did not wow...

Shishito peppers were yummy with the miso sauce. Palette was treated to an explosion of flavors. Watch out, though, cuz you may get a really hot one (like I did). Be sure to have your beer or water nearby.

Brussels Sprouts in black vinegar with hazelnuts and prosciutto was just OK. I've had much better ones. The sprouts were not roasted enough for me. They were more like steamed/boiled. I prefer them roasted with the outer leaves caramelized and crispy.

The Kabocha Ravioli in a light coconut broth was deeelish! Pop the entire ravioli in your mouth with the broth and be treated to a mouthful of creamy sweet kabocha that tastes nutritious, fresh and light. (Ravioli flavor changes with seasonal vegetable)

Roasted Baby Carrots were nicely caramelized and sweet. 

The Grilled Pork Ribs in hoisin bbq sauce came right off the bones and melted in our mouths with a very slight kick at the end...nice.

Favorite dish of the evening was the Grilled Pork Belly...melted in our mouths with the right amount of lean and fat. So flavorful. Wish I knew how to make this dish. Just thought portion was small compared to price.

The strawberries with charcoal cake was...well, not sure what to say except the cake actually had ground up charcoal in it that tasted gritty.

The cocktail menu is quite eclectic. I had the Pear-Ginger which boasted an enormous Campari ice cube that slowly melted. It was like 2 drinks in one. If you like ginger and grapefruit flavors, you must get this one. I may drop by just to enjoy another one, or two, of these when I'm in the city.

Our server was superb! She explained all the menu items and made sure we had all that we needed throughout the evening.

Tip: 
Everything is meant to be shared. Starting from top of menu, items range from light then increasing to heavier as it goes down the list. Menu changes seasonally, but some items are mainstays although they may change slightly in preparation or accompaniments. 

Make reservations.
author: Lil D.

description:
Outstanding corn ravioli.  Really really amazingly delicious.

I was really looking forward to dinner here, it's literally around the corner from my place and although I adore Aquarello I cannot trick anybody into taking me on a weekly basis.

We started with some amazing cocktails, I had this vanilla thing that looked beautiful and tasted even better. The hamachi appetizer was pretty to look at but nothing spectacular.  The hanger steak and pork belly were fine but not remarkable.  The ravioli is divine. If I ever return ill just order 3 of those bc it's a small serving.  Chocolate deconstructed s'more for dessert is unsightly (ganache looks like a log of poop) but so tasty.
author: Poppy C.

description: Castelvetrano olives. Friendly service. The 1760 and the Celery Chartreuse are spot on.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
I came here yesterday after my friend had told me about her good dining experience. The menu looked tasty and I wanted to try somewhere new so my bf and I came to 1760. We ordered: 

- fingerling potatoes w/ avocado 
- octopus 
- macherroni w/ crab 
- uni bucatini 

We enjoyed the appetizers as they were super tasty. I especially liked the octopus so I would def. recommend that! I also liked the macherroni. It was cooked to the perfect texture and was creamy, but citrusy. The thing that killed our experience was the uni bucatini... We were both extreme disappointed. The noodles and uni were cooked with a cheese sauce that was reminiscent of velveeta. The combination of uni and cheese was just completely wrong. I picked at it, but finally gave up on the dish. 

We didn't opt for dessert so we just asked for the check. The combination of the food + the $80 we threw down unfortunately left me unsatisfied.
author: Jackie M.

description: Service was great! Very friendly staff and food came out nice and quick. The food was delicious! Although for anyone who hasn't been the food is more like tapas so I recommend ordering two per person, or else order a few and charge them among everyone at the table. Their cheesecake is heaven on a plate! The places itself is pretty cool, nice low light and not too noisy.
author: Saidhbh M.

description: AMAZING spot. Exquisite small plates & cocktails in a casual yet sophisticated, community atmosphere. This makes for an excellent date spot since all of the plates are designed for sharing, not to mention they're all outstanding. The waitstaff was on top of everything as well.
author: Audrey Z.

description: Favorite place in SF - perfect combination of laid back chic and exquisite food and, more importantly, drinks.
author: James A.

description: Good food. Definitely try the octopus.  Service is kind and knowledgeable.  The wine list is grandiose but the red wines are still served a tad too warm for the price points.  The burrata was disappointing.  Melted on  Flatbread instead of served fresh.  But everything else was excellent.  I would recommend getting a reservation so you don't have to wait. But it was worth the wait.
author: Jacklyn H.

description: Great way to start your night. Amazing cocktails and food. I love the pork belly. The staff there is really sweet and helpful.
author: Yasmin C.

description: I absolutely love this restaurant! It's in fact one of my favorites in the city. The food is always exceeding my expectations (and they tend to be high), and you can literally close your eyes, point at anything in the menu and trust that it will be delicious. I especially love how they combine ingredients in each dish to create rich amazing flavors that are just amazing. I'm giving 5 stars to the wonderful culinary experience, the flawless service, and really good drinks. The atmosphere is also lovely. It's a perfect place for a romantic date or dinner out with friends. It's always a great choice. Oh and let me not forget, order the duck sandwich! It's amazing. And no, it isn't (or tastes like) just a good ol' sandwich.
author: C S.

description: Food is consistently very good. The little gem salad is reason enough to go back. The poppyseed bread with lavender butter is incredible. Service was way above average. Friendly, attentive and knowledgable on drinks and food. The cavatelli was not something I would order again. Didn't have enough flavor. Definitely order the carrots, roasted and seasoned perfectly.
author: Kevin K.

description:
Wow. Ive never been to a place that blew my.mind like this. Every order was out of this world
 Really. I never had food like this. My taste buds are still recovering. 

Every single thing we ordered was incredible:
Duck sandwich
Peas
Ribs
Ravioli
Lobster ceviche
Hamachi crudo

I think I need a change of pants....
author: Ilya S.

description: Service here was very impressive: fold your napkin as you leave the table, waiting staff was knowledgeable about the menu, enthusiastic about helping their customers, and just over all happy to be around. The food overall was good, not great, some dishes were too salty for my taste. My favorite dishes would have the be the hanger steak and the side of bread that comes with the pork fat.  The duck burger/sandwich was good but way too salty, the burger was split and we still couldn't finish our halves.
author: Mark G.

description:
went on an impromptu date here last night and was pleasantly surprised with the ambiance and service.  service was stellar with everything coming out quickly. 

the uni bucatini is a must order along with the duck sandwich and octopus.

i'll definitely be back here again!
author: Carli F.

description: Been here for brunch several times and enjoyed each experience. The menu is ideal for groups to share. Favorite dishes are the Brioche French Toast and Kimchi Fried Rice. Mimosas by the bottle were good and well-priced.
author: Iva M.

description: We had a great dinner here tonight. Roby, our server, was absolutely fantastic. The food was excellent... Very unique with beautiful presentation. You must try the corn ravioli, pork belly, and the duck sandwich. All around, this place was awesome.
author: Brittany T.

description: My favorite place in the city. So much better than all those other over-rated, must wait months for a reservation restaurants. Every dish is delicious which you get a chance to try since its small plates. My favorites are the Brussels sprouts and pork belly. A lot of people Iike the duck sandwich, but I find it too heavy/filling. It's good, but if I want duck I don't want it overly sauces and dressed. The wine list is amazing, but it gets pricey once you start with the alcohol. This place is amazing though. A must try!
author: Sandra G.

description: special dinner overindulgence...savory and robust flavors of 1760...modern, sleek and contemporary dining...sophisticated cocktails well crafted deliciousness...service impeccable...sweet cornbread the complimentary start this evening...flavorful brussel sprouts to start...hard boiled egg yolk sprinkled...bold good taste in very bite...crispy tender octopus second...slight outer char and wonderful easy chew center...potato compliments and another gluttonous start...uni pasta so well prepared..smooth silky uni keeping traditional sweet form...perfect balance for sweet and salt...noodles bite and uni smooth...finishing off with fried duck burger...switchblade knife stabbed above to keep monster creation standing...self describe the patty similar to a shredded duck confit formed and fried...wonder tender chew...nice warm slaw...between most wonderful bun...great heavy hitting dinner for two...one great cocktail each...$fifty-five per person,...recommend for gluttonous sinfully delicious meals...not for the lightweight salad eaters...
author: Hen A.

description: How did this place get 4 stars? 3 of 4 dishes were bad. The octopus was great, but the crab, bucatini, and duck sandwich were terrible. Drinks were good, ambiance good, service good. My review is purely about the food because that is why I go out to a restaurant. $118 for one of the worst meals of my life.
author: Brandon W.

description:
I haven't been wowed by a restaurant in a while but 1760 changed that around, even with my high expectations going in.  I'd rank this up there with State Bird Provisions right now.

The dishes that stick out in my mind are the monkfish liver mousse, crispy octopus, and roasted carrots.  Yes, they even made CARROTS taste that amazing!

Second tier (but still really really good) were the hamachi crudo, bbq pork belly, and uni bucatini.

The fried duck sandwich was tasty but overrated by Yelp.  The lamb cavatelli I'd definitely skip-- was expecting large hunks of slow-cooked lamb, instead could barely find the teeny bits of meat among the pasta.

The cocktails were also amazing.  Pear-ginger and the mango and spice drink for sweet/fruity cocktails, or try the basil mezcal sour for something different.

We had 4 people sharing 8 dishes + 1 dessert + 6 cocktails, and the damage was 80 per person.  I was concerned about portion sizes since we each got only 1 or 2 bites from each dish, but surprisingly even the guys were getting pretty full by the time the 6th dish came out.
author: S L.

description: Wow!!! Lobster Ceviche, Beef Tartar, Fried Duck Sandwich, Uni Bucatini and Milk Chocolate Ganache. Exactly what I had tonight. I'm speechless. Food was great and was just perfect. Super nice interior design. Love it and will come back again. Highly Recommended.
author: Sapphire S.

description:
we came here on the heels of michael bauers review and it set expectations low.  however, the meal was not disappointing. if you go into it with the right mindset, i suppose you cannot be let down.

on a weeknight, the place was packed.  the space is open, high ceilings, concrete floors.  the noise was ok as we were still able to carry on conversations between the four of us without yelling.  Service was excellent.  Drinks sound innovative and are on the sweet side but may not be for everyone.

the menu can be a bit confusing without any divisions between small/large plates, appetizers/main courses.  There is an invisible line so we opted for a combination.  

We had a squid dish, beef tartare, cavatelli, fried duck sandwich, raviolo, short ribs.  i think that was it.  this is why i take pictures of my food, because without them, i cant remember what i ate.
author: claudia y.

description: I went there for my birthday dinner.  While the food is delicious, I was seated in the middle strip of tables and I felt like I was eating good food in a railroad station because there was so much traffic coming up and down the aisles. So much for a relaxing dinner!  Also, it was two for dinner:, my husband drinks still water, I drink bubbly.  We were asked what we both wanted, we ordered our preferences, and I was given a 1 litre ($7) bottle of water, with no option of something smaller, nor told about this before hand. Ridiculous.  No atmosphere, predatory water policy, sadly, I will never go back.  The celebration dinner turned out to be, "let's hurry up and get out of here."
author: Cynthia T.

description:
Staphylococcal enteritis
That's what I got when I ate the lobster ceviche last Monday October 21st at 11PM.  Rather than go into the gory details, I'll explain what happened when I talked to them Wednesday at 5:40PM.  They basically called me a liar and said that I could not be right and that food borne illness takes at least 12 hours to occur.  The problem was improper food handling, poor hand washing, and a cream based dish that is the perfect medium for Staph.  Since I was the last meal of the day the toxin had plenty of time to grow.  I am a doctor, so I know what I know.
I never even got to ask them what they planned to do to make this right since they so rudely insulted me while scowling at me from their cell phones, when I politely inquired before their evening started.  
This is not how to run a business and I will never eat there again and will tell everyone why.  
Too bad, since I am a big fan of Acquerello and was looking forward to having 1760 be my late night food place.
I do not throw these accusations around lightly and I never mentioned that I would Yelp about it.  They left me no choice.  I feel very angry.  I was ill for the entire next day and could not work.   I wish I could have my $53 back, or at least my health.
author: Ken S.

description:
I had been dyinggggg to try this place for a few months now.  So, as a surprise for my birthday, my boyfriend remembered and made us reservations.  They recommend 4 - 5 dishes for two, but we ordered 6 (and got a freebie for my birthday) AND dessert. And we ate it all.  The amazingness and (almost) perfection of the meal made up for the fact that our drinks took about 20 minutes to arrive. 

Drinks: As I said, they took a LONG time, but they were pretty awesome.  I had the pear ginger and my boyfriend had the blood orange something or other.  4 stars each.

Food:

Lobster ceviche - 10 stars.  It's amazing. The coconut infusion with the lobster was perfect.  The whole dish was absolutely out of this world and a perfect start to the meal.

Beef Tartare - 3 stars.  It was okay, but they put an asian spin on it and the basil and mint overpowered the meat.  I'll take good ol' raw meat with a qual egg yolk on it any day.  

Burrata - it comes on toast and it is really awesome. My boyfriend isn't usually a huge cheese fan, but he'd probably give this 5 stars. I think it was his favorite or second favorite dish.  I'd give it 4 stars.

Charred octopus - 5 stars. I'm an octopus snob and this was delicious. Perfectly tender on the inside and the smoky char on the outside was wonderful.

Uni Buccatini -- 4 stars.  Neither of us are huge pasta fans, but the reviews on yelp had me sold for this dish. I also NEVER order uni out at sushi restaurants, so my boyfriend was really surprised when I wanted this dish.  He loves uni, so he was all for it.  

Squash stuffed ravioli -- 4 stars.  Freebie dish! Yay! We were getting full at this point, but it was still pretty great.

Pork Belly - 5 stars.  It was delicious.  I would have preferred to have a bit more crisp on the outside, but when it comes down to a 4 or 5 star review, I'd go with 5 stars.

Smore's dessert - 4 stars.

If you add up all my reviews, you'd think I'd give this place 4 stars, but the meal, as a whole, was something really special. The pairing and melding of flavors is something you only get in a handful of restaurants and more than made up for any shortcomings on dishes. Go here. Do it.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Despite the great food and wine and the beautiful remodel, the customer service completely ruined the experience for me. Taking into the account it's supposed to be a nicer restaurant with higher prices, that MUST be on point (I mean, that's half of what you're paying for, right?) 

To start off, we ordered two drinks. One of the drinks came right away, but 10 minutes later, no second drink. We had to ask again, and apparently they forgot. Took them another few minutes, and no apology or anything. Annoying, but still fine. The breaking point was when the bill came. They charged us for the wrong drink, which happens, but when pointed it out, their response was awful. I politely pointed out that he had put the wrong drink on the bill, and he looks at my with annoyance and goes "are you sure?" (this wasn't even the same guy who poured the drink, so how would be know?) When I told him what I got, and what was on the bill, he then responds with "Well, they're the same price." Umm, WTF? Seriously? The drink he charged us for was a higher price, and even if they were the same price, that was a super rude response. We pointed out the price difference, and he gave us a fake "sorry" and walked away. Overall, I walked away from here really annoyed we had just spent a lot of money and gotten horrible customer service. Will not be back.
author: audrey k.

description: My new favorite restaurant in the city! The food and drinks here are great! When you order, you order a bunch of different plates for everyone to share. I came here with my parents and we ordered about 6 dishes and 2 desserts and we were stuffed! Everything tasted delicious. I also ordered the pear-ginger cocktail which was super yummy. Would definitely recommend and definitely will come back.
author: Arda S.

description: One of the worst customer service I've experienced. We had a feeling that we were lost and forgotten there. We waited for our drinks about 20 minutes. Meals were small, so you'll still be hungry by the end of the dinner. Deserts were awful. Besides that they brought them with 15 minutes difference. If you want to spoil your evening 1760 is the best place to go!
author: Ivan K.

description:
Despite the mixed reviews, we tried 1760.  We both love the very refined and romantic sister-restaurant Acquerello, and we were eager to check out their take on a casual spot.  Unfortunately, we were very disappointed.  The bottom line is that for the $185 we spent on dinner for two, including the tip, we could have had an exceptional meal at many other restaurants in the City instead of the mediocre one we got at 1760.

The restaurant had an upbeat vibe and was decorated okay, though it veered too much toward bare and unfinished, rather than chic minimalism. The music was super loud, like a club, so conversation was almost impossible.  The service was very good, and our server was friendly, attentive, and helpful with making choices.  The real weakness, and it is a major one for a restaurant, was the food.  The menu is made up of small plates, and we tried 6 (it seems like a lot of food, but most of the portions are very small), and not a single dish was a stand-out.  Even worse, four of the dishes were barely edible.  The chef seems to love putting huge quantities of sugar, salt, or vinegar (and sometimes all three) on nearly every dish.  Some dishes were cloyingly sweet, others were terribly salty, and a couple were drowning in vinegar.  I love sugar, salt and vinegar, but I don't want my meal to be overpowered with those ingredients.  Even the cocktails we tried were heavy on the sugar. Surprisingly, the dessert was the only thing that wasn't too sweet, but sadly the sponge cake I had was bland and mushy.  The goat cheese plate was pretty good, but you can't really mess up good cheese you bought from someone else.

Even if the bill had been less, it still would not have been a value for the poor quality of food we got.  I am surprised Acquerello would want to have their name associated with this establishment.  Save your time and money and try some place else.
author: Christopher B.

description: Check it out before they get their Michelin star and do the customary Michelin star price raise.
author: Nathan M.

description: Honestly, this place gets way too much hype. It is absurdly expensive for the little amount of food you're getting. I will say that the food is good, but I went with a friend, didn't get drinks and we still payed $70 each and were still hungry after. One might say you're paying for the experience since its a beautiful venue, but maybe reserve this one more for a fancy night of going out for a drink, instead of the food.
author: Elena F.

description: 3 stars is good, but not going back good. I live and work really close so I was hoping this would be a great new place to take people for a less divey Polk Street dinner.  The food was for the most part really good. The service was good, but the place seems like it should be in the FiDi. No neighborhood feel, but I guess that is what they are angling for.  Supposedly it is an offshoot of the place across Sacramento from Brownie's that is in the former mausoleum. It is one of those restaurants that is less than 2 blocks from home, yet I never had any interest in going to. I guess this place, although I hoped to like it, is now in the same boat.
author: James T.

description: Sister restaurant to Acquerello, which if you haven't been, it's a must. The vibe at 1760 is vibrant. Order the whole menu and share with the table.  The menu changes so go with the flow. Don't puss out on dessert and a espresso to end your experience.
author: Sara K.

description:
I've always loved Aziza's cocktails, so when I found out 1760 was supposed to be Acquarello food + mixology from Aziza, I had to try it.  I love the small seasonal / local plates + artisan mixology. 

The menu isn't separated into sections per se, but dishes get more substantial as you go. Sharing family style is a great way to go, and they recommended 2-3 dishes per person. The 2 of us ended up with 6 dishes, a dessert, and some cocktails, which ended up being a good amount. 

Drinks: 
- Meyer Lemon Fresno Chile: tart from the sauvignon blanc vinegar and lemon, slightly spicy
- Mango and Spice: not as spicy as I had hoped with the long pepper, black pepper, and cayenne, but it wasn't too syrupy
- Cucumber/grape: great for summer or in between courses as a palate cleanser
- Pear and Ginger: love the red campari ice cube, which is a beautiful color. It has pretty pungent ginger flavor

Food: 
- Amuse bouche: hot and sour celery with blue cheese, eaten in one bite with your fingers, tasted exactly as it was described. I love blue cheese, so for me, it was a good way to get my appetite going 
- Warm pears: initially sounded a bit generic, but we gave it a try anyway, and it turned out to be the BEST dish of the night.  The pears were cooked just to the right texture, the goat cheese on the side of the bowl was just the right amount, and the smoked pomegranate and lightly dressed frisée helped to lighten it a bit
- Lobster ceviche: it came with a good amount of fresh lobster meat, accompanied by avocado, pineapple, kaffir lime. I prefer the lobster unadulterated, so I could have done without the cream underneath, but overall, it was a nice take on lobster
- Duck egg: fried, runny yolk, served on top of smoked salmon with Meyer lemon creme fraiche and perfectly textured croutons. You really do need to get each component in each bite to make the dish, and I wish it could have somehow come with more runny egg yolk 
- Pork belly: creative, served like a southern BBQ theme. There was a coleslaw purée underneath and a purple potato salad (great colors, fancy version of picnic and BBQ foods). The flavor on the pork belly was great, and it wasn't completely fatty, which was nice. The berry gelee on the side also went well with the pork
- Cavatelli: we debated between this and the uni pasta, but as it was the first colder / rainy night, we went with the more Italian comfort food style dish.  The pasta was fresh, cooked al Dante, and the vinegar braised pork was interesting. Still, I would have preferred a pork ragu, since the dish became pretty acidic in combination with the tomatoes
- Fried duck sandwich: essentially a duck burger. I like that they didn't just use a rich brioche or else it would have been too much.  The slaw was just ok, remoulade was also ok, but I loved the pickles.  Sadly, it did not come with fries 

For dessert, the peanut butter panna cotta was a very unique creation. With the fruit and berries, you would expect a PB+J kind of taste, but the panna cotta itself was light, and the peanut butter taste was subtle. However, once you add the white crunchy bits on top, you get not only texture but a good peanut butter kick. This is definitely one of the more unique and memorable desserts I've had lately.

Our server was so pleasant and attentive, and when cocktails took a while, he took care of the delayed drinks for us. He also kept checking into see if we liked our selections, and he changed our plates multiple times as we progressed through the meal.  Pacing of food was good, and they've definitely gotten the hang of things there. 

Even though 1760 is located supposedly in nob hill, it's not impossible to park around here, especially as it gets later on a weeknight.  It's definitely a welcome addition to the neighborhood, and it's perfect either for a small group or a date.
author: Marilyn T.

description: Great food. Loved the lobster ceviche and pork belly.
author: Adam K.

description: Great place to come and hang out. The space is warm and inviting, the wait staff friendly and knowledgeable. The food is the star, all dishes were creative, interesting and flavorful. The cocktails were also well conceived, tasty and fun. I highly recommend this place for a casual night out.
author: Garden Lover S.

description: Wow -- yum on the popcorn kale and grilled Octopus. Wine selection very nice too!! Get the white burgandy =)
author: Lisa B.

description: I've been to 1760 3 times and all three were quite divine. There are too many creative dishes to expand on and I see that other reviewers have done just this. If you haven't tried it, I encourage you to check it out. The flavors, uniqueness and creativity of most every dish makes this a fine, fine gourmet restaurant. I actually like it better than Acquerello. I think it's much more exciting and cutting-edge creative with new, unique flavors and combinations of tastes.
author: Janice H.

description: Great place for small plates and cocktails before a show or the movies. I loved the crab, brussel sprouts, and steak tartare dishes. But my favorite by far is the Duck burger! Its rich and flavorful and perfectly cooked. My husband and I split the burger which was more than enough when its paired with other side dishes. Also had the banana bread with Chunky Monkey ice cream and dehydrated peanut butter (like fancy Butterfinger flakes) which was to die for! All told, the bill without cocktails was $70... not bad for San Francisco prices!
author: Leila H.

description:
You cannot enjoy this bar without a reservation, as there is no 'hangout' space.

I cannot remember making a reservation to have a drink, ever.

When there was space, bartenders were great.

This hostess is a bitch.  Owners should know.
author: Steven H.

description:
Consistently delicious!

Mackerel 
Ribs
Chris L.
"5:00 Stirs"
Neighborhood gem, go find out for yourself
author: Ame W.

description: Great food, drink and atmosphere. Come early to get a spot otherwise you need to wait !! They always packed and busy every evening.!!
author: Katie E.

description:
We just had dinner our second time here last night. First was months ago and at the bar. Fantastic, sexy destination for great cocktails or dinner and drinks. The space is modern, elegant. The food is really divine. 
We had the burrata, fingerling potatoes, corn ravioli and hangar steak. The steak itself was superb but the sauce a little staid. All others were awesome. The fingerling potatoes, novel and mouthwatering. Watermelon and strawberry shrub cocktails refreshing and delicious, especially the basil touch to the strawberry.
