Dessert of the bavarian cake was playful looking like out of Dr.
Seuss book and was tasty and fun like a modern, gourmet version of Fruit Loops. Service was attentive. 
Highly recommend
author: Chetan I.

description: Let me start by saying, I very rarely post on yelp because I'm lazy and not many places impress me to be honest.  With that being said, I took my lady out for the evening after hearing good things about this place.  It had a great atmosphere, very respectful staff, and the food was absolutely DELICIOUS.  Every single meal had my taste buds shouting for more yummyness.  Even the drinks were phenomenal, I was genuinely blown away by the complexities and flavors in each drink/bite.  After dinner was over and my lady and I were discussing how great our meal was, desert arrived.  I have never seen desert so creatively but together and tasteful.  Chef Adam did an absolute awesome job and I will continue to recommend 1760 to my friends and family in the bay area!!  Again, thanks for a great time and phenomenal food.  Until next time..
author: Anthony P.

description: The restroom was nice and clean.  They had those fairly expensive thick disposable hand towels sitting out and not in a dispenser.  Nice!  I could see a tenant with really wet hands possibly contaminating the whole stack, but thankfully for me that wasn't the case.  It also seems that a bathroom attendant must replenish this stack probably hourly, so also glad you were on top of that.  I liked the black rocks in the hand sink, which added a great aesthetic.  Just don't let them get all mossy and gross, which they weren't.  I also liked the communal trough style hand sink outside of the restroom, bc sometimes you only need to wash your hands.  Quite thoughtful!
author: Big U.

description: Really good cocktails. They are very creative. Their food is good. We have eaten here a few times, and their menu changes which is nice.
author: J. L.

description: Our first experience was close to perfect. Everything was interesting and fresh. Beautiful room, original cocktails, attentive service and inventive dishes. Pasta with pork cheek was amazing.
author: Stu M.

description:
Hip and modern decor, beautifully classy with a touch of posh.

Highly anticipated as I hear this is a sister restaurant of the well renowned Acquerello.
Food lived up to it's expectations.  

The diced scallop sashimi with caviar and uni was an excellent way to start.  The flavors worked very well together.

Everything else that followed in succession (lightest to richest as served) was solid.  

We enjoyed some uni pasta, the bbq ribs (mediocre. The flavors weren't exciting as they we reminiscent of some Chinese/Vietnamese house special ribs), fried duck sandwich (as good as they say, very rich), crispy calamari (textures were intriguing and the avocado mousse works well with it), burrata cheese on toast points (ok dish, asian pears gave it a nice touch and presentation was beautiful), and the mezza? for dessert which consisted of shaved strawberry ice and rhubarb compote and ice cream.  This was absolutely fantastic. Very nice way to freshen and end a meal.

Cocktails were original and very tasty as well. Good job guys.
author: Tim T.

description:
3.5 stars.
I was a little wary after reading some of the reviews, but was generally pretty pleased with our early Wednesday night dinner at the bar of 1760.
I think the criticisms of portion size vs. price are a bit unfounded (if you think the value at 1760 is bad, don't go to Waiheke!).  Sizes were not huge but they were far from small.  We are big eaters, and we were full after 6 items between us, each around $10-$15 (tapas style, but larger than tapas servings).  
We'd read raves about the corn ravioli and were a bit disappointed with it - filling was heavenly but the pasta was thick, chewy and cold.  Our favorite thing was probably the duck burger - delicious and quite large ($15).  The steak tartare was a mixed bag - the almond spread was pretty yucky and threatened to ruin the fabulous meat and salad.  Speaking of salad - all the little salad accompaniments were fantastic. Do not ignore them! Some fabulous things happening there. Besides the duck burger all the dishes we tried had some high and low points.  None were bad, but all needed a tweak or two.  
Drinks were delicious but didn't go so well with the food.  If possible, I'd suggest waiting to eat until after cocktails are done.  I was concerned when I saw the very short and largely foreign wines by glass list, but was very pleasantly surprised after tasting a couple - great picks.
Service was exceptionally friendly and attentive if a touch confused at times.  There were a lot of people behind the bar with big variations in training and menu knowledge.  Our service didn't really suffer too much, but it was obvious that a couple of the people weren't quite ready for prime time.  Hopefully they'll get their legs quickly, as the crowds were piling in when we left around 7pm. 
Atmosphere is casual, modern and airy - liked it.
author: Ellen H.

description: Probably one of the best meals I had recently. Amazing service and amazing food. You have to get the lobster ceviche, one of the most flavorful dishes I've ever had.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Service is great. Community table was a blast. Food and drinks are exceptional. I'm still thinking about the duck sandwich and it's been weeks. It's a little pricey but definitely worth the splurge!
author: Roya P.

description: We arrived a little early and ordered drinks at the bar while waiting to be seated.  The restaurant is gorgeous and ambience very conducive to chatting over a cocktail with friends. We took advantage of the community style seating at the front of the restaurant looking out onto Washington Street. The pear-ginger cocktail with Campari ice cube was perfect - not too sweet, refreshing, and not at all syrupy. It being Negroni week, they also had an impressive menu of variations on and including the classic Negroni.  There was a slight wait to be seated, but the staff were friendly, very attentive and seated us as soon as our table was ready.  We ordered the hamachi, mushroom cavatelli, roasted chicken, fingerling potatoes, and spring peas.  The hamachi was of course gone in a second, and we enjoyed the additional ceviche dish for the wait on our table.  What stood out the most to me was the texture of the cavatelli that matched the mushrooms perfectly.  The lightness of the accompanying sauce was a perfect complement to the cavatelli.  The whole roasted chicken was done well and again, the sauce provided a perfect complement with its creamy but somewhat tart flavor.  Both fingerling potatoes and spring pea dishes were also done well - combining the inherent flavors of the ingredients with light seasoning for a just right taste - but my mind kept turning back to the flavoring of those sauces....sooo good but not quite traditional.  We had a great meal, and I left wishing I could have tried a little of everything else on the menu.  Clearly, I would definitely come back for more.
author: Christine T.

description: I went there for my friends birthday. Food was interesting, unique and fresh. We have carrots which were really really good. We also have brussel sprouts that were surprisingly delicious. Everything was served on small plates. I also really like the interior of the restaurant it was very modern and clean. Overall we had a great time. This is a good place for a date or a special occasion.
author: Mike B.

description:
Everything about 1760 was so great! Such a fun atmosphere (sat at the communal table with a big party) with plenty of amazing dishes and great service. 

Favorite dishes/cocktails (it's hard to pick from the list - it was all good!):
Meyer Lemon Fresno Chile cocktail was super refreshing 
Shishito Peppers - could snack on these for forever
Crispy Octopus
Pork Belly
ALL the seafood - Tuna Sashimi, Lobster Ceviche

Service: 
The sommelier was knowledgeable and happy to recommend some really great, reasonably-priced wines. The waitress talked us into Fernet shots at the end of the night since we decided to forgo dessert and they were delicious. Not your regular Fernet Branca - this was much better. 

To sum it up: you need to come here multiple times and order the whole menu, or come in a big group to taste everything. It's worth it.
author: Amy R.

description: One of my favorite restaurants on Polk street. Trendy atmosphere with super nice bartenders and servers. Cocktails are creative, sometimes almost too pretty to drink. My favorite is the pear and ginger. I've probably tried almost dish, but always order the shishito peppers. The quality and presentation of each dish is consistent and each is beautifully prepared. I also love the chocolate ganache - it's a deconstructed smore and one of the best deserts I've eaten. I also love the music - sometimes during a late dinner they play 90's hip hop (but it's not loud or distracting).
author: Alya G.

description: After a second visit, I'm even more impressed. It's hard to find pasta made so well and the small plates really are outstanding. Add that to a limited, small-producer wine menu (w/the purveyor on hand to chat) and it's clear 1760 is doing a lot right.
author: Corey B.

description: Decides to try this out because House of Prime Rib had a 2 hour wait. The staff here are very friendly and helpful. The menu is simple and light but there is a method to their madness. The different items all have different tastes so it's hard to give an overall grade for the food. Definitely not a good place to being groups. This is more of a place to go on a date. With that said this place is almost perfect mainly because of the inconsistency in food flavor, but makes it up with the atmosphere.
author: Jr A.

description:
Wonderful dining experience.
The food is creative and delicious with just the right amount of surprise. The menu varies but typically comprises small plates of seafood, veg, and a couple of meat options.  The raw seafood combinations are favorites (caviar, uni, scallop is amazing, as is the lobster ceviche). Service is spot-on: classically non-obtrusive but attentive, combined with being friendly and casual.
author: A. B.

description:
in three words, our experience was: Overpriced. Lackluster. Disappointing.

My husband and I have been wanting to try this place since it opened. It's always been too busy for us to get a reservation at a reasonable hour on a night we've decided to go out. We've figured that, because it's always busy, it must be good. The menu usually looks pretty appealing. We finally went last night because my brother was in town visiting. Given the overall rating, I was hopeful that it was be a great meal... we were sorely disappointed.

After telling the waiter it was our first time at the restaurant, he urged us to order "two or three items per person," which seemed ridiculous to us, given the prices on the menu ranging from $9 - $42 a plate. We ended up ordering three items -- the lobster ceviche, the fried duck sandwich, and the pork belly (plus the $5 bread and whipped pork fat, which was 5 small slices of bread). My husband ordered a cocktail.

When the lobster ceviche arrived, we understood why he told us to order more food. The proportion was miniscule.. and for $19... ridiculous. I was also turned off that the menu didn't indicate that the ceviche had cilantro in it--some people (including me) have a major aversion to cilantro--and it turned me off of the dish completely. It's one word. Add it to your menu if it's in a dish you're serving. While the duck sandwich and pork belly were more reasonable entree proportions, they were not worth the price tag. Pork belly is a hot menu item right now, and a place with prices like this should nail it....but it was off--like it had been sitting under the heat lamp for a few too many minutes. It was room temperature when it arrived at our table. The duck sandwich was good, but not great. Our bill was over $100, and we left hungry--ending up going elsewhere for more food that didn't cost an arm and a leg.

Our service was as lackluster as the food. Once our waiter realized we wouldn't be racking up a $500 bill (just a $100 one, as it turned out), our service felt rushed. We had multiple, different people delivering food and bussing our table. My husband told our waiter not to take his unfinished drink, and moments later, another man walked by the table and snagged his unfinished cocktail without asking. The only kudos I can give our waiter is keeping our water glasses full--considering that was the only thing my brother and I were drinking. 

There are way too many choices in the city for a place like this to survive. Maybe there's a market out there of clientele that can afford it, but it certainly isn't "affordable" by any means, and I don't think it belongs in the neighborhood. Sad to say, we will NOT be returning to 1760.
author: Allyson U.

description: Love love this place.  The food is 5 stars.  I feel like its a bit pricey, but its cool if u go with 4/5 people then you can share a lot of the small plates. Very tasty.
author: Lyly N.

description: Been here close to six times already. I really enjoy the small plates that are pretty tasty. Never had something that I didn't like. And the cocktails of course are a thing of Beauty.
author: mel l.

description: OMG.... OMG......love love this place.... Everything is so delicious, presentation artfully done and service impeccable. Our server space our orders and allowed us to take our time to sip our wine and enjoy our food. Shishito Peppers - suprisingly sweet with a few HOT in-between; Lobster ceviche - best ever tasted...ahh... the addicting sauce... we wanted to lick the serving spoon/plate; Lollipop kale - not sure what lollilop means but it is so good...didn't want to share but I had to ...next came the Hangar steak marinated with the most tasty rub,  mackerel on eggplant - perfectly cooked and our most favorite of all the favorites - if you love saffron & chorizo - be sure to get the octopus! We were stuffed but found room for the Milk chocolate Ganache. Most disappointing - they serve four barrel. Sadly, they do not serve Blue bottle, Verve, Stumptown or Sightglass!
author: Jay S.

description: Loved this place! I originally tried to book it for a date night but it was too hard to get a reservation. I ended up bringing clients there for a team dinner. The food is served tapas style which is fun for a group and you get to try really unique dishes. The cocktails were also fantastic and had great combinations. I had the Pear-ginger which I highly recommend. My fave dishes were the Brussel sprouts and crab Mac n cheese! Delicious. We also had a banana bread desert and chocolate ganache that was like a deconstructed s'more. Incredible. Great service too everyone was nice and attentive. This place would be good for a date, girls night, and even for work.
author: Amanda B.

description: Man, this place was pricey but well worth it! The meal consisted of the Hamachi Crudo, Dungeness Crab, Brussels Sprouts, BBQ Pork Belly, and Bucatini. I enjoyed every single bite, but my favorite was the Hamachi. It had a perfect blend of flavors with a nice little kick of spice. The cocktails were also great. I had the Pear Ginger, but my boyfriend's Garam Masala-Cardamom was quite tasty as well. Topping off the excellent meal was the excellent service. The staff was very welcoming, kind, and attentive from the moment we arrived to the moment we left. The hostess even helped me put my coat on. Top notch in every way.
author: Victoria G.

description: Opening night was fun! The cocktails are tasty, creative and consistent. The head bartender is a hottie : ) Food is good to the last bite. I prefer treating the dishes as individual entrées. The portions were a little on the small side to share like the waiter suggested. Overall, I'll definitely return for a date.
author: Moises T.

description:
This place is awesome! I've been waiting for a decent restaurant to open on Polk, and this is it! They completely remodeled the old La Parilla, and it looks so clean and modern, with lots of natural lighting. We ate at the bar, and the bartenders were so nice and knowledgable about the food and the drinks. Christopher is their head bar guy, and he was great. 

The food is small plates to share, and they are so yummy - the beef tartare, the warm potato salad, and the fried octopus were amazing! So much flavor, and not too heavy. Its all a bit pricey, but in my opinion, it is worth it. The only downside is that the wine list is limited, with the cheapest glass costing $11 - maybe they'll expand on that later on. All in all, awesome new place in SF!
author: Suzie P.

description: We arrived here at 10:15 last Saturday evening with them supposedly seating till 11pm. We ordered our four dishes and wine and while still eating our main courses our server approached us with menus at 10:45 saying it was last call for food, dessert and drinks.  Seriously?! While we're eating our meal and while it's fifteen minutes before you even stop seating?  This isn't exactly the cheapest place (nor the most expensive) and they seem a little undeservedly full of themselves anyway, but what sort of place expects you to choose your dessert and any additional drinks while you're still "enjoying" your main courses.  I asked her if I understood correctly and she cheerfully told me that it had been a slow night.  That may well have been the case but this is not good service at all and we weren't dawdling through our meal. We passed on ordering anything at all even though we wanted dessert and just got out of there and let them go home or out to the bars.  That was my second time there and certainly my last.  The food was okay and the duck sandwich was great.
author: Patrick D.

description:
Best of the west. Ravioli is magic in your mouth. Lobster finally meets the perfect chef,  light and delicious. 
A San Francisco treasure, don't miss it!
author: Wendy P.

description: Thank goodness Parilla is gone and 1760 is here. I love this place - the food is great and so is the service. I haven't had a bad thing here and the staff are always so friendly. My favorites are the lobster ceviche and the lollipop kale. The duck sandwich is yum too but so rich. The milk chocolate genache dessert is sooo good. You can't go wrong here.
author: Elzabeth G.

description: Had a fantastic dinner tonight with my fiancée and future parents. We ordered most of the menu and I would particularly recommend the shishito peppers, the lobster ceviche, the Brussel sprouts, and the pasta dishes. The wines were also excellent--you're in good hands with their recommendations. We can't wait to go back!
author: BJ S.

description: I had a great meal at 1760.  Highlights were the corn ravioli and the uni spaghetti.  The portions are somewhat inconsistent, the macaroni was enough for an entre, but the ravioli would not be filling enough for a main.
author: Emily B.

description:
We had a near perfect, wonderful, tasty, fun dining experience at 1760 last night, party of 4, excellent special "1760 Drinks" very friendly staff, great layout/design,
excellent food, sharing made sense, the chicken($42) was one of the Best in The City!
We have been walking by for over a year and they are always busy, we did an early Sunday dinner and it was nice n slow and then it filled up, the Buzz was not too loud,
Beer n Wine were reasonable, one desert 4 spoons and it was a Done Deal. We'll be back SOON...
author: Peter J.

description:
5 stars for food but two stars for the quantity/price ratio. 

Brussels sprouts have never tasted better.  The cavatelli with tomatoes and pork cheeks was perfectly al dente and the sauce was excellent.  Everything we had was inventive, but not fussy. And delicious.

BUT: four tiny pieces of hamachi for $16. The cavatelli was $17. You would have to double or triple the portion to have a full size portion, bringing the price of a bowl of pasta to at least $34. The $8 angel food cake consisted of tiny pieces of torn cake, covered with (admittedly delicious) brown sugar whipped cream.  I think there were 2 strawberries sliced on the plate. I could only laugh. It was like eating leftovers. 

Restaurateurs seem to have found a great way to lower food costs -- small plates. Cut portions in half, while only cutting the price a little.
author: eve t.

description:
Food: really great and unique food, worth the prices

Service: good, but almost too attentive.

Atmosphere: can get pretty crowded but a nice layout. Good for a date.
author: Phil S.

description: Love the food and drinks here. Get the uni bucatini, pork belly, lobster ceviche!
author: Veronica S.

description: This place is weird and way overpriced. We just happened to stumble in here while walking down Polk looking for a place that had some open seats and this is what we found. My date orders a bowl of cooked whole peppers. I thought peppers were more of a side type dish that you eat in addition to an entre or meat or something but no, this was served by itself like it was an appetizer. She also got these corn ravioli things that were tiny and came like 5 on a plate for $18. Neither food item was that good but charged us very premium prices. Our waitress was also weird and totally in our face (Jamie?), but whatever. The only decent thing I had there was my drink. It was some spicy Indian bourbon drink and it was actually really good and balanced. I was pretty impressed. But then again, it cost me $14 so it better be. Food is lame, drinks are decent, I won't ever go back.
author: Rick M.

description: I had the pleasure of dining at 1760 as well as a small handful of "top pick" restaurants across foodie blogs on a recent trip to SF. 1760 was absolutely the highlight of my entire trip and one of the best meals I've ever had. Coming from Vegas, the new land of celebrity chefs, I've enjoyed the Robuchons, Jose Andres, and Mario Batali's of the world... 1760 just raised the bar. With each plate you imagine that the next won't be able to surpass the last but the food continues to surprise. Absolutely loved it.
author: Travis F.

description: Love this place!  First time here. Beautiful ambiance, amazing cocktails and friendly staff. Haven't tried the food yet.
author: Blynn B.

description:
One of my favorites spots in SF.  I started with the hamachi crudo, which was excellent (and even made me eat my least favorite food, celery).  The maccheroni is possibly my favorite pasta dish (better than anything I've had at Babbo, and on par with the best of Marea), while the uni bucatini was another fantastically prepared pasta that in my mind was only marginally beaten by the maccheroni.  My dessert, a chocolate ganache, was decent, if not at the same level as the pastas.

Other aspects of the dinner experience were fantastic as well.  The restaurant is spacious, the bar area and its noise is separated from the main dining area, and the service is top notch.  Would definitely return to try all the other options on the menu.
author: Josh Q.

description: I thought the food at this restaurant was very poor. It had a creative menu, so I was excited to try it. But in its effort to be innovative, it lost the most important thing- to actually have decently tasting food. We had the goat cheese, ribs, and hanger steak. 1) I have never had goat cheese that I did not like- outside of this restaurant. 2) the ribs were a bad take on some Thai food- they should have left it to the Thai restaurants, 3) my mom had her first bite of the steak  and just said, "it's so chewy." The steak is paired with a tomatoes and green onions that are cold, so not only was it chewy, it was also cold. I rarely write reviews, but I just felt it was a crime to take out $90 for such horrible food. Please don't waste your money.
author: Meagan C.

description:
Very slick and modern looking space. 
We ordered 5 dishes for two people but we would've been fine with just 4. It was a little too much.
 We got the octopus which was amazing, Lobster ceviche was really good, Shishito peppers, Brussels sprouts and beef short ribs. They were all very good. I could do without the short ribs, they were ok, nothing extraordinary.
author: Nazanin S.

description: Great small plate offering with a great wine list. The Brussels Sprouts were so beyond expectations. Can't believe I'm raving about Brussels Sprouts. The steak was easily cut with a fork. Service was top rate. A lovely night out!
author: C S.

description: LOVE IT!   1760 is a very welcome addition to this area of polk.  Based on the other reviews, I think the menu changes a lot, I didn't seen many of the things other people were writing about on the menu.  There were two of us, we had 4 items which were enough.  The wine list was great, really wide range of prices which I liked.  Service was terrific!   Lots of nice touches in this place, felt like the pricing was on par.
author: DC T.

description: Ate at the bar last week, just a few drinks and appetizers and was very impressed by the excellent, professional staff.  Bartenders are absolutely amazing; the cocktail menu fresh and as a whole 1760 has a terrific atmosphere.  Only complaint can be the portion size, which is absolutely abysmal, think micro-food when you order, however, the Duck sandwich is adequately priced and you won't go home hungry.  The rest of the dishes are miniscule -- beautifully presented, but really when you are spending $50+ per person for drink, appetizer and entree please, please load on a bit more food.
author: Enrich S.

description: Delicious sl such great duck sandwich.  Usually packed, but good ambiance. Make a reservation or you'll have to find for some common space.
author: John L.

description: Came to 1760 for a celebratory dinner with my boyfriend and had an amazing meal. The ambiance felt very modern and "New York" and the food was plated beautifully. The food and drinks were delicious - the steak tartare and grilled pork belly were favorites as well as the chocolate ganache dessert. Highly recommend dinner here!
author: Vidya D.

description:
Amazing. 

Always packed, and for good reason. Our server and runners and bartenders were very attentive but not interruptive, the ambiance was classy but hardly pretentious.

Ranking of entrees goes as follows:
1. Octopus paella - best dish ever!!!
2. Burrata 
3. Uni buscatini
5. Corn Ravioli
4. Dungeness crab
5. Chocolate ganache
6. Shishito peppers
7. Duck burger 

The cocktails were fun too. But as with the food, don't expect too much portion for your buck. You're paying for taste, presentation and a uniquer-than-norm experience... Not quantity.
author: Mo P.

description: I've been a few times and have always enjoyed it here.  I don't love the decor, but the food makes up for it.  You must get the duck sandwich.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Amazing ! We had such a great evening on our first visit to 1760. We were warmly welcomed at the door and quickly seated and offered menus and drinks. 
 Our server was knowledgeable, sincere, and attentive . The entire service staff was extraordinarily helpful and personable. It was an especially nice touch to have Gianpaolo,the friendly and charismatic owner pour our wine and stay for a bit of conversation toward the end of the meal. He was relaxed and charming, in spite of having been open for business only a few weeks. He seems to have it all under control.

  The ambience is spare, sophisticated and chic, with perfect music and lighting for contemporary city dining. Polk Street has never looked so good as it does from the inside of the tall, curved windows that comprise the front wall.

Every dish was outstanding,beautifully presented, and very generous portions...The octopus was a favorite...but so was the hamachi, beef tartare, the peppers, brussels sprouts...The chocolate reinvention of s'mores was  sublime. All the basics had been turned on edge just enough to make them new and remarkable.

There were dishes I would still like to try ,an extensive wine list,...and I won't forget  about  the enticing  cocktails that might draw me in some evening.
 We are so lucky to live in the neighborhood...we will certainly go back! 

We are long time clients of Acquerello, with great affection and respect for their  enduring example of Italian food  and  service at its finest. 
We have to give a nod to Giancarlo Paterlini and Suzette,the owners of  Acquerello for their great influences. Like father,like son, it seems when it comes to getting it right in a restaurant. 

  Expert training and good genes can't hurt, but Gianpaolo has really nailed it in this space of his own creation.....Complimenti!!
author: Debra S.

description:
Awesome experience from the hostess all the way through to dinner.  Amazing cocktails and great unique food.  Quality is actually superior to price point in my opinion.

Staff is top notch. Haven't experienced such good service in a long time. Thank you to the great bartenders, chefs and servers!
author: Meredith G.

description: Last night I went to 1760 for the first time. It was lovely. Isabella was gracious and accommodating. The food was very good, and the ambiance was clean and sexy.
author: Catherine R.

description: I have never had a dish served, explained, and then, removed, and served to another table. Odd experience...would like to try again, but, not in a hurry.
author: Maven G.

description: Excellent food. So many delicious plates and cocktails to try.  We will definitely be back.
author: Brett B.

description: I had one of the most amazing dining experiences here. I had 5 dishes from their menu and they were all equally amazing. I had the Bucatini, potatoes, Short Ribs, Octopus, and the Duck Sandwich. The short ribs were so tenders and the octopus and duck sandwich were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Our waiter was very nice and had all our dishes come out in a certain order. It was like a symphony of flavors starting with the potatoes and ending in a grand finale with the Duck Sandwich. The restaurant was packed which is indicative of how popular it is. After that meal, I can definitely understand why. It was one of the best dining experiences I've ever had in SF.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
I had the 1760 special cocktail, the lobster ceviche, bucatini with uni, chocolate ganache and a glass of a light red wine.  I forget the name.

The cocktail was soooo yummy.  I could have sipped on that all day long.  The ceviche was perfect.  Just perfect.  

It was good to taste the bucatini but I think it was the weakest of what I ordered.  It was great in the start but as it cooled it sort of congealed and just isn't as nice.  It's very heavy and rich but it sort of reminded me of a very rich, sweet mac & cheese.  If someone else in your group orders it, have a taste but I wouldn't order it again myself.  And I love uni.

The chocolate ganache was delicious.  It's very rich and super flavorful. I do think it could use a bit more ice cream, or a bit less chocolate, to get you through but it is very yummy.

I really loved the service.  Casual but knowledgeable and patient.  I didn't love the delivery of each dish with an explanation, seems pretty over the top to me, but whatever.
author: Jen M.

description:
Nice ambiance.  Cute decor.  We had the hamachi crudo, kale lollipop, and fried duck sandwich.  Great presentation and yummy.  We had a 6pm rezzy but ended up sitting at the bar for dinner as the hostess told us my table had to be given back in an hour and a half...hmmm really??? I had called ahead and spoken to the hostess to make sure our table would be there at 6:15.  Considering there were so many open tables at the restaurant, I was surprised she was such the hostess nazi.  Change your attitude please!

Oh, and the drinks look delicious here.
author: Dotty L.

description: Absolutely delicious drinks and food. Try the duck burger and the sugar snap peas drink.
author: Jane Q.

description: One of the best meals I've had in the city in a while! The tapas style is perfect for date night and means you don't have to choose between all the delicious items on the menu. The BBQ pork belly was our favorite, the tuna was a little bit on the fishy side, not my personal favorite. Ambiance is nice, modern, and the service was very attentive. Great spot!
author: Fay V.

description:
I gotta say:  I LOVE this place.  We went just after it opened, we had high expectations, and we thought it was ok, but not great.  Because it's in the neighborhood, we decided to go back again a few months later and felt that it had really improved.  Now we have been back about twice a month for the last three months, and this is our favorite spot in the neighborhood.

The dishes are flavorful and delicious.  The menu changes often enough to keep things fresh, but not so frequently that you can't get a favorite dish over several visits before it comes off the menu.  And the cocktails are fantastic!  As is the service.

I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Dave C.

description: I wasn't impressed. The hostess's demeanor was more consistent with an Applebee's than a higher(er) end restaurant.  The cocktail menu was challenging.  This said, they are trying to do innovative items, and deserve credit for that.
author: Brian M.

description:
Jaded because my last restaurant out was Verbena a couple blocks down the road.  While 1760 is Acquerello's spin off, Verbena had this kind of staying wow power... BUT back to 1760, GREAT restaurant. I think the best dish I had was the Maccheroni.  Honestly, GET IT while it's still on their menu.  The pasta was perfectly al dente and that salsa verde pesto was out of this world.  Plus it had dungeness crab.  You honestly can't lose.

The other sides we ordered were great too, but the stand out was the Maccheroni. Initially, I thought "there's be no way I would order that dish Macaroni was spelt wrong" but dear god, I've been eating that wrong my whole life.  And I'll never be able to look at macaroni... or Maccheroni the same way again.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Good place to go to share appetizers! Skip the main course! 

Happy to have a new restaurant in the hood
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Both the food and drink here are delicious.  Problem is it's also pricy and therefore, must be judged based on other restaurants in its price category.  Once you do this, 1760 falls below the value threshold of what most consider reasonable.  So despite being thrilled with my meal and drinks, I left slightly annoyed by the price.

Food - excellent.  Duck sandwich might have been the best sandwich I have ever had.  Drinks - Aziza guy is killing it here just like he did at Aziza.  Beer list is underwhelming.  Setting - agree with others that the setting lies in an awkward no man's land between sparse and yet not minimalist.  Service - attentive and friendly
author: David C.

description:
Insanely good: lobster ceviche, brussel sprouts
Really good: octopus, peppers, hamachi, pork cheek
Disappointing: short ribs

Portions are a little small for the price but the things they do really well are home runs and make up for it. Seems menu would benefit from having 1-2 more entree type selections. Overall definitely a great addition to Polk street.
author: Maggie Z.

description: The portions are very small, especially the tuna. You could finish the entire tuna dish in two bites. It was FREEZING in there. A lot of people were wearing their coats inside. The place is completely bare-bone, I suppose they are going for a minimalist look. They need to step up with their portion size and do something more inventive. This place just didn't do it for me. So many better places in the city.
author: E. N.

description: Right location, right menu & price range for goof quality food served in a casual-chic-trendy ambience. I especially got impressed by how much attention they pay to the napkins and alignment of the stuff on the tables. Menu is tapas style, small but flavorful dishes so for 2ppl, you order around 4-5 plates and be sure you are full at the end of the dinner. Menu is ordered from the lighter  to the heavier and is served the same order. If you are really hungry, make sure you order fried duck burger which i haven't eaten anywhere else. They have good cocktails and lots of Gin oriented ones which made me super happy!
author: Beril Y.

description: If you like octopus,  you must get the crispy octopus paella.  5stars alone for this dish. Nuff said ...
author: Hanwook K.

description: New restaurant in town and unfortunately a lot went wrong during our hour spent there. The food was brought out in random order and various times. One friend was completely done eating before we started. Some dishes size or preparation left something to be desired, but the steak was wonderful!
author: Lauren D.

description: My wife and I consider this the go-to place in our neighborhood for a nice dinner.  It is a bit pricey, but probably worth every cent as the food is really special.  Some of the lighter dishes need to be tried, but if you are hungry, order the duck sandwich and it will complement the lighter dishes and let you leave without feeling hungry.
author: Peter S.

description: This place was AWESOME!  Great craft cocktails, well crafted small plates, and really amazing service!
author: John Z.

description: Loved the food here - very inspired with delicious and memorable flavors.  We had the lobster ceviche, crispy octopus paella, tempura mushrooms, BBQ ribs, and panna cotta. All were hits.  The crispy octopus was amazing - if you like octopus, you have to get this dish!  Cocktails were great, too.  The food is a bit pricey - but so are a lot of restaurants in that part of town, and I think it was worth it, especially with the friendly and attentive service.  Only negatives were that drinks took a bit of time to arrive (while food was very fast) and if you are sitting by the door it can be a bit drafty when it opens.
author: Stacey J.

description: Pretty tasty fare and beautiful space.  Standout was the octopus and lobster ceviche. Portions aren't big so be prepared.  I'd go back again if just to sit at the bar.
author: Eric C.

description: The 3 highlights of my life:  Marriage to my wife, birth of my kids, and dinner at 1760!
author: Kurt O.

description: Fantastic food, small exquisite portions, just don't come hungry. Truly some of  the best food I've ever eaten.
author: Wayne S.

description: We had the lobster ceviche, beef tartare, fried squid, uni bucatini, and short ribs.  We didn't like the peanut buttery sauce with the beef tartare.  The sauce made the overall plate very heavy and overpowered the beef flavor.  Ceviche, squid, and short rib plates were ok; you get about 3-4 pieces of meat each.  Portions were not huge but enough.  I loved the uni bucatini, but not everyone will appreciate it since it does have a strong uni taste.  I know my review sounds very contradicting and that was exactly how we felt about the food experience.  Decent price, good food but not great.
author: Yen F.

description: Above average overall, a bit salty.  We started with the Hamachi which was very delicious, with just a tad too many salt crystals.  Then came the roasted carrots,  perfection.  We finished with the potatoes and chicken, both very delectable but again a little too much salt.  Definitely would go here again,  just would ask for a few less pinches.
author: Nicholas P.

description: This place is fantastic. Food is always on point and consistent. Ian has been my server several times and he is INCREDIBLE. Amazing service and personable. Thanks 1760 for always providing consistent service and food!! Try the caviar bites, they're divine.
author: Jena L.

description: The short rib was amazing and they could do no wrong with the 8 legged dish. The 1760 drink, however, had the essence of fart and the punch of armpit.
author: Konrad K.

description:
Ate here tonight for the first time:

LOVED
Octopus - TO DIE FOR
Lobster ceviche -- TO DIE FOR

MEH
Uni pasta

SKIP
Cavatelli - Sauce reminded me of CHEF BOYARDEE
Shishito peppers - WAY TOO SPICEY; not sweet as advertised
Brussel Sprouts - TOO SALTY
author: Michael S.

description: I came to this restaurant 1760 Polk St. With my friend who came from Italy on a business trip, the food and the service are extremely very good!  Who ever is near by this restaurant it should definitely check it out. Crispy octopus and pork ribs are heavenly good
author: Semso r.

description: I was in SF for 5 days. I had dinner at 1760 twice. I hope they expand to the South Bay. If not I guess I will get to spend more time in the city.  I will be back. Do make a reservation!!
author: Carl L.

description: Let me start by saying that I have been to 1760 twice and I have noticed a sharp decilne in the overall food experience. Our party was composed by four european adults, and we all had similar negative feedbacks by the end of dinner: 1760 is rapidly becoming more focused on its appearance than its substance. Example: a waitress hired to decant food like a muse becomes a joke when the menu itself doesn't support (for either quality/quantity) her effort. "Folks, our menu is family-style (a phrase I can't stand anyway since it reminds me of the Olive Garden's Tv ads) and I'll recommend to order a few plates to share among the four of you". To start, we decided to share a Lobster Ceviche and a Burrata. The Ceviche arrived in a plate the size of Texas. Imagine looking at the map of Texas and locate the city of Dallas in the center: all in proportion, that was our micro Ceviche! With a renewed "spirit of family", we asked for a magnifier lens and we split it in four! Next the Burrata. With great joy, Burrata is becoming more and more popular nowadays. Burrata is a delicate and simple milk product from the Puglia region of Italy. The beauty of some of the simplest italian food is its genuine flavor. The dish presented at 1760 was everything but simplicity: the poor Burrata was hidden under a quarter pound of yellow/red peppers, and trapped with some mint on top of a Pugliese bread slice. Few more unidentified objects layed on top of it. Don't get me wrong, not a bad appetizer, but don't call it Burrata, since you couldn't taste it at all. Instead, call it Peperonata (which is a real italian dish made with peppers)! Our group at this point decided to abandon the decanted "family style concept" and move on as hungry individuals to attack the main entrees: incredibly enough we all ordered the same. Cavatelli pasta with smoked lobster mushroom drowned in tomato sauce! Not complaining about the quantity on this occasion (it would have been different if we had to share this again) we focused on the quality: 2 stars at the most! The ingredients per-se weren't bad, but they didn't blend well as a whole. In other words, we could taste every single ingredient without being able to appreciate the final product. The sauce didn't stick to the pasta, just like going to a concert where the acoustic is bad. Sure, the band is famous, you can hear the electric guitar, the drummer is explosive but you can't understand the singer and the result is not harmonius. This is how we felt when we left. In such a food-competitive environment, good luck to 1760.
author: Giorgio E.

description: Great atmosphere, really friendly service and food was plated perfectly. Some of the flavors didn't quite live up to the platting. The Brussels sprouts were great but the scallops were a bit oh hum. Wine list was good, I suggest getting a bottle if you plan to have more than a glass. Pricing was in line with SF prices, meaning a bit high. I would go back!
author: David G.

description: Service is a 5.  Food is overall a 4 for the price.  Decor is a 3.   Decor can be so much better especially since they have so much space to work with, and the high ceilings.  Food was very good, albeit carb-heavy.  The chef loves potatoes ;)  The portions were very generous, the amount that we ordered could've fed 4 people comfortably.  We ordered the crispy octopus, roasted potatoes, lobster ceviche, uni pasta, and finished the meal with their "smores" and banana bread desserts.   The desserts were heavenly, definitely should save room for those!  Lobster ceviche was amazing, a great balance of flavor (not sure what Bauer was talking about re: heavy use of coconut/sugar).  Crispy octopus was overcooked but the flavors were there.  Uni pasta was very heavy and lacking uni flavor.  Roasted potatoes were so good, especially with the lemon & avocado sauce!   We will be back to try the food again.
author: Christina L.

description:
Where to begin? Should I start with the ambiance? The muted, simple, and modern decor? The service? The wine? The refreshing cocktails? Nope, although all of those are 5 star - I'll start with what it all comes down to, the food. The chef and his talented team have managed to put together a menu filled with creativity and have executed it brilliantly. I've already been twice in the first week and I've been remarkably impressed with how well things are going given the recent opening. Let's get down to the details:

Sliced Hamachi - Delicious, fresh, great raw fish dish.
Shishito Peppers - you can find these on many a menu, but the inclusion of ground hazelnuts sprinkled atop the peppers was a welcome addition
Beef Tartare - With marcona almonds and chilis. One of the best dishes on the menu. As someone who rarely orders beef tartare, not only was I pleasantly surprised, but I would absolutely order it again. A signature dish to be sure.
Corn Ravioli - YOU MUST ORDER. This dish will take you back to your childhood. Home cooking comfort food in a sophisticated modern dish. 
Warm Potato Salad - Again, ORDER THIS. It's something I'd never think of ordering at a restaurant but it was DELICIOUS. Smoked egg is a perfect complement to the potatoes. Do it.
Fried Duck Sandwich - THE SIGNATURE DISH. IF YOU ORDER NOTHING ELSE, ORDER THIS SANDWICH. It's perfect. Slaw, pickles, spicy aoili. I want one right now. Imagine a Bake Sale Betty's Fried Chicken Sandwich with duck. Next level ish. 

Take me back to 1760.
author: Mike G.

description: Just had brunch here, it was amazing! Things to order: biscuits, duck sandwich with egg and the brunch punch. Bomb!
author: willard m.

description: Definitely a high end dining experience all around. The service was amazing and the food was unique and delicious. We got 7 dishes for 4 people, and I left satisfied, but not full. The 1760 cocktail was amazing and the uni pasta, burratta and corn ravioli were my favorites. Make a reservation!
author: Alyssa B.

description: 1760 definitely lived up to high expectations.  I tried 4 dishes: fingerling potatoes, brussels, mushroom tempura, cavatelli.  The mushroom tempura was my favorite, mostly because I loved the celery root in the dish.  The brussels came in a close 2nd for me, the sauce so rich and flavorful and the pepitas adding good texture.  I didn't enjoy the potatoes as much as the person I was dining with; I thought they were a bit dry and bland.  The cavatelli, one of the larger dishes on the menu, was flavorful, rich and creamy.  I'd get it again, for sure.  I also tried a cocktail, the 1760, which I really enjoyed!  Our server explained it as similar to a mojito but with mescal, which I thought was pretty spot on.  Our server was very helpful and friendly, kept our glasses full and made sure that we were taken care of throughout our dinner.  Overall, a great spot to enjoy amazing food and seems to be appropriate for both a casual night out or a more formal dining experience.
author: Krystol S.

description: Exciting flavors and variations. A little bit pricey for the class, but i would come back.
author: Sarah L.

description: Went here last Saturday and had an okay experience skirt steak was cold.. Sent it back and still came out cold seems like they just rearranged on a new plate... Ribs were too dried like they boiled all the fat out... Waiter with the long hair was too aggressive suggesting all the expensive items... The best dish absolutely was the fried mushrooms... And the wine expert was very knowledgeable.. It's ok place I guess.. A blah experience lol
author: daezi s.

description: 1760 has really put their act together.  We now visit monthly, and understand their menu.  Good job!
author: Chuck P.

description: If I could check 0 stars I would! What a disappointment! You don't have to be a formally trained Chef to know that the flowers of cilantro are never a good garnish. The uni pasta tasted like cheese squeezed from a kraft packet and the crab pasta had so much lemon the crab was completely lost. We had such high expectations but we're sadly disappointed.
author: D P.

description: The food was all amazing! We were able to sit immediately at the communal table. Our server was also very friendly -highly recommend
author: Cat J.

description: Loved the tapa style portions, food was good, ambiance is great.
author: Christine K.

description: Greasy and salty explains every dish. I was excited to try out this new restaurant, but underwhelmed by every aspect of the experience. The staff was eager to smile, but fell short when it came to describing the menu. A standard script was given by each waitress (we cycled through two) and the food runner when we asked about their favorite dishes. The brussel sprouts were cooked beyond recognition, over salted, and flavored with an excessive about of oil. The duck sandwich was tasty, but also dripped grease and left my mouth dry from salt. The one saving grace was the tuna sashimi. My visit made me miss the days of La Parilla. A cheap and dirty mexican restaurant that delivered tasty food without the contrived grey paint job and the over priced food.
author: Marc U.

description:
Came here on a late Sunday night because I was craving uni pasta and it was the only place I could have made a reservation. 
Really liked the atmosphere and warm welcoming hostess and servers as I walked in. 
We ordered the caviar, grilled octopus, bucatini, lollipop kale and crispy duck sandwich. 
When the caviar arrived I was a bit disappointed by it's size however the seafood was fresh, but nothing that sparked my palette with this dish.
The lollipop kale was not bad but it was too salty since the dressing was basically soy sauce.
The bucatini was dry and bland, the uni wasn't the best quality.
My favourite of the savoury dishes was the grilled octopus, it was not too salty and the octopus was perfectly cooked, appropriate spice and herbs was used to season this dish.
We ended with the crispy duck sandwich, since we were already a bit full after all the previous course. The first few bites of the sandwich was rich and heavy also pickles that were topped on the duck confit patty was too sour and over powering.

BUT what was amazing was the cocktails and dessert! 
I had the mango and spice and pear and ginger cocktails, both very refreshing and has an interesting  after taste. So cocktails are highly recommend. 
We decided to try the dessert since we still had space for something sweet. 
We ordered the carrot cake and milk chocolate ganache. Both very well
Plated and presented, very cool form of deconstructed desserts and has many different components and textures which made both desserts very Interested impressive. 
 I would say the desserts probably made up for the over salty courses and small portions of the savoury courses.
Whether to return to this restaurant is debatably, as I feel the price we paid for this dinner would have given me a five star dinner elsewhere.
author: Rania H.

description: Great atmosphere, food was really good but not fabulous.  I met a friend for dinner and enjoyed the location, I could ride the cable car from work.
author: Richard M.

description: Great ambience and service. Good for romantic date, double date, small-group putting, or when your parents come to town. I'd treat it as a special-occasion restaurant. The burrata on toast was simple and delicious. The corn ravioli popped with earthy sweetness. The Dungeness crab with cantaloupe broth and cantaloupe sorbet was as fussy as it sounds, but fun. The cavatelli with tomatoes and mushrooms was a bit off, but I'm not quite sure why. The drinks, wines, and desserts were all special.
author: Erika F.

description: I was so excited to try this restaurant. I made reservations and came with friends who have an 8-month old baby. The hostess couldn't have been more rude when we arrived. She told us that we would have to hold the baby during the entire meal because the restaurant does not have high-chairs and there would be absolutely no place to put the stroller. I am disappointed in hostess' attitude and the reaction to a baby. I have been to much better restaurants in the city that are more than accommodating. We did not stay for dinner and I have no intention of coming back, even without a baby.
author: Lindsay D.

description: good looking room. impressive wine list. smart, attentive server (she asked about any dietary restrictions). serves dinner until 11. the dining options are somewhat limited and the portions are modest, but the dishes we had were mighty tasty. not cheap, but the quality is there.
author: jack s.

description: Great place for food and great ambiance. Found this place on Eater app, and decided to give it a try and so glad we did. Reservation is a must. Everything was fantastic. The service was great, our waiter was friendly, helpful, and attentive. The manager came by a few times to check on us and answered the few questions that we had. The food and the cocktails were even better if that's possible. We started with two cocktails, The 1760 and the Pear Ginger. They were perfect drinks to get the night started. After the drink, we ordered a bottle of red wine per recommendation of the manager and it paired perfect with the rest of our dinner. So glad we asked for his opinion on the wine list, which was almost too overwhelming to say the least. Now, we need to talk about the food. Between the two of us, we had 5 entrees total and we still wish our stomachs were bigger so we  could try more. The food were mean to be shared, so the portions were perfect, not too small but not big which still left some room in our stomach for the next entree. We got the hamachi crudo, Shishito peppers, crispy octopus,  BBQ pork belly, and fried duck sandwich. Everything was just amazing. If there was one complaint, at least on my part, was that the duck was a bit on the salty side. However I would over look that since the rest of the meal was phenomenal.
author: Hai T.

description: Very expensive, very confusing menu.  Mostly I am annoyed that my waitress suggested my dining companion and I order FIVE dishes with 4 of them in the "medium to heavy" range, one of which was their famous duck sandwich which is entirely massive and would have been enough with just TWO other dishes (not four other dishes!!!!).  It was WAY too much food, we paid WAY too much money, we returned the entire duck sandwich to the kitchen in its entirely after I ate one single bite (she was too full to even try it).  I felt queasy when I realized how wrong our waitress had steered us (and we had asked for guidance!!!) and paid the tab ($175 for two people including tip!!!) and ran out the door feeling, frankly, totally robbed.  The time before this visit we didn't realize the dishes we were ordering were minuscule and not nearly enough food.  Overall this place is confusing and chaotic to dine at in my opinion.  Will never come back and am disappointed this can't be one of a my favorite new neighborhood places (as this is my neighborhood).  It is also very, very expensive in my opinion.  I am truly surprised this place has 4 stars on Yelp and think there are many better places to eat in SF.  I'm still angry thinking about my dining experience now - just angry!
author: Christin A.

description: Fried Duck Sandwich!!! Wow, I wish they were open for lunch, I would come in here weekly for my fix of this incredible sando.  Their pastas were amazing as well, so were the sauteed peppers and the brussel sprouts done like no other restaurant in SF.  I will be back, many times, and it cant be too soon.
author: Ashley K.

description: Not only the food was really good but service was top-notch. You do have to try the pork belly that was marinated for 3 days, then cooked for 3 more days... the brussels sprouts were a nice, nice surprise, I normally don't order brussels sprouts bu these ones were to die for... something else to die for: the cinnamon custard, so leave room for this. Their wine selection is great and in general, one of those places that you will just come back over and over
author: Tina B.

description: My husband and I had dinner there for new year's eve and it was incredible. WE had lots of dishes and all were really good. The brussels sprouts were probably the best ones I have ever had. I had two cocktails, which I really enjoyed. It was expensive in the end, but worth every penny. I would absolutely come back!
author: Camilla L.

description: The crispy octopus was ridiculously amazing with incredible flavors and presentation. Although it is on the expensive side I would order it any day. A definite MUST HAVE at 1760.
author: Nicholas S.

description: Service here was amazing! I'm dinging the restaurant for the portion size, price per plate, and flavor. We ordered roughly $60 of food per person and were still hungry.
author: Eryn M.

description: we tried about 8 or 9 of this dishes our first time here, everything was ridiculously good.   lobster ceviche - wow.  the ravioli I still dream about.  I housed the duck burger.  love the fresh pasta, the steak, you can't go wrong.
author: Matis A.

description:
I've been meaning to stop by for some and I'm glad I finally did.  
The bartender suggested a great hearty red wine by the glass and it was a healthy pour.  The cocktail menu looked very creative and my counterparts both enjoyed their drinks. 
The problem we had was that everything looked great on the menu!
We started with the lobster dish which was very tasty but our least favorite dish. The main reason being everything else was SO DAMN Good and had a bigger portion. 
The grilled octopus is to die for. I could just eat several of those every day. 
The uni with bucatini pasta very rich and wonderfully balanced. 
Monkfish liver very different taste and might not be for everyone, but I enjoyed it. 
Fried duck burger was excellent but we were so full we were eating for sport at that time. 
We had a few other small plates and all had a wonderful presentation and were delicious. 
Marg took great care of us both times we visited. 

I read a just ok review in the chronicle on this restaurant and I couldn't disagree more. I'm ready to go right now and get a good glass of wine and some octopus at the bar.
author: Drew R.

description: Brought a friend visiting from out of town. Both of us travel a lot for work and eat at great restaurants when we do. We both thought the food at 1760 was fantastic. Very nice meal, friendly service, good atmosphere.
author: Jim B.

description: I had a nice valentine's day date here recently. I absolutely LOVED the Caviar dish. They really did a good job of incorporating the Uni. The lobster ceviche was delectable as well, it was an interactive dish. We nearly had half of their menu. The lollipop kale was fun and a little off the beaten path of kale dishes. Nice use of the soy sauce with this dish. The one dish that was not as impressive was the Uni macaroni. They dish was way too heavy to be paired with Uni. Uni is so buttery and unique by itself, the cream sauce in this dish drowned out the lightness of the Uni, this dish made me sad, I felt like I wasted the uni. We also had the bucatini but that dish didn't stand out. The octopus was highly recommended but I wasn't impressed by it. It was fried, a little on the dry side and nothing to write home about in my opinion. We had the chocolate ganache caramel dessert which looked more like a piece of art than food. I had the pear ginger campari cocktail that was surprisingly on the sweet side... I usually love sweet girlie drinks. next I got the Disaronno cocktail (when was the last time I saw disaronno!!!) and it was alright. I agree with a previous post, the interior reminds me of NOPA without the top floor, the bar and glass partition is very similar. Maybe I'll be back for the fried duck sandwich and the monk fish liver which they were out of. Top service and unique casual attire on the servers. Overall a successful night.
author: Kathleen T.

description: The food and the wine -all fantastic- my favorite dish was the Lobster ceviche.  I know Christopher from when he was at Rohan Lounge and he is great - so hospitable and makes a great cocktail!  I almost did not experience this all with my first impression of the restaurant- we felt like walking away before it started.  We had an early reservation and the door was locked.  When the hostess saw us, she came over, unlocked the door and walked away - didn't open the door or say welcome !?!  She was very rude.
author: Monica D.

description: This is a newer restaurant that is definitely still working on perfecting their menu. However, the chances they take are commendable and generally very delicious. If you are looking for something new and interesting, you should check this place out, just don't expect perfection just yet. The space is one of my favorites in SF, very open with large windows. Two highlights were the hamachi crudo and lobster macheroni.
author: Samantha S.

description: I have been here twice since it recently opened and both experiences were outstanding. The service was helpful and attentive, and the food was visually beautiful and tasted wonderful. I think the sizes were good and don't understand the comments about being too small. For the quality of food and experience, it is actually not expensive for this type of meal in San Francisco. My favorites were the corn ravioli, potato salad and uni pasta. Without hesitation, I would recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for a great meal with very good service.
author: M H.

description: So good!  Everything about this place hits the right notes, delicious food, wonderful friendly service, nice decor, great wine and cocktails.  We especially liked our opening vegetable courses, one with artichokes and one with kale, as well as the corn raviolis.  But all were lovely, what a great find!
author: Nana S.

description: I'm in love!!  Multiple friends and coworkers were talking about this place and I decided to go for my birthday.  It was love at first site!  The service was spot on, the food was amazing, and I just want to keep going back.  The Beretta, crab pasta, duck sando...probably my top 3, but there are plenty of other amazing dishes.  The bartenders are so friendly and make some killer drinks.  Highly recommend a visit!
author: Steph O.

description: Lobster ceviche, burrata and pork belly were fantastic. Brussel sprouts were good, but with almost every restaurant serving their own variation these days I thought 1760's were ok. Lamb cavatelli was not great--soupy and the cut of meat wasn't very good. Cocktails were ok but a little too sweet for my taste and pricey.
author: Kaitlin B.

description: The food was great but VERY small plates for the price.  Three of us ordered the hamachi, the savory peaches, the uni bucatini, the fried duck sandwich, and the corn ravioli.  All tasted great but we were still hungry.  $11 dollars for a plate of peaches arugula, mint and yogurt seems a bit much.  They give you a half a sliced apple to wet your palate when we ordered that was marinated in maple syrup that and was soggy and not good.  The best thing we ate was the duck sandwich and the corn ravioli.  Probably wont be going back.  The asian hostess was mean and grumpy and didn't make us feel welcome.
author: Marc M.

description: Loved their Bocatini. So creamy! Book a table or something. They get really crowed!
author: Bonnie T.

description:
I've been really excited to try out this place since I heard about it a few months back, but I felt like it was over-hyped and didn't meet most of my expectations.

My friend and I had made reservations for 8 PM, and when we had gone in, we were told that we would be seated momentarily. Unfortunately, we didn't even get seated until 8:30 - a full half-hour after our reservation, which was a bit irritating.

Shishito Peppers - Completely underwhelming. My friend and I agreed that these   were easily the worst shishito peppers that we'd ever had (and we both love them)
Lobster Ceviche- This dish was great - the balance between the lobster, coconut, and lime was delicious.
Brussel Sprouts - I really wanted to like this dish more; the egg yolks were an interesting addition to the dish, but the dish as a whole was pretty over salted.
Burrata - This dish was my favorite of the night. The balance between the pear and burrata was delicious! Definitely a must.
Maccheroni- Good, but nothing too special? 
Milk Chocolate Ganache - The server described this as "Deconstructed Smore", and I have to say that this was one of the best desserts that I've had. The combination of textures and different tastes with the ganache was delicious. My friend and I actually contemplated ordering a second round before we thought about our New Year's Resolutions.

The 1760 - I was worried about the Mezcal in the drink as I'm not a huge fan, but it was a pleasant and mild kick to the cocktail.
Mango and Spice - Great balance of sweet and spicy.
Garam Masala-Cardamom - Definitely an interesting cocktail, but I think that the spices were a little much for me in the drink.

On the whole, I thought that the space was nice and enjoyed the service; however, I think that the food was definitely not up to par with the reviews and comments that I've heard. There were definitely some standouts (Burrata and Milk Chocolate Ganache), but on the whole, the food we ordered wasn't good enough for the price (If I come again, I'll definitely be trying other dishes).
author: Jonathan H.

description: This place was disappointing.  The menu was limited but sounded like good choices.  However, the mix of flavors did not do it for me.  The steak was sweet with a cinnamon-like taste and the flavors with the other dishes did not mesh well.  The wine was just ok.  The service was great though!
author: around town e.

description: Went here for drinks for the first time last night.  The bartender (Kyle) couldn't have treated my date and I any better and made an instant fan out of both of us.  We didn't order any food, but the drinks were fantastic.  Honestly, I feel comfortable saying that these were the best cocktails that I've had since moving to San Francisco a year and a half ago.  I will absolutely be back thanks to Kyle!
author: Paige M.

description: I have been to 1760 four times now and have NEVER been disappointed, in fact always pleasantly surprised with a new addition to the menu whether it be a food or drink item. We love the brussel sprouts which is on the Happy Hour menu for $3 less from 5-6pm, so are the Shisito peppers.  Cocktails are wonderful there! Love the Rosemary Blood Orange. Our waiter David was very helpful advising which dish is great, attentive. The dungeoness Maccheroni, pork Belly entree, lobster ceviche are among my faves! Go and have a great experience!
author: Flo H.

description: Great small plates, fun atmosphere & extensive wine list by the glass and bottle.  The brussels sprouts are a must-have, as well as the lollipop kale
author: Johnna M.

description: The shishito peppers were excellent and the hazelnuts sprinkled on top added nice texture and flavor.  Very much enjoyed the hamachi crude as well.  The pasta dishes were a bit underwhelming, but generally tasty.  The space was well done and the service was quite good.  Will definitely be back.
author: Andrea B.

description: The food is very good, but the cocktails are.. wow. I had the best Martinez of my life here, I asked to have it made with an old genever they had in a clay bottle and it blew me away.
author: Lou S.

description: I went here for my birthday and loved it.  The waitress coud NOT have been nicer.  The cosmos (cocktail) were the best I've ever had.  I also got the duck sandwich, which I loved.  It's beautiful inside and not too noisy.  The ambiance, food, service and cocktails all melded together perfectly.  Keep up the great work!
author: Scott B.

description: Overpriced tapas.  Actually outrageously overpriced tapas.  Don't charge full portion restaurant prices for small tapas plates.  The service was almost lightening fast so that we felt rushed.  They even took away a half finished glass of wine so I don't know if we were infringing on the next seating or what.  Food deserved 4 stars, service 2.5, and value for money about 1 star.  I wouldn't recommend with so many good restaurants in SF.  Maybe the tapas crave just hit there.   Total bill for 5 of us with 10 small plates (one of which we sent back and didn't get compted!), 4 beers, 4 glasses of wine was $295.  At half of that it might be a 4 star place.
author: Ken S.

description: Service was great, and the room was nice. They got pretty much everything right except for the food... completely underwhelming mediocre food. Some dishes were passable like the shishito peppers (which was the best thing we ate), but others like the the octopus and crispy duck sandwich were surprisingly not good. The duck got lost in the bun and drown in the coleslaw. I don't quite understand what the peanuts brought to the octopus. The pasta dishes were all meh. Adding uni (which I love) could not save the bucatelli. And pork cheeks could not save the cavatelli. I don't even mind small portions if they are delicious. There really was no cohesion of flavors to these dishes.
author: Y. C.

description: I want to say that I think that some of the food was great, but there really isn't anything on the menu that is very filling and at the same time, nothing is very healthy - there is a a lack of even a decent salad.  It's almost as if it's a really light bar menu (They have an amazing pick of all sorts of spirits)  and maybe that's what they intend to do but the truth is that the one dish that looked even slightly healthy was a dish of really salty peppers that honestly didn't taste that good, the Octopus was good but the sodium level was out the roof.  I appreciate a place that doesn't over feed you but this kind of goes a little too far I felt the need to stop by Trader Joes' on the way home and long for something to fill me up, so I took home a box of pumpkin waffles and syurp, I ended up not eating it but still I was still hungry, after spending a lot of money.  The most substantial thing was the three cocktails I had if they can get a food menu to match the drinks menu they will do great.  It's a fun place but they need to put some food on the menu.
author: Sara J.

description: Wanted to go someplace cool and new for my birthday.  I was not disappointed; AND we found a place that both my husband and I liked equally well.  This is not easy when there is no burger and fries on the menu!  The crab was my favorite; don't know how they make something so rich seem so light.  The fried duck sandwich was amazing; and I don't do duck or fried sandwiches......  Unlike much of the city, the wine list was not primarily Californian.  Fortunately the Wine Director, Gianpaolo was there whenever I needed him.  We look forward to returning soon.
author: Rosemary S.

description: Came here on a week night. We sat at the row of tables for two, but felt like they were a little close together. The staff was super accommodating when we asked to move to a more private table, even with a couple dishes and drinks already down. The food was tasty and interesting, different than lots of dishes at other restaurants. Our favorite was the lobster ceviche, and the octopus was also excellent. The service was great and they had nice touches like folding your napkin if you left your seat. Two things they could change are spacing out the small tables a bit more so people aren't on top of each other, and removing the utensil boxes from the tables. Seems odd to have a box of forks and knives sitting at the table for what is otherwise an upscale casual place. They even said the box had to stay at the table when I asked if we could move it. Recommended for the food and service though!
author: K W.

description: This was my first visit to 1760, for a business dinner with one other person.  The veggie dishes were amazing (brussels sprouts and a kale dish), and the octopus was delicious.  The pork belly was so-so, even a bit boring but maybe I was expecting too much from a belly.  One of the challenging bits was that it was so loud it was difficult to have a conversation.  The other was timing.  I understand that tapas style dishes are intended to be shared, but the way they were brought to us didn't really make sense.  After at least 30 minutes they brought both veggie dishes, then 30 minutes later the octopus and another 30 minutes later the pork.  I would have like to have a bite of this and a bite of that, but it wasn't possible - and the huge gaps between having food available to eat  was just ridiculous. We did have a beautiful dessert to share, but no coffee, and it came in a reasonable time. In total, our dining experience was nearly 3 hours.
author: Jan H.
